taxonomicNotes: Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Lindholm (1929) recognized Testudo tornieri Siebenrock, 1903 as the type of a new genus, for which he established the name Malacochersus. The genus is monotypic, with only one species currently recognized. Genetic studies have demonstrated that Malacochersus is most closely related to Asian Indotestudo and Eurasian Testudo (Le et al. 2006; Parham et al. 2006; Fritz and Bininda-Emonds 2007). Phylogeographic studies of the species have not yet been realized, but are clearly needed in view of its disjunct distribution. Vernacular names used for the species in East African Kiswahili are Kobe ya Mawe and Kobe kama Chapati.

Sometimes considered as a subspecies of M. duodecimcostatus, but its specific status has been reconfirmed by analysis of karyotype, molecular genetics and molar pattern (Kryštufek 1999, Jaarola et al. 2004). A chromosomally polymorphic species; relationships are unknown (Wilson and Reeder 2005).
Eastern populations are now considered as a separate species, M. liechtensteini (Wilson and Reeder 2005).

Telmatobius punctatus was previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius brevirostris; it was elevated to specific status by Lehr (2005) based on differences in morphological features and colour patterns.

Microtus liechtensteini is part of Microtus multiplex species-complex. Its formerly continuous range in the Alps was split into three parts during the last glaciation which led to the evolution of three species: Microtus liechtensteini (south of the Alps east of the river Adige and Balkan mountains), Microtus multiplex (south of the Alps west of the river Adige), and M. bavaricus (north of the Alps in a small refuge in Bavaria and Northern Tyrol) (Haring et al. 2000, Spitzenberger et al. 2000, Spitzenberger 2002, Musser and Carleton 2005, Martinkova et al. 2007).
The validity of this species needs to be confirmed (Wilson and Reeder 2005, G. Amori pers. comm. 2006).

The genus Coptodactyla Burmeister, 1846 occurs in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprises 14 species (Reid 2000, Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).
The genus Epirinus currently comprises 29 species with a combined distribution restricted primarily to the coolest climates of South Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Neosisyphus Müller 1942 shows a widespread distribution in the Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently represented by 22 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is in urgent need of revision. This species has frequently been cited as N. macroruber for reasons of gender in Latin usage, although no formal abridgement of the name has been published. It is a close relative of N. rubrus Paschalidis 1974, which has also been assessed for the IUCN Red List.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabaeus. This species is currently considered to comprise two varieties, a typically finer punctuate variety that is widespread in southern Africa and a more coarsely punctate variety that occurs in the lowlands of southeast east Mozambique and northeast South Africa and may deserve species status.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

This species has recently been transferred from the genus Drepanocerus Kirby 1828 to the new genus Eodrepanus Barbero, Pallestrini & Roggero 2009. It is represented in both the Afrotropical and Oriental regions with five species found in the Afrotropical region currently considered valid. Eodrepanus fastiditus (Péringuey, 1901) is often confused with a close relatives Eodrepanus bechynei (Janssens, 1953) and Eodrepanus parallelus (Raffray, 1877).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 24 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the forest and savannas of the Afrotropical region.

The genus Copris shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Copris inhalatus comprises four subspecies, Copris inhalatus inhalatus (Quedenfeldt, 1884), Copris inhalatus grandis Nguyen-Phung & Cambefort, 1986, Copris inhalatus perturbator Péringuey, 1901, and Copris inhalatus santaeluciae Nguyen-Phung & Cambefort, 1986.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 23 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the forest, savanna and upland grassland of the Afrotropical region.

The genus Heliocopris Hope 1837 is found in the Afrotropical and Oriental regions with one species shared between the Afrotropical and Palaearctic regions, possibly in a Saharo-Sindian pattern of distribution. Most of the taxa are endemic to the Afrotropical region where 44 species are currently recognized as valid (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus, Scarabeolus, which is primarily restricted to Africa.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 13 (d'Orbigny 1913), which is restricted to highland regions in west central, northeast, east, and southern Africa.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 23 (d'Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the forest, savanna and upland grassland of the Afrotropical region.

The genus Caccobius Thomson 1859 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. In the Afrotropical region, it is currently represented by 42 species that are considered valid (ScarabNet 2009).
The genus Gymnopleurus Illiger, 1803 shows a range in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is currently represented by 33 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 16 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in forest, savanna and grassland of the Afrotropical region. Othophagus kavirondus is cited as the valid name for this species (Ferreira 1972, Schoolmeesters 2011) but its synonym, Onthophagus kavirondi d’Orbigny 1913, was described two years earlier.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Catharsius Hope 1837 is currently represented by 80 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). There is undoubtedly a good deal of confusion in the taxonomy of Catharsius pandion and published distribution records need to be treated with caution. It appears that it is one of a complex of closely related species that are similar in appearance and difficult to separate since the diagnostic morphological features vary in prominence and shape according to body size. Although there is no doubt that the taxon treated here as Catharsius pandion is a valid species, the application of the name, Catharsius pandion, to this species needs to be validated by a revision of the group taxonomy.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.
The endemic Australian genus Demarziella Balthasar, 1961 comprises 14 described and two undescribed species (Matthews 1976, Matthews 1986, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 19, which is centred in dry to moist savannas throughout the Afrotropical region and includes a number of known elephant dung specialists occurring on either deep sands or finer-grained soils. As in all Onitis, there is variation in body size and the shape and prominence of diagnostic femoral armament in males leading to synonyms for this widespread species described from both Zimbabwe (Onitis cerrutii Müller 1949) and Mozambique (Onitis janssenii Gomes Alves 1954).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 24 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the forest and savannas of the Afrotropical region.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Gymnopleurus Illiger, 1803 shows a range in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is currently represented by 33 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Other than in colour, South African specimens do not appear to differ appreciably to G. reichei from Kenya.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Copris shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 32 (d'Orbigny 1913), which is widely distributed across the dry to moist savannas of the Afrotropical region.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 31 (d'Orbigny 1913), which is widely distributed throughout the savanna and highland grassland of the Afrotropical region and is equivalent to the Palaearctic and Oriental subgenus Furconthophagus Zunino 1979.

The genus Neosisyphus Müller 1942 shows a widespread distribution in the Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently represented by 22 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is in urgent need of revision. This species has frequently been cited as N. ruber for reasons of gender in Latin usage although no formal abridgement of the name has been published. It is a close relative of N. macrorubrus Paschalidis 1974, which has also been assessed for the IUCN Red List.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively (ScarabNet 2009). This species was formerly classified as one of two members of the genus Drepanopodus Wiedemann 1823, which was recently synonymised with the genus Scarabaeus (Forgie et al. 2005).

The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Catharsius Hope 1837 is currently represented by 80 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is probable that understanding of the genus, species, and their distributional ranges would benefit from a revision.
The endemic Australian genus Demarziella Balthasar, 1961 comprises 14 described and two undescribed species (Matthews 1976, Matthews 1986, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Metacatharsius Paulian 1939 is predominantly restricted to the Afrotropical region where 62 species are currently considered valid (ScarabNet 2009). A single species, Metacatharsius inermis Castelnau, extends from the Afrotropical region across Arabia to the western edge of the Oriental Region in a Saharo-Sindian pattern of distribution.

The genus Copris shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).
The genus Garreta Janssens, 1940 is shared between the Afrotropical and Oriental regions with eleven species currently recognized as valid in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species has been classified within Onthophagus Group 11 (d'Orbigny 1913), which is widespread throughout the dryer savannas of the Afrotropical region.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.The genus is taxonomically well known.

Onthophagus is a diverse and cosmopolitan genus, with approximately 2,000 species distributed worldwide. The great diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with over 90 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The genus Caccobius Thomson 1859 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. In the Afrotropical region, it is currently represented by 42 species that are considered valid (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Liatongus Reitter 1893 shows a wide disjunct distribution in the Afrotropical, Oriental, eastern Palaeartic and western Nearctic regions. In the Afrotropical region, it is currently represented by 15 valid species (ScarabNet 2009).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species remains unassigned to a group.

The genus Caccobius Thomson 1859 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. In the Afrotropical region, it is currently represented by 42 species that are considered valid (ScarabNet 2009).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 24 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the forest and savannas of the Afrotropical region. This species is entirely metallic green. Another sympatric Group 24 species, Onthophagus leucopygus Harold 1867, in which the elytra are white rather than metallic, is thought to be a further synonym of Onthophagus impressicollis Boheman 1860.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabeolus.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species belongs to Onthophagus Group 4 (d’Orbigny 1913), which shows a distribution restricted to tropical east African highlands and cool temperate highlands of South Africa.

The genus Copris shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to a group that is restricted to the southeast coastline and adjoining highlands of South Africa and is currently represented by six valid species between which there has been much taxonomic confusion (see also assessment of Copris victorini Boheman, 1857). Copris ritsemae has been described as a taxon that is distinct from its close relative, Copris caelatus (Fabricius, 1794), and it appears that most published locality data for Copris ritsemae is due to confusion with that species.
The genus Epirinus currently comprises 29 species with a combined distribution restricted primarily to the coolest climates of South Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 16 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in forest, savanna and grassland of the Afrotropical region.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is in Onthophagus Group 7 (d'Orbigny 1913), which may be equivalent to the Palaearctic subgenus Eremonthophagus. Group 7 is widely distributed across the savannas of the Afrotropical region.

Ixodina freyi (Janssens, 1953) was recently transferred from Drepanocerus Kirby, 1828 to the re-validated genus, Ixodina Roth (Krikken 2009). It is represented in both the Afrotropical and Oriental regions with seven species found in the Afrotropical region currently considered valid.
The genus Gymnopleurus Illiger, 1803 shows a range in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is currently represented by 33 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species belongs to Onthophagus group 17 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is dominated by species showing rain forest, highland grassland, or cooler climatic ranges and is widespread in the Afrotropical region.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 31 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widely distributed throughout the savanna and highland grassland of the Afrotropical region and is equivalent to the Palaearctic and Oriental subgenus Furconthophagus Zunino 1959.

The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Allogymnopleurus Janssens 1940 is currently represented by 18 Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009). It is considered that Allogymnopleurus chloris (Klug 1855) is merely a shiny green colour variety of Allogymnopleurus thalassinus (Klug 1855), which comprises iridescent cupreous, green and blue varieties as well as a black variety.

The genus Gymnopleurus Illiger, 1803 shows a range in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is currently represented by 33 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Gymnopleurus virens typically shows coarse punctuation on the prothoracic disc and has been recorded in Angola, Namibia, South Africa, and Ethiopia. Metallic green individuals with a distribution on the South African Highveld, in moist coastal regions (South Africa, Mozambique), and in Zimbabwe (Australian CSIRO 1970-1986, unpublished records), that show finer punctuation of the prothoracic disc, have been treated variously as a variety of G. virens or as an outlier occurrence of G. sericeifrons Fairmaire 1887. Gymnopleurus sericeifrons is otherwise located on uplands in east and northeast Africa. There are four synonyms for G. virens, all of which were described from untraceable or unspecified localities in east and northeast Africa.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 12 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the dry to moist savannas of the Afrotropical region, and is equivalent to the Palaearctic and Oriental subgenus, Trichonthophagus.

The genus Euonthophagus Balthasar 1959 is represented in both the Palaearctic and Afrotropical regions. The Afrotropical taxa remain relatively poorly known and probably comprise rather more than the sixteen species currently listed as valid (A. Davis pers. comm. 2012).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2005): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21, and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Kheper that is represented in the Afrotropical and Oriental regions (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Sisyphus Latreille is biogeographically widespread across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic and Oriental regions, with a restricted occurrence in the Central American part of the Neotropical region. It is currently represented by 18 species in the Afrotropical region, but is in urgent need of revision. Sisyphus natalensis Balthasar currently remains a valid name but in the unpublished revision of Paschalidis (1974) it is cited as a synonym of Sisyphus sordidus Boheman 1857 described from Caffraria, an imprecise area centred on the modern province of KwaZulu-Natal and adjoining parts of the Eastern Cape. It needs to be compared with Sisyphus caffer Boheman 1857, also described from Caffraria. Both species are currently synonymised (Haaf 1955) with Sisyphus crispatus Gory, a name which has no validity as it comprises a species complex, according to the unpublished revision of Paschalidis (1974).
The endemic Australian genus Monoplistes Lansberge, 1874 comprises six described and two undescribed species.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 7, which occupies a range in cooler regions found in the south and in tropical eastern highlands.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2005): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively.  This species belongs to the subgenus Kheper that is represented in the Afrotropical and Oriental regions (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Cheironitis Lansberge, 1875 is centred on the Palaearctic, western Oriental and Afrotropical regions, and is currently represented by eleven species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Cheironitis scabrosus (Fabricius, 1776) is extremely closely related to an undescribed species with which there may be some limited overlap in range. Only males of the two species may be differentiated using minor morphological differences on the middle tibia.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabaeus.

The genus Neosisyphus Müller 1942 shows a widespread distribution in the Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently represented by 22 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is in urgent need of revision.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 20 (d’Orbigny 1913), which occupies a range restricted to the arid southwest of Africa and the southern edge of the Sahara Desert from west to northeast Africa. It is sometimes confused with a close relative that is distributed across the deep sands of the southern Kalahari Basin.

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 31 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widely distributed throughout the savanna and highland grassland of the Afrotropical region and is equivalent to the Palaearctic and Oriental subgenus Furconthophagus.

The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Catharsius Hope 1837 is currently represented by 80 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is probable that understanding of the genus, species, and their distributional ranges would benefit from a revision.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabaeus.

The genus Metacatharsius Paulian 1939 is predominantly restricted to the Afrotropical region where 62 species are currently considered valid (ScarabNet 2009). A single species, Metacatharsius inermis Castelnau, extends from the Afrotropical region across Arabia to the western edge of the Oriental Region in a Saharo-Sindian pattern of distribution.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species remains unassigned to a group.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Odontoloma Boheman 1857 is restricted to the Afrotropical region where most of the twenty species currently considered valid show southerly centres of distribution (ScarabNet 2009). Owing to the very small body size and great similarity in appearance between most species, the taxonomy of this genus is difficult and requires revision.
This species belongs to the armatus complex (Matthews 1961).

The genus Copris Muller 1764 shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

Latodrepanus laticollis has been recently transferred from Drepanocerus Kirby, 1828 to a newly described genus, Latodrepanus Krikken, 2009. It is represented only in the Afrotropical region where four species are currently considered valid.

The genus Euoniticellus is centred on the Afrotropical and Palaearctic regions, with representatives in the Oriental region and one species on Caribbean islands. It currently comprises some fourteen valid Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Tesserodon Hope, 1837 occurs in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprise 13 species (Matthews 1974, Storey 1991, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Gymnopleurus Illiger, 1803 shows a range in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is currently represented by 33 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). The taxonomy of G. humanus has been recently reviewed. It was re-established that cupreous specimens from Angola, described under different names (G. modestus Lansberge, 1886; G. sericatus Erichson, 1843), were indeed synonyms of blue individuals described from South Africa as G. humanus (Davis and Génier 2007). Individuals described from the northeast savannas were removed from synonymy with G. humanus under the revalidated species name of G. humeralis Klug, 1855 (Davis and Génier 2007).

The genus Sisyphus Latreille is biogeographically widespread across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic and Oriental regions, with a restricted occurrence in the Central American part of the Neotropical region. It is currently represented by 18 species in the Afrotropical region, but is in urgent need of revision. Along with four other species, Sisyphus caffer is currently still officially synonymised (Haaf 1955) with Sisyphus crispatus Gory 1833, a species whose type has not been seen since 1900 and whose identity is not verifiable using the description (Paschalidis 1974). However, Schoolmeesters (2011) lists Sisyphus caffer Boheman 1857 as a valid species with Sisyphus pygmaeus Klug 1862 and Sisyphus sordidus Boheman 1857 listed as synonyms and Sisyphus caffer goryi Harold 1859 as an infraspecific taxon. The latter two taxa are considered valid species by Paschalidis (1974).

According to Vaz-de-Mello (2008), the genus Pedaridium is monotypic. However, it contains at least one undescribed species currently under study, in addition to the type species. It is present only in the Eastern Parana subregion, in the Parana Forest and Araucaria angustifolia Forest provinces.

The genus Copris shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Material formerly considered to represent Copris fallaciosus was recently divided (Nguyen Phung 1988) into two closely related species, Copris denticulatus Nguyen Phung, 1988 and Copris fallaciosus Gillet, 1907, which is a nomen novum for the pre-occupied species name of Copris integer Harold, 1869. Other preceding names relate to type series containing more than one species (Copris lunarioides Waterhouse, 1891, Copris laticornis Péringuey, 1901).

The genus Euoniticellus is centred on the Afrotropical and Palaearctic regions, with representatives in the Oriental region and one species on Caribbean islands. It currently comprises some fourteen valid Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009). Euoniticellus nasicornis is sometimes confused with its very widespread relative E. intermedius (Reiche, 1848).
The genus Xinidium Harold 1869 shows a distribution restricted to moist highland grassland of southeast Africa and currently comprises three species.

The genus Diastellopalpus Lansberge, 1886 is restricted to intertropical parts of the Afrotropical region and currently comprises 32 described species (Josso and Prévost 2000), most of which show montane or rainforest distributions (Davis and Scholtz 2010).

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabaeus.
The endemic Australian genus Monoplistes Lansberge, 1874 comprises six described and two undescribed species.

The genus Odontoloma Boheman 1857 is restricted to the Afrotropical region where most of the twenty species currently considered valid show southerly centres of distribution (ScarabNet 2009). Owing to the very small body size and great similarity in appearance between most species, the taxonomy of this genus is difficult and requires revision.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 16 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in forest, savanna and grassland of the Afrotropical region.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 16 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in forest, savanna and grassland of the Afrotropical region.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 10 (d’Orbigny 1913), which shows a wide distribution in the savannas of the Afrotropical region.

The genus Epirinus currently comprises 29 species with a combined distribution restricted primarily to the coolest climates of South Africa (ScarabNet 2009). Epirinus validus and E. sulcipennis Boheman are the largest-bodied of the Epirinus species.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 18, which is widespread throughout lowland to upland drier savannas of the Afrotropical region on both deep sands and finer-grained soils.

The genus Cheironitis van Lansberge 1875 occurs across the Palaearctic, western Oriental and Afrotropical regions, and is currently represented by eleven species in the Afrotropical region. Cheironitis damarensis Felsche, 1907 is a junior synonym of this species (ScarabNet 2009).
The flightless endemic genus Coproecus Reiche, 1841 conprises one described and one undescribed species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Temnoplectron Westwood, 1841 occurs in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprises 16 species (Matthews 1974, Reid and Storey 2000, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera: Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to the subgenus Sceliages. All of the species are restricted to the south of the Afrotropical region (Forgie et al. 2002, ScarabNet 2009) where they are specialized to breeding using the soft body contents of dead millipedes. As type material of S. gagates could not be located for a recent revision of the genus, a neotype has been designated (Forgie et al. 2002).

The genus Caccobius Thomson 1859 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. In the Afrotropical region, it is currently represented by 42 species that are considered valid (ScarabNet 2009).

Scybalophagus consists of five species that are distributed throughout Argentina, Peru, Chile and Bolívia. Its specimens are recognized by the following characters: mesotibia and metatibia with transverse carinae; head not elongate and dorsum monocolored.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 23 (d'Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the forest, savanna and upland grassland of the Afrotropical region.
The species currently includes Sulcorebutia krahnii Rausch, however, this should be considered as a form of Rebutia steinbachii ssp. tiraquensis

The species is doubtfully distinct from G. erinaceum J.G.Lamb (P. Demaio pers. com. 2010).

G. amerhauseri subsp. altagraciense H.Till & Amerh. is considered to be a synonym (Charles 2009).

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. buenekeri (Swales) P.J.Braun & Hofacker. The latter was previously considered a good species, genetic studies are required to see if it should be raised to species level again.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. angelsiae R.Kiesling & Metzing.

Only the populations in the state of Puebla represent the distribution of M. pectinifera, those in northwest of Oaxaca correspond to M. solisioides, which Hunt et al. (2006) consider to be a subspecies of M. pectinifera (subsp. solisioides (Backeb.) D.R.Hunt) . The concept of M. pectinifera assessed here, excludes solisioides, but a separate assessment for solisioides has not been completed.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. densispina Hofacker & Herm.

This species, formerly in the paraphyletic genus Laudakia, was assigned as the type (and presently sole) species of the new genus Stellagama by Baig et al. (2012). While this wide-ranging lizard, which presently has seven recognized subspecies (although this number varies according to different authors), is considered likely to be a species complex, "more extensive work is still required before splitting the S. stellio complex" (Baig et al. 2012), as most work to date has been morphological and genetic research is needed to clarify divisions in this taxon (Baig et al. 2012). S. stellio daani was previously synonymized with the nominate form, but its distinctiveness was recognized by Almog et al. (2005), and it is considered a distinct subspecies in the review of Laudakia conducted by Baig et al. (2012).
This taxon was raised to species rank on the basis of a large genetic divergence from Elaphe quatuorlineata and clear morphological differences (Lenk et al. 2001).
This species is included in Dolichophis following Nagy et al. (2004), rather than Hierophis.
The validity of subspecies described from western Siberia and the Altai region, E. d. niger Golubeva, 1923 and E. d. tenebrosa Sobolevsky, 1929, is disputed.

There are three subspecies: Coronella austriaca austriaca is present over most of the species range; C. a. fitzingeri (Bonaparte, 1840) inhabits the southern part of the Italian Peninsula and the island Sicily; C. a. acutirostris Malkus, 1995, has been erected for the populations of the north-western Iberian Peninsula.

Simotes semicinctus was described in the 19th Century from a specimen with the locality data "probably Borneo", and was never subsequently rediscovered (Tillack et al. 2008). Wallach and Bauer (1996), accepting this uncertain locality data, referred this species to the Southeast Asian genus Oligodon. Tillack et al. (2008), however, examined this specimen in detail and concluded that it is not referable to Oligodon. Considering the locality data unreliable and comparing the specimen with snakes globally, these authors reached the unexpected conclusion that S. semicinctus is a junior synonym of Coronella austriaca. The Borneo locality must consequently be considered in error, as has been found with other specimens from the same collection (Tillack et al. 2008).
This species is included in Dolichophis following Nagy et al. (2004), rather than Hierophis.
Two varieties are recognized: the nominate boeckeleriana and transiens (K.Schum.) R.Haines.
Morphological features suggest that this species is closely related to Nepenthes rajah Hook f. on Borneo, as well as to N. mira Jebb & Cheek and N. mantalingajanensis Nerz & Wistuba, also of Palawan.

Ophrys melitensis is treated by some as one morphologically and phenologically highly variable entity of Ophrys × flavicans. The total range of Ophrys × flavicans extends from Cataluna across the Balearic Islands, southern France and mainland Italy to Dalmatia, Sicily and Malta (Pedersen and Faurholdt 2007).

V. anagallis-aquatica hybridises with V. catenata Penell. The hybrid, V. ×lackschewitzii appears to have replaced V. anagallis-aquatica in many rivers in southern Britain. It is not clear how widespread V. ×lackschewitzii is nor whether it may either pose a threat to V. anagallis-aquatica or compromise the red list assessment for either parent, however in the UK it is difficult to distinguish records of the three taxa.
This species has three subspecies: the nominate form, Eremias scripta ladsini, and E. s. pherganensis. The latter is confined to the Fergana Valley, an area under heavy human pressure.
West African subpopulations may represent a different species from that found in the Egyptian type locality (Trape et al. 2012).
Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and resurrected the name Tenuidactylus for the clade including T. turcmenicus.
This species is included in Platyceps following Nagy et al. (2004). Schätti (2004) and Schätti and Schmitz (2006) include Platyceps rogersi in synonymy with P. ventromaculatus.

The status of several described subspecies is unclear, with various authors referring to Lytorhynchus d. gaddi, L. d. arabicus and L. d. mesopotamicus as either subspecies or junior synonyms of L. d. diadema (competing views discussed in Bauer et al. 2017).

The status of L. kennedyi has been considered uncertain for several decades, with Leviton and Anderson (1970) suspecting that future research would demonstrate that these are conspecific. While some authors have followed these authors in provisionally accepting it as valid, others recognize it as simply a colour morph of L. diadema (discussed in Sindaco et al. 2013 and Bauer et al. 2017).  The situation is complicated further since competing evidence suggests both that the two species have been found in sympatry, supporting the notion that the two taxa re specifically distinct (Martens 1993); and that a specimen from Libya well outside the range of L. kennedyi exhibits the same patterning, supporting the idea that it is a colour morph (Moravec 1995). Bauer et al. (2017) refrain from making a judgment on the taxonomic status of L. kennedyi, but recognize the Libyan specimen as L. d. diadema.

An accepted synonym is Veronica chillensis Kunth.
Its common name is Necklace Weed.
Vigna hosei Backer ex. K.Heyne belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Bambara Groundnut V. subterranea (L.) Verde. (Maxted et al. 2004).
Vigna schlechteri Harms belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Cowpea V. unguiculata (L.) Walp. (Ng and Padulosi 1991, Maxted et al. 2004, Tomooka et al. 2011).
Balashov (2016) lists this species under the genus Bilania Schileyko, 1986, while Bank (2013) accepts Bilania only as a subgenus of Carpathica.

This species is a member of a group of large Arion species which have often been confused with one another, and sometimes require dissection for successful identification. Misindentification is common between:

A. ater (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. rufus (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. vulgaris Moquin-Tandon, 1855 (=lusitanicus auctt. non Mabille);
A. lusitanicus Mabille, 1868; and,
A. flagellus Collinge, 1893.

The distribution and taxonomic position of this species are not clear. In some parts of its area, the species probably co-occurs with other close-related species of the genus (Turnovo, Lovech, Dryanovo). According to Welter-Schultes (2012) Bulgarica varnensis as well as some other Bulgarian representatives of the genus Bulgarica (B. fraudigera, B. hiltrudae, B. pseudofraudigera and B. urbanskii) are synonyms of Bulgaria fritillaria. Because of some minor differences in their populations those taxa are accepted as separated species (subspecies?), but the complex needs taxonomic revision.

This species is readily confused with the closely related A. silvaticus Lohmander, 1937 and there are arguments for considering them both part of the same species (Geenen et al. 2006, Rowson et al. 2014). However, most works (e.g. Welter-Schultes 2012) treat them separately.

This species is a member of a group of large Arion species which have often been confused with one another, and sometimes require dissection for successful identification. These species include, amongst others;

A. ater (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. rufus (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. vulgaris Moquin-Tandon, 1855 (=lusitanicus auctt. non Mabille);
A. lusitanicus Mabille, 1868;
A. flagellus Collinge, 1893.

Older literature records of this species are very unreliable as the species can not be reliably different from T. scutulum and T. maugei on shell morphology, with similar shells and individual variability. The species are reliably distinguishable exclusively by means of detailed genital investigation (W. de Mattia pers. comm. 2017).
This species is known to have a local subspecies, Oxychilus (Oxychilus) mortilleti planus (Clessin, 1877) endemic to Germany.
Waldén (1983: 268, note 27) commented that two forms are found: a  larger and a smaller (normal) that do not seem to intergrade.
Backeljau et al. (1994) concluded that A. urbiae and A. anguloi are most probably conspecific, whereas the genetic types of A. subfuscus may represent two different species.

There are several subspecies recognised with smaller ranges and one with a more widespread range, based on current knowledge. Further research on the molecular systematics of this group may change the species/subspecies limits.

The smallest smoother subspecies Clausilia rugosa parvula has the widest distribution from France north to Poland, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg to the Alps (Switzerland, Austria, Italy) while it extends to the southeast to Croatia and Slovenia, and further north to the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

Other subspecies have a smaller range:
Clausilia rugosa rugosa: France
Clausilia rugosa andusiensis: France
Clausilia rugosa belonidea: France 
Clausilia rugosa lamalouensis: France
Clausilia rugosa magdalenica: Spain
Clausilia rugosa penchinati: Spain, France.
Clausilia) rugosa pinii: Italy, France
Clausilia rugosa provincialis: France 
Clausilia rugosa reboudii: Spain, France

According to B. Rowson (pers. comm. 2016) this species is very difficult to distinguish from the closely related A. subfuscus (Draparnaud, 1805); A. fuscus (O.F. Muller, 1774); A. irati Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995; and A. lizarriti Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995. Even behavioural observation and dissection may be insufficient. More research on the three Garrido et al. (1995) species is required to clarify their distinctness, and their Red List status should arguably be considered provisional until then.

This species is readily confused with the closely related A. circumscriptus Johnston, 1828 and there are arguments for considering them both part of the same species (Geenen et al. 2006, Rowson et al. 2014). However, most works (e.g. Welter-Schultes 2012) treat them separately.

This species is a member of a group of large Arion species which have often been confused with one another, and sometimes require dissection for successful identification. These species include, amongst others;

A. ater (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. rufus (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. vulgaris Moquin-Tandon, 1855 (=lusitanicus auctt. non Mabille);
A. lusitanicus Mabille, 1868; and,
A. flagellus Collinge, 1893
There are taxonomic inconsistencies and a lack of a detailed revision of the genus Tandonia. The name Tandonia ehrmanni may be correct for this species.

Wollaston (1878) recognised three forms of this species:

a) major from laurisilva zones at intermediate and high elevations; this was the larger, more highly coloured form, with a long thin subvertical ventral lamella and a truncated, expanded columella (Seddon 2008: Plate 8C).

b) minor from exposed submaritime cliffs on Madeira; this was the smaller, paler form, with a short subvertical ventral lamella and a truncated, narrower columella. Waldén (1983, p. 268, note 25) suggests minor is probably an “ecophenotype” rather than a true subspecies. This form is smaller - 6.5 mm height, three mm breadth (Seddon 2008: Plate 8D).

c) intermedia from exposed submaritime cliffs on the Desertas Islands and Pico Branco; this form was intermediate in size, with a subvertical ventral lamella better developed and positioned further from the angle of the lip.

Oxychilus oppressus is reported for the whole of Sardinia and it is found in a vast variety of habitats, from extremely dry sand dunes to waste areas and also amongst halophile coastal vegetation, a few meters from the sea. Nevertheless, these records are based mainly upon shell characters that are known to not be extremely reliable in Oxychilidae. Thus, a thorough anatomical and molecular revision is highly recommended, and it would not be surprising if further research revealed a more complex situation within Sardinian Oxychilidae.

This species can be confused with the closely related A. circumscriptus Johnston, 1828 and A. silvaticus Lohmander, 1937. There are arguments for considering these two, or even all three, part of the same species (Geenen et al. 2006, Rowson et al. 2014).

In respect to other Tyrrhenian Oxychilus, O. pilula is well characterized by its Retinella-like shell. Anatomically it shares characters with Oxychilus s.str.: penis with flagellum and internal ornamentation of penis consisting of pleats and rows of papillae. Its nearest species is O. cellarius, but it differs from it by virtue of the 10-12 rows of polygonal papillae in the inner penial complex.

Giusti (1968) described Lehmannia caprai from the Island of Gorgona, which was later assigned to be a junior synonym of L. melitensis. Nevertheless, Lehmannia melitensis as well as the whole genus needs a thorough taxonomical revision.
This species was moved to the genus Drusia by Martínez–Ortí and Borredà (2012). The identity of this species with respect to D. deshayesii requires confirmation.

According to B. Rowson (pers. comm. 2016) this species is very difficult to distinguish from the closely related A. subfuscus (Draparnaud, 1805); A. fuscus (O.F. Muller, 1774); A. irati Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995; and A. molinae Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995. Even behavioral observations and dissections may be insufficient. More research on the three Garrido et al. (1995) species is required to clarify their distinctness, and their Red List statuses should arguably be considered provisional until then.

Accepted as Chamaeleo anchietae in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). This species has a wide and disjunct distribution. DNA barcoding shows that outlying populations of northern Tanzania and Rwanda attributed to this species are a separate, unidentified taxon. Two sub-species were described by Laurent in 1952 (C. anchietae marunguensis and C. a. mertensi) which derive from highlands on the western side of Lake Tanganyika, but this treatment needs to be confirmed by genetic analyses.

This species was referred to the new genus Trioceros by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Its taxonomy is somewhat complex, as a number of subspecies have been described and their validity challenged (see Tilbury 2010 for a summary), and the status of records from Kenya, Tanzania, South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo (outside Kivu Province) is in need of verification. These records are provisionally assigned to "Trioceros rudis incertae sedis" by Tilbury (2010) and are consequently not included in this assessment pending taxonomic investigation. Records from Ethiopia may represent confusion with T. bitaeniatus (Tilbury et al. 2010) and are not considered here. Trioceros sternfeldi, previously considered a subspecies of T. rudis, is now considered a full species. The population from Aberdares National Park in Kenya, previously also considered to belong to T. rudis (Tilbury 2010), has been described as T. kinangopensis (Stipala et al. 2012). Finally, records of T. rudis from the Albertine Rift region make up the bulk of this species occurrence, but in general they are of uncertain status and may not be T. rudis sensu stricto - unless they come from the Rwenzori  Mountains, which is the type locality of T. rudis.
Accepted as Chamaeleo gracilis in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank.The combined molecular and morphological analysis of Barej et al. (2010) necessitated major taxonomic changes to this taxon, and these authors elevated the subspecies T. w. perreti to species rank and removed T. serratus from synonymy. The correct assignment of one record close to the north Manengouba Mountains (Gounwouo et al. 2006) is uncertain, as this may represent either T. wiedersheimi or T. perreti (Barej et al. 2010). T. serratus is difficult to distinguish morphologically from T. wiedersheimi, and the distributional limits of these two taxa are in need of resolution (Barej et al. 2010).

There are two sub-species of this species, T. goetzei goetzei and T. goetzei nyikae (Tilbury 2010). The sub-species have not been investigated in a phylogenetic framework, but there is potentially divergence between them given their wide distribution but isolation on montane grassland plateau environments.

Accepted as Trioceros ellioti in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). T. ellioti overlaps with T. bitaeniatus in distrubution, and therefore there are occasional mis-identifications. Most sources agree that it prefers more moist habitat and is at higher elevations than T. bitaeniatus.
Ahaetulla dispar was described by Günther in 1864 as Tragops dispar based on specimens collected from Anaimalai Hills, Western Ghats (Smith 1943).

Mocoa bilneata was described by Gray in 1846 based on material from the summit of Nilgiri Hills. Species now assigned to Kaestlea have been assigned to various genera and until recently were placed in the genus Scincella. Eremchenko and Das (2004) erected the new genus Kaestlea to accommodate peninsular Indian species.

The genus Brachyophidium Wall, 1921 is a monotypic genus comprising a single species Brachiophidium rhodogaster Wall, 1921. Smith (1943) included it under the genus Teretrurus Beddome, 1886, however, currently it is placed back under the genus Brachyophidium (Das 2003).
Ophisops beddomei was first described as Pseudophiops beddomei by Jerdon in 1870 from Brahmagherry Hills in Wayanad, and it was later allocated to the genus Ophisops Ménétries, 1832 (Smith 1935).
Lycodon flavomaculatus was described by Wall in 1907 based on specimens collected from Khirkee, Poona District, Maharashtra (Smith 1943).

Ahaetulla perroteti was described by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril in in 1854 as Psammophis perroteti based on specimens collected from India (Smith 1943). No specific type locality has been assigned so far.

Trimerusurus strigatus was described by Gray in 1842 (Smith 1943) based on specimens collected from Madras Presidency (see Boulenger 1896). The generic assignment of this unusual species is in need of clarification: Kraus et al. (1996), David and Ineich (1999) and Das (2003) treated it as species of Protobothrops, but Herrmann et al. (2004) and Malhotra and Thorpe (2004) suggested removing this species from Protobothrops and to treat it under Trimeresurus sensu stricto. This has generally been followed since (although the taxonomic arrangement proposed by David et al. 2011 reassigns all species in Trimeresurus sensu stricto as generally understood to Craspedocephalus, these authors' Craspedocephalus is identical to the accepted concept of Trimeresurus s.s., and explicitly includes T. strigatus). No genetic data is available, however, and both hypotheses regarding this species' generic assignment should be considered provisional.

Plectrurus perroteti was described by Duméril and Bibron in 1854 based on specimens collected from the Nilgiri Hills, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1943). The specific epithet is misspelt as perrotetii (see McDiarmid et al. 1999).

Vicia barbazitae Ten. & Guss. is a secondary wild relative of Common Vetch V. sativa L., and more remotely Hungarian Vetch V. pannonica Crantz, it is also a tertiary wild relative of Faba Bean V. faba L., Narbon Bean V. narbonensis L. and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches including Articulated Vetch V. articulata Hornem., Bitter Vetch V. ervilia (L.) Willd. and Winter Vetch V. villosa Roth. (Maxted 1993, 1995).

V. barbazitae is split into two recognized varieties: V. barbazitae var. barbazitae Ten. & Guss. and V. barbazitae var. incisa (Orph.) Boiss.
Vicia kalakhensis A.Khattab, N.Maxted & F.A.Bisby belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of the Narbon Bean V. narbonensis L. and to the tertiary Gene Pool of Faba Bean V. faba L. (Maxted 1995).

Vicia assyriaca Boiss. is a secondary wild relative of Hungarian Vetch (V. pannonica Crantz), a tertiary wild relative of Narbon Bean (V. narbonensis L.) and Common Vetch (V. sativa L.) and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches Faba Bean (V. faba L.),  Articulated Vetch (V. articulata Hornem.), Bitter Vetch (V. ervilia (L.) Willd.) and Winter Vetch (V. villosa Roth.) (Maxted and Douglas 1996).

Townsend (1967) and Meikle (1977), based on observations of herbarium material, consider V. assyriaca to be a synonym of V. noeana. Davis and Plitmann (1970), however, retained the two as distinct species, while noting the existence of intermediate forms. No introgressive specimens have been found and the specific distinction is warranted (Maxted 1995).
Vicia tigridis Mouterde belongs to Taxon Group three of Hungarian Vetch V. pannonica Crantz (Maxted 1995).
Vicia hyrcanica Fisch. & C.A.Mey belongs to Taxon Group three of Hungarian Vetch V. pannonica Crantz. (Maxted 1995).

Subspecies:
C. calyptratus calcarifer Peters, 1871.

The taxonomy of Chamaelo dilepis, which may instead be a species complex, is uncertain and problematic (Largen and Spawls 2006). Pending resolution of this situation, Chamaeleo quilensis from Central and East Africa are here treated as "sporadic variants of Ch. dilepis" following Tilbury (2010). The name Chamaeleo ruspolii has historically been applied to a morphologically uniform population from Somalia and northern Ethiopia, however, broader geographical sampling within the range of C. dilepis indicates that C. ruspolii is likely to fall within the range of natural variation in C. dilepis, and moreover that it appears to represent the northern end of a spectrum of intergradation, with southern Ethiopian populations exhibiting characters intermediate between "C. ruspolii" to the north and East African C. dilepis (Largen and Spawls 2006).

Although some authors still recognize the form C. d. quilensis as well as subspecies (C.d. roperi Boulenger 1890, C. d. idjwiensis Loveridge, 1942, C. d. isabellinus Günther 1893, C. d. martensi Mertens, 1964 and C. d. petersi Gray, 1865), these should be treated with extreme caution pending a full taxonomic review of this species. Considerable confusion in identifications as well as complete overlap for sub-species records exist. Recognition of these subspecies at this time over-inflates the taxonomic quotient and unnecessarily complicates the situation (Tilbury 2010).



[[Taxonomic Notes for South African Regional Assessment - relevant parts can be incorporated into the global Taxonomic Notes above as required and this section can then be deleted:
A number of subspecies of C. dilepis (C. d. dilepis, C. d. idjwiensis, C. d. isabellinus, C. d. martensi, C. d. petersii, C. d. ruspolii) are recognized, partly due to morphological variation across the species' very large geographic range (Klaver and Böhme 1997, Neças 2004). The validity of these subspecies is unclear and a detailed taxonomic revision of the species complex would be useful. A preliminary phylogenetic analysis indicates there are multiple species within this complex, even within South Africa (Main et al. 2018). Included in the C. dilepis species complex are the extralimital species C. roperi and C. quilensis, but their taxonomic status also requires investigation. Tilbury (2010) considers all of the above-mentioned taxa, as well as C. angusticoronatus, as variants of a polymorphic C. dilepis.

Only one subspecies is present in South Africa, Lesotho and Eswatini, namely C. d. dilepis., however, a recent molecular study suggests that the South African subspecies may actually constitute two separate taxa (Main et al. 2018).]]
O. brachyantha A. Chev. & Roehr. is tertiary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).
O. glaberrima Steud. is a cultivated rice speces (African rice) and is also a primary wild relative of cultivated rice (Asia rice) (O. sativa L.).
O. barthii A. Chev. is a primary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.).
This species is not aquatic.
Because of the wide distribution of this species, many herpetologists believe that this is a species complex (R. Inger pers. comm.).

Recent DNA studies have elucidated the taxonomic status of this species. Previously, the name was applied to populations from four large islands (Isabela, Fernandina, Santa Cruz-Santa Fe and Santiago) and numerous associated satellite islets (Van Denburgh and Slevin 1913, Kizirian et al. 2004). Following DNA analysis, Benavides et al. (2007) restricted the range of the species to the Isabela-Fernandina islands, with the Santiago and Santa Cruz-Santa Fe populations now being recognized as Microlophus jacobi and M. indefatigabilis, respectively.

This species has four subspecies:
P. jerdonii jerdonii (Günther, 1875)
P. jerdonii bourreti (Klemmer, 1963) - Bourret's Pitviper
P. jerdonii meridionalis (Bourret, 1935)
P. jerdonii xanthomelas (Günther, 1889) - Red Spotted Pitviper.
Polhill (1968) described the species as closely related to C. iringana, which is common in the same general area but at lower altitudes.

Coelognathus radiatus was described by Boie in 1827 as Coluber radiatus based on specimens collected from Java, Indonesia. Dr. Patrick Russell's work "Indian Serpentes" published in 1801 also has drawings of this taxa (Smith 1943). This species has been long included under the genus Elaphe (Smith 1943), but following Helfenberger (2001) and Utiger et al. (2005), the Oriental Ratsnakes have been assigned to the genus Coelognathus.

Following revision of Trimeresurus by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004), the generic identity of this species remains to be clarified. David et al. (2011) exclude this species from their arrangement of Trimeresurus sensu lato, and suggest that it is likely to warrant a new genus (in their scheme, subgenus).

The historical concept of Agkistrodon blomhoffii included four subspecies: A. b. blomhoffii, A. b. brevicaudus, A. b. siniticus and A. b. dubitatus). Paik et al. (1993) elevated the Korean subspecies brevicaudus to specific status, a decision subsequently supported by genetic data (Xu et al. 2012). Based on mtDNA studies, Wang and Zhao (2007, 2008) found that Gloydius blomhoffii dubitatus and G. b. siniticus are both referrable to G. brevicaudus. Consequently the concept of G. blomhoffii accepted here is restricted to Japan and Kunashir Island.

Psammophis indochinensis is variously treated as a full species (e.g. Hughes 1999, Pauwels et al. 2003, Nguyen et al. 2009) or as a subspecies of P. condanarus (e.g. McKay 2006, Cottone and Bauer 2009). Cottone and Bauer (2009) remark that "the validity of the subspecific division of [P. condanarus] has not been critically assessed". Based on the disjunct distributions of the two taxa and morphological differences highlighted by Pauwels et al. (2003) it is probable that the two forms represent different species (P. David and A. Bauer pers. comm. 2013) and this scheme is followed here. A full revision is however needed to clarify the relationships of these two taxa (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2013).
Taxonomic study is required to assess whether populations across this large geographic area are truly conspecific. Two subspecies are recognized, Cylindrophis r. ruffus and C. r. burmanus.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Natrix. This species has long been treated as a subspecies of X. piscator. Literature records of this species and X. piscator, which occur in sympatry (Zug et al. 2006, Vogel and David 2006) are confused. The subspecies X. f. schnurrenbergeri is now recognized as a full species (Vogel and David 2006). Additional study of this species complex is warranted, as additional species may exist under the name X. flavipunctatus.
No taxonomic issues.
This species was placed in the genus Ophites by Zhao and Adler (1993), but Lycodon is the name in most frequent use for this species and the change has not been widely accepted.

Python bivittatus was recently recognized as a full species (Jacobs et al. 2009), having previously been considered a subspecies of P. molurus. The subspecies P. b. progschai has been erected to describe populations from Sulawesi (Jacobs et al. 2009).

There are several recognized sub-species of Narcissus poeticus: N. poeticus subsp. poeticus, N. poeticus subsp. radiiflorus (Salisb.) Baker and N. poeticus subsp. verbanensis (Herb.) P.D.Sell. (eMonocot 2010).
