Hemidactylus gracilis was described by Blanford in 1871 based on specimens collected from southeast Berar and Raipur in Central Province (now in Chhattisgarh) (Smith 1935).

This species is not included in Ashburner and McAllister (2013) as the authors have not seen material of this species, however it is accepted by the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (Govaerts 2014).
Oligodon venustus was described by Jerdon in 1853 as Xenodon venustum based on specimen collected from north Kanara, Karnataka (Smith 1943). Smith (1943) opines that the type is lost.

authority: Schurian, van Oorschot & Van den Brink, 1992
taxonomicNotes:
This species was first described in 1992 from four Turkish provinces (Konya, Adana, Kahramanmaras and Gaziantep). Then in 1994 Frédéric Carbonell described a new subspecies, P. (A.) theresiae larseni from Lebanon.

In 1999, a thorough review by Olivier et al. of all the theresiae specimens had the following outcomes:
-  Genetic study established that P. t. larseni should be elevated to a full species. P. theresiae was thus restored to being a Turkish endemic.
-  The specimens which had been used to establish the karyotype and chromosome number for theresiae came from Konya whilst the type specimens came from Adana. However, the Adana specimens were found to have a different chromosome number. It was thus decided to describe the Konya population as a new species: P. guezelmavi.
-  The specimens from Kahramanmaras and Gaziantep were identified to be Polyommatus poseidon.
 
 It was thus established that theresiae is an endemic species known only from the type locality in Adana.

Fred Stauffer, Didier Roguet, Mathieu Perret (Conservatory and Botanical Garden of Geneva, Switzerland) and Doudjou Ouattara (University Nangui Abrogua, Côte d'Ivoire), are currently working on the taxonomic revision of the Genus Hyphaene.

Individuals from the Chatham Island population have more black area on the thorax than South Island populations (Marinov and McHugh 2010) and differing DNA analysis (Nolan et al. 2007), and may prove to be a different subspecies.

Massive habitat modification throughout New Zealand (particularly the North Island) since c.1820 has created new selection pressures on this genus, that has affected distribution, morphology and genetics, possibly leading to positive hybridisation. This species has suspiciously variable morphology, and its taxonomy needs to be studied in greater detail (R. Rowe pers. comm. 2011). Despite the recent recognition of several species, it is probable that several more or less isolated taxonomic groups remain 'undiscovered' in this species (Rowe 1987).

Wolfe (1953) expressed doubt over the species status - it may be a subspecies of Uropetala carovei (White, 1846), however this was rejected by Rowe (1987), and it has been considered a valid species by several subsequent authors (e.g., Schorr and Paulson 2012).
Central Saharan populations were recently recognized as a distinct species, Agama tassiliensis (Geniez et al. 2011).

A systematic revision of this species has been warranted for some time, based on evidence that the traditional concept was not monophyletic (Jadin et al. 2012). On the basis of molecular evidence reported by these authors, Jadin et al. (2012) redescribed Cerrophidion godmani and described two new species - C. sasai (Costa Rica and Panama) and C. wilsoni (Guatemala and El Salvador) - to encompass populations south of Guatemala formerly assigned to this taxon.

This species is paraphyletic, and resolution is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of Crotalus simus in much of its range. The species concept applied here follows Savage et al. (2005), who designated a neotype for this species and applied the name to Central American snakes formerly considered to belong to C. d. durissus.

Based on patterns of multilocus isozyme variation, Mendoza-Quijano et al. (1998) recognized Sceloporus variabilis marmoratus as a distinct species (Sceloporus marmoratus), and they proposed that the remaining S. variabilis populations be split into multiple species. In commenting on the proposed split, Crother et al. (2000) pointed out that the sample of marmoratus was from a single locality more than 500 km from the closest sample of S. v. variabilis and concluded that more extensive sampling from intermediate localities is needed to determine if marmoratus and variabilis are separate lineages.

Sceloporus variabilis marmoratus is retained here following Crother et al. (2000) and Bell et al. (2003) pending further investigation of its taxonomic status.

U. ornata and the previously recognized U. philbyi exhibit a high degree of morphological and genetic similarity (Wilms et al. 2007). These authors therefore treat U. philbyi as a subspecies of U. ornata, where it had previously provisionally been placed (e.g. Wilms and Böhme 2007), and this scheme is followed here. U. ornata itself has variously been treated as either a full species or a subspecies of U. ocellata (see Wilms and Böhme 2007 for a discussion of this lizard's taxonomic history).
Zhao (1997) described this species based on specimens from Hainan originally attributed to Rhabdophis chrysargos.
Alcea grossheimii Iljin is distinguished from the other Alcea species of the flora of Armenia by character of the stamen tube pubescence. Close to A. tabrisiana Boiss. & Buhse.
Along with a complex of morphological features Allium struzlianum Ogan. differs from closely related species by strong vanilla aroma.
Allium baytopiorum Kollmann & Özhatay is allied to A. dictyoprasum Ledeb. and A. hamrinense Hand.-Mazz.
Allochrusa takhtajanii Gabrieljan & Dittrich differs from close relative species A. versicolor (Fisch. & C.A.Mey.) Boiss. by type of pubescence, shape of leaves and petals.

Astragalus holophyllus Boriss. has no closely related species and makes up a monotypic section Holophyllum Boriss. Its closest relatives are A. latifolius Lam., A. candolleanus Boiss., A. sukaczevii Derv.-Sok. & Elenevsky from the section Proselius (Steven) Bunge. The species differs from the mentioned relative(s) by elongate-elliptic (not linear-cylindric) pods, weak, prostrate (not erect) peduncles, always entire leaves, while the mentioned relative(s) have both entire leaves and those consisting of one to six pairs of leaflets.
Closely allied to A. capicus Bieb. and A. caucasicus Pall.
Astragalus trabzonicus Ekici, Aytaç & Akan is close to A. adzharicus Popov and A. arguricus Bunge.
Astragalus longivexillatus Podlech & Ekici is related to A. armeniacus Boiss.
Astragalus shagalensis Grossh. differs from the other species of the section Onobrychium Bunge by structure of calyx and soft squarrose pubescence of the whole plant, etc.
Astragalus coelestis Boiss. differs from closely related species: A. brachycarpus M. Bieb., A robustus Bunge and A. subrobustus Boriss. mainly by deflexed peduncles, drooping flowers and pods.

Astragalus bylowae Elenevsky differs from closely related A.ornithopodioides Lam. by shape of pods and leaflets and very short calyx teeth. It differs from another closely related species A. glochideus Boriss. by small calyx (4 mm in the former while 6 mm in the latter).

Bufonia takhtajanii Nersesian is close to B. sintenisii Freyn, B. macrocarpa Ser., B. capsularis Boiss. & Hausskn., B. elata Boiss., from which differs by the morphology of caudex, length of stem leaves and pedicels, morphology of sepals and buds.

This species has had a complex taxonomic history with other Ambystomatids such as Ambystoma tigrinum, A. velasci and A. californiense (Frost 2011). There are 5 recognized subspecies of A. mavortium (Crother 2012), based mainly on colour patterns and geographic distribution; the validity of the subspecies has not been examined recently.

Centaurea rhizocalathium (K.Koch) Tchich. is similar to C. armena Boiss. in the majority of its characteristics but phyllaries of the former totally lack an appendage or end in a mucro up to 2 mm long. Although very different in structure of appendages, C. rhizocalathium and C. armena seem to be closely related and further studies are needed to show whether they may be considered as separate species.
Centaurea vavilovii Takht. & Gabrieljan differs from closely related Centaurea behen L. primarily by its largely winged stems.

Centaurea tamanianiae M.V.Agab. differs from the related species C. ruthenica Lam. and C. hajastana Tzvelev by shape and number of stem leaves, shape and size of involucre, achene and pappus, presence of a narrow membranous edge of involucre leaves.
Centaurea demirizii Wagenitz is related to C. glastifolia L.
Chaerophyllum karsianum is known only from the type locality. The species resembles relatively widespread Ch. bulbosum L.
Chaerophyllum posofianum is closely related to Ch. bulbosum L. and Ch. karsianum Kit Tan & Ocakverdi.

Cirsium davisianum Kit Tan & Sorger is a distinct species known only from the type specimen and thus, needs further collection. The acaulescent habit, radical leaves and phyllary characteristics are not shared by any other Turkish or Caucasian members of Sect. Epitrachys.
Cirsium eliasianum Kit Tan & Sorger is apparently related to C. simplex C.A.Mey.
Cirsium trachylepis Boiss. is related to C. sommieri Petr. and C. osseticum (Adams) Petr.
Colchicum leptanthum K. Perss. is close to C. serpentinum Woronow ex Miscz. and C. munzurense K.Perss.
Cousinia takhtajanii Tamanian differs from closely related species by narrow involucre leaves, arcuately reflexed from the constriction.

Dianthus grossheimii Schischk. is 20-40 cm tall plant with lanceolate-linear leaves and quite dense corymbose inflorescences, distinguished from closely related D. cretaceus Adams by stem tallness, larger flowers and calyces as well as pink or purple (not white or pale pink) petals.
Erodium sosnowskianum Fed. differs from densely pubescent E. armenum (Trautv.) Woronow by poor pubescence and structure of sepals.
Ferula mervynii is a very distinct species.
Festuca xenophontis Markgr.-Dann. is related to F. azgarica E.B.Alexeev.

Gladiolus hajastanicus differs from closely related G. kotschyanus Boiss. by smaller size of the whole plant as well as papery, very disrupted scales of bulbotubers, small number of flowers in an inflorescence, very elongated lower lobes of the perianth limb. From G. szovitsii Grossh. it differs mainly by papery and not fibrous scales of the bulbotuber.

The name Grossheimia caroli-henrici (Gabrieljan & Dittrich) Gabrieljan considered a synonym of Centaurea caroli-henrici Gabrieljan & Dittrich is accepted according to Czerepanov (1995) and Takhtajan (2008).
Heracleum sommieri is close to H. sosnowskyi Manden.
Heracleum cyclocarpum K. Koch is very close to the robust H. sphondylium subsp. transsilvanicum Brummitt from the Carpathians.
Hypericum theodori Woronow is not included in The Plant List (2010) but accepted according to Czerepanov (1995) and Takhtajan (manuscript).
Iris timofejewii Woronow belongs to sect. Poroniris. The species is close to Pontic Iris pumila L.
Kirno is a local common name of Lilium ciliatum in Trabzon.
Linaria zangezura Grossh. differs from Linaria grandiflora Desf. mainly by character of inflorescence and slightly smaller petals.
Lotus armeniacus Kit Tan & Sorger resembles L. angustissimus L.
K. M. Person (1992) relates Merendera mirzoevae with M. eichleri Boiss., from which it differs habitually and by a number of characteristics of staminal nectaries, seeds, arilloids, etc.
Minuartia armena Schischk is described according to collections made by Ja. I. Mulkidjanyan in the Flora of Armenia (1956. Vol. II. Pp. 56-57).
Minuartia daralagexica Schischk. is described based on collections by Sh. Aslanyan and R. Karapetyan (Shishkin & Avetisyan 1956).
Myosotis daralaghezica T.N.Popova is a peculiar species with special pubescence of stem and leaves (stiff accumbent hairs assidenous on white protuberances).
Nepeta alaghezi Pojark. holds intermediate position between N. betonicifolia C. A. Mey. and N. mussinii Henckel.
Closely related to Onobrychis radiata (Desf) Bieb.
Onobrychis meschetica Grossh. has no close relations to the other taxa in the genus.
It is related to O. armeniaca Klokov.

Ornithogalum gabrielianiae differs from closely related O. hyrcanum Grossh. by more elongated and usually incurvate upper part of the bulb, its partly connate scales, absence of bulblets, etc. From another close relative O. bungei Boiss. it differs by smaller number of leaves, less dense and shorter inflorescence, etc.

There is only a single specimen of Orobanche schelkovnikovii Tzvelev from Aparan floristic region of Armenia in the Institute of Botany of the National Academy of Sciences of Armenia (ERE) ("In declivitate occidentale montis Kethan-dagh. In steppa montana, 18.06.1940, A. Fedorov", ERE 68687), determined by N.N. Tzvelev, but with notification that this specimen differs from the type by accrete sepals. In the “Flora of Armenia” (Tsaturyan and Grigoryan 1987) it is indicated that distribution of this species includes Erevan (Garni), Darelegis (Dzhermuk) and Zangezur (Khndzoresk) floristic regions. It is necessary to investigate material in other herbariums, first of all in Komarov Botanical Institute (LE).
Papaver sjunicicum M.V.Agab. is close to P. armeniacum (L.) DC. and P. zangezuricum Mikheev.
Papaver roseolum M.V.Agab. & Fragman is close to P. dubium L. and P. purpureomarginatum Kadereit.
Psephellus appendicigerus (K.Koch) Wagenitz is related to P. pulcherrimus (Willd.) Wagenitz.
Psephellus zangezuri Sosn. is endemic to South Armenia described from Tatev, Zangezur. Type is kept at ERE.
Psephellus fajvuschii (Gabrieljan) Greuter differs from the other representatives of the subgenus Xanthopsis by prostrate stems densely leafy at base.
Psephellus straminicephalus (Hub.-Mor.) Wagenitz is a taxonomically isolated species.
Psephellus avaricus (Tzvelev) Wagenitz belongs to the sub-genus Odontolophus.

Psephellus cronquistii (Takht. & Gabrieljan) Gabrieljan differs from closely related species mainly by branched stems (branched into 6-12 branchlets terminated by heads) and sharp colour of the appendages of involucre leaves (outer brown, inner bright).
Specimens of Psephellus debedicus (Gabrieljan) Gabrieljan with entire not only upper cauline, but also lower and basal leaves are not rare.
Differs from Psephellus erivanensis subsp. holargyreus (Bornm. & Woronow) Greuter by smaller heads and appendages of the middle leaves of involucre.
Psephellus geghamensis (Gabrieljan) Gabrieljan is described from Khosrov Reserve, Armenia. The type is kept at ERE, isotype at LE. The species is distinguished by spherical heads.

Psephellus manakyanii (Gabrieljan) Gabrieljan is described according to collections made by V. A. Manakyan in the surroundings of Margaovite, Khalab range, southwestern slope above village Margaovit, 14.6.1961, in Armenia. The holotype is kept at ERE and the isotype at ERE, LE, G, K.
It differs from closely related species by involucre leaves with equally distributed erect cilia, as well as the stigma with lobes having spare-shaped points.
Ranunculus vermirrhizus A.P.Khokhr. needs taxonomic research.
Ranunculus tempskyanus Freyn & Sint. is allied to R. fibrillosus K.Koch.
Ranunculus aragazi Grossh. is closely related to R. merovensis Grossh.

Centaurea hajastana Tzvelev differs from the other representatives of the type subgenus occurring in Armenia by large 3-4-serial involucre with widely scarious appendage of involucre leaves, very large edge flowers and special morphology of achene and pappus. The closest species occur in Central Iran (C. lachnopus Rech.f.) and Middle Asia (C. androssovii Iljin, C. gontscharovii Iljin).
Rosa zangezura Jarosch. was described by P. Jaroshenko in 1945 from Zangezur and Megri floristic regions of Armenia. The species has small, white flowers and seven leaflets.

Rosa sosnovskyana Tamamsch. is described by S. G. Tamamshyan from the Aparan floristic region of Armenia. This is a tall shrub with greyish bark and small stramineous spines; hypanthium bridtled; leaflets glabrous.
Scorzonera safievii Grossh. is described from the Daralegis floristic region, Armenia. The type is kept at BAK.
Related to S. divarcata Ledeb.
Stachys choruhensis Kit Tan & Sorger is allied to S. rupestris Montbret & Aucher ex Benth.

Sterigmostemum acanthocarpum (Fisch. & C.A.Mey.) Grossh. is an accepted name according to Czerepanov (1995) and Takhtajan (manuscript).

Materials existing in Azerbaijan are collected in 1932-33. In Armenia the species was collected more recently.
Symphytum hajastanum Gvin. differs from closely related S. asperum Lepechin by morphology of pollen grains, ratio between size of calyx and corolla.
Noccaea sintenisii has no close relatives in the genus.
Thymus markhotensis Maleev is described from the Markotkh range, Krasnodar Kray, the Russian Federation.
Thes species is considered to be close to T. aucheri DC., from which it is distinguished by a number of properties and especially morphology of the achene.
Tragopogon otschiaurii Kuth. is related to T. reticulatus Boiss. & Huet.
Tragopogon makaschwilii Kuth. is related to T. elatior Steven.
Tragopogon meskheticus Kuth. has no close relation to the other species in the genus.
Tragopogon armeniacus Kuth. differs from the other species of the genus occurring in Armenia by morphology of marginal achenes, stem colour, size of flowers and pappus.

Pseudolysimachion spicatum (L.) Opiz. subsp. transcaucasicum (Bordz.) Gabrieljan was described by by Bordzilovsky in 1927 from the Idzhevan floristic region of Armenia. The plant has no glandularpubescence; stem hairs are directed downwards; petals are white, rarely pale bluish; sepals incised to base.
Astragalus tatlii Pesmen resembles A. mikrophyton Sirj. & Rech. fil.
Cirsium pugnax Sommier & Levier has a very complicated synonymy (Menitsky 1996) and is a rather variable species according to many parameters (A. Mikheev pers. comm. 2008).
Telmatobius rubigo was previously referred to as Telmatobius marmoratus (Barrionuevo and Baldo 2009).

Two subspecies are recognized in Tropical East Africa. The complex including Aloe macrocarpa is taxonomically difficult and needs to be revised throughout the range from Ethiopia to South Africa and from East to West Africa.
A. macrocarpa is taxonomically difficult and needs a thorough revision.

Until recently, this species was included within Daboia russelii, a species understood to have a widespread but heavily disjunct distribution within South and Southeast Asia. The number of recognized subspecies of this wide-ranging snake is variable, but six are traditionally accepted (Thorpe et al. 2007). Morphological analysis suggests, however, that only two distinct forms exist, one (D. r. russelii) restricted to the Indian subcontinent and the other (for which the name with priority is D. r. siamensis)  found in the remainder of the snake's range (Wūster et al. 1992). These authors refrained from elevating D. r. siamensis to a full species due to the lack of molecular research to support this conclusion. More recently, using both molecular and morphological data, Thorpe et al. (2007) found strong support for this division and recognized two distinct species, D. russelii (incorporating the former subspecies D. r. pulchella and D. r. nordicus as well as D. r. russelii) and D. siamensis (incorporating D. r. limitis, D. r. sublimitis and D. r. formosensis). Due to low divergence between members of each lineage, Thorpe et al. (2007) do not recognize distinct subspecies of either form.
It was only known from the type locality in Paksong (collected once in 1928). It was refound in 2011.

This species was sunk into Dissotis princeps, a widespread species (South Africa to Ethiopia) by Jacques-Felix (1983), but since it is abundantly distinct (e.g. three leaves per node, not two) the treatment in Flora of West Tropical Africa of keeping it as a distinct species is followed here instead.

The species name Alchemilla xanthochlora is accepted by the Rosaceae Database (Jung et al. 2013). The species taxonomic definition is partially unresolved and has a number of synonyms (The Plant List 2014).
The species and subspecies is still under review by the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (WCSP 2014). The species is frequently found in both Pulsatilla and Anemone genera.

The species has several suggested synonyms (The Plant List 2014). Subspecies Aquilegia nigricans subsp. subscaposa (Borbás) Soó is an accepted infraspecific name of Aquilegia nigricans and also synonym of Aquilegia subscaposa Borbás (The Plant List 2014).

Although Aquilegia nigricans and Aquilegia nigricans subsp. subscaposa (Borbás) Soó were considered synonyms in the literature (Chifu et al. 2006, Sarbu et al. 2013), these two taxa grow in different ecological habitats and have distinct flower colour and should and therefore be considered as two different species (A. Badarau pers. comm. 2014). Aquilegia nigricans subsp. subscaposa (Borbás) Soó is strictly linked to calcareous mountainous areas.
Leucojum vernum var. vernum and L. vernum var. carpathicum are recognized varieties of this species.

In the Euro+Med Plantbase (Greuter 2006-2009), this species is treated as a synonym of Leontopodium nivale ssp. alpinum (Cass.) Greuter. However, Leontopodium alpinum is an accepted species in The Plant List (2012) and in GRIN Taxonomy (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2012).
This is of unclear taxonomic status (Etheridge and Williams 1985, Abdala et al. 2012).

Includes the following subspecies (Reales et al. 2004);

Salvia officinalis subsp. officinalis
Salvia officinalis subsp. gallica
Salvia officinalis subsp. lavandulifolia
Salvia officinalis subsp. oxyodon

The subspecies Salvia officinalis subsp. lavandulifolia (Vahl) Gams is considered a valid species, Salvia lavandulifolia Vahl, by some workers (e.g., Castroviejo et al. 2010, G. Blanca pers. comm. 2014), however we consider it here as a subspecies of Salvia officinalis L. following Reales et al. 2004.

This species was formerly thought to be a population of Trioceros sternfeldi (Tilbury 2010), but was recently described as Trioceros hanangensis by Krause and Böhme (2010). Molecular phylogenetic analyses of mitochondrial markers (Jan Stipala unpub. data 2013) suggests that the "T. sternfeldi" population in the Ngorongoro crater highlands is more closely related to T. hanangensis than to T. sternfeldi. However, the phylogenetic trees were not fully resolved and no nuclear markers were included, so further research is needed.

The subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) was elevated to generic rank by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Barej et al. (2010) elevated the former subspecies to species rank based on molecular and morphological differences from the nominate taxon. Accepted as Trioceros perreti in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank. Mertens (1940) synonymized Chamaeleon (=Chamaeleo) serratus within Chamaeleo wiedersheimi on the basis that specimens examined, including those from the Bamenda Highlands, were indistinguishable from a C. wiedersheimi paratype from the same locality. This view was subsequently supported with reference to additional material and the original description (Mertens 1968, Klaver and Böhme 1992). The holotype of C. serratus, with the unspecific locality "Südkamerun", is lost, and was probably destroyed during World War II (Klaver and Böhme 1992), so has never been available for comparison. Combined morphological and molecular research by Barej et al. (2010) found that Bamenda specimens belong to a clade separate from Trioceros wiedersheimi. Designating a neotype for T. serratus, these authors therefore resurrected this name for the newly-recognized species, fixing the type locality as Belo, Mt Oku, and removed it from synonymy with T. wiedersheimi. The two species are, however, difficult to distinguish morphologically, and the distributional limits of these two taxa are in need of resolution (Barej et al. 2010).

Arnold et al. (2008) revised the taxonomy of this species, formerly considered the only endemic species of Hemidactylus on Cape Verde and including the subspecies H. b. boavistensis (Boavista and Sal) and H. b. razoensis (Santo Luzia and Raso) in addition to populations from Fogo and São Nicolau unassigned to any subspecies. These authors re-elevated H. b. boavistensis to full species status and described the Fogo population as a new species, H. lopezjuradoi. The São Nicolau population was retained within H. bouvieri on the basis that available material is too poorly-preserved to permit morphological description, but was found to be genetically distinct from typical H. bouvieri. Arnold et al. (2008) consider that once better material becomes available this form will warrant description as a distinct taxon.

Hynková et al. (2009) suggested that Boa imperator is likely to warrant recognition as a full species. This arrangement was further supported by Reynolds et al. (2014) and is followed here. Two subspecies are recognized: B. i. imperator and B. i. sabogae (Reynolds and Henderson, in press).

Adams (2004) separates Juniperus lutchuensis Koidz. (Ryukyu Islands, Honshu – Shodzuoka Pref.) from J. taxifolia but not on any consistently distinct characters. Instead, its separation is in his analysis based on Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA (RAPD) which is a controversial method to detect differences at the species level. Juniperus lutchuensis was described in 1918 and has commonly been treated as a synonym of J. taxifolia, including Farjon (2005) and is here treated the same.

Koidzumi (1918) described Juniperus lutchuensis from Okinawa in order to replace Hayata's interpretation of J. taxifolia Hook. & Arn., which he considered to be a different species only found in the Ogasawara Islands (Bonin Is.). He described the new species as being a dense, prostrate shrub with acute leaves and dark purplish cones occurring near the sea shore. Wilson (1916, 1920) referring to the juniper of the Ryukyu Islands ["Liukiu Is."] misapplied the name J. conferta Parl. and included the littoral form of J. rigida that occurs only on the shores of the main islands in Japan. Comparison of the material from the two island groups has made it clear that they are a single species. In the Ogasawara Islands, where the type was collected, erect shrubs to small trees can be found among shrubs and tall grasses often some distance from the shores. Decumbent forms, although rare, develop over rocks. The wider littoral zones on the less steep Okinawa Group have given opportunity for the selection and spread of this prostrate growth form of the same species. Its apparently disjunct distribution in two disparate archipelagos separated by the deep waters of the western Pacific Ocean was first recognized by Walker (1976) in his Flora of Okinawa and the southern Ryukyu Islands.
There are some taxonomic queries about the boundary between this species and other Chinese junipers.
Some authors consider Microtus pyrenaicus a synonym of Microtus gerbei, although there is debate about which name is appropriate (Musser and Carleton 2005).

Hooker treated Mann 1309 (Jan. 1862, 10,500 ft.), the first specimen known of this species, as identical to the European 'Devil's Bit Scabious', Succisa pratensis. Succisa trichotocephala was only described as a separate species in 1952, before which the African plants were only varietally distinguished (in the 1930s) as Succisa pratensis var. kamerunensis B.L.Burtt.
Juniperus centrasiatica is a synonym of this and appeared in the 1998 World List of Threatened Trees as LR/nt.
Dipsacus is genus of about 15 species restricted to Eurasia (Europe - eight species) and Tropical African mountains. This is the only species known in West-Central Africa.
Accepted as a valid taxon by most cactus researchers including Bravo-Hollis and Sanchez Mejorada (1991),  Arredondo et al. (2001), Dicht and Luüthy (2001), Anderson (2001) and Hunt et al. (2006).

Without doubt a 'good' species. However, originally described in the genus Puna, a recent study (Stuppy 2001) has shown that the taxon undoubtedly belongs to the genus Tephrocactus (not Opuntia as indicated in the CITES Checklist).

Basionym: Puna bonnieae D.J. Ferguson & R. Kiesling, Cact. Succ. J. (US) 69: 290 (1997). Type: Argentina, Catamarca, Dept. Tinogasta, near Loro Huasi, November 20, 1994, R. Kiesling 8710 (SI, holotype).

Synonyms = Maihueniopsis bonnieae (D. J. Ferguson & R. Kiesling) E.F. Anderson, Cact. Succ. J. (US) 71(6): 325 (1999); Opuntia bonnieae (Ferguson & Kiesling) Halda & Janeba, Cactaceae etc. 9 (4): 160. 1999.
Hunt et al. (2006) treat O. pachyrriza as being conspecific with O. megarrhiza, but that treatment is not followed here and the two species are assessed separately.

Originally described by J.N. Rose in 1906. Later recognized by Britton and Rose (1919) and by Bravo (1978). Recently studied by Hernández et al. (2001).

Hunt et al. (2006) treat O. pachyrriza as being conspecific with O. megarrhiza, but that treatment is not followed here and O. pachyrriza is assessed separately.

Lepus granatensis was formerly included in L. europaeus or L. capensis; but see Palacios (1983, 1989), and Bonhomme et al. (1986). The population of hares in Sardinia, to which the names mediterraneus Wagner, 1841 and typicus Hilzheimer, 1906, are applied, in the past have been assigned to this species based on Miller (1912), who regarded it as closest to granatensis, though he retained it as a "...very distinct species" because of its small size. If in the future mediterraneus is confirmed as a synonym of granatensis, it has priority over granatensis. The Sardinian population is included in L. capensis until its taxonomic status is resolved. L. granatensis is parapatric with L. europaeus in northern Spain, and in this region mtDNA from granatensis has been found in populations of europaeus. Molecular phylogeny has shown that L. granatensis is indeed a full species and one of three hare species present on the Iberian Peninsula (Alves et al. 2003, Estonba et al. 2006). Previous questions regarding taxonomic distinction of L. granatensis from L. capensis have been resolved by genetic and morphological comparisons (Mitchell-Jones et al. 1999, Alves et al. 2003).

There are three subspecies: Lepus granatensis granatensis (Iberian Peninsula except northwest), L. g. gallaecius (northwest Spain, Galiza, and central Asturias), L. g. solisi (Mallorca Island) (Hoffmann and Smith 2005, Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016,  Alves and Acevedo 2018).
Juniperus coahuilensis var. arizonica which was previously included under this species, is now recognized as a distinct species (Farjon 2010).

This species has been erroneously referred to J. taxifolia by several authors, but that name only applies to a species occurring on the Bonin Islands (Ogasawaka Gunto) and on the Ryukyu Islands of Japan described by Hooker & Arnott (1838). Parlatore (1868) partly misapplied the name as he also included elements from China (e.g. R. Fortune 47) which belong to J. formosana. This species was first described from Taiwan by Hayata (1908) in his 'Flora Montana Formosae' (not in the Gardener's Chronicle of that year); the lectotype is from A-li Shan (Mt. Morrison). The misapplication was clarified by Hayata in a later paper (Hayata 1909) in which he demonstrated that J. taxifolia Hook. & Arn. is a different species. Later discoveries made it clear that J. formosana is widespread in warm temperate China. Variation in the leaves of some specimens have been treated as distinct taxa but none of these appear to be consistent.  A single aberrant specimen was collected by H. von Handel-Mazzetti in SE Sichuan and described as a forma (Handel-Mazzetti 1929) with very small, divaricate leaves, apparently forming a small shrub. This would perhaps have been a suitable cultivar (it was found at ca. 2,750 m alt.) but it was not taken into cultivation. It may no longer exist in the wild either in that locality. Similar specimens have been collected from Taiwan, which makes it likely that this form occurs from time to time, perhaps as a mutant.

Martínez (1946) described J. monosperma var. gracilis from the lower slopes of the Sierra Madre Oriental in NE Mexico, but on the IUCN Redlist this taxon is recognized as a distinct but related species J. angosturana R.P.Adams

Juniperus baimashanensis was accepted as a distinct species in Flora of China 4: 72-73 (1999) and was assessed by the China Plant Specialist Group as CR B1ac(ii)+2ac(ii). It is here considered to be not distinct from J. squamata.

Two varieties are recognized: the typical variety occurs as a small tree while var. humilis de Laub. is a low growing, sometimes decumbent shrub. Both are locally abundant and although assessed as Least Concern are not listed separately.

Caiman crocodilus has four subspecies currently recognized:  C. c. crocodilus, C. c. fuscus, C. c. chiapasius, and C. c. apaporiensis. Caiman yacare previously was considered to be a fifth subspecies (i.e., C. c. yacare). However, it is now generally accepted as a full species (King and Burke 1989), and is no longer treated as a subspecies (Escobedo-Galván et al. 2011).

Busack and Pandya (2001), using morphological analysis, stated that there were no differences between subspecies. However, Venegas-Anaya et al. (2008), using mitochondrial DNA analysis, recognized three out of these four subspecies (no samples from C. c. apaporiensis used in this study) and delimited geographically distributions within the C. crocodilus complex. DNA analyses also suggest a geographic divergence in two groups: the Mesoamerican group including C. c. fuscus and C. c. chiapasius and the South American group, which includes C. c. crocodilus and C. yacare (Amato and Gatesby 1994; Venegas-Anaya et al. 2008).

Recent morphological analysis of the Apaporis River caiman (C. c. apaporiensis), based on holotype and paratypes skulls from the Chicago Field Museum (USA), corroborates a significant morphological differentiation with the rest of the C. crocodilus subspecies (Escobedo-Galván et al. 2015a) as reported by Frederico Medem in 1952. However, DNA analysis conducted with additional paratypes from Colombian collections showed that several of those skulls identified as C. c. apaporiensis in the Instituto de Ciencias Naturales, National University of Colombia collection fall into the C. c. crocodilus clade (Bloor 2013). Nevertheless, a more in-depth study is being initiated in late 2018, to collect less fragmented DNA (from live individuals rather than ancient bones) and larger sample sizes (for both morphological and genetic analyses), which will hopefully provide new evidence on the validity of this subspecies.

FitzSimons (1930) considered the population around Port St Johns in the Eastern Cape province of South Africa, as a new species, Arthroleptis wageri, but Poynton (1964) synonymised this species with the more widespread A. wahlbergii which is assessed below. Genetic studies to uncover any substantial genetic differentiation for the Eastern Cape population is currently underway.
Some isolated populations in the north of its range could be separate taxa.
This is a restricted concept following the split of the broader concept into this and Sclerophrys pusillus (Poynton et al. 2016).
It is not clear that this species is distinct from Heleophryne purcelli (L. Minter pers. comm.).

This form is a complex of more than one species, probably comprising several species (M.-O. Rödel pers comm.). In many parts of its range, the distinction between this species and Hemisus marmoratus is not clear. Ongoing taxonomic work (by de Sá and colleagues) will result in reshaping our knowledge of cryptic species richness and distributions of populations currently assigned to Hemisus marmoratus and H. guineensis.

It is possible that the subspecies Hemisus marmoratus sudanensis constitutes a separate species (Rödel 2000). This species is probably a complex comprising several species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). Ongoing taxonomic work (by de Sá and colleagues) will result in reshaping our knowledge of cryptic diversity and distributions of populations currently assigned to Hemisus marmoratus and Hemisus guineensis. In several parts of its range, this species is not readily distinguishable from Hemisus guineensis.

Pickersgill (1996, 2007) recognized Afrixalus unicolor (Boettger, 1913) as a distinct species; thus Afrixalus fornasinii from South Africa to southern Tanzania (including the area around Lake Malawi) and A. unicolor from southern Tanzania (including Zanzibar and Pemba Islands) to Kenya. However, here we follow Schiøtz (1999) in considering these to constitute a single species.

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) described Hyperolius fumatus as a new species, but we follow Frost (2007) Amphibian Species of the World 5.1 http://research.amnh.org/herpetology/amphibia/index.php in treating it as a synonym of H. marmoratus. Similarly, Pickersgill (2007) treated verrucosus, taeniatus, aposematicus, alborufus, and nyassae as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including them under H. marmoratus.

Portik and Blackburn (2016) have suggested that Kassina maculata is more closely related to Phylctimantis than to other species of Kassina (based on the evolution of its reproductive modes), and they recommend that this species be transferred to Phlyctimantis. Additional taxonomic work is possibly required to verify these findings.
Although this species has often been confused with Leptopelis kivuensis (see Schiøtz 1999), Roelke et al. (2011) clarified the difference between the two species.

Pristimantis charlottevillensis differs from other Caribbean and South American members of the genus by its vocalizations, morphology, sexual size dimorphism, and chromosome complement. This is a presumed sister taxon to P. terraebolivaris (Kaiser et al. 1995).
Subpopulations previously assessed as Noblella peruviana in fact pertain to Psychrophrynella usurpator.

Telmatobius punctatus was previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius brevirostris; it was elevated to specific status by Lehr (2005) based on differences in morphological features and colour patterns.
There are questions around the taxonomy of this concept and it could comprise several cryptic species (E. Lehr and A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
This species is a complex of more than one species.

This species hybridises in places with Breviceps mossambicus, leading to confusion about its distributional limits (Poynton and Broadley 1985). Breviceps adspersus pentheri in the Eastern Cape might be a distinct species L. Minter pers. comm.).

This species hybridises in places with Breviceps adspersus, leading to confusion about its distributional limits (Poynton and Broadley 1985). Some specimens previously referred to B. mossambicus have recently been separated to a new species, B. fichus (Channing and Minter, 2004).

This form consists of many cryptic species. We follow Channing et al. (2005) in removing Kenyan and Tanzanian population from this species, under the name Cacosternum plimptoni. Ethiopian populations should presumably also be separated as a distinct species, but for now we treat them as part of C. boettgeri.

We follow Scott (in press) in considering the subspecies, Cacosternum nanum parvum, as a distinct species. Specimens from north-eastern Kwa-Zulu Natal have been found which have a different call, and might represent another undescribed species (E. Scott, unpublished data).
We follow Scott (in press) in considering Cacosternum parvum as a species distinct from C. nanum.

The taxonomic status of this species in relation to Phrynobatrachus parvulus and P. ukingensis requires clarification (Poynton and Broadley 1985b). It is likely to represent more than one species based on molecular evidence (S. Loader pers. comm. Nov 2012). Zimkus et al. (2010) noted that nominal Phrynobatrachus mababiensis covers two distantly related species.
This form almost certainly consists of a number of cryptic species (Rödel 2000).
This species is part of a complex of poorly understood species closely related to Xenopus laevis.
We treat this as a species distinct from Ptychadena pumilio, following Poynton and Broadley (1985).

Tomopterna kachowskii and T. elegans have been removed from synonymy with this species (Zimkus and Larson 2011). This species still requires taxonomic research to understand its full distribution and status, particularly subpopulations in Zaire (Zimkus and Larson 2011).

This species is a tetraploid species species that is very similar to, and easily confused with, Tomopterna cryptotis, T. delalandii and T. damarensis (Channing and Bogart 1996; Dawood and Channing 2002).

The biological identities of some of the Peruvian subpopulations need to be clarified (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. February 2014). Until such time, all subpopulations currently allocated to Telmatobius timens are encompassed in this assessment.

This variety was distinguished by Adams (1994) from the common form in Mexico and recognized by Farjon (2005) in his Monograph of Cupressaceae and Sciadopitys. It is now treated as a good species (Farjon 2010).

Western populations have been proposed to constitute a distinct species, Coluber mormon (Fitch et al. 1981), but this distinction has been demonstrated to be invalid (Corn and Bury 1986; see also Greene 1984).

Wüster et al. (2001) described a new species of Drymarchon from northwestern Venezuela, bringing the species total for the genus to four (five if couperi is recognized as a species). This taxonomic rearrangement treats D. corais and D. melanurus as distinct species. The species in the United States, Mexico, Central America, and South America west of the Andes and in Venezuela is D. melanurus. D. corais occurs in South America east of the Andes (Wüster et al. 2001).  Wüster et al. (2001) also recognized D. couperi and D. margaritae, previously considered subspecies, as full species but without examining specimens, based on previously published (but unspecified) morphological differences and application of the evolutionary species concept. Subsequent checklists (e.g. Crother et al. 2003, Collins and Taggart 2002) have adopted this taxonomy.
McCranie (2011) agreed with these taxonomic changes, but noted that these actions were taken on the basis of limited sampling and emphasized the need for further study to clarify the taxonomy of this group. The resulting concept of D. melanurus is likely to be a species complex; McCranie (2011) suggested that two species-level taxa may be included under the name D. melanurus in Honduras alone.
The subspecies victa of peninsular Florida is treated as a species by some authors.
The molecular and morphological distinction from H. ruber has recently been described (Monadjem et al. 2013).
Hyla arborea is the central member of the Hyla arborea complex, which includes several species of European and Asiatic tree frogs.

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

Based on mtDNA evidence, A. cingulatum (sensu stricto) inhabiting the eastern Gulf Coastal Plain and the Atlantic Coastal Plain in northern Florida are distinct lineages; the Suwannee River and a large distributional gap separate them (Pauly et al. 2007). Further data are needed to determine whether these two lineages warrant recognition as different species (Pauly et al. 2007).

This genus originally contained two species, one from the Canary Islands, the other from Madeira. These taxa were characterised by large orthostyle shells. Further research on the Canarian taxa L. cuticula, has shown this to be a member of the family Vitrinidae (Alonso et al. 2000, Bank et al. 2002). Hence, Lampadia is now a monotypic genus, with one species restricted to Porto Santo (Seddon 2008).

Seddon (2008) noted that this species is apparently allied to Caseolus calva rather than to Lemniscia michaudi. Bank et al. (2002) placed the species in the genus Caseolus, but did not give any grounds for this revision. Wollaston (1878) and Pilsbry (1893-1895) also commented on the lack of similarity to the type species from Porto Santo, so on the basis of shell characters to other Caseolus species, the view of Bank et al. (2002) is used.

Six subspecies have been described (Ansell 1972; summarized in Cassinello 1998). However, the morphological differences between them are not well defined, and there are several apparent zones of hybridization, evidence of an urgent need for the reassessment of subspecies (Cassinello 1998).
There is uncertainty about the taxonomic status of a number of Namaqualand populations which may or may not belong to this species (Henning et al. 2009).

Seddon (2008) reported that Wollaston (1878) and Walden (1983) noted that var. subdubia is apparently intermediate between L. wollastoni and L. nivosa; both authors nonetheless treated wollastoni as a distinct species. The intermediate is only found on a very small area on Pico do Concelho, whereas in most parts of their ranges the two species are clearly and distinctly separable. The subfossil shells from the Quaternary deposits below Pico do Concelho are larger than the living shells.

Two different subspecies are recognised by some authors: Leptaxis wollastoni forensis (Wollaston, 1878).
Mandahl-Barth(1950) treated  the population of this islet (Islet of Ilheu de Fora off its eastern coast) as a distinct subspecies.
No subspecies are recognized (Hall 1981, Hoffmann and Smith 2005).

There are currently two recognized subspecies, Lepus callotis callotis and L. c. gaillardi (Anderson and Gaunt 1962, Hall 1981, Hoffmann and Smith 2005, Brown et al. 2018), evidence is accruing that these may represent independent species due to differences in habitat, physiology and behavior dividing the two forms, which are separated geographically. DNA analysis also suggests a possible third subspecies, the Altimira Jackrabbit (L. c. altimarae), presently described as L. californicus altimirae (Brown et al. 2016).

No subspecies are recognized (Hall 1981, Hoffmann and Smith 2005). Lepus insularis has been recognized as a close relative to L. californicus found on mainland Baja, significant differences have been noted between the two to support its classification as a distinct species (Dixon et al. 1983). However, recent delineation of nuclear and mitochondrial differences, and the relatively small differences in the structure of a single bone in the skull (jugal) between L. insularis and L. californicus, do not support the specific level of L. insularis, thus this form may be considered a subspecies of L. californicus (Álvarez-Castañeda and Lorenzo 2017).
This species is comprised of two very distinct subspecies, L.v. verreauxii from the coast and ranges and L.v. alpina from the southern Alps.

Preliminary genetic evidence suggests that there may be at least two species of African Elephant, namely the Savannah Elephant (Loxodonta africana) and the Forest Elephant (Loxodonta cyclotis) (Roca et al. 2001, 2005). A third species, the West African Elephant, has also been postulated. The IUCN SSC African Elephant Specialist Group currently accepts the single species proposal and has indicated that more extensive research is required before any decision is made to support any proposed re-classification of the African Elephant. Additionally, there is concern that premature allocation of more than one species may leave hybrid individuals in an uncertain conservation status (IUCN SSC African Elephant Specialist Group 2003). As only the Savannah Elephant occurs in southern Africa, the change in taxonomy will not affect any of the southern African populations.

Belongs to the silenus species group. This taxon was formerly known as Macaca maurus. This species hybridizes with M. tonkeana in areas where their ranges overlap at the base of the Toraja Highlands (Tempe depression).

Sheviak and Bowles (1986) described Platanthera praeclara by dividing Platanthera leucophaea into two separate morphological species differing significantly in pollination mechanisms and in geographic distribution.  The original name P. leucophaea was retained for the species occupying the upper Mississippi River drainage and the Great Lakes region in an area corresponding to the prairie peninsula.  The species inhabiting the prairies of the Missouri River drainage (west of Mississippi River) - the center of the tallgrass prairie formation - was named P. praeclara.

According to Modi (1986), karyotypic analysis indicates that M. breweri should be synonymized with M. pennsylvanicus; morphological differences between the two are attributable to island effects in breweri. Microtus breweri and M. pennsylvanicus are marginally distinct electrophoretically. Moyer et al. (1988) presented cranial and dental evidence supporting recognition of M. breweri as a species distinct from M. pennsylvanicus. Jones et al. (1992), Baker et al. (2003), and Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005) recognize M. breweri as a distinct species.
This species was described by Cumberlidge (1999), and additional localities and ecological notes were provided by Cumberlidge and Huguet (2003).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Microtus bavaricus is part of Microtus multiplex species-complex. Its formerly continuous range in the Alps was split into three parts during the last glaciation which led to the evolution of three species: Microtus liechtensteini (south of the Alps east of the river Adige and Balkan mountains), Microtus multiplex (south of the Alps west of the river Adige), and M. bavaricus (north of the Alps in a small refuge in Bavaria and Northern Tyrol) (Haring et al. 2000, Spitzenberger et al. 2000, Spitzenberger 2002, Musser and Carleton 2005, Martinkova et al. 2007).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species was described by Cumberlidge (1993) with additional localities and ecological notes provided by Cumberlidge (1997, 1998, 1999).

In the Bokermannohyla alvarengai group. Bokermannohyla itapoty differs from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters, colour patterns and advertisement call features (Lugli and Haddad, 2006).

The genus Mucubatrachus was recently proposed by La Marca (2007). Hedges et al. (2008), however, placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis culatensis can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (La Marca, 2007).
In the genus Rhinella following Frost (2007). Rhinella veredas can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Brandão et al., 2007)
We follow Jdeidi et al. (2001a,b), Plötner and Ohst (2001) and Plötner et al. (2001) in treating this as a species distinct from Pelophylax bedriagae.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now described as P. fouquettei; Lemmon et al. 2008).
We follow Matsui et al. (2005) in separating this species from Microhyla ornata.

authority: (Fei, Ye & Huang in Fei, Ye, Huang & Chen, 1999)

taxonomicNotes: We follow Litvinchuk et al. (2005) in separating this species from Ommatotriton vittatus.
Veith et al. (2003) treated Rana holtzi as conspecific with R. macrocnemis. However, we follow Çevik et al. (2006) and Baran et al. (2007) in considering Rana holtzi to be a valid species.

Taricha sierra was formerly recognized as a subspecies of Taricha torosa.

Phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA data (Tan and Wake 1995) revealed the following clusters in T. torosa: (1) northern Sierra Nevada (Shasta to Nevada counties); (2) central Sierra Nevada (El Dorado to Fresno counties); (3) southern Sierra Nevada (Tulare to Kern counties) (independently derived relative to 1 and 2, above); (4) southern coastal California (San Diego and Orange counties); (5) central coastal California (Los Angeles to central and northern California). This study and additional allozyme data (Kuchta and Tan 2006) provided the basis for a phylogeographical history of T. torosa. Among other things, the data are consistent in indicating that populations in the southern Sierra Nevada are more closely related to T. torosa torosa than to T. t. sierra.

In the interests of taxonomic stability, Kuchta and Tan (2006) refrained from advocating changes in the taxonomic status of Taricha torosa torosa and Taricha torosa sierra, pending completion and publication of ongoing studies.

Kuchta (2007) examined genetic and morphological variation in Taricha torosa and concluded that T. torosa and T. sierra are distinct evolutionary lineages that should be recognized as distinct species.

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis rhigophilus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca, 2007).

The genus Mucubatrachus was recently proposed by La Marca (2007). Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis flabellidiscus can be distinguished from other similar species by very expanded discs and a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca, 2007).

authority: (De la Riva, Reichle & Cortéz in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: Psychrophrynella iani is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
Ischnocnema penaxavantinho is diagnosed on the basis of adult morphology, advertisement call, and ecology (Giaretta et al., 2007).
Phyllomedusa araguari differs from other similar species in colour pattern, size, advertisement call and breeding site (Giaretta et al., 2007).
Hydrolaetare caparu can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and advertisement call features (Jansen et al., 2007).

The species named Fejervarya nicobariensis in the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists of Threatened Species was in fact Hylarana nicobariensis. The true Fejervarya nicobariensis was inadvertently omitted from the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists. The validity of the species was affirmed by Dubois and Ohler (2000).

In the Rhinella marina group. Rhinella cerradensis can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (adult and tadpole), colour patterns and advertisement call features (Maciel et al., 2007).

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

There are taxonomic concerns regarding this species (Bidau pers. comm.). See Wilson and Reeder (2005) for a full synopsis. This species is monotypic. There is some incongruence between C. dorbignyi, C. perrensis, and C. roigi, because of the high instances of hybridization among populations as well as species (de Freitas 2016).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is monotypic (Patton 2015)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":15037,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica","16":10}">This species is monotypic (Patton 2015).
Included in Ctenomys mendocinus by Cabrera (1961). This species forms a paraphyletic group with C. talarum (Parada et al. 2011).
Originally described as a subspecies of Plecotus austriacus, but clearly distinct; see Mayer and von Helversen (2001) for genetics and Tvrtkovic et al. (2005) for morphology.

Formerly included in Myotis mystacinus. Myotis nipalensis possibly represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species (K. Tsytsulina pers. comm. 2008).

The taxonomy and nomenclature of this taxon is unclear. Miniopterus macrocneme has variously been considered as a subspecies of M. pusillus. Hill (1983) suggests all Papua New Guinea records of M. medius should be M. (pusillus) macrocneme. Thus there is much confusion over existing records (T. Reardon pers. comm.). Populations of Miniopterus in Sulawesi and the Kei Islands represent M. pusillus, not M. macrocneme.

Although Humans express a staggering diversity of skin colour and morphological attributes, gene flow is steady enough to prevent speciation. Kurzweil (2005) estimates that the “singularity”, the hypothesis that the rate of technological advancement will lead to runaway artificial intelligence exceeding Human intellectual capacity and control, will occur around the year 2045.
This species is monotypic (Bidau 2015).

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name Bos primigenius for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of Aurochs under the name Bos primigenius, while the domestic forms of cattle are considered under Bos taurus (see Gentry et al., 2004). Grubb (2005) lists B. primigenius as a subspecies of B. taurus, contrary to most authors, but we do not follow that arrangement here.
This taxon was until recently considered a subspecies of parva, but is included in Hutterer (2005), and hence here as a species. This species is monotypic (Carraway 2014).
This species is monotypic (Ceballos and Arroyo 2014).

Mormopterus planiceps is widely regarded as a species complex. Adams et al. (1988) recognized two species on the basis of allozyme data within M. planiceps, but these were never formally described or named (M. sp. 3 and M. sp. 4 in Adams et al. 1988). An additional species recognized by Adams et al. occurs along easternmost Australia and is also part of the traditional M. planiceps species group (M. sp. 2 in Adams et al. 1988; T. Reardon pers. comm.). Even within these unnamed taxa (i.e., M. sp. 2, M. sp. 3, M. sp. 4) there are likely to be further splits. Most notably M. sp. 4 probably contains two species that reflect its distribution – M. sp. 4 is thought to occur in two disjunct regions (southwestern Australia and southeastern Australia) (N. McKenzie pers. comm.). Maps, and indeed separate common names, for these taxa can be found in Menkhorst (2001).

Does not include Myotis schaubi (Armenia and western Iran) and Myotis bombinus (southeastern Siberia, northeastern China, Korea, Japan). Two subspecies of M. nattereri are recognized: M. nattereri nattereri (N Africa, Europe, SW Asia Minor, Palestine) and M. n. tschuliensis (Caucasus region, Iraq, Turkmenia).

Part of the Iberian population has been described as a new cryptic species named Myotis escalerae (Ibañez et al. 2006), and recent genetic work indicates that true nattereri may not occur on the Iberian Peninsula, and that what occurs there is a third lineage which may have a broad range in southern Europe (12% genetic difference) (J. Juste pers. comm. 2007). However, for the purposes of this assessment escalerae is treated as part of nattereri.
No subspecies are recognized by Grubb (2005), although previous taxonomies recognized various subspecies.
Two subspecies are recognized by Wilson and Reeder (2005): N. g. goral, and N. g. bedfordi.
Generic synonym = Erythronesokia.

Generic synonym = Scotorepens.
Synonyms = N. caprenus; N. aquilo.
Tasmanian populations may represent a separate species (T. Reardon pers. comm.).

No significant morphometric differences have been detected between populations. The wide geographic separation and presumably long isolation of the eastern and western populations means genetic differentiation between these regions is possible, although this has yet to be investigated (Whitaker et al. 2002).

This is a polytypic species with taxonomic problems associated with the subspecies. The currently accepted subspecies are: Orcula austriaca austriaca, O. austriaca faueri Klemm, 1967, O. austriaca goelleri Gittenberger, 1978 and O. austriaca pseudofuchsi Klemm, 1967.
This taxon was originally assessed under the name Hemicycla adansoni for the Red List, however the nomenclature has changed and it is now renamed as Hemicycla pouchet (see: Ibanez and Alonso 2007)
Fauna Europaea (Bank et al. 2006) considered this species to be a synonym of the more widespread species F. wauteri and as such listed it under this name.

Mandahl-Barth (1950) recognised six subspecies including D. pulvinata which Walden (1983) raised to species level. Bank et al. (2002) still recognise 4 subspecies from the islets, D.c.maxima (Ilheu de Ferro), D.c.calcigena (Ilheu de Baixo), D.c.barbozae (Ilheu da Fonte d'Areia).

An anatomically well differentiated undescribed species, which has previously been confounded with C. spadae, has been recognized by A. Hallgass between Monte Catria and Gualdo Tadino in the border region of Marche and Umbria (Hallgass pers. comm. 2011).
M. solidior is difficult to distinguish from other Monacha species based on shell characters only (mainly M. carascaloides) (Hausdorf 2000).
The species was previously described as Bulimus bicallosus.
According to www.animalbase.org, the valid generic affiliation of the species is Helicopsis  rather than Xerolenta. Damjanov & Likharev (1975) do not mention the species.
There is a distinct subspecies, Urticicola isaricus ventouxianus, endemic from Mont Ventoux.
The species was originally described as a variety of Phenacolimax major, and has been elevated to species rank by Boato et al. (1986).
Some authors consider this species must be included in Helicella instead of Xerotricha genus (Gittenberger and Manga 1977).
The species has often been confused with Xerosecta introducta in the past.

C. grovesiana is taxonomically inhomogeneous and seems to represent a group of distinct species or at least a Rassenkreis, which is in urgent need of revision; the well differentiated form C. scissa (Paulucci, 1881), originally described as a variety of C. cavannae (Paulucci, 1881), belongs anatomically to the grovesiana-group (unpublished data of A. Hallgass).
This is a polytypic species with the currently accepted subspecies being: Orcula gularis gularis and O. gularis oreina Pilsbry, 1934.

Cameron et al. (2006) has shown that there appears to be a range in size from the two extremes of form with S. depauperata representing one most common size form and S. latina the smallest extreme. Both Seddon and Cameron’s research on the fossil deposits of Porto Santo do not recognise any fossil material as S. latina, but recognise that at sites, material appears to have a consistent shape and form. Cameron et al. (2006) show that types of the two species are extremes of the range of variability.
Fauna Europaea (Bank et al. 2006) recognizes two subspecies: Jamina quadridens quadridens and J. quadridens elongata.
The species has been described in Lieferung 3/4 of vol. 1 of the Neue Folge of Rossmässler's Iconographie, which appeared on 24 Dec. 1883, and should be cited with that year.

Pintér (1977) created for this species the new Subgenus Szentgalya. This is not accepted by Bank  (2011) in Fauna Europaea (which this assessment is following), but Liberto et al. (2010) elevate Szentgalya to the rank of a full genus.
The species occurs parapatrically with X. obvia and could be conspecific with this species (Pintér 1969). The taxonomic status of the species needs a serious reinvestigation.
The subpopulation on Lampione constitutes perhaps an undescribed conchologically well characterised subspecies.

Gittenberger (1993) indicated that this species probably constitutes a species complex given the wide conchiological variability presented, but currently this is still to be confirmed. Some records for this species from Portugal have to be corrected due to confusion with C. intersecta.

Bank et al. (2002) list the species as Helix (Helicogena) groviana A. Férussac, 1832, on the basis that the name L.  undata (Lowe) is preoccupied by Helix undata (Gmelin, 1791). However, Waldén (1983) noted the assertion by Cockerell (1922) that “Helix groviana Férussac” as a senior synonym of undata is unfounded; in his view the name is a misspelling of H. groyana Férussac 1821 which is a nomen nudum. Given the large number of papers that had used L. undata as the valid name since Cockerell (1922), Seddon (2008) continued to use Leptaxis undata (Lowe).

There are two island subspecies recognised, which Cameron and Cook (1999) treated as full species:
Leptaxis groviana leonina Lowe, 1852 Bugio
Leptaxis groviana vulcania Lowe, 1852 Deserta Grande and Chão

Irikov (2008) wrote: "We consider there is needful investigation of genital anatomy in details and check-up the material of M. oshanovae in the future, wherefore we assume the taxon validity only conventional".

According to Balashov (2017) this species is probably a synonym of H. retowskii, and in addition, he found a population of Helicopsis snails near to the type locality of H. paulhessei that correspond closely to the type description, suggesting that if valid, the species may not be extinct.
The type locality is Mansilla de la Sierra (La Rioja).

This species is usually considered to contain two subspecies: Helix secernenda secernenda Rossmässler 1847 and Helix secernenda schlaeflii Mousson 1858, the latter being recorded from the southern part of its range. The separation on subspecific level ist still under debate, so the assessment considers the species as a whole.
This is a polytypic species with two subspecies: Trochulus clandestinus clandestinus and T. clandestinus putonii Clessin, 1874.

Grossu (1983) mentioned two names as "forms": f. bakowskiana Clessin and f. pulchella Kimakowicz, whereas Helicopsis instabilis jachnoi Clessin as a sub-species. The database of Fauna Europea (www.faunaeur.org) and the book of Damjanov and Likharev (1975) does not mention sub-species or forms of the species.
Prieto (1986) suggested that O. silvae could contain more than one species, with the subpopulations of the east part of its range belong to another different species.
The validity of Xerocrassa prietoi muroensis Graack 2005 needs further research.

Fauna Europaea and AnimalBase treat this as a distinct species. Ehrmann (1956), however, treats it as a synonym of Trochulus hispidus. Germain (1930) treated it in the same way, if the name "choanomphala Locard" is a mistyping and refers to the taxon. According to Prockow (2009), it is a synonym of Trochulus caelatus (Studer, 1820). Until recently T. coelomphala was confounded with large forms of T. hispidus; the taxon is in need of a critical revision.
It is possible that the specimens from Nigeria are a different species (R. Hutterer pers. comm.).

It was described as a subspecies of Xerocrassa murcica (currently X. subrogata). It is accepted as a valid species by some authors but only as a subspecies of Xerocrassa murcica by others. The taxonomy needs to be clarified.

According to Fauna Europaea the species is comprised of the following subspecies: Chilostoma pouzolzi pouzolzi (Deshayes, 1830), C. pouzolzi bosniensis Kobelt, 1871 and C. pouzolzi montenegrina Rossmassler, 1836. In Subai's view (in prep.) this species should be classified to the genus Dinarica.

Bank et al. (2002) retain three taxa, Steenbergia pauperculum, S. desertae, and S. duplex following the belief that the conchological forms identified are distinct species. In contrast, Cook and Lace (1993) suggest that the variability in conchological forms relates to incomplete speciation. There have been further investigations into the anatomical and genetic variability of these taxa on Porto Santo. Lace (1992) showed that there are euphallic (fully hermaphrodite) populations and hemiphallic (lacking male distal genitalia) populations. Neither Cook nor Lace followed Mandahl- Barth (1950) in considering Steenbergia duplex and Steenbergia desertae as distinct species, instead placing the shell forms as a single species (Cameron et al. 1999). Further research by Craze and Lace (2000) show that there are distinct associations with habitats, they suggest that the toothed and untoothed populations represent sandy and rocky populations as opposed to those from more vegetated sites. There are other conchological differences in the taxa, notably the granular surface sculpture, but it is possible that further work may resolve this taxonomic issue.

P. revelata has been considered by some authors synonym of P. subvirescens (Bellamy 1839). The latter species lives in SE England and Wales, as well as in Britany in France. P. revelata is the name for the Ponentina populations living in South France, Spain, and Portugal, but some research is need to know if all these populations are more than one different species. Populations of Ponentina from Morocco are considered a different species. More research about this genus is needed to know the population size.
This is a species complex potentially comprising at least six species (L. Lavrenchenko pers. comm.).

This genus is known from the Madeiran archipelago, and is one of the genera that Pilsbry (1920) suggests may have been in Madeira since the Tertiary period. Pilsbry comments that the strong parietal callus is a feature seen in snails of arid regions. Schileyko (1998) placed Staurodon as a subgenus in the genus Vertigo, but had no anatomical data to support this case. The retention of the genus Staurodon in subfamily Nesopupinae follows Waldén (1983) and Bank et al. (2002).

Bank et al. (2002) place S. saxicola as the synonym rather than S. seminulum. As page priority goes to S. saxicola, Seddon (2008) used the name S. saxicola.  Cameron in his various papers on Madeira used the name S. saxicola.
Waldén (1983) follows Wollaston (1878) in only recognising one taxa, placing seminulum as a synonym. In National Museum of Wales collections at some sites there are two shell morphologies which merit further investigation and as such the two forms were illustrated by Seddon (2008).

This is a polytypic species. The currently accepted subspecies are: Orcula dolium dolium, O. dolium edita Pilsbry, 1934, O. dolium gracilior Zimmermann, 1932, O. dolium infim Pilsbry, 1934, O. dolium pseudogularis A. J. Wagner, 1912, O. dolium raxae Gittenberger, 1978 and O. dolium brancsikii Clessin, 1887 (Bank et al. 2006).
The specific validity of this taxon is under discussion. In the Italian checklist (Manganelli et al. 1995) it is treated as a synonym of T. pyramidata.
Westerlund (1894) reports Buliminus (Chondrulus) munitus.

Bank et al. (2002) retain three taxa, Steenbergia pauperculum, S. desertae, and S. duplex following the belief that the conchological forms identified are distinct species. In contrast, Cook and Lace (1993) suggest that the variability in conchological forms relates to incomplete speciation. There have been further investigations into the anatomical and genetic variability of these taxa on Porto Santo. Lace (1992) showed that there are euphallic (fully hermaphrodite) populations and hemiphallic (lacking male distal genitalia) populations. Neither Cook nor Lace followed Mandahl- Barth (1950) in considering Steenbergia duplex and Steenbergia desertae as distinct species, instead placing the shell forms as a single species (Cameron et al. 1999). Further research by Craze and Lace (2000) show that there are distinct associations with habitats, they suggest that the toothed and untoothed populations represent sandy and rocky populations as opposed to those from more vegetated sites. There are other conchological differences in the taxa, notably the granular surface sculpture, but it is possible that further work may resolve this taxonomic issue.
This species is under taxonomic investigation, and particularly the identification of records of this species from eastern Europe have to be corroborated.

Four subspecies are considered within X. frater: X. frater frater (Dohrn & Heynemann, 1862), X. frater pollenzensis (Hidalgo, 1878), X.frater pulaensis Beckmann 2007, and X. frater newka (Dohrn & Heynemann 1862), with the last two taxa having a very reduced area of occupancy.
A taxonomic review of the genus Trochulus spp. is underway by Gerhard Falkner and Ted von Proschwitz.

It is difficult to distinguish this species from M. crenophila, and from the species of the group M. (Paratheba) hemitricha. Furthermore, there are no constant conchological differences between M. ovularis and M. (Paratheba) ascania  and M. (P.) bithynica and M. (Metatheba) stipulifera (Hausdorf 2000).

C.camporroblensis has been cited in Catalonia (Province Tarragona) by Altmira (1959) and Bech (1990), and in Andalusia by Alonso (1975). These records are now thought to be erroneous, and this species is not present in these areas of the Iberian peninsula.

Schütt (2001: 108) allocates this species in the genus Ljudmilena followed by Kebapci (2007). However, this allocation has been hypothetical and needs corroboration by either anatomical or DNA-based research.

A. Hallgass (pers. com. 2011)has recently detected Helix pantanellii De Stefani, 1879 at its type locality Monte Fionchi (less than 20 km distant from the Monti Reatini) and found it similar to Monacha ruffoi in anatomical characters, but different in color and form of aperture. This opens the possibility that M. ruffoi might be a local summit form of M. pantanellii.

This is one of the least studied European Xerocrassa species. As it is often confused with conchologically similar species, the available literature is almost impossible to interpret. A completely new approach is needed to clearly define this species and clarify its correct distribution area.

Prieto (1986) and Puente (1994) considered this a synonym of Helicella itala (Linnaeus 1758). Nevertheless, Gittenberger and Carr (2002) after the finding of a second population consider that H. valdeona is a valid species, differring from H. itala by conchological and anatomical characters.
In Turkey there are also Buliminus komarowi O. Boettger, 1880 and Buliminus scapus L. Pfeiffer, 1853.
A taxonomic review of the genus Trochulus spp. is underway by Gerhard Falkner and Ted von Proschwitz.

Seddon (2008) noted that these animals were originally listed as Vitrina when they were described by Lowe and Gould, Waldén (1983) placed the species as Phenacolimax Stabile, 1864, but the main revision by Groh and Hemmen (1986) established the new subgenus Madeirovitrina for the Madeiran species. Work by Alonso et al. (2000) established the genus Plutonia for all the species of Vitrinidae in the Atlantic islands, including subgenera: Guerrina, Madeirovitrina, Insulivitrina and Canarivitrina. In contrast Schileyko (2003) elevated Guerrina and Madeirovitrina to full genera leaving only Canarivitrina in Plutonia. This treatment follows Alonso et al. (2000). Mordan and Martins (2001) reviewed the species from Azores and noted that all the Atlantic island species could be considered a monophyletic group based on the position of the penial retractor muscle.

This species has been placed in various genera: Groh and Hemmen (1986) tentatively allocated this species to the genus Eucobresia rather than with the other Madeirovitrina species. Seddon (2008) and Bank et al. (2002) placed with other Madeirovitrina species, which are now placed in the genus Plutonia.

Gittenberger (2004) treated Arianta xatartii as a subspecies of Arianta arbustorum. But Bank et al. (2006) still consider it as a valid species. Gittenberger first (2001) considered it as a species, later as a subspecies (2004), but after having re-analyzed the data he now (2007) again considers it a species (personal communication to Ruud Bank, not published). The main reasoning is because of the the geological history.

The species has two subspecies, the nominate subspecies is distributed in Albania and in Greece, whereas the subspecies Orcula wagneri ljubotinensis Sturany 1914 is found in the Shar Planina region (Ljubotin) in the boarder region of Macedonia (FYROM) and Kosovo.

Bank et al. (2002) list the species as Helix innominata Gray, 1825, Ann. Phil., 15 [= NS., 9] (6): 412, on the basis that this name has priority over Caseolus compactus (Lowe, 1831). Gray refers to G. B. Sowerby I, 1824, Zool. J., 1 (1): 58, pl. 3 fig. 8 "Another minute species which we have represented at f. 8 is common at Porto Santo". Seddon (2008) invoked articles 23.9.1.1 and 23.1.9.2 of ICZN to preserve the established usage of Caseolus compactus (Lowe, 1831) since 1848, suggesting that all papers citing Caselous compactus and its subspecies use this name, and none have used Helix innominata.

Mandahl-Barth (1943) listed three subspecies whereas Walden (1983) list five, with additional taxa from Porto Santo. Cameron et al.
