(2006) showed some are conspecific within the subfossil deposits on Porto Santo. Further research may show that the geographically separate subspecies should be treated as a separate species.
Gittenberger (1978) separated Orcula spoliata and O. austriaca as two distinct species.
This species has been described in 1830 from a loess deposit in Baden-Württemberg, Germany. There is no reliable actual record for this species in Baden-Württemberg.
There is one distinct subspecies: Urticicola glabellus telonensis, endemic from the countryside of Toulon.
Manganelli et al. (1995) mentioned the species with an uncertain taxonomic value.

Schileyko (2005) noted that the generic name Heterostoma was preoccupied by a Trematode name, and hence replaced the generic name with Mandahl-Barth’s Steenbergia for the other two taxa that are currently regarded as conspecific.

Bank et al. (2002) retain three taxa, Steenbergia pauperculum, S. desertae, and S. duplex following the belief that the conchological forms identified are distinct species. In contrast, Cook and Lace (1993) suggest that the variability in conchological forms relates to incomplete speciation. There have been further investigations into the anatomical and genetic variability of these taxa on Porto Santo. Lace (1992) showed that there are euphallic (fully hermaphrodite) populations and hemiphallic (lacking male distal genitalia) populations. Neither Cook nor Lace followed Mandahl- Barth (1950) in considering Steenbergia duplex and Steenbergia desertae as distinct species, instead placing the shell forms as a single species (Cameron et al. 1999). Further research by Craze and Lace (2000) show that there are distinct associations with habitats, they suggest that the toothed and untoothed populations represent sandy and rocky populations as opposed to those from more vegetated sites. There are other conchological differences in the taxa, notably the granular surface sculpture, but it is possible that further work may resolve this taxonomic issue.
This species has three recognised subspecies: Petasina leucozona leucozona, P. leucozona heteromorpha, and P. leucozona ovirensis.

This species was considered as a synonym of M. gregaria by Giusti (1973). In the Italian checklist (Manganelli et al. 1995), the species is again recognised as valid, but with the remark that it needs urgently a systematic study.
This species was classified as a synonym of T. hispidus by Proćków (2009: 128). Bank (2013) maintains the species within Trochulus.
Type locality: "Tout le Portugal".

According to Fauna Europaea, there are two distinct subspecies: Semifructicicola costulata costulata and S. costulata serbica A.J. Wagner, 1914, which is in contrast to AnimalBase. Dhora and Welter-Schultes (1996) note that its systematic position is unclear.

There are three subspecies: Helicopsis striata austriaca, H. s. hungarica and H. s. striata.

Helix muehlfeldtiana Rossmässler, 1837 is considered a junior synonym of Helicopsis striata (O. F. Müller, 1774). Records for this taxon from Balkan countries refer to H. striata or other species (A. and P. Reischütz, pers. comm., 2011; Neubert 2011, pers. comm., 2011).
Prior to 1966, this species was not recognised as distinct from C. aspera, thus early records cannot be attributed to either species.
The species resembles Helix figulina, according to www.animalbase.org it is more globulous than Helix figulina, the aperture is more circular, and the margin more reflected.
This species is often confused with other Vitrinidae species.

This widespread species has been investigated by Proschwitz et al. (2009) revealing that there is another species often confounded with P. muscorum, which proved to be a separate species (Pupilla pratensis (Clessin, 1871)).
This species has been revalidated by Falkner et al. (2002). Its taxonomic validity needs to be fully investigated, especially at the molecular level.

As Helix metabola is based on juvenile specimens which belong to Theba pisana (as already remarked by Kobelt), the appropriate name for the endemic Cernuella of Lampedusa is C. lampedusae (Kobelt, 1890). The taxonomic position and specific validity are questioned (Cianfanelli 2002). In the Italian checklist this species is not mentioned, not even as a synonym.
Wollaston (1878) described two varieties; one variety lentiginosa and var. stellaris and  Bank et al. (2002) retain both subspecies in their Madeiran list.

Walden (1983) recognized a varietal name used by Wollaston, Caseolus commixtus var. pusilla, as meriting specific status, giving it the name baixoensis. Seddon (2008) reports difficulty separating Caseolus baixoensis Walden, 1983 and Caseolus compactus vigiae Walden, 1983, and in the absence of type material of the latter considered that these may be conspecific.

The taxonomic history of the genus Ponentina is very complex. Some authors consider there are more than one species, mainly Ponentina subvirescens (Bellamy, 1839) and Ponentina ponentina (Morelet, 1845), while others believe there is only one valid species (Ponentina subvirescens) (authors summarized in Puente 1994, Arrebola 1995, Arrébola and García 1999). According to Arrébola (1995),  the discrepancies between the specimens described in the literature as P. subvirescens, P. ponentina or synonyms, especially at the level of the anatomy of the reproductive system, suggest that more than one species exist, as future more specific studies might demonstrate. Particularly, the study of one of the traditionally considered synonyms concludes with the specific validity of Ponentina martigena (Férussac, 1832), considered as Trichia (=Trochulus) martigena by Arrébola and García (1999).
The species has often been confused with Xerosecta cespitum (Draparnaud, 1801) and was considered as a synonym of this species by some authors.

Nomenclatural comments: Bank et al. (2002) recognised that Helix nivosa var. planata (Lowe, 1855) is preoccupied by Helix planata Maton & Rackett, 1807, and hence gave it a new name.

Mandahl-Barth (1950) recognised three subspecies from different islands. As these forms are distinct as well as geographically isolated all three are discussed here:
Leptaxis nivosa nivosa (Sowerby, 1824)
Leptaxis nivosa calensis (Bank et al., 2002)
Leptaxis nivosa craticulata (Lowe, 1852)
Several subspecies have been described (Kokshoorn and Gittenberger 2010).

Arianta chamaeleon is a polytypic species. However, the taxonomic status of these subspecies is problematic. The currently accepted subspecies are: Arianta chamaeleon chamaeleon (L. Pfeiffer, 1868), A. chamaeleon carnica (Ehrmann, 1910), A. chamaeleon wiedemayri (Kobelt, 1903), A. chamaeleon subglobosa (Ehrmann, 1910) and A. chamaeleon tullina (Ehrmann, 1910).
The species was previously described as Helicella macedonica.

Candidula claudia (Sacchi, 1954) is a synonym to this species. The form C. scissa (Paulucci, 1881), originally described as a variety of C. cavannae, is considered to belong to the form group of C. grovesiana.
Sacchi has described C. claudia from Capri and the peninsula Sorrent, but this species is anatomically and conchologically identical with C. cavannae, and thus has to be regarded as a younger synonym.

Soós (1943) believes that Helicopsis talmacensis is not synonymous to this species, but that it is a subspecies of H. instabilis. In this assessment however, H. talmacensis records are also considered.
This name was considered incertae sedis by Puente (1994).

This species is also known under the name Chondrus zebrula (Férussac 1821). The subspecies Ch. zebrula tantalus (L. Pfeiffer 1846) has wider geographic range in Turkey, and according to Damjanov & Likharev (1975) it lives in Bulgaria. The third subspecies, Ch. zebrula spoliatus (L. Pfeiffer 1846) lives in Greece, and in Izmir, Turkey (Schütt 2001).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands have been treated by Valido et al. (1999).

In the south-eastern Balkans (particularly Bulgaria and Greece), this species may be confused with other, conchologically very similar species. Records from these areas need corroboration by anatomical studies.

This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Darevskia, following Arribas (1998, 1999), Fu et al. (1997), Fu (1998) and Harris et al. (1998). It is not certain that the eastern and western populations belong to the same species; further taxonomic studies are needed to resolve this issue. Subspecies D. p. praticola inhabits the northeastern part along the Caspian Sea. D. p. pontica (Lantz and Cyren, 1919) inhabits the coast of the Black Sea and north-western Caucasus.

Six genetically and geographically distinct lineages have been identified in Natrix tessellata, and some or all of these may warrant specific recognition following further research (Guiking et al. 2004).
Eastern populations of Malpolon formerly allocated to M. monspessulanus are now included within M. insignatus following Carranza et al. (2006).

This species is included in Platyceps following Nagy et al. (2004).

Animals from Israel and Jordan are Platyceps collaris, not P. najadum. Five distinct subspecies are generally recognized, P. n. dahlii Schinz, 1832 inhabits the Balkans, Cyprus, western Turkey, Syria and Iraq; P. n. kalymnensis Schneider, 1979 is present on the island of Kalimnos in the Aegean Sea; the nominative subspecies, P. n. najadum is found in the Caucasus and in Asia Minor; P. n. albitemporalis Darevsky and Orlov, 1994 has been recorded from south-eastern Azerbaijan; populations from southern Turkmenistan (western and central Kopet Dagh) and northern Iran are allocated to P. n. atayevi Tuniev and Shammakov, 1993.

A phylogeographic study of this species based on mtDNA (Kalyabina et al. 2001) identified three groups of populations. Further studies of contact areas are needed to evaluate the taxonomic status of these three lineages (Crochet and Dubois 2004).

Ten subspecies are recognized:
The nominate subspecies, L. a. agilis is distributed in Western Europe and western Central Europe;
L. a. argus Laurenti, 1758 inhabits Central Europe, east to the Carpathian Mountains and to eastern Poland;
L. a. chersonensis Andrzejowski, 1832 - Moldavia, right-bank Ukraine, Belarus, the Baltic States, Leningrad region and south of the neighbouring Karelia. In the east, approximately from the left-bank valley of the river Dnieper a narrow area of intergradation with the neighbouring eastern subspecies is noted;
L. a. bosnica Schreiber, 1912 occurs in the mountains of Croatia, Macedonia, Bulgaria and Greece;
L. a. exigua Eichwald, 1831 occupies the whole eastern part of the distribution range up to the Crimean Peninsula and Ciscaucasia in the south;
L. a. grusinica Peters, 1960 inhabits the coast of the Black Sea and submountane regions of the Caucasus in the south-west of the Krasnodar Territory, Abkhazia, in the Colchic lowland and Ajaria;
L. a. brevicaudata Peters, 1958 occurs in northern and western Armenia, southern Georgia and on the southern slopes of the Great Caucasus range within the North Ossetia;
L. a. iorensis Peters and Muskhelishwili, 1968 occurs on the southern slopes of the Caucasus range: in the valley and ravine of the upper current of the river Iori in Georgia;
L. a. boemica Suchow, 1929 inhabits submontane regions of North Ossetia, Ingushetia, Chechnya, Dagestan and Stavropol Region;
L. a. tauridica Suchow, 1926 inhabits the southern mountains of Crimea.

Although the generic epithet Podarcis is masculine (Böhme 1997, Böhme 1998), tiliguerta is a noun (meaning "lizard" in the local Sardinian language) and therefore it is not conjugated. This taxon possibly consists of at least two separate species, one on Sardinia and one on Corsica (C. Corti pers. comm.).

There is near unanimity of opinion that Ovis ammon is the appropriate Latin binomial for all Argalis. Prior to 1998, some authorities considered the Severtzov Sheep of Uzbekistan to be Urial, but following Bunch et al. (1998), it has generally been included as an Argali. One exception is Mitchell and Frisina (2007), who follow some earlier taxonomists in recognizing a separate species O. polii, under which they put a few additional subspecies (see below on subspecific taxonomy).

Argali live over a vast geographic range, but are separated into more-or-less disjunct populations, some of which are morphologically identifiable. How much (if any) of the taxon’s disjunct distribution is natural and how much the result of anthropogenic influence remains open to date. Similarly, how (and even whether) various populations should be classified subspecifically remains contentious. Wilson and Reeder (2005) and Fedosenko and Blank (2005) recognize nine subspecies: O. a. ammon, O. a. collium, O. a. comosa (= jubata), O. a. darwini, O. a. hodgsoni, O. a. karelini, O. a. nigrimontana, O. a. polii, and O. a. severtzovi. Geist (1991) recognized all of these except collium and severtzovi (which at the time was still considered a urial); he also considered that jubata had precedence over comosa. Shackleton and Lovari (1997) followed Geist’s (1991) classification except for adding collium as a valid subspecies. Within China, some authors have recognized additional subspecies. Wang (2002) recognized O. a. littledalei, adametzi, and sairensis (all within the range occupied by karelini or collium by the above authorities), and dalailamae (within the range occupied by hodgsoni, above) in addition to ammon and darwini (but did not recognize O. a. jubata). Yu (2001) recognized dalailamae as distinct from hodgsoni, but did not recognize the subdivisions within karelini or collium (and also did not recognize jubata). Mitchell and Frisina (2007) recognized ammon, darwini, jubata, dalailamae, and hodgsoni (as well as karelini, nigrimontana, and severtzovi under O. polii). Tserenbataa et al. (2004), based on mtDNA analysis, questioned the validity of separating O. a. ammon and darwini within Mongolian populations. There is uncertainty regarding the subspecific status of Argali in Gansu and adjacent Inner Mongolia; there are also differing opinions regarding the morphometric and/or geographic separation between polii and karelini. It may well be that future genetic work, similarly to Tserenbataa et al. (2004) and Wu et al. (2003) will suggest that clinal, rather than threshold variation characterizes many argali populations. Clearly, more research is required to clarify the taxonomy of the species.

Because subspecific taxonomy remains unresolved, most subspecies that are recognized cross international borders, and the species occurs in many countries with differing management regimes, this account treats Ovis ammon by country (and, where appropriate, by population) rather than by subspecies.

Subspecies found in Mongolia: Recent genetic studies (Tserenbataa 2003, Tserenbataa et al. 2004) suggest that all Argali in Mongolia represent a single subspecies. Two subspecies were formerly recognized, Altai Argali O. a. ammon and Gobi Argali or Mongolian Argali O. a. darwini.
The validity of the subspecies Ovis canadensis californiana has recently been questioned (Wehausen and Ramey 2000).

The Domestic Sheep and its wild ancestor the Urial are treated here as separate species (following inter alia Shackleton 1997), called Ovis aries and Ovis orientalis respectively. These taxa are sometimes considered to be conspecific, in which case the name Ovis orientalis has generally been used to refer to the wild species and its domesticated form, although some authors use the name Ovis aries for both the wild species and its domestic descendants (see Gentry et al. 1996, BZN 2003, Gentry et al. 2004 and Wilson and Reeder 2005).

"Wild sheep" and "wild goats" found on Mediterranean islands are generally recognized to have been introduced by humans (Shackleton 1997, Wilson and Reeder 2005), and genetic and archaeozoological studies suggest that they are feral populations of ancient domestic stocks (e.g., Groves 1989, Vigne 1994, Hiendleder et al. 1998, Manceau et al. 1999, Kahila bar-Gal et al. 2002). Consequently, such taxa should be included in the respective domestic species (Capra hircus, Ovis aries) and not as subspecies of the wild taxa (as proposed by Gentry et al. 1996, Gentry et al. 2004, and Gippoliti and Amori 2004).

Grubb (2005) recognized four subspecies: O. n. nivicola, O. n. borealis, O. n. kodarensis, and O. n. koriakorum. However, many Russian authors recognize a different set of subspecies: O. n. nivicola Eschscholtz, 1929 (Kamchatka); O. n. borealis Severtzov, 1873 (Taimyr); O. n. alleni Matsche, 1907 (East Siberia, Yablonovy and Stanovoy Ridges, to Verkhoyansky Ridge in the north); O. n. lydekkeri Kowarzik, 1913 (northeastern Siberia, from Lena River in the west to Stanovoy Ridge in the east, and Verkhoyansky Ridge in the south); and O. n. koriakorum Tschernyavsky, 1962 (Chukchi Peninsula and Koryak District) (K. Tsytsulina pers. comm.). Clearly subspecific taxonomy remains uncertain.
Previously sunk by Marais into K. thomsonii, but based on a number of differences and the geographical separation of the two populations, Whitehouse resurrected this species (see Whitehouse 2002).

The specific epithet refers to plants from the coast of Eritrea, which Reynolds considered to be identical to plants from north of Dar es Salaam. Reynolds thought this latter material was introduced, but further collections suggest the species is native to East African coastal regions, and Carter (1994) suggested that its identity with Eritrean material should be considered with caution. But recent flowering material indicates that this species may well be conspecific with the aloe from Massawana now called (A. eumassawana). It is probable that A. massawana is synonymous with A. kirkii from Zanzibar, but the type material at RBG Kew for the latter is insufficient to confirm this (Carter 1994).
A number of subspecies are recognized, but these are not assessed here.
This species has a different chromosome number (2n=30) to other species in the genus (2n=22) and is thus reproductively isolated.
This species is very similar to G. microcarpus G.J.Lewis found growing in the Drakensberg in South Africa. It may also be confused with the east and northeast Africa G. pauciflorus Baker.

Comprises two subspecies, the typical subspecies is assessed separately here, but subsp. multicaulis S.Carter & L.E.Newton has not been assessed, because like the species it is considered Least Concern.
At least six subspecies have been recognized.
In the Melanophryniscus moreirae group according to the original description (Maneyro et al. 2008).
In the Nearctic the species is replaced by its sister species Aeshna septentrionalis (Burmeister, 1839). By some authors this species is considered to be a subspecies of A. caerulea.
The identification of pale species of Sympetrum is problematic and records predating the revision by Joedicke (1994) can not be trusted.
Several types of females of Ischnura aralensis occur which differ in colour and morphology. This led to much confusion and to the description the synonym Ischnura haritonovi Dumont, 1997.

The nominate subspecies of this butterfly was described from Ethiopia and Sudan. Two additional subspecies are recognized from Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi, the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda (ssp. extendens) and another from western Tanzania (ssp. similis).
This butterfly has the three subspecies J. h. hierta, J. hierta cebrene and J. hierta paris.
A large number of subspecies are described for this extremely widespread butterfly.

Formerly includes anubis, cynocephalus, papio, and ursinus, but see Jolly (1993), Kingdon (1997) and Groves (2001) and others who recognized these as distinct species (Grubb et al. 2003). The Arabian population was formerly recognised with the name arabicus Thomas, 1900. Recent studies demonstarted Arabian hamadryas baboons migrated naturally into Arabian Peninsula via land bridges that formed periodically during glacial maxima at the straits of Bab el Mandab in the southern Red Sea (Winney et al. 2004, Kopp et al. 2014).

This butterfly (known as P. daplidice for the last 250 years) was recently separated into two species: P. daplidice and P. edusa Fabricius, 1777 (Geiger et al. 1988), but the latter is currently considered to be a subspecies of the former (Porter et al. 1997; Honey and Scoble 2001). Nominotypical daplidice occurs throughout northwest Africa, the Iberian peninsula, Corsica, Sardinia and northwest Europe (occurs occasionally in the UK as an infrequent migrant/vagrant). P. daplidice edusa occurs in northwest France, and Italy eastwards, with a hybrid zone in northwest Italy. The taxa were separated by electrophoretic analysis and cannot be separated with any degree of certainty on external morphology.
This species has the two subspecies H. p. perspicua and H. perspicua camerounica.
There are no subspecies described for this butterfly.
Two subspecies are recognised: the nominate subspecies and Capys alphaeus extentus.
This species is recognized as having the two subspecies T. c. cassus and T. cassus outeniqua.

Three subspecies of this species are recognised. These are merope (in Queensland, South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales), duboulayi (in Western Australia) and salazar (in Tasmania) (Herbison-Evans and Crossley 2009).
As many as 27 subspecies have been described for this species.

Two subspecies are noted: Harpendyreus aequatorialis aequatorialis Sharpe, 1892 (Type locality: Kenya: Mount Elgon), and Harpendyreus aequatorialis vulcanica Joicey & Talbot, 1924 (Type locality: Tanzania: Arusha district).
Two putative subspecies have been proposed for this butterfly: Junonia oenone oenone and J. oenone epiclelia.
Some authors treat the population in Northwest European Russia as Artemisia latifolia Ledeb.
Valid taxonomy should be Aconitum napellus L. ssp. corsicum (Gayer) Seitz (Jeanmonod and Gamisans 2007).
Accepted name in Flora Norsk is: Papaver radicatum ssp. laestadianum.

Colchicum corsicum Baker has been split in two taxa: C. corsicum Baker occupying the eastern part of the distribution area, and C. arenasii Fridl. occurring in the western part (Figari is the limit between the two) (Friedlander 1999).

The species was recorded in the past from Sardinia but that is a mistake as those reports refer to C. verlaqueae Fridl.

The species is divided into two subspecies: Dianthus nitidus ssp. nitidus and D. nitidus ssp. lakusicii. The nominate subspecies is an endemic to the Western Carpathians, with its occurrence limited to the territory of Slovakia. Dianthus nitidus ssp. lakusicii is found in Montenegro and Serbia.
In the contact zone of the distribution areas of Pulsatilla slavica and P. subslavica introgressive hybridization takes place and hybrid swarms occur.
Two subspecies considered: Coincya rupestris ssp. leptocarpa (Gonz.-Albo) Leadlay and Coincya rupestris Porta & Rigo ex Rouy ssp. rupestris.

The taxonomy is critical. There are at least two similar and related species in this region.

Until recently other populations from northern Hungary (distributed in the Northern Medium Mountains and Pilis Hills and on an isolated locality near Sopron) were included in the species Thlaspi jankae. Plants from these subpopulations are, however, lower, have smaller organs (petals, silicules, styles and pollen grains) and a smaller number of chromosomes (T. jankae has 28 chromosomes, whereas the north Hungarian populations have 14 chromosomes). In 1978 the north Hungarian subpopulations were described as a separate species, T. hungaricum. Several Hungarian authors continue to designate them T. jankae and they included them in this species during its monitoring for the Natura 2000 network in the territory of Hungary (Mereďa and Hodálová 2011).

In Slovakia the group Pulsatilla grandis is represented by three closely related species: P. grandis, P. slavica and P. subslavica. Pulsatilla grandis is the most thermophilous species and occurs in southern parts of Slovakia, whereas P. slavica is the most cryophilic representative of this triad and is distributed in northern parts of  the country.  The Large-flowered Pasque Flower easily hybridizes with other species of the genus growing on the common localities. In Slovakia there are hybrids with P. patens and P. subslavica.

Fritillaria gussichiae was previously considered as a variety of F. graeca, however some put it closer to F. pontica. It is a well defined species with its flower having a distinctive shape and colour.

The taxon Colchicum fominii is now included in C. arenarium (Persson 2007). Colchicum fominii was described from steppes near the present Moldavian/Ukrainian border. Recent studies of material from this region showed that the species does not differ enough from C. arenarium to count as a separate species but that it could rather be a geographic race (K. Persson pers. comm. 2010).
This species might be identical to a species from Romania, Onosma viridis. There is currently research done on the taxonomy of a number of Balkan species.
In some areas in southern Peloponnese, Ophrys argolica forms hybrids with O. spruneri and in the northern parts hybrids with O. oestrifera.

The taxa in this group have been treated in different ways, recognizing different species such as the classification of the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS 2007). In agreement with this criteria but, in an infraespecific category we find Hanks (2002) or Aedo (2014). Following the previous treatment for the European Assessment we consider all the following taxa: N. triandrus, N. triandrus var. capax (=N. loiseleuri), N. pallidulus, N. pallidulus var. paivae, N. iohannis and N. lusitanicus, under the denomination of Narcissus triandrus. All these taxa are included in Section Ganymedes and are endemic of the Iberian Peninsula, except a little population of N. triandrus var. capax present in the Glennans Islands (Bretagne, France). Alakaloid of Amarillydaceae are exclusive for this family, but all the Section Ganymedes have the unusual sceletium type alkaloids (like mesembrane), typical of Aizoaceae South African plants (Pigni et al. 2013).
There is taxonomic research about this and other endemic species in Austria and Germany. This is a not well studied group with lots of endemics.

It is known as Dianthus praecox ssp. lumnitzeri in Slovakia and also as D. plumarius ssp. lumnitzeri and D. plumarius ssp. regis-stephani. There is some taxonomic disagreement if this is a species or a subspecies. But taxonomic studies are underway at the University of Heidelberg and the Corvinus University in Budapest.
The accepted name in Italy is Galatella sorrentinoi Tod.

There are over 50 synonyms for Galanthus nivalis and this is due to several reasons: it is a variable species and throughout its distribution a number of taxa have been named in an attempt to record this variation; because of its long history in cultivation, a large number of taxa and cultivars have been recognised, leading to an even greater proliferation of names; and before many other species had been described, most Galanthus were referred to or associated with G. nivalis, probably because it was the best known and most ubiquitous species (Davis 1999).
Euphrasia genargentea might not be the accepted name of this species, it could be either Euphrasia nana (Rouy) Prain or Euphrasia minima var. genargentea Feoli (The Plant List 2010).
It is closely related to H. hyrzinum and was often confused with this species.

Where Pulsatilla subslavica occurs with other related species, hybridization takes place: in the southern part of the range with P. grandis, in the northern part with P. slavica. This backcrossing results in transient individuals, even whole populations, which are difficult to identify (Mereďa and Hodálová 2011).
There are two known subspecies: Arnica montana ssp. montana and Arnica montana ssp. atlantica A.Bolòs described in 1948.
Diplotaxis ibicensis (Pau) Gómez-Campo is a wild relative of brassica crops as well as being related to cultivated perennial wall rocket, D. tenuifolia (L.) DC.

Allium grosii Font Quer is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Gentianella anglica is considered one of the few endemic plants of Great Britain. However, the taxonomic status of this species is still uncertain. It is not clear whether G. anglica is a species or whether it is part of the Gentianella amarella aggregate (Wilson 2009). Taxonomic research is currently underway.
This genus is taxonomically critical, but this species is relatively recognisable.
The Portuguese populations are considered as the subspecies Festuca brigantina subsp. brigantina by some (F.B. Caldas pers. comm. 2015).

Lestes umbrina has been treated as a synonym of both L. coccinus and L. nodalis. See Lieftinck (1960) for an account of the confusion that has surrounded this species. Some records of L. umbrina are likely to be misidentifications of L. coccinus or L. nodalis.
Asahina (1986) described a subspecies, C. p. fernandi from Meghalya.

Raffaelli and Villar (1987) revised the taxonomic rearrangement of Polygonum romanum Jacq. to recognise three taxa at the subspecific rank:

Polygonum romanum Jacq. subsp. romanum from Italy, although not generally consideredthere at the subspecies level;
P. romanum Jacq. subsp. gallicum (Raffaelli) Raffaelli & Villar, comb. & stat. nov. from southern France (Languedoc) and mainland Spain, and;
P. romanum Jacq. subsp. balearicum Raffaelli & Villar, subsp. nov., from the Baleares, Spain.

As presently understood this species is monotypic (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). Szczerbak and Golubev (1996) highlight morphological differences which may justify treating the junior synonym Agamura cruralis as warranting at least subspecific status, but note that comparative material is insufficient to confirm this assignment.
This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but it is now placed in the genus Timon (Mayer and Bischoff 1996; Fu 1998, 2000; Harris et al. 1998; Harris and Carretero 2003).
This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Darevskia, following Arribas (1998, 1999), Fu et al. (1997), Fu (1998) and Harris et al. (1998).
The nominate subspecies E. c. collaris is found over most of the species range, the exception being near Tuzluca (eastern Turkey), where E. c. macrospilotus (Werner, 1904) is found.
This taxon has previously been recognised as a subspecies of Phrynocephalus helioscopus.
In Middle Asia the species is represented by the subspecies B. t. melanocephala (Annandale, 1904), which might represent a distinct species (N. Orlov pers. comm. September 2008).

This species is not closely related to Lacerta sensu stricto Harris et al. (1998), and has been placed in a different genus (Muller 2002). This was referred to subgenus Parvilacerta Harris, Arnold & Thomas, 1998. This subgenus includes two species: Parvilacerta fraasii (Lehrs, 1910) and Parvilacerta parva (Boulenger, 1887).
The generic assignment of this taxon is still unclear.
The type specimen for this species was misidentified as T. ruderatus (Rastegar-Pouyani, 2000).

This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Darevskia, following Arribas (1998, 1999), Fu et al. (1997), Fu (1998) and Harris et al. (1998). Three subspecies are described. The nominative subspecies D. v. valentini is distributed in the whole Transcaucasia. D. v. lantzicyreni (Darevsky and Eiselt, 1967) occurs through most of Turkey. D. v. spitzenbergerae (Eiselt, Darevsky and Schmidtler, 1992) is known only from the type locality in vilayet Khakyari in extreme southwestern Turkey.

Galanthus elwesii is often confused with G. gracilis, as both of these species have glaucous leaves and two green marks (or one very large green mark) on each inner perianth segment, and they can occur in similar localities and populations. Galanthus gracilis and G. elwesii are closely related, but they can be easily distinguished from one another by the type of vernation (the position of the leaves when they are in bud), which is applanate (leaves flat against each other) and supervolute (one leaf encircling the other), respectively. Other distinguishing characteristics, which are reliable but not totally discrete for each species, are the width of the leaves and the general dimensions of the plant: G. gracilis usually has narrow leaves and is generally of smaller dimensions than G. elwesii. The leaves of G. gracilis are frequently twisted but they can also be straight. Molecular data (Lledo et al. 2004, Larsen et al. 2010) infers that these two species are distinct.

The confusion between G. elwesii and G. gracilis is especially critical in their European ranges, and at the present time their exact distributions are poorly understood. Molecular studies are currently being undertaken with the aim of addressing these problems and questions concerning species delimitation.
Further systematic work is currently under way on this taxon. It seems possible that it might be a complex of more than one species.

This species is often treated under the synonym Ononis hackelii, for example in the Annexes of the Habitats Directive or in Portugal (ICN 2006). But the accepted name is Ononis maweana Ball. according to ILDIS (2010).
It belongs to the subgenus Oreogeum together with Geum montanum and G. reptans. However, it is relict and endemic species and very distinct in comparison to the other two species of this subgenus.

There is a long standing debate regarding the nomenclature of this particular taxon. Fritillaria montana was named from Italy in 1832 while F. orientalis and F. tenella from the Caucasus in 1805 and 1808 and furthermore, F. degeniana from Serbia in 1906. Attempts were made to differentiate F. montana and F. orientalis in the mid 1930s in the former USSR (Tomović et al. 2007). Differences between F. orientalis and F. montana are given (Tomović et al. 2007).

The accepted name in France (Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle 2003-2010) and in Bosnia and Herzegovina is Fritillaria orientalis Adams.

M.G. Alexeenko (1946) divided Schivereckia podolica into five species: S. podolica (Besser) Andrz. (western Ukraine, Moldova, Romania), S. mutabilis (M. Alexeenko) M. Alexeenko (eastern Ukraine, Middle Russian upland in Russia), S. berteroides Fish ex Alexeenko (Bachkortostan and south Ural), S. monticola M. Alexeenko (central Ural) and S. kuznezovii M.Alexeenko (northern Ural). Modern systematic (Cherepanow et al. 1999) regarded Schivereckia podolica as single species with geographical and ecological variations of characteristics. So far strict diagnostic signs, for differentiation of these geographical races as independent species, are absent.
The taxonomy of this species is questionable and more research is needed.

It belongs to the subgenus Eugeum (Gajewski 1957) and it is closely related to Galium coccineum Sibth. & Sm. Gajewski (1957) considered that G. rhodopaeum is a hybrid between G. coccineum and an unknown Geum species. “According to A. Strid (in litt. Oct 2000) this is presumably a more or less fertile hybrid between G. coccineum  and G. rivale” (Kurtto et al. 2004). In addition, Randjelović and Zlatkovic (2010) report a hybrid between G. rivale and G. rhodopaeum in the Vlasina plateau. Obviously, hybridization between several Geum species in overlapping parts of their ranges is common.
Veronica euxina was described in 1925 from Bulgaria. M.V. Klokov (1975) described Veronica gryniana. Tzvelev (2005) regarded Veronica gryniana as a synonym of Veronica euxina.
The relationship of this species with A. tillyardi Laidlaw, 1919 needs to be rexamined; the latter species may be a junior synonym of A. approximans.
This species is very similar to Planaeschna chiengmaiensis Asahina, 1981 and might eventually prove to be a junior synonym (Karube 1999).
The Puya clade is no longer considered to belong to the Pitcarnioideæ subfamily, but is a sister of the Bromelioideæ (Givnish et al. 2004, Horres et al. 2000, Terry et al. 1997).

According to Janarthanam and Henry (1992) U. purpurascens Graham was validly published on the basis of materials observed in Mahabaleshwar. J. Graham's catalogue in general did not deal with dried specimens in herbariums. In absence of original materials preserved in any of the herbaria, Janarthanam 82941 (MH) collected from the type locality after a lapse of about 150 years is designated as neotype. U. arcuata proved conspecific to U. purpurascens. It is allied to U. albocoerulea differentiated with character of sickle shaped spur of corolla. U. purpurascens Graham is undoubtedly a distinct species and its inclusion under U.graminifolia Vahl by Taylor in 1989 appears to be erroneous.

Although this species is recognized as distinct in Indian literature, it has been included in U. graminifolia by Taylor and appears as such in IPNI and TROPICOS.
The taxonomy of this species is in need of review (L. Heaney pers. comm. 2006).

Brassica nivalis Boiss. & Heldr. is a wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

Two subspecies are native to Europe: B. nivalis ssp. jordanoffii (O.E. Schulz) Akeroyd & Leadlay and B. nivalis Boiss. & Heldr. ssp. nivalis (Euro+Med PlantBase 2006).

This species has been listed as a possible synonym of Phrynocephalus versicolor Strauch, 1876 (Wermuth 1967). Both genetic and morphological evidence supports its recognition as a distinct species (Dunayev 1989, Solovyeva et al. 2014), a scheme that has been widely followed subsequently (Brushko 1995, Tuniyev and Ananjeva 2010, Solovyeva et al. 2014). Solovyeva et al. (2014) found that an undescribed, morphologically distinct taxon from the Dzhungarian Gate was genetically close to P. melanurus.
In a nomenclatural review of Phrynocephalus, Barabanov et al. (2007) referred P. grumgrzimailoi to the synonymy of P. melanurus based on the type locality and lectotype morphology. This work was however not a formal taxonomic review, and the name P. grumgrzimailoi has since been recognized in Chinese literature. This distinction is however "based on unreliable material and should be revised" (A. Barabanov pers. comm. 2018). Pending further taxonomic work, this account follows Barabanov et al. (2007) and the recommendation of A. Barabanov (pers. comm. 2018) in treating P. grumgrzimailoi as a junior synonym of P. melanurus.
The TIGR Reptile Database recognizes P. vlangalii var. lidskii as a good species: P. lidskii Bedriaga, 1909 with P. erythrurus cited in the synonymy.

Wang and Fu (2004) investigated the systematics of the Phyrnocephalus versicolor species complex, which they defined to include P. przewalskii and P. frontalis as well as what were then understood to be eastern populations of P. versicolor (western ones apparently being attributable to P. guttatus). On the basis of molecular evidence, these authors synonymized all three taxa under the name P. przewalskii. The same results, however, revealed two hithero unsuspected, reciprocally monophyletic clades within the complex. Although P. versicolor sensu stricto appears to be a junior synonym of P. przewalskii based on the type locality (the type specimens themselves have not been examined to confirm this), Wang and Fu (2004) argue that the name should be applied instead to the separate northern clade (Clade E of Wang and Fu 2004) following ICZN rules on the conservation of prevailing usage. This arrangement has subsequently been accepted as valid (Babarov and Ananjeva 2007). The southern clade of the former P. versicolor complex is (as of April 2016) undescribed (Wang and Fu 2004).  Terbish et al. (2006), while noting that populations further north are likely attributable to P. guttatus, nevertheless included these records within P. versicolor, thereby extending its range into northern Mongolia, Russia and Siberian Kazakhstan. This account, however, follows Wang and Fu (2004) and Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008) (who assign all Kazakh records to P. guttatus) in restricting this species to China and southwest Mongolia. The population from Tuva in Siberia and the Altai Mountains described as the subspecies P. v. kulagini is likewise attributable to P. guttatus (Wang and Fu 2004). Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007) consider P. hispidus  a subspecies of Phrynocephalus versicolor, a scheme still adopted by the Reptile Database. On genetic grounds Solovyeva et al. (2014) identified a distinct clade within the P. versicolor complex from the Dzungarian Gobi to which they apply the name P. hispidus. This taxon was not formally redescribed and its distribution has yet to be accurately characterized, but is treated here as a separate taxon.
Wagner (1897) has described this as a separate species. Boeckel (1939) recognized as the subspecies of C. tergestinum. Fauna Europaea lists as a separate species.
The taxonomy of the Azores-graylings is still under debate. At this moment only H. miguelensis is considered a separate species.
Lactuca palmensis Bolle is a wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L.

Allium melanantherum Pančić is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium podolicum Racib. & Szafer is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Avena canariensis Baum & al. is a tertiary wild relative of oats, Avena sativa L. and A. byzantina K. Koch. (Maxted et al. in prep.).

Allium pervestitum Klokov is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium macedonicum Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium pruinatum Spreng. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). A bulbiferous variant has been described as A. pruinatum var. bulbiferum Cout. (endemic to Portugal).

Although A. pruinatum is thought to be endemic to Portugal, A. rubrovittatum var. occidentale Rouy ex Willkomm (based on a specimen collected at Algerciras in southern Spain) is regarded by Stearn (1978) and by Pastor Díaz and Valdés (1983) as a synonym of A. pruinatum (Mathew 1996).

Allium melananthum Coincy is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Three subspecies are native to Europe: M. sylvestris subsp. orientalis (Uglitzk.) Browicz, M. sylvestris subsp. praecox (Pall.) Soó and M. sylvestris (L.) Mill. subsp. sylvestris (Kurtto 2009).

Malus sylvestris (L.) Mill. is a primary wild relative of apple, M. domestica Borkh. (GRIN 2010).

The nomenclatural status of the species should be reconsidered (see Brullo et al. 2010) who commented that the characters of this species are well within the bounds of A. permixtum, and proposed to include both A. phthioticum and A. breviradium as synonyms of A. permixtum). For this assessment, the Annotated Checklist of Greek Flora (Dimopoulous et al. 2013) is followed.

WCSP (2018) considers Allium breviradium (Halácsy) Stearn (and Allium neapolitanum var. breviradiatum Halácsy to be synonyms of this species.

Allium integerrimum is a doubtful taxon and may belong to Allium sphaerocephalon subsp. sphaerocephalon (P. Delipetrou and I. Bazos pers. comm. 2015).

Allium integerrimum Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Lactuca perennis L. is a wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L.

Allium stearnii Pastor & Valdés is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Specimens from Ranomafana in the eastern rainforest belt agree with this species genetically, but further work is required to clarify the status of rainforest forms (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011). Research is needed to clarify the extent of differentiation between Madagascarophis meridionalis and M. colubrinus and to establish whether a hybrid zone exists (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011).

Because of notable difference in reproductive biology, oviparous highland subpopulations may represent a distinct, undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007); if this proves to be the case this species will then require reassessment. This is a variable species throughout the south and southwest, exhibiting marked variation in colouration between geographic areas, although this is not currently thought to reflect taxonomic differences (A. Raselimanana pers. comm. May 2011). A red-tailed skink without the striped patterning of M. igneocaudatus, which is sympatric with the nominate form between Kirindy and Morondava, appears to represent a still-undescribed species (A. Raselimanana pers. comm. May 2011).
The Furcifer verrucosus, F. nicosiai, F. oustaleti group is in need of major revision and probably contains as yet undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007).

Molecular data have shown that Trachylepsis gravenhorstii is a complex of undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007). Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).
Taxonomic research is needed to identify whether the populations from Andohahela and Ivohibe represent the same or distinct species (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

This species exhibits inter-population variation that warrants taxonomic investigation (Vences et al. 2002). Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

Calumma hilleniusi has variously been considered either a full species or a subspecies of C. brevicorne (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 2006). The identity of southern subpopulations currently assigned to this species requires verification (Vences et al. 2002).

The taxonomy of this species and its relationships to similar, unassigned specimens from other high- and mid-elevation sites in Madagascar are in need of intensive taxonomic research (Glaw and Vences 2007).

This species resembles, but has long been recognized as distinct from, Calumma brevicorne,  being noted as C. sp. aff. brevicorne when first collected (Brygoo 1978). It was formally described only when Raxworthy and Nussbaum (2006) clarified the taxonomy of this species group.
In the past, this gecko has been treated as a subspecies of Paroedura bastardi, but genetic studies support its recognition as a distinct species (Jackman et al. 2008).
This species was recently split from Spanish Brassy Ringlet (E. hispania).
Thymelicus christi was formerly considered a subspecies of the Lulworth Skipper (T. acteon)
The taxonomic status of this taxon and its relationship to C. leander, C. arcania, and C. gardetta are unclear and require further research.

Pipistrellus tenuis probably represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species. This taxon belongs to the coromandra subgroup of pipistrellus species group. Ellerman and Morrison-Scott (1951) and Sinha (1999) considered Pipistrellus mimus Wroughton, 1899 to represent forms from South Asia. The taxon glaucillus Wroughton, 1912, considered earlier as distinct subspecies, has been synonymized following Sinha (1980) (Srinivasulu et al. in press). We follow the IUCN SSC Chiroptera Specialist Group (P. Racey pers. comm. 2008) in recognizing Pipistrellus murrayi as distinct from P. tenuis.

Greer (1977) synonymized Riopia (at that point containing the African genus Mochlus as a synonym following Broadley 1966) within the large, predominantly Asian genus Lygosoma. This scheme was followed until Wagner (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. No other Mochlus taxa were included in this study, and the content of this revalidated genus was not discussed, however these authors noted that all African taxa are distinct from Asian forms and confined Lygosoma and Riopa to Asia (Wagner et al. 2009, P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). By implication, all African taxa other than Lepidothyris fernandii, L. hinkeli and L. striatus are presently considered to belong to Mochlus (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012).

Elevated to species status by Broadley (2000), but intergrades between Trachylepis punctatissima, T. striata and T. wahlbergii have been reported from some parts of Botswana and Gauteng, South Africa. Broadley (2000) recommended that the identity of these specimens be investigated to resolve the specific status assigned to what were previously subspecies of T. striata. Older specimen records of the T. striata complex should be checked using the key in Broadley (2000).

Medicago saxatilis M. Bieb belongs to the section Medicago, and is a secondary wild relative of the widely cultivated species M. sativa L. ssp. sativa, commonly known as alfalfa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

Medicago tenderiensis Opperman ex Klokov is a primary wild relative of the widely cultivated M. sativa L. ssp. sativa, commonly known as alfalfa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). Atawneh et al. (2009) consider Medicago tenderiensis is a synonym of Medicago sativa ssp. falcata (L.) Arcang.
Torenia bicolor is an annual decumbent herb.
According to new taxonomy it is endemic to Europe (Spitzenberger et al. 2006). The Asian and African populations belong to other species.

This taxon is representative of the taxonomical problem with the genus Ophrys. The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Garden, Kew (2015) follows the recent but controversial synthesis of Pedersen and Faurholdt (2007) and Faurholdt and Pedersen (2009).

Thus, two extremes can be followed:
- there is one species, Ophrys bertolonii, with several geographical and/or ecological subspecies (and hybrid swarms), or;
- there are several species in the complex, each one with a narrow geographical distribution, plus several hybridogenous species narrowly distributed.

In order to take more easily in consideration historical confusions and also field uncertainty even for part of recent data, we have chosen here to consider a species sensu lato approach for the whole group, and to detail each of the most individualised taxa as a subspecies above the same binomial.

Because Ophrys bertolonii sensu lato does not represent the biological reality on the ground and is evidently Least Concern, we follow here the approach that acknowledges that each subspecies component represents an evolutionary entity with its own threats and conservation problems.

N.B: The 2010 European regional assessment was based on the traditional O. bertolonii concept sensu stricto, i.e. sensu O. romolinii (syn. O. bertolonii subsp. romolinii).

V. oroboides Wulfen in Jacq. is a tertiary wild relative of faba bean (V. faba L.), narbon bean (V. narbonensis L.), Hungarian vetch (V. pannonica Crantz and common vetch (V. sativa L.) and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches articulated vetch (V. articulata Hornem.), bitter vetch (V. ervilia (L.) Willd.) and Winter vetch (V. villosa Roth.) (Maxted 1993, 1995).
This species was previously included in the genus Ophisaurus.
The relationship between Aparallactus capensis and A. nigriceps (of southern Mozambique) should be investigated if possible.

Lathyrus cirrhosus Ser. belongs to the family Fabaceae, subfamily Faboideae, and is a secondary wild relative of L. sativus L., the cultivated grass pea (Yunus and Jackson 1991, Sarker et al. 2001, Brink and Belay 2006),  L. cicera L. and L. odoratus L.,  and more remotely is a tertiary wild relative of L. ochrus (L.) DC. (Kupicha 1983).
Medicago kotovii Wissjul. belongs to the section Medicago and is a secondary wild relative of alfalfa, M. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
Rorippa lippizensis (Wulfen) Rchb. is a wild relative of watercress, Nasturtium officinale W.T. Aiton and N. microphyllum Boenn. ex Rchb.

Trifolium incarnatum L. belongs to the section Trifolium, and is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated crops crimson clover (T. incarnatum L.) and red clover (Trifolium pratense L.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). Two subspecies are native to Europe: Trifolium incarnatum ssp. incarnatum and Trifolium incarnatum ssp. molinerii (Balb. ex Hornem.) Ser. in DC. (Zohary and Heller 1984).

Crambe grandiflora DC. is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

Lathyrus heterophyllus L. belongs to the family Fabaceae, subfamily Faboideae, and is a secondary wild relative of L. sativus L., the cultivated grass pea (Yunus and Jackson 1991, Sarker et al. 2001, Brink and Belay 2006),  L. cicera L. and L. odoratus L., and more remotely is a tertiary wild relative of L. ochrus (L.) DC. (Kupicha 1983).

Isatis vermia Papan. is a wild relative of brassica crops and of dyer's woad, I. tinctoria L. Strid (1986) notes that I. vermia is related to the widespread and variable species, I. tinctoria, but differs in the flowering period and a combination of morphological characters. This is reflected by Euro+Med PlantBase (2006), who note that this is a doubtful species, close to I. tinctoria, and is therefore a preliminary accepted species.
Diplotaxis gomez-campoi Mart.-Laborde is a wild relative of brassica crops as well as being related to cultivated perennial wall rocket, D. tenuifolia (L.) DC.
Lepidium heterophyllum Benth. is a wild relative of brassica crops and garden cress, L. sativum L.
Barbarea sicula C. Presl is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress).

Medicago bondevii Kouharov belongs to the section Spirocarpos, and the subsection Pachyspireae and is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated barrel medic (M. truncatula), and a tertiary wild relative of alfalfa (M. sativa) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
Diplotaxis ilorcitana (Sennen) Aedo, Mart.-Laborde & Muñoz Garm. is a wild relative of brassica crops as well as being related to cultivated perennial wall rocket, D. tenuifolia (L.) DC.

Astragalus arenarius L. is a wild relative of the cultivated form, milk-vetch. Two varieties are recognized in the north Baltic region: A. arenarius var. arenarius Bluff. in coastal areas and A. arenarius var. glabrescens Rchb. in the east.
The taxonomy of this species in southern Africa is being investigated, and the presence of cryptic taxa has been suggested (Bates et al. 2011, 2012).

Seven subspecies have so far been described, however, a taxonomic review is required as some may represent full species (Spawls et al. 2002). Broadley et al. (2003) recognize D. l. shirana as the full species D. shirana, noting that "many of the isolated populations of the north seem to represent good evolutionary species". Largen and Spawls (2010) indicate that the name Duberria abyssinica would be applicable to another northern population, endemic to the Ethiopian highlands, if found to be distinct, but while noting that northern populations are "almost certainly" distinct species these authors prefer to apply the name D. lutrix to Ethiopian populations. Pending a formal revision that clarifies the distribution of true D. lutrix and other taxa within this species complex, we follow Largen and Spawls (2010) in retaining northern forms, including D. shirana and D. abyssinica, within D. lutrix.


Two allopatric subspecies of Duberria lutrix are recognized in southern Africa, namely D. l. lutrix (South Africa, Lesotho, and Eswatini (Swaziland)) and D. l. rhodesiana (Zimbabwe and Mozambique), but they are genetically deeply divergent and probably represent separate species (Bates et al. 2014). Broadley and Blaylock (2013) noted that molecular data suggests that most recognized subspecies of D. lutrix, extending from the Cape to Ethiopia—including D. l. rhodesiana—probably represent distinct species.
Broadley (1996) synonymized Cryptolycus with Lycophidion.

Fyson (1921) described it as a variety under Eriocaulon dianae. He recognized the variety richardiana mainly based on the robust nature of the plants, which is now considered to be not of much taxonomic value. Whereas, the prominent root stalks in this taxon is a constant and unique feature. Hence Ansari and Balakrishnan (1994) elevated it as a species.
Eriocaulon sedgwickii is an annual species common on rocky plateaus of the Western Ghats.

Only Fimbristylis salbundia subspecies pentaptera is represented in southern India, subspecies salbundia is only at Meghalaya (Cook 1996). Bhargavan (1989) treats the occurrence of Fimbristylis salbundia, without segregation of subspecies and reports occurrence in Kanyakumari and Madhurai in Tamil Nadu.
Hence there is taxonomic confusion which needs to be resolved.
Murdannia semiteres is annual common in wet areas. It was described by Fr. Santapau in  Poona Agricultural College Magazine 41(4): 15 (1951).
Anthoxanthum borii is endemic to Western Ghats.
Cyathocline lutea was first described in 1847.
Eriocaulon horsley-kundae var. megalocephalum Fyson is the basionym.
Lindernia viscosa is a glabrescent plants sometimes recognized as a separate species - L. multiflora (Roxburgh) Mukherjee (Cook 1996).
Fimbristylis dauciformis is very similar to F. crystallina (Cook 1996).

Eriocaulon odoratum is one of the most variable species, exhibiting great differences in size and structure as well as in habitats and altitude. Hooker (1893) while establishing the species, E. collinum differentiated it from E. odoratum by the non-protruding petals in male flowers. This character is has been considered as an inconsistent one. Hence, Ansari (2009) after examining a large number of specimens from various herbaria including the type of E. collinum and specimens authenticated by earlier workers namely, Fyson, Fischer and Moldenke concluded that the two species are conspecific.

Isachne bicolor was described from Mhaismal plateau in Maharashtra. The description and the illustration in the original publication do not complement each other (Cook 1996). This is treated in the fascicles for flora of India by Prakash and Jain (1984).
Mariscus cyperoides is the valid name of Cyperus cyperoides.
Fimbristylis lawiana is a small, erect perennials with bulbous rhizomes and fibrous roots, 6-18 cm high.
Mariscus maderaspatanus is the valid name of Cyperus maderaspatanus.
Utricularia reticulata is a large twining herb growing in moist localities, typically on lateritic plateaus. It is a carnivorous species.

Paspalum canarae is a widespread annual grass in moist areas. Plants with tubercle based hairs along the margins of the upper glume and lemma of lower floret have been recognized as var. fimbriatum by Veldcamp. Grassbase (Clayton et al. 2006 onwards) do not consider this as a separate variety.
Utricularia praeterita is a small annual growing in wet soil, grasslands and rock outcrops.

The taxonomic history of Coluber florulentus and its subspecific forms is discussed by Schätti (1988), who redescribed this species and the subspecies C. f.  keniensis, and described the West African subspecies C. f. perreti. Schätti (1988) confirmed the validity of C. smithii (later determined to be a subspecies of Platyceps brevis by Schätti and Charvet 2003) and C. taylori as species distinct from C. florulentus. Nagy et al. (2004) assigned C. florulentus to Platyceps.
Further studies are necessary to clarify the status of a population from Chapada Diamantina, Minas Gerais, which exhibits different colouration from those elsewhere (A.S. Argôlo pers. comm. 2012).

Psammophis indochinensis is variously treated as a full species (e.g. Hughes 1999, Pauwels et al. 2003, Nguyen et al. 2009) or as a subspecies of P. condanarus (e.g. McKay 2006, Cottone and Bauer 2009). Cottone and Bauer (2009) remark that "the validity of the subspecific division of [P. condanarus] has not been critically assessed". Based on the disjunct distributions of the two taxa and morphological differences highlighted by Pauwels et al. (2003) it is probable that the two forms represent different species (P. David and A. Bauer pers. comm. 2013) and this scheme is followed here. A full revision is however needed to clarify the relationships of these two taxa (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2013).

There are two subspecies:
T. chilensis chilensis (Schlegel, 1837)
T. chilensis coronellina (Werner, 1898).
The validity of Psammophylax tritaeniatus fitgeraldi Broadley, 1960 has been questioned (see Uetz et al. 2018).

Subspecies:
D. polylepis polylepis (Günther, 1864)
D. polylepis antinori (Peters, 1873).

According to Hertz (1976), various specimens of this species had previously been assigned to Anolis semilineatus. However, whether A. semilineatus (Cope 1864 (part) should be listed as a synonym for this species is still unclear.
It is assumed that all reported occurrences are of the same species and that the taxonomy is fully resolved; little work has been done to check this.

There appears to be some uncertainty about the taxonomic status of the species. While Fitch and Seigel (1984) list Nicaraguan records for the species, these are not mapped by Köhler (2008), putting into doubt that these records pertain to A. sminthus. Furthermore, Köhler (1996) and Köhler et al. (1999) treated Norops heteropholidotus as a valid species, yet Fitch and Seigel (1984) presumed it to be a subspecies of A. sminthus.

The status of Varanus ocellatus is uncertain; it has been variously treated as a synonym of either V. albigularis or V. exanthematicus (Bennett 2004). This account follows Bennett (2004) in considering this form a synonym of V. exanthematicus with a distribution in Sudan (presumably South Sudan given the distribution for V. exanthematicus provided by this author). Specimens from Djibouti, Somalia and Ethiopia previously attributed to V. ocellatus are now understood to represent V. albigularis (Ineich 2001, Largen and Spawls 2006).

This species is part of a species complex whose taxonomy is in need of resolution. A highly divergent haplotype was identified from Ethiopia in an analysis by Pook et al. (2009). These authors suggest the name Echis varius, presently a junior synonym of E. pyramidum, may be applicable to this form, but caution that morphological study is required to confirm this; this taxon was considered distinct by Cherlin (1990) in a review of Echis taxonomy. This work (in Russian in a journal with limited circulation among taxonomists) has however subsequently been "ignored" (Largen and Spawls 2010) and no attempt has yet been made to systematically evaluate Cherlin's proposals (Largen and Spawls 2010) although recent molecular work by Pook et al. (2009) validates his recognition of Arabian populations as the separate species E. borkini and E. khosatzkii.

Since a number of forms within the Varanus indicus species group appear to be island endemics, the likely future discovery of new species may affect the conservation status of this species. For monitors in the Caroline, Mariana and Bonin Islands, future study of molecular and morphological similarities and dfferences to distant populations will help in elucidating whether the species occurs naturally on these islands or was introduced (Cota 2008). Recently subpopulations from New Ireland, Lavongai and Djaul islands have been referred to the resurrected species V. douarrha (Weijola et al. 2016).

A number of subspecies have been described:
Anolis olssoni olssoni Schmidt, 1919
Anolis olssoni alienus Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni dominigensis Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni extentus Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni ferrugicauda Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni insulanus Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni montivagus Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni palloris Schwartz, 1981.

Takydromus sexlineatus ocellatus is sometimes treated as a full species. Additional hidden diversity may exist within this widespread species, at least in Myanmar where at least one cryptic species is thought to exist within this complex (G. Wogan unpubl. data).

There has been considerable taxonomic debate over the angular-toed or thin-toed geckos, and they have been variously assigned to Cyrtodactylus, Cyrtopodion and Tenuidactylus (Auffenberg et al. 2004). This species was referred to the genus Cyrtopodion by Auffenberg et al. (2004), following the simplified arrangement presented by Anderson (1999), and despite the assignment of this species to Altigekko by Khan (2003) Following Bauer et al. (2013) it is now treated under Altiphylax.

Gymnodactylus walli was, for a long time, considered a synonym of C. stoliczkai, until Khan (1992) provided a case to recognize G. walli as a separate species, an action subsequently supported by Auffenberg et al. (2004).

Auffenberg et al. (2004) consider Alsophylax (Altiphylax) boehmi to be a junior synonym of this species.

The taxonomic rearrangement of Campbell and Lamar (2004) (based on morphology) was corroborated by the molecular data of Wuster et al. (2005), confining Crotalus durissus (previously understood to range throughout the Neotropics) is restricted to South America (M. Martins, pers. comm. 2010). Rivas et al. (2012) propose recognizing the current subspecies Crotalus d. vegrandis from the lowlands of Maturín and Anzoátegui (northeastern Venezuela) as a full species based on morphological characters mostly related to colour pattern. This scheme is adopted by the Reptile Database as of November 2018 (Uetz 2018), however C. d. vergrandis is retained as a subspecies here pending confirmation that it warrants specific status.
[VSG to rule on this treatment]
Previously incorrectly thought to be a separate species, Hypnale walli is now treated as junior subjective synonym of Hypnale nepa (Maduwage et al. 2009).

The distribution of this species (sensu stricto) is likely to be reduced considerably in the near future as current work suggests further taxonomic splitting (A. Malhotra pers. comm. August 2010). This is likely to give rise to new species with much smaller ranges and hence increased conservation concern.

This species has five subspecies:
O. monticola convictus (Stoliczka, 1870) - Indo-Malayan Mountain Pitviper
O. monticola monticola (Günther, 1864)
O. monticola makazayazaya (Takahashi, 1922) - Taiwan Mountain Pitviper
O. monticola orientalis (Schmidt, 1925) - Oriental Mountain Pitviper
O. monticola zhaokentangi Zhao, 1995 - Gaoligong Mountain Pitviper.

This species has two subspecies:
Typhlops diardi platyventris Khan, 1998
Typhlops diardi diardi Sschlegel, 1839.

This is a species complex (Langstroth 2005, Nogueira 2006) which contains two recognized subspecies: C. schreibersii schreibersii Wiegmann, 1834
C. schreibersii albostrigatus (Griffin, 1917).

Its taxonomy is disputed. It was separated from P. melalophos by Wilson and Wilson (1977), recognized as a species by Aimi et al. (1986).

Presbytis femoralis was formerly regarded as a subspecies of P. melalophos (Chasen 1940; Napier 1985; Oates et al. 1994). It is now separated from P. melalophos and recognised as a species (Pocock 1935; Wilson and Wilson 1975, 1976; Weitzel 1983; Aimi et al. 1986; Aimi and Bakar 1992, 1996; Groves 2001), but its taxonomy remains disputed (e.g. Vun et al. 2011). With current available information, three subspecies are recognised under Presbytis femoralis which show variability in the colour of the head and the direction of hairs on the chest (Groves 2001; Groves and Roos 2013; Roos et al. 2014). See individual subspecies pages for description.

Subgenus (Episemion) Aphyosemion krystallinoron Sonnenberg, Blum & Misof, 2006 was previously regarded as an aberrant population of Aphyosemion callipteron. The dorsolateral body colour of adult males is metallic blue-green, versus metallic gold in A. callipteron. Males have three or four rows of red dots on sides of body versus a single midlateral broad reddish-brown line in A. callipteron. A. krystallinoron is known from a small number of localities in southeastern Equatorial Guinea and northern Gabon west of the distribution area of A. callipteron.

This crayfish is very closely related to Procambarus regalis and the two may be synonymous. The only differences noted by Hobbs are slight differences in the symmetry of the gonopods and differences in tuberculation of the annulus ventralis (D. Johnson pers. comm. 2010).
Robust perennial grass growing in clumps, short rhizomes, attains a height of 200 cm.
Type: Ethiopia, Simien, Mt Selki, Schimper II 687 (P, holo.; K, UPS)
Poor literature.
A shortly rhizomatous perennial with erect slender culms to about 60 cm high, occasionally higher.
Robust erect perennial bunchgrass with stout culms to about 100 cm high.
A slender semi-aquatic plant about 3 feet high on the edge of swamps after the rainy season ; flowers yellow, usually in pairs on slenders pedicels
Rob Scott-Shaw has it listed as Colpodium hedbergii (African taxon).
Type: Seret 669, Zaire (holo- BR).
An annual erect herb, branching from base, to 45 cm high
Type: Gérard 3359, D.R. Congo (Ubangi-Uele).

Annual herb in general ramified, sometimes with simple stem from 15 to 40 cm high, with opposed leaves, the limb is elliptic lanceolated or linear from two to five cm. Flowers bluish, linear with capsules long from seven to eight mm.
Juncus exsertus ssp. lesuticus
There is a need for more taxonomic studies on this species (L. Heaney pers. comm. 2006).

This species was previously assessed under the name as Zamia amblyphyllidia, however, Calonje et al. (2010) have confirmed that Z. erosa takes priority over Z. amblyphyllidia.


Type notes:

From Calonje et al. (2010), Taxon 59(2): 637-642: 'The lectotype designation of Zamia erosa O.F. Cook & G.N. Collins by Eckenwalder (1980) is corrected to a neotype as it does not constitute original material on which Cook & Collins based their description. The neotype designation is itself superseded, as the specimen selected by Eckenwalder is in serious conflict with the protologue, a conclusion based on overlooked descriptive and geographic information in the protologue, and new collections recently made near the type locality. A new neotype is designated.'

Type information:

Collector and Number: O.F. Cook & G.N. Collins s.n., NA Sheet #88468, Negative #2376
Locality: Puerto Rico, Vega Baja, 1899
Type Location(s): NT—NA

Yellow-legged frog populations now recognized as Rana sierrae formerly were included in Rana muscosa. Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).
Rana luteiventris was included in this species before it was elevated to species status by Green et al. (1996, 1997).
Some systematists doubt that Lithobates subaquavocalis is distinct from L. chiricahuensis.
In 2000, Doweld proposed that all Gnetum species should be changed to Thoa, except two Asiatic species, mainly based on seedcoat structure.
Koopman in Wilson and Reeder (1993) included this in synonymy under R. clivosus, whereas others maintain it as a separate species.
There are no recognized subspecies of Romerolagus diazi (Hall 1981).

Four subspecies have been described: Salamandra atra atra; S. a. aurorae; S.a. prenjensis; and S. a. pasobiensis. The status of these subspecies remains questionable. S.a. prenjensis is often not considered to be valid. S.a. aurorae has been sometimes considered to be a separate species. Joger (1996), using serum proteins, showed significant differences, and he proposed the elevation of S.a. aurorae to a full species. Veith et al. (1998), analyzing mitDNA of S.a. aurorae did not find any significant difference. Riberon et al. (2001) indicate a complex pattern of divergence for the alpine populations, without reaching or stressing any taxonomic consequences.
The species is considered valid in The Plant List (2011), however other sources treat it as Hedyotis diffusa Willd.
The taxonomic status of the species requires resolution. Subsp. gracilis is endemic to Thailand (Yamazaki 1990).
There is a disagreement whether or not three subspecies of S. arizonensis should be recognized. This species is monotypic (Koprowski et al. 2016).
Common names refer to all species found in the Andropogon genus.

When the species was first described in 1956 the species was considered "Quite distinct from all other species hitherto known in West Africa with some affinity to Chamaecrista grantii Oliv., which is widespread in West Africa".

The genera Gynura and Crassocephalum have been confused in Africa, particularly by Bentham who believed them to be synonymous. This led to the Vienna Congress 1905 conserving Gynura over Crassocephalum, but Cassini’s original descriptions and observations are clear in delimiting the two genera. Crassocephalum style arms are similar to those of Gynura, but the appendages are shorter, asymmetrical and with a tuft of papillae at the junction of style-arm and appendage. Occasionally Gynura specimens appear to have this kind of style arm but this is a result of damage to the exposed organs and the style-arms remaining inside florets at the bud stage prove to be normal. The significant differences between the two editions of Flora of Tropical West Africa for these two genera highlight the problems that have occurred, including confusion concerning the determination and allocation of specimens to the appropriate species.
This species is closely related to Maerua crassifolia and Boudet et al. (1986) suggest that M. de-waillyi may in fact be an ecotype of M. crassifolia.

Bullock described Gongronema obscurum "with some hesitation" in 1961: "the four specimens cited are certainly very much alike and are sufficiently different in facies from all the numerous specimens of G. angolense which I have seen. The differences may well be of the same kind, however, as those which I have considered insufficient to separate Marsdenia leonensis and M. glabrifolia from G. latifolium, and the specimens will then represent no more than an ecotypical form of G. angolense. The point is one which can be settled finally only by further field observations. If it will survive such treatement, the new growths of G. angolense after bush clearance or burning would provide strictly comparable specimens."

No such investigation appears to have been carried out since and the "Catalogue des Plantes Vasculaires du Mali" (1986) and the "Cataloge des Plantes Vasculaires du Burkina Faso" (1991) also state the possibility of this species actually being an ecotype of G. angolense, highlighting that all known specimens of the species lack mature fruits.

A genus revision occurred in 1998, moving this species from Gongronema to Marsdenia. There was no further mention of the possibility of M. obscura being an ecotype of Marsdenia angolensis N.E.Br. and Goyder (pers. comm. 2007) confirms its accepted status as a species.

This species is very closely related to Oldenlandia capensis, from which it differs in its more robust stems, thicker leaves provided with a very conspicuous white midrib, and a more conspicuously fimbriate stipular sheath (Bremekamp 1952).

In the Flora of China (Fu et al. 2010) it is noted that the Chinese plants described do not correspond well with Florin’s original description of Ephedra minuta.
