 The Northwestern or cacsilensis subspecies is distributed on the western side of the Andes from the north central to the southern Peru to the northern extreme of Chile, whereas the Southeastern subspecies or guanicoe is found throughout all of Patagonia to the extreme Austral end of the continent. Both lineages apparently formed due to the presence of the Andean altiplano (plateau) that served as a biogeographical and ecological barrier separating the populations to east and west of the Andean continental divide. The hybrid zone came about through genetic flow between the two subspecies where a geographic contact zone existed in the region south of the altiplano in Central Chile, in far northwestern Patagonia, and with an extension northeast into northwestern Argentina and southern Bolivia (Marín et al. 2013).  An alternative to the classification of two subspecies is the possibility they could be considered Evolutionary Significant Units (sensu Moritz 1994, Marín et al. 2013). 

At the current population level at least eight, independent genetic and demographic or Management Units (MUs, according to Moritz 1994 definition) have been identified that should be managed separately in order to maintain their local genetic adaptiveness (Marín et al. 2013): 1) Peruvian Hyper-Arid Desert, 2) Chilean Pre-Andean Altiplano, 3) Chilean Arid Zone and Pre-Puna, 4) Bolivian Chaco, 5) North and Central Patagonia, 6) Patagonia Occidental, 7) Patagonia Austral, and 8) Fueguian Zone. Guanaco populations in northeast and northcentral Argentina that were not included in Marín et al. (2013) have yet to be assessed for MU classification. 

Although previous taxonomic classification was based upon phenotypic characteristics (Wheeler 1995, González et al. 2006), there have been no wide-scale studies dealing with morphological variations in the species. Preliminary examination of Guanaco skulls at museums indicates a differentiation between individuals across the continent in Bolivia, Chile, Patagonia, and Tierra del Fuego (Groves and Grubb 2011).

Grubb (1993) lists five subspecies: H. a. amphibius from eastern Gambia to Sudan, Ethiopia, the northern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Tanzania and Mozambique, H. a. tschadensis from Nigeria and Chad, H. a. kiboko from Somalia and Kenya, H. a. constrictus from Angola, the southern DRC and Namibia, and finally, H. a. capensis from Zambia southwards to South Africa. It is important to note, however, that this classification has not been widely accepted (Eltringham 1999; Beckwitt et al. 2016), and recent taxonomic research of this species is lacking. Furthermore, these five subspecies are visually indistinguishable in the wild, and the geographic extent of each range remains vague (Eltringham 1993).

The subspecies sicula was described by Cristaudo et al. (2007). The taxonomic identity of the subspecies has been questioned by Leonardis et al. (2009), who suggest that the subspecies bears similarity to Vulpia sicula var. sicula.

There are five recognized varieties of this taxon (Dobignard and Chatelain 2010):
- P. foetidum var. brachysiphon Maire, distributed in the Atlantic coast of Morocco and adjacent areas of Chicht, Tafelnay, Cap Ghir, Forêt d'Admine, Vallée de l'oued Massa, Taderrast.
- P. foetidum var. oranense Batt, distributed along northeastern Morocco and northwestern Algeria (Maire 1959).
- P. foetidum var. rifanum Maire, endemic to Northern Morocco, where it has been recorded from Imzorène and Gareb (Benito et al. 2002).
- P. foetidum var. saldense Batt, endemic to Algeria, where it has been recorded from two localities, one at the north and one at south west of Gouraya mountain (R. Khellaf pers. comm. 2016) in Bejaia (Bougie) (Maire 1959).
- P. foetidum var. tunetanum Batt, occurring in central Tunisia (Maire 1959); its taxonomic status needs confirmation because it could be a different species (E. Véla pers. comm. 2016).

Subpopulations occurring in Libya at Wadi ben tajura, Gussbat, Hadida, Garian (Jafri and El Gadi 1978) have been identified as P. collinum (Cosson and Durieu 1854) but their taxonomic status requires confirmation and may refer instead to this species.
Two subspecies are currently accepted, subsp. cupanii and subsp. glossophyllum. Montane plants in cultivation differed from plants of lowland origin (J.-M. Tison pers. comm. 2016).

The genus Vagaria consists of only two species with disjunct distributions; one is endemic to Morocco, the other is endemic to the Levant. Vagaria is similar to Pancratium, but the flowers have small staminal cups that are split to the base. DNA studies have shown that it does not belong to any other genus.
According to Milović (2016) all records of C. pallasii Goldb. and C. longiflorus Raf. from Croatia refer to C. thomasii Ten.
This species is suspected to be a form of F. trichophylla (e.g., Devesa et al. 2013) and more research is needed to confirm its species rank.
WCSP (2015) considers the species valid as Festuca calabrica Huter, Porta & Rigo ex Hack.

Further work is required to understand the taxonomic relationships within this genus in relation to the distribution of species and the status of proposed subspecies. In particular, the differences between C. multiflorum (and C. longifolium) and C. neapolitanum, are very unclear.

C. neapolitanum sensu strictu is restricted to southern (and perhaps central) Italy (J.-M. Tison pers. comm. 2015).

Fridlender et al. (2014) proposed the following subspecies;
  • C. neapolitanum (Ten.) Ten. subsp. neapolitanum: uncertain endemic to Southern Italy (Campania and Basilicata).
  • C. neapolitanum (Ten.) Ten. subsp. kochii (Parl.) Fridl.: northeast Italy, Slovenia and Croatia (southern limit in Zadar – Krka area) near the seashore at low altitude (0-200 m, up to 400 m).
  • C. neapolitanum (Ten.) Ten. subsp. visianii (Parl.) Fridl.: Dalmatia, above all at an altitude from 300 to 1400 m (some populations at sea level in Herzegovina and southern Croatia).
  • C. neapolitanum (Ten.) Ten. subsp. haynaldii (Heuffel) Fridl., stat. nov.: Romania.
In parts of its distribution it is known as Urginea fugax (Moris) Steinh.
The taxonomic status of the species needs to be investigated to confirm its separation from other Biarum species.
Subpopulations in the eastern Balearic Islands are treated as Arum pictum subsp. sagittifolium (Roselló and Sáez 1997).
This species is considered valid as a subspecies of Trisetum flavescens (Trisetum flavescens subsp. tenue) by Dimopoulis et al. (2013) and Euro+Med Plantbase (Valdés and Scholz 2009).
WCSP (2018) considers this species to be a synonym of Festuca circummediterranea Patzke.

The taxonomy of this species is rather complex. It is considered a valid species and an Iberian endemic by some sources (Franco and Afonso 1994, Tison 2009, The Plant List 2014, WCSP 2014), but the recent review by Flora Iberica (López González 2013) treats this taxon as a synonym of Gagea foliosa subsp. elliptica [ellyptica] A.Terracc and thus occurring in the Iberian Peninsula and Morocco (Anthos 2014). The database Euro+Med (2014) considers it a synonym of Gagea granatellii (Parl.) Parl, which by its turn is considered synonym of G. lacaitae in Flora Iberica.

However, in addition to the study of juvenile and immature stages, the molecular data (Tison et al. 2013) confirm the independence of G. elliptica, G. granatellii, G. lacaitae and G. lusitanica.

The name of Gagea nevadensis has been used to identify different taxa of Gagea (G. bohemica, G. durieruri and G. souleirolii) but they don't fit well with the type specimen. For this reason, the name is under discussion under the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (Art. 69) (G. Lopez).

However, the species currently called G. nevadensis has no other available name and is morphologically, genetically and geographically well-defined (Tison et al. 2013).

Some authors maintain a broader concept of this taxon e.g., For example López González (2013) considers Gagea nevadensis a subspecies of Gagea foliosa (as the subspecies Gagea foliosa subsp. nevadensis); López González considers the identity of the Gagea nevadensis’ plants from Serra da Estrela and Sierra Nevada, used in chromosome counts, to be doubtful, and perhaps closer to G. soleirolii.
Euro+Med Plantbase (Valdés and Scholz 2009) consider the senior name of this species to be Ctenopsis delicatula (Lag.) Paunero.

Brullo and Giusso Del Galdo (2006) reviewed this species and described three subspecies; subsp. nitida (Abruzzi to Mt. Pollino), subsp. aprutia (central Apennines) and subsp. sicula (northern Sicily). However Bartolucci et al. (2018) maintain just the nominate subspecies and subsp. sicula.

We follow the restricted definition of the taxon proposed by Tison et al. (2013). The species has been much cited across the whole Mediterranean basin except desertic parts but all these mentions are considered erroneous, the most frequent being G. cossoniana Pascher, G. dubia A.Terracc., G. elliptica (A.Terracc.) Prain, G. heldreichii (A.Terracc.) Stroh, G. lacaitae A.Terracc., G. nevadensis Boiss., and G. ramulosa A.Terracc. (J.-M. Tison pers. comm. 2016). The monophyly of G. foliosa in its true sense is confirmed by molecular data (Tison et al. 2013).

According to Strid (in Strid and Tan 1991) Stipa rechingeri is a form of S. pennata L. subsp. pulcherrima (C. Koch) Freitag.

Gonzalo Estébanez (2013), in a revision of the genus Stipa, considered S. rechingeri to be conspecific with S. novakii, with Stipa novakii Martinovský the senior name. However Dimopoulos et al. (2013) accepts S. rechingeri as a separate species in the recently published checklist of vascular Greek flora.

Further taxonomic work is required to confirm the identity of this species.

A. europaeum was previously considered a synonym of A. gramineum (Pedrola-Monfort and Caujapé-Castells 1996), however, both species are now considered valid, with A. europaeum located in the south of the Iberian Peninsula and North Africa, while A. gramineum is an exclusively African species (Del Hoyo and Pedrola-Monfort 2010).
This species has been confused with Biarum bovei from the eastern Mediterranean and B. mendax from the southwestern Iberian Peninsula

Biarum mendax is a recently described species from western Spain. It has been confused in herbaria with B. bovei and B. dispar. Its decurrent pistilodium on a stipite relates B. mendax to B. kotschyi (Schott) from Turkey. However, the connate tube margins connects it to B. bovei from the eastern Mediterranean.
Records from the Rif Mountains in Morocco refer to Avena marginata according to Romero Zarco (1996).

This species appears to be taxonomically complex. We do not accept the synonymy proposal including the closely related Prospero fallax by Hamouche et al. (2010) because no further work has been done on this point, and a lot of morphological characteristics are stable in cultivation, distinguishing the two species (E. Véla and J.M. Tison pers. comm. 2018), which are generally still considered distinct species (Dobignard and Chatelain 2010, WCSP 2016). Furthermore, some peripheral subpopulations traditionally included in P. obtusifolia, like S. obtusifolia var. glauca Gatef. & Weiller in Morocco, or the controversial S. obtusifolia subsp. intermedia sensu auct. lib., need further studies before accepting their inclusion in, or to affirm their exclusion from, P. obtusifolia sensu stricto (E. Véla pers. comm. 2018).
The species is clearly little-known and not widely taxonomically recognised.
There are authors who recognise up to three subspecies within P. balbisii but for the purpose of this assessment, no infra-specific taxa are recognised.

Although this species is very widely spelt as revelieri, the correct spelling is revelierei (e.g., The Plant List 2017), according to Art. 60.7 of ICN (Peruzzi et al. 2015, L. Peruzzi pers. comm. 2017).

The relations between this and R. petrana in southern Jordan and with R. phoenicia requires study (O. Fragman-Sapir pers. comm. 2016). R. phoenicia is considered a synonym by some but is maintained as a separate taxon here.
According to Martin et al. (2015), Orchis laeta is considered here including coloured forms sometimes called Orchis x blidana as hypothetic hybrid swarms O. laeta x O. olbiensis.

Populations in southern Albania and FYR Macedonia (22 chromosomes) have different chromosome counts from those in northern Greece (18 and 20 chromosomes) (Papanicolaou and Zacharov 1980, V. Matevski pers. comm. 2015).

Plants from FYROM (Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Galićica region) have a different chromosome number (2n=22) as first reported by Sopova and Sekovski (1982) and verified by Ranđelovic, Sekovski and Dimeska (2007). Correspondingly, Shuka et al. (2009) reported a white form of C. cvijicii, under the name C. cvijicii f. tartarii, from eastern Albania, Mt. Ostrovica and Mt. Mali i Thate, which are close to the Galićica region.

Further study is required to confirm the identity of records from parts of the species range.
This species is presumably of hybridogenic origin between S. lingua and Serapias spp. Vegetative multiplication is active (E. Véla pers. comm. 2018).

According to Tan and Iatrou (2001) C. hadriaticus is divided into three subspecies (subsp. hadriaticus, subsp. parnonicus. subsp. parnassicus.). However, according to the same authors C. hadriaticus is quite variable in its characteristics and subdividing the species may be considered unsatisfactory although some of this variation is correlated with geographic distribution. None of the subspecies are accepted by Dimopolos et al. (2013) as valid taxa.
Allium agrigentinum is a primary relative and potential gene donor to garlic (A. sativum)
Confirmation of the taxonomic identity of this species is required, and it is considered a synonym of Narcissus bulbocodium L. by Flora Iberica.

We follow the recent treatment on Narcissus (Aedo 2013) and therefore N. serotinus would be restricted to those plants with normally one flower per scape, 6-teethed pale-yellow coronas, and floral tubes that sharply broaden.

Here we follow the taxonomic treatment of Aedo (2014) and therefore N. elegans would be referred to those plants with several flowers per scape (in opposition to N. serotinus and N. obsoletus, with one or rarely more) and wider leaves that are still present when blooming.
This species presents hybridization with Narcissus assoanus, named N. x pujolii, in the southern areas of its distribution range, e.g. in the Region of Murcia, Spain (S. Ríos Ruiz pers. comm. 2015).

There appears to be confusion between different literature sources about the identity of this plant, with many conflicting accounts of its status and distribution. This account follows the distribution given by WCSP (2018) and the eMonocot (2016).

This species was recently described as a fertile hybrid between Narcissus asturiensis and N. nivalis (Fernández Casas 2009), but its taxonomic status is still rather unclear. The same author points out that this species as long been confused with one of its parents, namely N. nivalis. The recent revision of the Genus Narcissus in Flora Iberica does not consider this as a valid species (Aedo 2013). Its acceptance as a valid species in the Plant List (2017) is followed here, but clearly further taxonomic study is required.
This taxon has been recognized by Luceño (2008).

Narcissus albicans (Haw) Spreng is a variable species normally included within N. cantabricus DC (Anthos 2014). Both taxa belong to the Bulbocodii Section and are considered to be separated species according Fernández Casas (2009, 2013).

The genus Hannonia is endemic to Morocco with a single species. Hannonia hesperidum is very similar to Vagaria ollivieri, with which is sometimes considered synonymous. It is difficult to distinguish between them in a vegetative state, but Hannonia hesperidum is more slender, with geminate flowers, and flowers earlier.

This species is accepted according to the specialist of the genus in the Flora Ibérica (Luceño 2008). The Euro+Med database (2016) does not recognize C. lachenalii Schkuhr from Flora Europaea (Chater 1980) as a synonym of C. furva.

The description of part of the morphological variability of this species as Carex lucennoiberica (Maguilla and Escudero 2016, 2017) has restricted the distribution of C. furva to the Sierra Nevada, in southern Spain.

WCSP (2017, citing Tutin et al. 1980, Davis 1984, Everett 2013, Christenhusz et al. 2013) considers this species to be a synonym of Tulipa orphanidea Boiss. ex Heldr., however Tulipa hageri and T. orphanidea are considered separate species according to Strid and Tan (1991), Zonneveld (2009), Van Raamsdonk and De Vries (1992), Van Raamsdonk et al. (1997), and Dimopoulos et al. 2013). According to Van Raamsdonk and De Vries (1992), T. hageri, T. orphanidea and T. whittallii are separate species occurring exclusively in the Aegean region (including Asia Minor) with T. hageri being the most widespread. According to Zonnenveld (2009) Tulipa orphanidea has three subspecies: subsp. orphanidea, subsp. whittallii (Dykes) Zonn. (= T. whittallii Dykes, endemic to western Turkey), and subsp. doerfleri (= T. doerfleri).

According to Flora Europaea (Tutin et al. 1980) and Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean islands (Davis 1984) Tulipa hageri (Parnitha, Penteli) is included in T. orphanidea with the following distribution: Greece Gr-Cr/Pe, StE, NE, KK, Bulgaria, Turkey; E. Mediterranean element).

Tulipa hageri var. thasia was described from Thasos (Stojanov and Kitannnov), but this taxon is not quoted in any flora.

For this assessment, T. hageri is considered as a separate valid taxon.
Small plants may resemble F. aestivalis and large plants resemble F. dichotoma (Cook 1996).

Allium scorzonerifolium is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops columnaris Zhuk. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii.

Aegilops cylindrica Host is a secondary wild relative of bread wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, durum wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including emmer wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., einkorn wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and sanduri wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii (van Slageren 1994).

Based on the interpretation of the bread wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops kotschyi Boiss. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii.

Based on the interpretation of the bread wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops neglecta Bertol. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii.

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops longissima Schweinf. & Muschl. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii.

This species comprises two varieties: Ae. peregrina var. brachyathera (Boiss.) Maire & Weiller and Ae. peregrina var. peregrina (van Slageren 1994).

Aegilops speltoides Tausch is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii. (van Slageren 1994).

van Slageren (1994) recognizes two subspecies: Aegilops speltoides subsp. ligustica (Savign.) Zhuk. and Aegilops speltoides subsp. speltoides.

Aegilops tauschii Coss. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii (van Slageren, 1994)

Aegilops triuncialis L. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii. (van Slageren 1994).

There are two subspecies: Ae. triuncialis subsp. persica (Boiss.) Zhuk. and Ae. triuncialis subsp. triuncialis (van Slageren, 1994).

Aegilops umbellulata Zhuk. is a secondary wild relative of bread wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, durum wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including emmer wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., einkorn wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and sanduri wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii (van Slageren 1994)

Allium schoenoprasum L. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including Onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh Onion (A. fistulosum L.), Leek (A. porrum L.) and Garlic (A. sativum L.) (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Two subspecies are native to Europe: A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum (DC.) Čelak. and A. schoenoprasum L. subsp. schoenoprasum (Euro+Med PlantBase 2006); these are primary wild relatives of Chives.

Three subspecies are recognized in Iberia: A. schoenoprasum subsp. orosiae, A. schoenoprasum subsp. latiorifolium and A. schoenoprasum subsp. schoenoprasum.
Asparagus officinalis L. is a primary wild relative of cultivated Asparagus (A. officinalis) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Avena fatua L. is a primary genetic relative of Oats (Avena sativa L.) (Jellen and Leggett 2005, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Four subspecies are native to Europe: A. fatua subsp. aemulans (Nevski) H. Scholz, A. fatua subsp. cultiformis Malzev, A. fatua L. subsp. fatua, and A. fatua subsp. meridionalis Malzev (Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly 2009).

Avena sterilis L. is a primary genetic relative of Oats (Avena sativa L.) (Jellen and Leggett 2005, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). Five subspecies are native to Europe: A. sterilis subsp. atherantha (C.Presl) H.Scholz, A. sterilis subsp. ludoviciana (Durieu) Gillet & Magne, A. sterilis nothosubsp. malzevii H. cholz, A. sterilis L. subsp. sterilis and A. sterilis subsp. trichophylla (K.Koch) Malzev. (Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly 2009).

Vicia ervilia is relatively isolated with Vicia and as such is in the tertiary gene pool of Common Vetch V. sativa L., and more remotely Hungarian Vetch V. pannonica Crantz and Winter Vetch V. villosa Roth., it is also a tertiary wild relative of Faba Bean V. faba L., Narbon Bean V. narbonensis L. (Maxted 1993, 1995).

It belongs to the secondary Taxon Group of Articulated Vetch V. articulata Hornem. and to Taxon Group 1B of cultivated Bitter Vetch V. ervilia (L.) Willd. (Kupicha 1976).

Triticum monococcum L. is a primary wild relative of cultivated Einkorn Wheat (T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum), Bread Wheat (Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum), Durum Wheat (T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Hush.), Emmer Wheat (T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell.), Spelt (T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell.), and Sanduri wheat (T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii).

Triticum monococcum L. comprises three subspecies (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2015): T. monococcum subsp. monococcum and T. monococcum subsp. sinskajae (Filat. & Kurkiev) Valdés & H. Scholz, both cultivated, and T. monococcum subsp. aegilopoides (Link) Thell. which is the wild and here assessed.

Medicago turbinata (L.) All. belongs to the section Spirocarpos, subsection Pachyspireae. It is a primary wild relative of Barrel Clover M. truncatula Gaertn. and a tertiary wild relative of cultivated Alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). The species contains a variety native to Europe, Medicago turbinata (L.) All. var. aculeata Moris.

Medicago truncatula Gaertn. belongs to the section Spirocarpos, subsection Pachyspireae, and is a primary wild relative of cultivated Barrel Clover M. truncatula and a tertiary wild relative of cultivated Alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

Medicago scutellata (L.) Mill. belongs to the section Spirocarpos, subsection Rotatae. It is a secondary wild relative of several cultivated crops, including M. arabica (L.) Huds. (Spotted Medic), M. polymorpha L. (Bur Medic), and M. truncatula Gaertn. (Barrel Clover), and is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated Alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

The species Medicago sativa L. belongs to the section Medicago, and is a primary wild relative of the cultivated crop Alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). There are five subspecies of M. sativa recognized by Small (2011): M. sativa subsp. caerulea (Less. ex Ledeb.) Schmalh., M. sativa subsp. falcata (L.) Arcang. var. falcata, M. sativa subsp. falcata var. viscosa (Rchb.) Posp., M. sativa subsp. glomerata (Balbis) Rouy and M. sativa subsp. xvaria (T. Martyn) Arcang. M. sativa L. subsp. sativa is also recognized but its native range cannot be determined due to the extent of its naturalized occurrence.

Medicago rigidula (L.) All. belongs to the section Spirocarpos, subsection Pachyspireae. It is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated crop Barrel Clover (M. truncatula Gaertn.), and a tertiary wild relative of cultivated Alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

Medicago constricta Durieu belongs to the section Spirocarpos, subsection Pachyspireae, and is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated crop Barrel Clover, M. truncatula Gaertn., and a tertiary wild relative of cultivated Alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

Lupinus angustifolius L. is an Old World lupin species, and contains within its primary gene pool two subspecies native to Europe: L. angustifolius L. subsp. angustifolius (cultivated Blue Lupin), and L. angustifolius L. subsp. reticulatus (Desv.) Arcang. (Singh et al. 2007). A significantly more dissected classification of 14 varieties is provided by Kurlovich and Stankevich (2002).

According to Clements et al. (2005), L. angustifolius belongs to the primary Gene Pool of cultivated Blue Lupin (L. angustifolius) and to the secondary Gene Pool of Yellow Lupin (L. luteus L.).
Hordeum secalinum Schreb. is a tertiary wild relative of Barley, H. vulgare L.(USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

Hordeum murinum L. is a tertiary wild relative of Barley, H. vulgare L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

Five subspecies are native to Europe: H. murinum subsp. glaucum (Steud.) Tzvelev, H. murinum subsp. leporinum (Link) Arcang., H. murinum subsp. montanum (Hack.) H. Scholz & Raus, H. murinum L. subsp. murinum, and H. murinum subsp. setariurum H. Scholz & Raus (Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly 2009).
Hordeum marinum Huds. is a tertiary wild relative of Barley, H. vulgare L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

Hordeum bulbosum L. is a tertiary wild relative of Barley, H. vulgare L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). Two subspecies are native to Europe: H. bulbosum L. subsp. bulbosum and H. bulbosum subsp. nodosum (L.) Baum (Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly 2009).

Hordeum brevisubulatum (Trin.) Link is a tertiary wild relative of Barley, H. vulgare L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). One subspecies is native to Europe: H. brevisubulatum subsp. violaceum (Boiss. & Hohen.) Tzvelev (Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly 2009).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

The taxonomy of this species is debated. Breteler (1960) reduces Abrus pulchellus and A.mollis and others to synonyms of A.fruticulosus. Kumar and Sane (2003), for example, list A. fruticulosus as a recognized species with no synonyms.

A. ehrenbergiana is similar to A. hockii, but differs in having only 1-2(-3) pairs of pinnae, and a somewhat different distributional range; also occupies drier habitats. Also resembling A. seyal for which it has been mistaken.
The genus Arachis comprises 80 wild species and the cultivated crop Arachis hypogaea L. (Fabales, Leguminosae) commonly known as groundnut or peanut. All Arachis species are native to South America.
Previously recognized as Astracantha albispina (Sirj. & Bornm.) Podlech, in 1983, the current accepted name for this assessment is Astragalus albispinus Sirj. & Bornm. (Zarre et al. 2008).
Previously accepted as Astracantha floccosa (Boiss.) (Podlech 1983) and currently accepted as Astragalus floccosus Boiss. (Zarre et al. 2008).
Astragalus abnormalis is included in the section Incani (Mehrabian et al. 2007)

Astragalus L. with about 2,500-3,000 species in the world is considered the largest and most complex genus of angiosperms. It is distributed primarily in cold arid and semiarid mountainous regions of the Northern Hemisphere and South America (Chaudhary and Srivastava 2007).
Astragalus atricapillus is included in the section Hypoglottidei (Maassoumi 1988).
Astragalus ikonnikovii is the species of Subsect. Erionotus that grows at the highest altitude (Podlech 1988).

Although the species name was published as Astragalus retufoliatus Y.C.Ho, an orthographic correction of the name was made by Podlech in Thesaurus Astragalorum in 2008, and the proposed name is Astragalus retusifoliatus Y.C.Ho.
Astragalus davuricus (Pallas) DC. Is often found as a synonym of Astragalus stevenianus DC. but its accepted synonym is A. davuricus K.Koch, leading to confusion.

There has been a recent transfer of the genus, the species was originally described as Astragalus zemuensis W.W.Sm and in 2006 the new combination Oxtropis zemuensis (W.W.Sm.) L.B.Chaudhary was published (Chaudhary 2006).
Numerous hybridizing populations involving Baptisia leucophaea Nutt. and B. sphaerocarpa Nutt. Were identified over the entire range of B. sphaerocarpa (Alston and Turner 1963).
Two varieties are recognized var. scarabaeoides and var. pedunculatus.

The genus Caragana has over 80 species out of which 10 species have so far been identified in Pakistan. Caragana species are deciduous shrubs distributed widely throughout the Euro-Asian continent, from Northern Europe and central Asia, eastwards to Russian Siberia, Korea and Japan, and south to Nepal, Bhutan, Sikkim and northern India (Meng et al. 2009).
Erect annual herb with a single or numerous ascending, appressed pubescent branches, (10-)20-80 cm tall; stipules absent; pod globose.
Crotalaria chrysochlora is a perennial herb with a large woody rootstock and purple veined flowers.

Ornamental species easily recognized by its large green bird-like flowers and grey-tomentose thick soft-wooded stems (Moore 2005). Two subspecies are recognized: subsp. cunninghamii and subsp. sturtii.

Crotalaria heidmannii is a much-branched annual herb. It is easily confused with the large flower forms of C. sphaerocarpa. The is some doubt as to its distinction from C. stenopoda from Angola (Lebrun and Stork 2008).

Crotalaria johannis occurs just north of the range of C. variegata in Angola and it is not excluded that it might be an extreme variant of C. variegata (Polhill 1982). For the purposes of this assessment it is treated as a separate species.
Crotalaria naikiana Zate is now treated as a synonym of C. montana according to Ansari (2008) and this assessment is made using this revised taxonomy.
Dolichos schweinfurthii is an herbaceous perennial plant with fleshy annual stems and a woody root-stock.
Droogmansia pteropus is a perennial herb, sub shrub, shrub and rarely a small tree.
The name was originally spelled charlieriana but, by the present rules which seek to standardize the derivation of Latin epithets from modern surnames, the second “i” is omitted.
Indigofera hochstetteri is a spreading annual herb.
Indigofera oblongifolia is a perennial shrub.
Schrire (1997) described this species as closely related to Indigofera macrantha Harms from north Uganda and south Ethiopia.
Much-branched half-woody herb with pilose, brown, cylindrical branches.
Several subspecies and varieties of this species are recognized.

Lathyrus pallescens (Bieb.) Koch is in the section Lathyrostylis (Shehadeh et al. in prep). Following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 4 of the cultivated grass pea (L. sativus L.), chickling vetch (L. cicera L.), sweet pea (L. odoratus L.), Cyprus vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including broad-leaved everlasting pea (L. latifolius L.), caley pea (L. hirsutus L.), and Spanish vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

Lathyrus sphaericus Retz. is in the section Lineraicarpus (Shehadeh et al. in prep). Following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 4 of the cultivated grass pea (L. sativus L.), chickling vetch (L. cicera L.), sweet pea (L. odoratus L.), cyprus vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including broad-leaved everlasting pea (L. latifolius L.), caley pea (L. hirsutus L.), and Spanish vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

Lupinus bakeri is often considered difficult to differentiate from L. elegans. Usually the distinction is made based on the keel of L. elegans being ciliate opposed to glabrous and the tips of the leaflets being rounded and not acute as seen in L. bakeri (McVaugh 1987).
This species is gene pool secondary relative of Lupinus mutabilis Sweet (CWR 2016).

The genus Lupinus is considered one of the most taxonomically difficult groups in the Pacific northwest, this is generally due to factors and process such as hybridization, introgression and phenotypic plasticity.

Medicago secundiflora Durieu belongs to section Lupularia. It is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated crop black medic (M. lupulina L.), and a tertiary wild relative of cultivated alfalfa, M. sativa L. ssp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
Mimosa brachycarpa most closely resembles M. somnians, but they are distinguished on the dissection of the ovary (Barneby 1991).
Mimosa nuda is considered by Barneby (1991) to consist of five main varieties var. glaberrima, var. gracilipes, var. ramosa, var. angusta and var. nuda.

Ophrestia upembae (Hauman) Verdc. From the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Katanga Province) is very close with identical leaflet venation but finer twining stems and longer petioles (Pope et al. 2001).

Cytisus jankae was described as related to C. tmoleus and C. austriacus and it has been reported that C. pindicolus Halacsy of Albany and Greece is a form of the same species (Cristofolini 1991). However, C. pindicola Halacsy is a recognized synonym of C. austriacus and therefore not included on this assessment.

There are minor segregates from Cytisus that persist in local floristics such as Chamaecytisus, therefore the species has been found in Floras and reports as Chamaecytisus jankae (Velen.) Rothm. In this assessment has been followed Polhill and Van Wyk (2005), who in Legumes of the World re-included Chamaecytisus in Cytisus following Cristofolini (1991); Käss and Wink (1997); Cubas et al. (2002) and Wink and Mohamed (2003).

Trifolium angustifolium L. belongs to the section Trifolium, and is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated crops crimson clover (T. incarnatum L.), and red clover (Trifolium pratense L.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). The species has two varieties native to Europe: Trifolium angustifolium L. var. angustifolium and Trifolium angustifolium L. var. intermedium Gib. & Belli (Zohary and Heller 1980).
This species was described in 1999 (Pokle 1999).

This species has many synonyms. Chakrabarty and Gangopadhyay (1996) found in an examination of more than 500 herbarium specimens that it was impossible to maintain Acacia torta, A. diadenia and A. gageana as distinct from A. caesia.
Oxytropis shivai is now recognized as a synonym of O. cachemiriana.

An extremely variable species due mostly to the pubescence. It can be confused with Cullen martinii which has a shorter lower calyx-tooth and few dentate leaflets or with C. virens, which has much shorter leaflets.
Pterocarpus lucens is a deciduous tree between 7-18 m in height.
There are two known varieties var. glabrescens J.M.Black and  var. villifera.
Rhynchosia minima is exceedingly difficult to divide into lower taxa, its range of variation is very great and experimental techniques are needed (Gillett et al. 1971).

The taxonomy for this species is not precisely defined. The species is currently only known from a specimen (Drege #s.n.) collected in what is today KwaZulu-Natal province (South Africa). No further specimens or observations of this species are currently available, and this is mainly due to its taxonomic uncertainty (Baker 1923, African Plant Database version 3.3). Baker (1923) in his revision of the South African Rhyncosia species, inscribed R. nitida between the imperfectly known species, explaining that following the specimen (Drege #s.n.) description, in which the plant was described as having three seeds, it has to be excluded that it was a Rhyncosia species, as the ovary in that genus only has two ovules.
Two known varieties:  var. cannabina and var. sericea (Benth.) N.T.Burb.
Swartzia Schreb. is a genus of ca. 180 species of trees and shrubs that are prevalent in lowland Neotropical moist forests from southern Mexico to Bolivia and southern Brazil (Torke 2007).
Two recognized varieties: var. barbatala from Papua New Guinea and Queensland and var. glabra Bosman & De Haas from Papua New Guinea.

This is a complex taxon and in the past it has been confused with Tephrosia purpurea (L.) Pers., a species from Africa, Asia and northern Australia (Maconochie 1985). Further research is needed to determine whether Australian material is referable to T. purpurea. T. brachyodon is a variable species with several varieties. There is also some confusion between T. laxa var. angustata and T. brachyodon var. multiflora (R.Br.) Domin (Wheeler 1992). Further work is required to define taxon limits (I. Cowie pers. comm. 2010).
Loc and Vidal (2001) recognize Tephrosia siamensis as a synonym of this species.
Tephrosia paradoxa is closely allied to T. stormsii (Brummit 1968), with which it is apparently sympatric over a wide area.

There is some uncertainty about the taxonomic placement of this species, as it might be synonym of Tephrosia angustissima as suggested by Wunderlin and Hansen (2008), but is here treated as an accepted name until its taxonomic status is clarified.
Very closely related to Trifolium ochroleucum Huds. or to Trifolium pannonicum Jacq. and perhaps only part of a larger complex population (Gillett 2001).
Trifolium obscurum is easily differentiated from allied species by its short corolla and the shape of the equal calyx teeth (Zohary and Heller 1984).

Trifolium pratense L. belongs to section Trifolium and is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated crop crimson clover (T. incarnatum L.), as well as a primary wild relative of cultivated T. pratense (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

It has eight subspecies that are native to Europe: T. pratense ssp. baeticum (Boiss.) C. Vicioso, T. pratense ssp. expansum (Waldst. & Kit.) Hausskn., T. pratense ssp. kotulae (Pawl.) Soják, T. pratense ssp. maritimum (Zabel) Rothm., T. pratense ssp. nivale (W.D.J. Koch) Arcang., T. pratense L. ssp. pratense, T. pratense ssp. sativum (Schreb.) Schübl. & G.Martens, and T. pratense ssp. semipurpureum (Strobl) Pignatti. There are a further four varieties of T. pratense that are native to Europe: T. pratense var. americanum Harz, T. pratense var. frigidum Gaudin, var. T. pratense maritimum Zabel, and T. pratense var. pratense.

Trifolium scabrum displays some variation in morphological structure, however, it is distinguishable from its allies by the lanceolate and the broad and lignifies calyx teeth that are usually observed as erect or spear slightly sideways (Zohary and Heller 1984).

Trifolium subterraneum L. belongs to section Trichocephalum, and is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated species T. repens L. (white clover) and T. pratense L. (red clover) (Zohary and Heller 1984, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). It has three subspecies native to Europe: Trifolium subterraneum L. ssp. subterraneum, Trifolium subterraneum L. ssp. oxaloides Nyman and Trifolium subterraneum L. ssp. yanninicum Kayzn. & F. H. Morley (Euro+Med PlantBase 2010).
Vigna microsperma superficially resembles V. parkeri even though they are not closely related and they can be easily distinguished as all the flowers are in an apical cluster in V. microsperma.

Z. quilonensis was descibed as a new species of Zornia in 1969 (Ravi 1970), however, Pramanik (1990) notes that this species was originally described from peninsular India as Zornia angustifolia var. oblongifolia W & A. Pramanik (1990) considers that a specimen misidentified as Zornia diphylla (L.) Pers from West Bengal is Z. quilonensis and also that usually the identity of Z. quilonensis is confused with the Ceylonese species Z. walkeri Arnot. A specimen in the Edinburgh herbarium collected from India by R. Wight was determined as Z. gibbosa by Grierson, A.J.C and Long, D.G in 1978, but is now labelled as a syntype of Z angustifolia var. oblongifolia.
Avena murphyi Ladizinsky is a wild relative of oats, A. sativa L. and A. byzantina K. Koch.

In the Habitats Directive, Ornithogalum reverchonii is listed with the authority Degen & Herv.-Bass. This assessment was carried out under the assumption that this is a mistake and that the listed species refers to Ornithogalum reverchonii Lange.

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops crassa Boiss. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii.
Asparagus oligoclonos Maxim. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Asparagus (A. officinalis L.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Asparagus schoberioides Kunth is a secondary genetic relative of cultivated Asparagus (A. officinalis L.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Allium oliganthum Kar. & Kir. belongs to Taxon Group 2 of Chives A. schoenoprasum L. and Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don (Friesen et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2013).
Asparagus dauricus Fisch. ex Link is a secondary genetic relative of cultivated Asparagus (A. officinalis L.).

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops juvenalis (Thell.) Eig is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii.
Allium thunbergii G.Don belongs to Taxon Group 2 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don and Taxon Group 3 of Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2013).
Allium ledebourianum Schult. & Schult.f. belongs to Taxon Group 2 of Chives A. schoenoprasum L. and Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don (Friesen et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2013).

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops sharonensis Eig is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat Triticum aestivum subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat T. turgidum subsp. durum, and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon, Einkorn Wheat T. monococcum subsp. monococcum, Spelt T. aestivum subsp. spelta, and Sanduri Wheat T. timopheevii subsp. timopheevii.

Allium karelinii Polijakov is a tertiary wild relative of Onion A. cepa L; it also belongs to Taxon Group 2 of Chives A. schoenoprasum L. and Taxon Group 3 of A. chinense G.Don (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013).

In the literature this species is predominantly referred to as Allium semenovii Regel (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014, The Plant List 2014).

It belongs to Taxon Group 3 of both Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don and Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2013).
Helianthus argophyllus Torr. & A.Gray belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus atrorubens L. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus bolanderi is closely related, and morphologically similar, to H. exilis (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006) which is also sometimes referred to as the Aerpentine Sunflower (i.e. California Native Plant Society (CNPS) 2013).

It is belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and to Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus grosseserratus M.Martens belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and to Taxon Group two of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus maximiliani Schrad. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus neglectus Heiser belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus niveus (Benth.) Brandegee belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Helianthus nuttallii has three subspecies, H. nuttallii subsp. nuttallii, H. nuttallii subsp. rydbergi and H. nuttallii subsp. parishii. The former two are native to both Canada and the United States of America and the latter is thought only to occur in California.

This species belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus pauciflorus Nutt. has two subspecies: H. pauciflorus subsp. pauciflorus and H. pauciflorus subsp. subrhomboideus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

It belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus petiolaris Nutt. has two subordinate taxa: H. petiolaris subsp. fallax and H. petiolaris subsp. petiolaris (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus praecox has three subordinate taxa: H. praecox subsp. praecox, H. praecox subsp. runyonii and H. praecox subsp. hirtus (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).

The species belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

This species hybridizes with Helianthus tuberosus L. and has often been given the misapplied name H. tomentosus Michaux, especially in cultivation (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).

Helianthus resinosus Small belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus.
Helianthus salicifolius A.Dietr. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus tuberosus L. belongs to the Taxon Group 1b of the cultivated Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus. It also belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L.

Cucurbita okeechobeensis is a secondary genetic relative of Moschata Pumpkin/Squash (C. moschata) and Pepo Pumpkin/Squash (C. pepo), and a tertiary genetic relative of Cushaw (C. argyrosperma), Fig-leaf Gourd (C. ficifolia) and Maxima Pumpkin/Squash (C. maxima) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992). The taxonomy of the P. brucei complex has been recently revised. It is now represented by three subspecies, P. brucei brucei (Reiche 1849), P. brucei cyanostolus (d’Orbigny 1902), and the recently described P. brucei njombeensis Moretto 2004. Of several other species names formerly placed in synonymy with P. brucei, two have been reinstated as valid species, P. chalcostolus (d’Orbigny 1902) and P. cyanopterus (d’Orbigny 1904). Two further species in the complex have also been described in recent years, P. werneri Moretto & Nicolas 2002 and P. freyi Moretto 2004.
Warncke (1977) considered Dioxys atlantica as a subspecies of Dioxys cincta (Jurine, 1807).

Pseudoanthidium canariense is a species belonging to the subgenus Pseudoanthidium Friese, 1898 (Warncke 1980, Michener 2007, Ascher and Pickering 2012).


Warncke (1980) stated that Pseudoanthidium canariense should be the subspecies Anthidium lituratum canariense.
This species was described as a subspecies of S. phaeoptera (Kirby, 1802). Warncke (1992) still thought it was a synonym of the former. It belongs to the nominate subgenus.

The taxonomic status of Ammobates handlirschi (Friese, 1895), a close north African relative to A. dusmeti, needs to be confirmed by more comprehensive study, especially by methods of population biology based on DNA.
Osmia tenuispina in Stanek (1964) and Hoplitis tenuispina in Tkalcu (1977c, 2000a) are misidentifications of Hoplitis mazzuccoi (Gusenleitner and Schwarz 2002), see Schwarz et al. (2005).

Bombus butteli is closely similar to B. ecuadoris. They have been considered separated species (e.g., Franklin 1913, Milliron 1973b) although Franklin conceded that B. butteli might be ´only a variety of subspecies´ of B. ecuadorius. However, B. ecuadorius females are very rare in collections and only five specimens are known. Of these only one was a male, and is labelled 'Bolivia/?Peru', whereas the rest of Milliron's B. ecuadorius are from Ecuador, with the exception of one queen from 'Peru' with no specific locality data. This putative male also differs from the females in having yellow hairs intermixed on the front and rear of the thorax, what was not mentioned in the original description of this male (under the name B. nigrothoracicus) by Friese (1904), which Franklin (1923) then used as the sole basis for associating the male with B. ecuadorius. Another possible interpretation views the male holotype of B. nigrothoracicus instead as a semi melanic male of B. melaleucus, which might explain the difference in colour pattern and distribution from other B. ecuadorius. However, a consequence of this interpretation would be that the only remaining known difference between B. ecuadorius and B. butteli would be in colour pattern, because the main morphological justification for regarding them as a separate species (the broader apical process of the gonostylus of the putative male B. ecuadorius, now B. melaleucus in the broad sense) would have been removed. Further evidence is awaited (Paul Williams http://www.nhm.ac.uk/NHMUK 2013).

This species is synonymous with B. californicus, based on the lack of differentiation in DNA barcodes between individuals with this color pattern and those with the B. fervidus s. str. color pattern (Williams et al. 2014).

Williams (1998) and Williams et al. (2014) consider that Bombus intrudens, B. variabilis, B. sololensis, B. guatemalensis, and B. mysticus might all be parts of one species based on morphological evidence, noting the lack of any documented reason (other than differences in colour pattern) why these five taxa should not be considered conspecific. Further study is hampered by a lack of fresh material of North American B. variabilis for analysis of genetic relationships. Although B. intrudens is the oldest available name for this species, the name B. variabilis has been in common use for the species since 1950, and it could be argued that the latter name be used in the interest of stability (Williams 1998).

Williams (2014) provides a detailed review of the taxonomic status of this species. In short, a number of authors have regarded this species as conspecific with B. auricomus, while other authors have treated them as separate. Williams (2014) and Williams et al. (2014) considers them separate based on morphological and colour patterns (Williams 1998), allozymes (Scholl et al. 1992), and DNA sequence data (Cameron et al. 2007, and more recent unpublished work).

Recent DNA barcodes support that Bombus sonorus is conspecific with B. pensylvanicus (Williams et al. 2014). A population from the south of Mexico (state of Chiapas) is morphologically and genetically distinct from the rest of North America, and could be a separate undescribed species. Further sampling is needed to clarify the situation.

Bombus robustus is closely similar in morphology to B. vogti, but has been considered a separate species (e.g., Milliron 1973b, Asperen de Boear 2007). Bombus vogti and B. robustus are usually separated using colour. Although B. rosbustus is variable in colour, the name is applied to individuals with extensive yellow bands, whereas the name B. vogti is used for individuals that lack yellow bands and are often most completely black. There is still very little material available about males of these species, although there are slight differences in the morphology of the genitalia. While awaiting more evidence from critical studies of patterns of variation, these species are treated separately (http://www.nhm.ac.uk/bombus, Williams 2013).

Included in Amblysomus by Simonetta (1968), Meester (1974), Petter (1981) and Meester et al. (1986). Bronner (1995a, 1995b) elevated it to the genus Neamblysomus and retained it as such (Bronner 2013). Externally this species resembles the Hottentot Golden Mole (A. hottentotus) and the Highveld Golden Mole (A. septentrionalis), and has been misidentified as such by some authors. There are no recognised subspecies.

Traditionally recognized as a subspecies of the Zulu Golden Mole (A. iris - a species now incorporated into A. hottentotus and A. corriae). Bronner (1996) raised septentrionalis to a full species based on unique chromosomal and craniometric properties. No subspecies currently recognized (Bronner and Jenkins 2005), but A. orangensis from Parys/Heilbron Free State Province, may qualify for subspecies status pending the availability of chromosomal and genetic data.

Previously described as a subspecies of A. hottentotus, this species is now recognised as a
distinct species, and differs from other taxa in cranial measurements (Bronner 1996). Currently, no subspecies of A. marleyi have been described.

Previously included in A. hottentotus; but elevated to a full species by Bronner (2000) based on unique karyotype, robust build and subtle craniometric differences from A. hottentotus and A. septentrionalis. No subspecies have been identified (Skinner & Chimimba 2005).

The species Amblysomus corriae now includes two groups previously classified as the subspecies Amblysomus iris corriae and Amblysomus hottentotus devilliersi (Meester et al. 1986). Amblysomus iris was subsequently reclassified as a subspecies of A. hottentotus, and corriae was elevated to species level, including the subspecies devilliersi (Bronner 1996). Currently two subspecies are recognised: A. c. corriae from the Western and Eastern Cape, and A. c. devilliersi from the Western Cape (Bronner 1995, 2013).

Bronner (1995, 2013) assigned this species to the genus Neamblysomus. Consistent colour, dental and DNA differences exist between the topotypical subpopulations from the eastern (Kruger National Park) and western geographical extremes (Bronberg Ridge and Modimolle) of its distributional range suggesting that these are potentially distinct species (Bronner 1990, 1995). Furthermore, ongoing molecular research suggests pronounced genetic partitioning between the Kruger National Park (KNP) and the other two subpopulations (Maree et al. 2003; Jackson 2007). More specimens from the KNP area are urgently needed to clarify the taxonomic status of this subpopulation. The outcome could have profound implications for the conservation status of the species

Some authors (Ellerman et al. 1953; Simonetta 1968) treated this taxon as only a subspecies of C. sclateri, but consistent differences in fur colour and chromosomal properties, and their preference for quite dissimilar ecotypes, indicate that they are distinct species (Bronner 1995). A recent phylogenetic analysis supports distinction between these species based on subtle morphological differences (the position of foramen ovale relative to the sphenorbital fissure) and nuclear gene sequences (Asher et al. 2010). Geographic variation is not sufficiently marked to warrant recognition of subspecies (Bronner 2013).

Although previously included within the genus Amblysomus by Petter (1981), the group, currently listed under the genus Chlorotalpa, were found to differ significantly in morphological, chromosomal and geographic traits (Meester 1974), and thus those genera are considered distinct (Skinner & Chimimba 2005). Based on geographic variation and cranial size and shape, four subspecies have been recognized: C. s. sclateri, C. s. guillarmodi, C. s. montana, and C. s. shortridgei (Bronner 2013). The apparent geographic discontinuity between these subspecies and the isolation of their preferred habitat appears to warrant this subspecific separation (Bronner 1995).

Traditionally taken to include populations that Bronner (1996, 2000) recognized as valid species, namely A. septentrionalis, A. robustus, A. marleyi and A. corriae (in part). Amblysomus hottentotus includes five subspecies: hottentotus, pondoliae, iris, longiceps and meesteri (Bronner 1995, 2013). Recent cytogenetic and molecular analyses show that A. h. longiceps and A. h. meesteri are unique lineages and will likely be elevated to species status (Gilbert et al. 2008; Mynhardt et al. 2015). Furthermore recent analyses using mitochondrial DNA reveal several evolutionarily significant units in the Greater Maputaland–Pondoland–Albany region (Mynhardt et al. 2015), and thus demonstrate A. hottentotus to comprise a species complex.

Aardvarks were originally thought to be congeneric with the South American anteaters (Myrmecophaga), until they were put in their own genus: Orycteropus. After 1872, aardvarks were also put in their own order: the Tubulidentata. But this order was long considered to be closely related to the Xenarthrans and the pangolins in the now obsolete clade "Edentata" (Lehmann 2007). It is only since the beginning of the 20th century, that aardvarks have been considered to be basal "ungulates". It was also at this time that the seven then recognized species were merged into the single species Orycteropus afer (Shoshani et al. 1988). Since then, Tubulidentata is the only order of Mammals to be represented by a single living species. To date, 18 subspecies have been described (Meester 1971). However, their validity is doubtful and studies in this regard are ongoing. Finally, at the turn of the millennium, molecular phylogenetic analyses integrated the aardvarks into the new super-cohort Afrotheria, next to elephants, hyraxes, sea-cows, sengis, tenrecs, and golden moles.

Lundholm (1955) created the subgenus Kilimatalpa within Chlorotalpa for this species, whereas Simonetta (1968) placed it in the genus Carpitalpa , but assigned one subspecies (tropicalis) to the genus Chlorotalpa. Meester (1974) included stuhlmanni in Chrysochloris, an arrangement followed by Bronner (1995) who assigned it to the subgenus Kilimatalpa. Recent (but still unpublished) phylogenetic analyses support elevation of  Kilimatalpa to generic rank.  There are four recognized subspecies, at least one of which, balsaci from Cameroon, may be a distinct species (Bronner and Jenkins 2005).

Provisionally includes Kilimatalpa as a subgenus (Bronner 1995), although recent (but still unpublished) phylogenetic analyses suggest that Kilimatalpa should be recognized as a separate genus; see comments under C. stuhlmanni.

Up to ten subspecies have previously been recognized, but size and colour varies clinally, hence validity of these taxa is dubious (Meester et al. 1986). The only known specimen of damarensis may have been incorrectly labelled as no Chrysochloris have subsequently been collected in Damaraland, Namibia (Meester 1986).

In the past the single family was included in the order Insectivora, but now the family is in the monophyletic order Macroscelidea and the newly created super-cohort Afrotheria. Currently, there are 19 living species recognized in four genera. The soft-furred Sengis or elephant-shrews include three genera: Petrodromus is monospecific, Macroscelides has three species, and Elephantulus contains 11 species. The four species of giant Sengis belong to the genus Rhynchocyon. The common name “Sengi” is being used in place of elephant-shrew by many biologists to try and disassociate the Macroscelidea from the true shrews (family Soricidae) in the order Soricomorpha. See the IUCN SSC Afrotheria Specialist Group web site and www.sengis.org for additional information. For general biological information, please consult Perrin and Rathbun (2013) and Rathbun (2005, 2013).

In the past the single family was included in the order Insectivora, but now the family is in the monophyletic order Macroscelidea and the newly created super-cohort Afrotheria. Currently, there are 19 living species recognized in four genera. The soft-furred sengis or elephant-shrews include three genera:  Petrodromus is monospecific, Macroscelides has three species, and Elephantulus contains 11 species. The four species of giant sengis belong to the genus Rhynchocyon. The common name "sengi" is being used in place of elephant-shrew by many biologists to try and disassociate the Macroscelidea from the true shrews (family Soricidae) in the order Soricomorpha. See the Afrotheria Specialist Group web site and www.sengis.org for additional information.

Monotypic. Lundholm (1955) described this taxon as a subgenus of Chlorotalpa, as well as the subgenus Kilimatalpa for C. stuhlmanni from east Africa. Simonetta (1968) elevated Carpitalpa to generic rank to include Kilimatalpa. Meester (1974) instead assigned C. arendsi to Chlorotalpa and C. stuhlmanni to Chrysochloris, commenting that differences between the Chlorotalpa species did not warrant subgeneric separation. Phylogenetic analyses of morphometric data (Bronner 1995), and recent phylogenetic analyses based on both morphological and genetic data (Asher et al. 2010) confirm that C. arendsi has diverged considerably from the Chlorotalpa species and Chrysochloris (Kilimatalpa) stuhlmanni, necessitating its allocation to a distinct genus,

In the past the single family was included in the order Insectivora, but now the family is in the monophyletic order Macroscelidea and the newly created super-cohort Afrotheria. Currently, there are 19 living species recognized in four genera. The soft-furred sengis or elephant-shrews include three genera: Petrodromus is monospecific, Macroscelides has three species, and Elephantulus contains 11 species. The four species of giant sengis belong to the genus Rhynchocyon. The common name “sengi” is being used in place of elephant-shrew by many biologists to try and disassociate the Macroscelidea from the true shrews (family Soricidae) in the order Soricomorpha. See the IUCN SSC Afrotheria Specialist Group web site and www.sengis.org for additional information.

In the past the single family was included in the order Insectivora, but now the family is in the monophyletic order Macroscelidea and the newly created super-cohort Afrotheria. Currently, there are 19 living species recognized in four genera. The soft-furred sengis or elephant-shrews include three genera: Petrodromus is monospecific, Macroscelides has three species, and Elephantulus contains 11 species. The four species of giant sengis belong to the genus Rhynchocyon. The common name “sengi” is being used in place of elephant-shrew by many biologists to try and disassociate the Macroscelidea from the true shrews (family Soricidae) in the order Soricomorpha. See the IUCN SSC Afrotheria Specialist Group web site and www.sengis.org for additional information.
Originally, Chrysospalax was created as a subgenus, with Chrysochloris trevelyani as type species (Poduschka 1980). Presently, no subspecies have been described.

Meester (1974) listed six subspecies distinguished mainly by subtle differences in pelage colour: villosus, transvaalensis, leschae, dobsoni, rufopallidus and rufus. The validity of these subspecies is uncertain (Bronner 2013).

While Warncke considers Andrena fulvata as a subspecies of A. angustior, Andrena angustior fulvata Stöckhert, 1930, almost all the other authors after him recognize Andrena fulvata as a distinct species (E. Scheuchl pers. comm. 2014), and this will be the criteria applied for the purposes of this assessment.

This species is included in the EC Habitats Directive (EEC 1992) as Narcissus humilis but that is not a legitimate name. It is therefore treated here as Narcissus cavanillesii Barra & G.López (The Plant List 2017, Aedo 2013).

Orchis “sezikiana” is a controversial taxa, variously considered as a subsp. of O. quadripuctata, a subsp. of O. anatolica, as an hybrid between both, or as an autonomous species. It was described in southwestern Turkey where O. quadripuctata is not known and given for Cyprus also where O. quadripunctata is also not known. Some hybrids reported from Crete or Greece have been named sezikiana but probably erroneously because of a convergence.

From review of Orchis literature (e.g., Kretzschmar et al. 2007) and Greek (Petrou et al. 2011, Alibertis 2015) or Turkish / Cypriot (Kreutz 1998, 2004), the true sezikiana from Turkey is not O. quadripunctata s.s. nor s.l. It could be a paleohybridogenic species, more or less stabilized, possibly different between typical southwestern Turkish and convergent Cypriot populations? Orchis genus monographs in all cases consider them as an eastern subsp. of O. quadripuncata, however we do not follow this approach here.

In Albania the species hybridizes with Orchis pauciflora forming the hybrid of Orchis pauciflora x O. quadripunctata, firstly reported by Golz and Reinhard (1984) in the Llogora Pass and recently from the Sotira Village in Gjirokastra district (L. Shuka pers. comm. 2016).
Hordeum pusillum Nutt. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum euclaston Steud. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum parodii Covas is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
O. ridleyi Hook. f is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).
Hordeum pubiflorum Hook.f is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Eleusine floccifolia Spreng. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Finger Millet E. coracana (L.) Gaertn. (Phillips 1972).
Hordeum fuegianum Bothmer, N.Jacobsen & R.B.Jørg. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum brachyantherum Nevski is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer 1995).
Hordeum cordobense Bothmer, N.Jacobsen & Nicora is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Eleusine tristachya (Lam.) Lam. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Finger Millet E. coracana (L.) Gaertn. (Phillips 1972).
H. halophilum Griseb. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Avena abyssinica Hochst. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of A. sativa L.
Eleusine kigeziensis S.M.Phillips is a primary wild relative of Finger Millet E. coracana (L.) Gaertn. (Phillips 1972).
Hordeum jubatum L. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum procerum Nevski is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum comosum J.Presl is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum flexuosum Steud. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).

Since Pascoe’s 1877 description, Hadramphus tuberculatus has been included in three genera and is synonymous with two names in the literature. Pascoe originally placed Hadramphus tuberculatus in the genus Lyperobius (Pascoe 1877), but in Kuschel’s 1971 revision the species was moved to Hadramphus Broun (Kuschel 1971). Kuschel later erected the genus Karocolens to include the type species K.  pittospori (a Molytine weevil from the Poor Knights Islands, NZ) (Kuschel 1987).  In 1999 however, Craw re-instated Karocolens  pittospori within Hadramphus (Craw 1999) and Karocolens is now synonymised with Hadramphus.

This species has three subspecies:
T. mairii mairii (Gray, 1841)
T. mairii brongersmai Malnate & Underwood, 198)
T. mairii plumbea (Macleay, 1877).

T. m. brongersmai and T. m. plumbea are likely to be synonymous because of similar distribution.

Longstanding taxonomic issues (summarized by Wüster et al. 2005) exist within Acanthophis , with the names A. praelongus and A. antarcticus having been widely used to encompass both Australian and New Guinean taxa, including a number of Australian populations flagged as being distinct (Wüster et al. 2005). These authors provide the first modern phylogenetic framework for analyzing variation in the genus, and attribute Northern Territory and northern Queensland representatives of their 'clade A1' to the Acanthophis rugosus complex, a form shared with New Guinea and previously treated as a subspecies of A. antarcticus, although the name A. praelongus is still applied to this group by some authors (Wilson and Swan 2013). This clade is itself divided into two broadly sympatric forms and Wüster et al. (2005) note that the oldest name available for the second clade is Acanthophis hawkei. Although these authors refrain from considering this taxon a separate species and no subsequent taxonomic work appears to have validated it, Threatened Species Scientific Committee (2012) state that "[Acanthophis hawkei] is conventionally accepted as a distinct species". Subsequent work found that a Kimberley form, which had long been assumed to belong to the A. rugosus complex but not previously included in comparative analysis, warranted recognition as a distinct species related to A. pyrrhus (Maddock et al. 2015), to which Maddock et al. (2015) gave the name A. cryptadrymos. Detailed systematic research is required to resolve outstanding issues within this complex, as molecular approaches alone may be insufficient and a number of candidate species within the group exhibit sympatric or parapatric distributions (Wüster et al. 2005).

Six different subspecies have been recognized in Australia (Barker and Barker 1994), largely based on colour pattern, although the boundaries between many of these are fluid and poorly defined (Cogger 2014). Of there only Morelia spilota imbricata is supported by genetic data and geographic isolation.

This status of populations assigned to this species in New Guinea is unclear (O'Shea 2007). Seven subspecies are typically recognized; the elevation of several to species level by Hoser (2000) was made without comment and has been rejected by subsequent workers (Schleip and O'Shea 2010). Hoser's proposed subspecies Morelia spilota harrisoni is poorly-defined, being based on a small sample with variable characters that overlap with previously recognized M. spilota subspecies, and is considered invalid by Schleip and O'Shea (2010). Additionally, it has been argued that the name Morelia harrisoni was not validly published (Kaiser et al. 2013). Pending resolution of taxonomic issues within New Guinea carpet pythons, it has recently been proposed that all New Guinea representatives of this species should be regarded as M. s. variegata sensu lato (forthcoming New Guinea python book).

The genus Cyptochirus Lesne, 1900 was recently revalidated from synonymy with Drepanocerus. It is currently considered to comprise four closely related Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009). However, there may be some confusion in the taxonomy of these described taxa.
The genus Epirinus currently comprises 29 species (ScarabNet 2009) with a combined distribution restricted primarily to the coolest climates of South Africa.
The genus Heteronitis Gillet 1911 is restricted to the savannas of Africa where it currently comprises five valid species (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 18, which is widespread throughout lowland to upland drier savannas of the Afrotropical region on both deep sands and finer-grained soils.

The previous taxonomic concept for N. mirabilis included N. rowanae and N. tenax. N. rowanae was reinstated as a separate species in 2005 (Clarke and Kruger 2005), andN. tenax was described as a separate species in 2006 (Clarke and Kruger 2006).

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species is in Onitis Group 12 that comprises only two species. O. parainflaticollis was only described in 1977, possibly due to its rarity.

The species was named as Lutra perspicillata by Geoffroy 1826 and as Lutrogale perspicillata by Gray 1865. Two subspecies were reported (Pocock 1941) (1) L. p. perspicillata - in northeast and southern India, Myanmar and Sumatra; and (2) L. p. sindica - in north and northwestern India and Pakistan. Another subspecies L. p. maxwelli, whose current status is uncertain, is reported from the marshes of southern Iraq (Mason and Macdonald 1986).

Seven subspecies were reported by Pocock (1941) (1) L. l. lutra in Europe and northern Africa; (2) L. l. nair in southern India and Sri Lanka; (3) L. l. monticola in northern India (Himachal Pradesh, Sikkim and Assam) Nepal, Bhutan and Myanmar; (4) L. l. kutab in northern India - Kashmir; (5) L. l. aurobrunnea in Garhwal Himalayas in northern India and higher altitudes in Nepal; (6) L. l. barang in southeast Asia (Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia); and (7) L. l. chiensis in southern China and Taiwan. Imaizumi and Yoshiyuki (1989) considered Japanese Otters a distinct species (L. nippon). It is treated separately by Wozencraft in Wilson and Reeder (2005), but that approach is not followed here pending further review.

Lutra sumatrana was first described by Raffles in 1822 as Lutra barang; by Gray in 1865 as Barangia sumatrana; and Lutra lovii by Gunther 1876. Pohle (1920) identified two subspecies L. s. lovii and L. s. brunnea. However, there is dispute about its authenticity (Pocock 1941). Recent genetic studies have confirmed it as a single species related to Lutra lutra (Koepfli et al. 2008).

Wozencraft (2005) regarded this species as conspecific with the congeneric Congo Clawless Otter A. congicus. The two are here retained as distinct species (see van Zyll de Jong 1972, Wozencraft 1993, Somers and Nel 2013). Only one subspecies has been recognised within the assessment region (Meester et al. 1986), reaching as far north as Zambia and Angola (Skinner & Chimimba 2005).

The spelling of the species epithet in Aonyx cinerea (Illiger, 1815) was incorrect; the genus name 'Aonyx' is masculine  and hence the adjectival species name 'cinerea' should be changed to have a masculine ending. The species is now correctly named as A. cinereus (Illiger, 1815). Also referred to as Amblonyx cinereus (Illiger, 1815), Amblonyx concolor Rafinesque, 1832 and Amblonyx cinerea by Pocock 1941. Two subspecies were reported (Pocock 1941) (1) A. c. concolor in northeast India, Myanmar extending to Sumatra and (2) A. c. nirnai in the hill ranges of southern India (Hussain et al. 2011).
