Rausch and Rausch (1995) examined karyotypic and morphological characteristics of shrews on Saint Lawrence Island and the Alaskan mainland and found no significant differences; they concluded that S. jacksoni should be regarded as a subspecies of S. cinereus. Van Zyll de Jong (in Wilson and Ruff 1999) recognized S. jacksoni as a species. A study of mtDNA variation by Demboski and Cook (2003) found that S. jacksoni and S. cinereus are not sister species. The North American mammal checklist by Baker et al. (2003) cited Demboski and Cook (2003) in regarding S. jacksoni as a valid species.

Formerly reported as Sorex minutus. Taxonomic status of Sorex dehli, which was descriebd from Crimea but subsequently shifted to S. volnuchini (Hutterer 2005) requires re-examination. Russian authors synonymized dahli with minutus.
Previously misidentified as S. cinereus, but now recognized as a distinct species based on numerous morphological characters by Rausch, Feagin and Rausch, 2007.
This species is still subject to taxonomic controversy, with little conclusive information currently available for the species (Hutterer 2005).

Alexander (1996) conducted a morphometric analysis of skulls and determined that the shrew heretofore known as Sorex obscurus neomexicanus, Sorex vagrans neomexicanus, or Sorex monticolus neomexicanus should be recognized as a distinct species, S. neomexicanus. This shrew was considered a subspecies of Sorex monticolus by George, in Wilson and Ruff (1999). MtDNA data of Demboski and Cook (2001) are not consistent with recognition of S. neomexicanus as a distinct species; instead, S. neomexicanus was nested phylogenetically within various populations of S. monticolus from southwestern North America. Nevertheless, Baker et al. (2003) followed Alexander in recognizing S. neomexicanus as a distinct species, as did Hutterer (in Wilson and Reeder 2005). Kays and Wilson (2009) also state that S. neomexicanus is a distinct species.

Sorex orizabae was included as a subspecies of vagrans by Hennings and Hoffmann (1977), and later included as a subspecies of oreopolus by Junge and Hoffmann (1981), but most recently is considered a separate species by Carraway (2007).
Talpa streeti is considered to be a synonym of Talpa davidiana (Krystufek et al. 2001).
Molecular evidence suggests that T. levantis contains two allopatric cryptic species of unresolved nomenclature (Bannikova et al. 2015).

Wang (2003) placed this species in the genus Nasillus. Both U. atronates and U. nivatus were named as subspecies of U. andersoni, but Hoffmann (1984) assigned them to U. gracilis. Wang (2003) recognized a number of described and undescribed subspecies, but the status of these needs to be addressed in the context of a wider systematic revision.
Previously included in Uropsilus gracilis, but separated based on form and distribution (Smith and Xie 2008).
This species was originally described as Nesoscaptor uchidai, but Motokawa et al. (2001) recognized a close relationship to Mogera insularis.
Hutterer (2005) considers robusta as a synonym of M. wogura of Japan, but they are treated as separate species here. The taxonomy of Mogera is complex and further clarification is required.
Populations of this species from east Honshu and west Honshu plus Shikoku exhibit considerable genetic differences (Tsuchiya et al. 2000).
This taxon is sometimes regarded as a subspecies of Mogera tokudae (see Hutterer 2005), but sufficient karyotypic differences exist to warrant species recognition.
This may be a species complex of lenguarum and probably includes some synonyms which are valid species.
Synonyms of this species include Phyllotis garleppi. It is a monotypic species (Salazar-Bravo 2015).
The species authority is not Hodgson, 1849, as is entrenched in the literature (see Musser and Carleton 2005).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Neodon irene is sometimes referred to as a synonym of N. sikimensis (Smith and Xie 2008).
Sometimes included as a subspecies of Neodon irene, with which it is morphologically similar (Smith and Xie 2008). Allen (1940) indicated that this form may only be a southern subspecies of N. irene.

This species was previously recognized as a subspecies of D. groenlandicus. Dicrostonyx taxonomy is complex and not well resolved. The complex was regarded as part a single circumpolar species, D. torquatus, until the 1970s when karyological and breeding studies indicated the possible existence of a superspecies complex among North American Dicrostonyx (Rausch and Rausch 1972, Rausch 1977, see also Krohne, 1982). Former subspecies occurring in western Canada and Alaska were recognized as separate species based mainly on karyotypes (Rausch and Rausch 1972; Rausch 1977; Krohne 1982; Honacki et al. 1982; Jones et al. 1986, 1992). Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) reviewed these and subsequent studies and recognized eight Dicrostonyx species, six of which (groenlandicus, hudsonius, nelsoni, nunatakensis, richardsoni, and unalascensis) occur in North America; this is the taxonomy adopted here. Baker et al. (2003) recognized D. exsul, D. kilangmiutak, and D. rubricatus as species, but Musser and Carleton recognized exsul as a synonym of D. nelsoni, and kilangmiutak and rubricatus were treated as synonyms of D. groenlandicus.

This species was previously recognized as a subspecies of D. groenlandicus. Dicrostonyx taxonomy is complex and not well resolved. The complex was regarded as part a single circumpolar species, D. torquatus, until the 1970s when karyological and breeding studies indicated the possible existence of a superspecies complex among North American Dicrostonyx (Rausch and Rausch, 1972; Rausch, 1977; see also Krohne, 1982). Former subspecies occurring in western Canada and Alaska were recognized as separate species based mainly on karyotypes (Rausch and Rausch, 1972; Rausch, 1977; Krohne, 1982; Honacki et al., 1982; Jones et al., 1986, 1992). Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) reviewed these and subsequent studies and recognized eight Dicrostonyx species, six of which (groenlandicus, hudsonius, nelsoni, nunatakensis, richardsoni, and unalascensis) occur in North America; this is the taxonomy adopted here. Baker et al. (2003) recognized D. exsul, D. kilangmiutak, and D. rubricatus as species, but Musser and Carleton recognized exsul as a synonym of D. nelsoni, and kilangmiutak and rubricatus were treated as synonyms of D. groenlandicus.
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).
The genus need taxonomic revision; this taxa could be two species.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This rodent was formally considered to be a synonym of D. dorsalis, it was recognized as a species in 1995.
his species is monotypic (Paresque and Hanson 2015). Previously it has been considered synonymous with Oligoryzomys transitorious.

Earlier retained as a species as described (Cabrera 1961, Gyldenstolpe, 1932), but swept under Hershkovitz’s (1962) broad concept of callosus and provisionally retained as such by Musser and Carleton (1993). Olds (1988, also Anderson 1997) recognized C. venustus as separate from C. callosus proper, and defined it broadly to include boliviae and fecundus in Bolivia and NW Argentina (also see account of C. boliviae); others have more narrowly applied the name to the C Argentinian populations (e.g., Salazar-Bravo et al. 2001, 2002a; Vitullo et al. 1990) as distinct from fecundus (here = C. boliviae). Banded chromosomal comparisons with C. callidus provided by Vitullo et al. (1990), who considered the two, along with fecundus (here = C. boliviae) to form a closely related group, as did Espinosa et al. (1997). Salazar-Bravo et al. (2002a) similarly recognized a callosus venustus clade, also embracing callidus and fecundus as species, although the taxa represented in these studies are not entirely equivalent.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is monotypic (Patton 2015)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":15037,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica","16":10}">This species is monotypic (Patton 2015).
This species has sometimes been included in the genus Maresomys. Two subspecies are recognized.

Systematists have debated synonymy between viewed olivaceus and xanthorhinus. Based on apparent morphological and ecological separation in local settings, some systematists consider them distinct (Osgood 1943, Patterson et al. 1984, Pearson 1995) whereas others consider olivaceus as a polytypic species, also including southern xanthorhinus, based on broader regional trends of morphological and morphometric variation (Mann 1978, Yañez et al. 1978). Recent work with transects between where Valdivian rainforest (olivaceus morphotype) transitions into Patagonian steppe (xanthorhinus morphotype) have given evidence of demic intergradation, which strongly supports the synonymy argument (Smith et al. 2001, Pearson and Smith 1999). This assessment includes the species known as A. llanoi, A. mansoensis, A. xanthorhinus, A. hershkovitzi and A. markhami.
This is a species complex, and the relationship of this species with other Abrothrix needs further taxonomic research and revision (H. Zeballos, N. Bernal and B. Patterson pers. comm.).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This species is monotypic (Percequillo 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).

Deltamys has been considered a subgenus of Akodon (Ellerman 1940, Cabrera 1961) and alternatively as a genus (Gyldenstolpe 1932, Massoia 1980). Genus status was determined based on morphological (Bianchini and Delupi 1994, Gonzalez and Massoia 1995) and genetic (Smith and Patton 1999) characteristics. Previous Red List assessment conducted as Akodon kempi.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Thalpomys lasiotis type specimen belongs to the genus Bolomys, the correct name for this species should be T. reinhardti (Bonvicino and Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).

This species is included in the Phyllotini, but the tribal position of this species needs to be reviewed (H. Zeballos pers. comm.). There is a need to review the taxonomic status of the two subspecies (H. Zeballos pers. comm.).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Wiedomys pyrrhorhinos has been variously classified as a species of Oryzomys or Thomasomys (see Musser and Carleton 2005).

This taxon was described as a subspecies of Phyllotis darwini, but it was considered a distinct species by Reig (1978) and Galliari et al. (1996); determination of status and distribution requires further investigation (Musser and Carleton 2005). This species is monotypic. Molecularly, P. bonariensis is included within a widespread clade. A more thorough geographic sampling of these taxa is required to resolve species-level boundaries within this clade (Steppan and Ramirez 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Steppan and Ramirez 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Steppan and Ramirez 2015).
Further taxonomic studies into the subspecies of P. osilae are needed (H. Zeballos pers. comm.).

This is a species complex which needs taxonomic revision (H. Zeballos and N. Bernal pers. comm.). The taxonomic status of the species in Cordoba, San Luis and Santiago del Estero (Argentina) needs to be reviewed (U. Pardinas pers. comm).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Bonvicino (1994) considers Nectomys grandis to be a different species. Nectomys magdalenae has been synonymized with Nectomys grandis (Bonvicino and Weksler 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Previously recognized as a subspecies of M. montanus; electrophoretic and cytological evidence confirm its specific status (Modi 1986).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae. Species was split, to give new species M. kermanensis (Golenishchev et al. 2000).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Volemys (Smith and Xie 2008).

Some authors have considered M. abbreviatus to be conspecific with M. miurus of the Alaskan mainland. Jones et al. (1992), Baker et al. (2003), and Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005) recognize M. abbreviatus and M. miurus as distinct species. According to Weksler et al. (2005) this species is recognized as a cospecies with M. miurus.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species was formerly listed as a subspecies of M. arvalis (Musser and Carleton 2005).

authority: Golenishchev, Malikov, Nazari, Vaziri, Sablina & Polyakov, 2003
taxonomicNotes: The species has the same karyotype of Microtus guentheri, but did not hybridize with that species during experiments (Golenishchev et al. 2003). The population of voles that comprises M. qazvinensis was previously assigned to Microtus irani.
The species consists of two allopatric chromosomal races (“arvalis” and “obscurus”: Wilson and Reeder 2005) which are now reported as two distinct species (Tourgard et al. 2013).
Lasiopodomys fuscus was formerly included in Pitymys leucurus (Smith and Xie 2008).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Previously, this species was included within Aepeomys lugens.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is monotypic (Voss 2015)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":15037,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica","16":10}">This species is monotypic (Voss 2015).
Teta et al. (2004) have suggested that Bibimys torresi may be conspecific with B. labiosus based on morphological and molecular analysis. This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).

Generic synonyms Akodon, Scapteromys. Formerly in Muridae family. Described as a species of Akodon; transferred to Bibimys by Massoia (1980), who noted the need to clarify the differentiation of this form from B. torresi. This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
Whitaker and Hamilton (1998) recommended that subspecies nigrescens and struix be regarded as synonyms of alleni.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Synonym = Z. borreroi.

Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Was in the Red List under the genus Oryzomys.

Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Weksler and Bonvicino 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Weksler and Bonvicino 2015).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Weksler and Bonvicino 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Weksler and Bonvicino 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Oligoryzomys delticola and O. eliurus are likely synonyms of O. nigripes (see Weksler and Bonvicino 2005).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Pacheco (2003) suggested that Thomasomys paramorum might be a species complex, based on some geographic polymorphism in several characters (Pacheco 2015).

Recent studies suggest that T. baeops may be composed of more than one taxon (Pacheco 2003; Lee et al. 2011; Pacheco 2015). However, see Lee et al. (2015) because some of the taxonomic confusion involves T. taczanowskii that can cause problems with identification between it a T. baeops. Some specimens from farther north in Colombia are not included, but are part of the baeops species complex and are pending taxonomic review (M. Gómez-Laverde and V. Pacheco pers. comm.). Different species of this group are present in central part of the Cordilleras Central of Colombia (M. Gómez-Laverde pers. comm.).
This species was formerly included in the Thomasomys aureus complex. Currently it is accepted as a different species (Pacheco 2003, Voss 2003).
Voss (2003) considered Thomasomys hudsoni a valid species, contrasting it with T. cinnameus and T. gracili. Pacheco (2003, 2015) provided a full set of morphological characters for the species.

Initially, Thomasomys vulcani was considered as a subspecies or synonym of Aepeomys lugens (Musser and Carleton 1993, Cabrera 1961). Later, Pacheco (in Voss et al. 2002) considered it to be a form of Thomasomys proper. Additional comparisons including the holotype of rhoadsi Stone prompted to recognize that rhoadsi is a junior synonym of T. vulcani (Pacheco 2015).
Generic synonym Phyllotis. Synonyms include Graomys griseoflavus medius (Cabrera 1961). This is a monotypic species (Braun and Patton 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Formerly in the genus Clethrionomys, which is here considered a synonym of Myodes. There is debate whether the populations on Daikoku and Rebun islands represent a separate species, Myodes sikotanensis (Musser and Carleton 2005, Abe et al., 2005). Specimens identified from China as regulus belong to this species. M. regulus is now considered to be endemic to the Korean Peninsula (Musser and Carleton 2005).
Was included as a synonym of Clethrionomys rufocanus, but recognized as a separate species by Wakana et al. (1996) on the basis of molecular study.
The two subspecies of this species are debated and need futher research to be validated, R. cariri cariri and R. cariri baturiteensis (Costa et al. 2011).

Wang (2003) recognized five subspecies: 1) Eothenomys custos cangshanensis Wang and Li 2000; Yunnan (Cang mountain of Dali); 2) E. c. custos (Thomas, 1912); NW Yunnan; 3) E. c. hintoni Osgood, 1932; W Sichuan; 4) E. c. ninglangensis Wang and Li, 2000; N Yunnan, S Sichuan; 5) E. c. rubellus (Allen, 1924); N Yunnan (Smith and Xie 2008).
Eothenomys chinensis is the type species of Anteliomys, which is in turn a synonym of Eothenomys (Musser and Carleton 2005).
Eothenomys wardi was formerly included in E. chinensis (Smith and Xie 2008).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

The distribution limits between this species and O. amazonicus need to be reviewed (B. Patterson pers. comm.). This treatment includes O. juliacae which may be a distinct species (H. Zeballos and B. Patterson pers. comm.).
This new species of Proedromys is distinguished from P. bedfordi by external and cranial measurements, as well as dentition (Liu et al. 2007).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
It was transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).

This species needs further taxonomic review (N. Bernal pers. comm.). Formerly assessed for the Red List as A. puer in Muridae. Subgenus Akodon, A. boliviensis species group (Myers et al. 1990). In that revision of the boliviensis group, Myers et al. (1990) referred lutescens, classified as a subspecies of A. andinus by Cabrera (1961) to subspecies of A. puer.  Some years after Anderson (1997) indicated that lutescens has priority over puer.
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species has been misidentified with A. mimus and A. fumeus in the past. This species share many morphological attributes with A. fumeus and present a sister relationship (Smith and Patton 2007).

There has been some confusion between specimens of A. orophilus and A. mollis. Further taxonomic review of these species is needed as there are three distinct karyotypes (H. Zeballos and E. Vivar pers. comm.). Records of this species from Ecuador (Moreno and Albuja, 2005) are considered to be A. mollis (H. Zeballos and V. Pacheco pers. comm.). There are two recognized subspecies of Akodon orophilus, A.o. orophilus and A.o. orientalis. Both subspecies were originally described as subspecies of A. mollis. Intergradation between subspecies A. orophilus and A. orientalis has been reported in the Puca Tambo region, and color variations have been related to differences in environmental conditions (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This is considered to be a species complex which requires further taxonomic investigation.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Further research is needed to determine whether the Peruvian record is the same as thase in the Colombian and Venezuelan populations (V. Pacheco pers. comm.). This species is a synonym with Ichthyomys trichotis (Thomas 1897), Rheomys trichotis (Thomas 1906), Anotomys trichotis (Handley 1976). It is a monotypic species (Voss 2015).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Voss 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Voss 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

The entire genus requires taxonomic revision. Cricetulus tibetanus is often included in C. kamensis (Smith and Xie 2008). R.S. Hoffmann separates the forms kamensis, lama, and tibetanus, following earlier taxonomic work recognizing each as good species. This treatment is followed by the Mammals of China (Smith and Xie 2008). This form is treated as a synonym of C. kamensis by Musser and Carleton (2005).

The entire genus requires taxonomic revision. Cricetulus lama is often included in C. kamensis (Smith and Xie 2008). R.S. Hoffmann separates the forms kamensis, lama, and tibetanus, following earlier taxonomic work recognizing each as good species. This treatment is followed by the Mammals of China (Smith and Xie 2008). Cricetulus lama is treated as a synonym of C. kamensis by Musser and Carleton (2005).

The entire genus requires taxonomic revision. R.S. Hoffmann separates the forms Cricetulus kamensis, lama, and tibetanus, following earlier taxonomic work recognizing each as good species. This treatment is followed by the Mammals of China (Smith and Xie 2008). The Mammals of China recognizes two subspecies Cricetulus kamensis kamensis (eastern Xizang and southern Qinghai) and C. k. kozlovi (northern Qinghai, northwestern Gansu, and southern Xinjiang) (Smith and Xie 2008). The forms lama and tibetanus are treated as synonyms by Musser and Carleton (2005).
Generic synonym Rheomys. This species is monotypic (Voss 2015).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Otomys anchitae by Dieterlen and van der Straeten (1992).
This species was previously synonymized with O. irroratus. Current taxonomic research supports the distinctiveness of this species (S. Maree pers. comm.).
This is most likely a species complex. Otomys kempi is possibly distinct from this species based on mitochondrial DNA sequencing data (S. Maree pers. comm.).
This was included as a synonym of O. typus, but Taylor et al. (2011)  resurrected this species.

No subspecies are recognised for Pseudomys fieldi. The original Shark Bay specimen was described as Pseudomys praeconis, but research demonstrated that P. praeconis should be synonymised with P. fieldi, described from a single Alice Springs specimen (Baynes 1990).
This is probably a species complex (K. Aplin pers. comm.).

This species belongs to subgenus Coelomys Thomas, 1915. Ellerman (1961) listed three subspecies, namely Mus famulus famulus Bonhote, 1898, Mus famulus cooki (sic) (Ryley, 1914) and Mus famulus popaeus (Thomas, 1919). Mus famulus cooki (sic) (Ryley, 1914) is now considered as a separate species Mus cookii Ryley, 1914, and Mus famulus popaeus (Thomas, 1919) - earlier reported as Leggada nitidula popaea Thomas, 1919, has been proposed to be a subspecies of Mus cervicolor by Corbet and Hill (1992). Thus, presently only Mus famulus Bonhote, 1898 is a valid name from the region.
This species forms and unresolved species complex with Mus minutoides in East Africa and Central Africa.

Although originally described as a species; Mus neavei was later regarded as a subspecies of M. sorella (Ansell 1978; Meester et al. 1986; Skinner & Smithers 1990). More recently, however, Petter (1981) suggested that M. neavei should be reclassified to species status, as it differs from M. sorella in its fur colour, body size, and its cranial and molar structure. This recommendation was corroborated and accepted by Musser and Carleton (1993) and Bronner et al. (2003). Although, commonly confused with M. indutus (the Desert Pygmy Mouse) and M. minutoides (the Pygmy Mouse), this species can be distinguished by its lower three-rooted second molar and pro-odont incisors (Meester et al. 1986).

authority: Auffray, Orth, Catalan, Gonzalez, Desmarais & Bonhomme, 2003
taxonomicNotes: This species is highly distinct genetically, but morphologically very similar to M. cervicolor, therefore, this species is probably much more widespread, as some specimens are hidden within M. cervicolor (Musser and Carleton 2005).

This species belongs to subgenus Pyromys Thomas, 1911. Ellerman (1961) listed six subspecies, namely Mus platythrix platythrix Bennett, 1832, Mus platythrix sadhu (Wroughton, 1911), Mus platythrix ramnadensis (Bentham, 1908), Mus platythrix bahadur (Wroughton and Ryley, 1913), Mus platythrix gurkha (Thomas, 1914), and Mus platythrix shortridgei (Thomas, 1914). However, Marshall (1977) has rearranged Mus platythrix complex under three species namely Mus platythrix Bennett, 1832, Mus saxicola Elliot, 1839 and Mus shortridgei (Thomas, 1914). The last species does not occur in South Asia. One population of Mus platytheix with chromosomal variation from Araku, Andhra Pradesh and Pune, Maharashtra (Agrawal 2000)
F. Dieterlen and L. Lavrenchenko disagree with Happold and consider the presence of this species as valid in Ethiopia.
This species was in the genus, Hydromys; transferred to Baiyankamys by Helgen (2005).
This species has been included in the genus Neohydromys by some authors (e.g., Flannery 1995).

Further study is needed on the taxonomic status of this species, especially its relationship with Melomys lutillus. According to Musser and Carleton (2005) these two species are closely related, and M. frigicola was formerly considered a subspecies of M. lutillus, but was elevated to full species status by Menzies (1996).
This species is sometimes considered a subspecies of A. draco (Smith and Xie 2008).
A split from M. natalensis.

The single specimen from Sichuan is larger and darker than typical examples of the species, with more specimens needed to determine if it represents a separate species (Smith and Xie 2008). This may be a complex of several species, and further taxonomic studies are needed to resolve this.
Should perhaps be included in Praomys.
Vandeleuria oleracea represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.
The genus Apomys was reviewed by Musser (1982), with modifications by Musser and Heaney (1992). The species has since been reviewed and remains as a distinct species (Heaney et al. 2011).
Formerly included in D. incomtus but elevated to a full species by Carleton & Martinez (1991).
Generic synonym = Rattus.
What is currently called, Rattus novaeguineae, might contain more than one species.
This species is closely related to Rattus losea (K. Aplin pers. comm.).
This species is often considered to be a subspecies of Rattus niobe. It was recognized provisionally as a distinct species by Musser and Carleton (2005) pending further study of the R. niobe complex.
Formerly known as Rattus jalorensis, this species is closely related to Rattus baluensis (Musser 1986).
Generic synonym = Mus.
Species one of the undescribed species mentioned in Flannery (1990).
No subspecies are recognised for Leporillus conditor.
Previously listed as a subspecies of A. hindei.

The Thevenard Island form was previously thought to be a distinct taxon found on islands, but research has shown that this is merely a larger form of the same species. Further taxonomic study may be warranted to consider the extent and implications of morphological variation across the species's extensive range.
A split from A. niloticus.
F. Petter (1975b) synonymized it with Gerbillus juliani which would then include Somalia in the distribution.
Included in Gerbillus (Granjon 2013).
Included in Gerbillus (Granjon 2013).
Retained as a valid species by Musser and Setzer (2005) following Lay (1983). Considered to be incertae sedis by L. Granjon (2013).
D. Schlitter believes it should include G. dunni. Includes Gerbillus bilensis.
We follow Happold (2013) by including Gerbillus ruberrimus and G. diminutus within G. pusillus. G. diminutus is sometimes considered to be incertae sedis.

We follow Granjon (2013) by provisionally including Gerbillus mauritaniae in G. nancillus. Ndiaye et al. (2016) showed that it represents a distinct lineage within the genus Gerbillus, that may deserve a subgeneric rank.
This species was first published with the incorrect spelling Carmichaelia munroi, after David Monro, and the name should be spelt as Carmichaelia monroi (Godley 2003).

Carmichaelia suteri Kirk is an accepted species in the Flora of New Zealand (Allen 1961) but is listed as a synonym of C. uniflora in a later revision of Carmichaelia by Heenan (1995), a specialist of the genus.

There is some confusion between Carex sociata Boott and Carex chinensis Retz associated with some herbarium specimen data. However, experts consider them to be distinct (T. Katsuyama pers. comm.). Both the Flora of China (2008) and The World Checklist (WCSP 2015) list these as individual accepted species and this taxonomy is followed in this assessment.

This orchid has a disjunct distribution which requires further taxonomic study. Matthew (1999) allocated the plants from the Khasia hills in northeast India to Peristylus gracilis and the Sikkim plants to P. tipuliferus. Seidenfaden (1977) also believed that the plants from Khasia that Hooker had referred to Habenaria aristata, were best assigned to P. gracilis.

Habenaria humicola, H .reneformis, H .porphyricola, H. humistrata, H. siamensis and H. poilanei form a group of similar and probably closely related species. The complex is in need of further study to investigate whether these species can be maintained as distinct entities (Pedersen et al. 2011).

This orchid is restricted to north-eastern Turkey and the Caucasus, but it is possibly conspecific with Dactylorhiza lancibracteata (K.Koch) Renz which is found in the Caspian area. It is also similar to D. saccifera (Brongn.) Soó, and may have arisen from parents related to D. saccifera and D. euxina (Nevski) Czerep. This orchid is also known to hybridize with D. armeniaca Hedrén, D. nieschalkiorum H.Baumann & Künkele and D. euxina (Hedrén 2001).

Festuca laxa Host. is an accepted species in the WCSP (2016) but it is sometimes considered to be in the genus Leucopoa (Foggi et al 2005), as Leucopoa laxa. This species was published by Host in 1802 and should not be confused with the illegitimate name F.laxa Gaudin published later in 1811, which is a synonym of F.elatior L. (WCSP 2016).
This species was placed in Festuca subg. Subulatae by S.L.Lu, but it is not closely related to other species in this subgenus (Zengyi et al. 2006).
The Flora of Australia (Wilson 2009) suggests due to several morphological characters that the placement of this species in the genus Glyceria warrants review.

This species has many special characters of anatomy, embryology,  cytology and palynology such that it was separated to a new family of  monocotyledons, the Acanthochlamydaceae (Baochan and Kao 1998).
This species is currently under taxonomic revision (J. Melville pers. comm. 2017).

Equisetum palustre is known to hybridize with a number of other species of the genus. However, none of these hybrids are frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or the outcomes of this assessment.
The American subpopulations often included in this species are a separate species: Equisetum braunii. They are therefore not considered for this assessment.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name apart from former works not separating B. eruciformis from B. syzigachne (synonym B. eruciformis ssp. baicalensis (Kusn.) Hultén).

Two subspecies are known: T. bulbosa ssp. barrelieri and T. bulbosa ssp. laxiflora (Conti et al. 2005).

T. bulbosa ssp. laxiflora is considered a valid species T. laxiflora Guss. and has been separately assessed.
Rorippa austriaca (Crantz) Besser is a wild relative of watercress, Nasturtium officinale W.T. Aiton and N. microphyllum Boenn. ex Rchb.

Agrostis stolonifera L. is a wild relative of the cultivated form, creeping bent grass.

Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly (2009) recognize seven subspecies which are native to Europe: A. stolonifera ssp. albida (Trin.) Tzvelev, A. stolonifera ssp. filfiolia (Link) H. Scholz, A. stolonifera ssp. gaditana (Boiss. & Reut.) Valdés & H. Scholz, A. stolonifera ssp. maritima (Lam.) Vasc., A. stolonifera ssp. scabriglumis (Boiss. & Reut.) Maire, A. stolonifera ssp. stolonifera and A. stolonifera ssp. straminea (Hartm.) Tzvelev. However, the subordinate taxa are poorly defined and taxonomic recognition between authors is inconsistent. It is therefore unlikely that taxonomic issues will affect the conservation or Red List assessment of this species.

The normal concept of R. flammula includes some subordinate taxa (such as ssp. scotica) and some hybrids (e.g. R. ×levenensis Druce ex Gornall), however this is not considered likely to affect this evaluation or the status of the species.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
One of a group of very closely related sibling species including A. barbareae, A. cineraria and A. danuvia. The taxonomic status of these taxa is uncertain.
A divergent population of this species is known from the English Company Islands (Craig Moritz pers. comm. 2017).

Zug et al. (2004) assigned New Guinean records of this species to the new taxa Carlia aenigma and C. aramia, restricting C. longipes to northern and northeastern Australia. On the basis of mitochondrial, allozyme and morphological data, Donnellan et al. (2009) subsequently authors assigned records from the Northern Territory, the northern Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait islands to a distinct species, for which the name Carlia sexdentata was available, and several records from Darnley Island to a third species, Carlia quinquecarinata.
Work is underway to attempt to resolve the systematics of this taxon, which is thought to represent a species complex (C. Hoskin pers. comm. 2017).

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017), one of which was genetically close to C. spaldingi. Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to the clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved polyphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingi and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size). Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. spaldingi following Cogger (2014).

Differences between populations from New Guinea and Cape York and those from the remainder of the species' Australian range suggest that this taxon may be a species complex (G. Shea and A. Allison pers. comm. 2014).

This species has three recognized subspecies: Varanus panoptes panoptes Storr, 1980, V. p. rubidus Storr, 1980 and V. p. horni Böhme, 1988. Molecular evidence suggests that at least the two Australian subspecies may be specifically distinct (S. Keogh and S. Donnellan, unpubl. data)

Longstanding taxonomic issues (summarized by Wüster et al. 2005) exist within Acanthophis , with the names A. praelongus and A. antarcticus having been widely used to encompass both Australian and New Guinean taxa, including a number of Australian populations flagged as being distinct (Wüster et al. 2005). These authors provide the first modern phylogenetic framework for analyzing variation in the genus, and attribute Northern Territory and northern Queensland representatives of their 'clade A1' to the Acanthophis rugosus complex, a form shared with New Guinea and previously treated as a subspecies of A. antarcticus. This clade is itself divided into two broadly sympatric forms and Wüster et al. (2005) note that the oldest name available for the second clade is Acanthophis hawkei. Although these authors refrain from considering this taxon a separate species and no subsequent taxonomic work appears to have validated it, Threatened Species Scientific Committee (2012) state that "[Acanthophis hawkei] is conventionally accepted as a distinct species". Detailed systematic research is required to resolve outstanding issues within this complex, as molecular approaches alone may be insufficient and a number of candidate species within the group exhibit sympatric or parapatric distributions (Wüster et al. 2005).

Longstanding taxonomic issues (summarized by Wüster et al. 2005) exist within Acanthophis , with the names A. praelongus and A. antarcticus having been widely used to encompass both Australian and New Guinean taxa, including a number of Australian populations flagged as being distinct (Wüster et al. 2005). These authors provide the first modern phylogenetic framework for analyzing variation in the genus, and attribute Northern Territory and northern Queensland representatives of their 'clade A1' to the Acanthophis rugosus complex, a form shared with New Guinea and previously treated as a subspecies of A. antarcticus. This clade is itself divided into two broadly sympatric forms and Wüster et al. (2005) note that the oldest name available for the second clade is Acanthophis hawkei. Although these authors refrain from considering this taxon a separate species and no subsequent taxonomic work appears to have validated it, Threatened Species Scientific Committee (2012) state that "[Acanthophis hawkei] is conventionally accepted as a distinct species". Detailed systematic research is required to resolve outstanding issues within this complex, as molecular approaches alone may be insufficient and a number of candidate species within the group exhibit sympatric or parapatric distributions (Wüster et al. 2005).

Demansia reticulata reticulata and D. reticulata cupreiceps have long been considered subspecies of Demansia psammophis, in part following Storr et al. (1986). This treatment was followed by Wilson and Swan (2013) while Cogger (2014) recognized only D. r. reticulata as being distinct from D. psammophis. These arrangements neglect evidence presented by Hutchinson and Tyler (1996) that D. psammophis and D. reticulata (=D. r. cupreiceps of Storr 1978) co-occur in the Flinders Ranges with no evidence of intergradation. This suggests a species boundary exists between between D. psammophis and D. r. cupreiceps, and the most recent treatments follow Storr (1978) in treating D. reticulata, including D. r. cupreiceps, as a species distinct from D. psammophis (e.g. Wallach et al. 2014).
The boundary between this species and Furina ornata is poorly defined and requires resolution both geographically and taxonomically (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Numerous intermediate forms exist.
The boundary between this species and Furina diadema is poorly defined and requires resolution both geographically and taxonomically (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Numerous intermediate forms exist.
Sometimes confused with Psedonaja mengdeni, an therefore probably under-recorded.

This species was described (as Pseudechis pailsei, later emended to pailsi - Wüster et al. 2001) from Queensland and the assignment of Northern Territory records, which were found to be significantly genetically different by Wüster et al. (2005), to this species has been considered tentative. This issue is further complicated by the taxonomy of this and several related 'pygmy mulga snakes' (Pseudechis australis group), three of which (P. rossignoli, P. pailsi and P. weigeli) were described outside the peer-reviewed literature and between which species limits have subsequently been unclear (Wüster et al. 2005, Kuch et al. 2005, Maddock et al. 2017). The original description of P. pailsei was made without reference to the earlier description of Cannia weigeli, and supposedly diagnostic features of these forms appear to be identical (Wüster et al. 2001). Maddock et al. (2017) conducted a wide-ranging genetic study of this group in an effort to clarify species delimitation. These authors caution that their sampling is limited, but their results provisionally support recognition of P. pailsi, P. weigeli and P. rossignoli as distinct species, and of a tenth species they refer to as 'NT dwarf form' which appears to correspond to Northern Territory records previously assigned to P. pailsi. These authors' sampling only included three samples of P. pailsi and they acknowledge that additional data is required to confirm specific status for both the Northern Territory form (which was recovered as the sister taxon to P. pailsi) and P. weigeli. No attempt has been made to characterize morphological differences between these three putative taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

No genetic revision of Leiopython has been undertaken, with several species (L. biakensis, L. fredparkeri, L. huonensis and L. montanus) having recently been described only from museum material, none with collection dates more recent than 1967. Live specimens are known only for L. albertsii and L. meridionalis, in part due to the difficulty of tracing specimens from remote areas of New Guinea (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2018). The validity of these taxa must consequently be considered uncertain.
The validity of subspecific divisions in this taxon are unclear, as they have not been supported by preliminary genetic data (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).
Formally elevated to species level having previously been included within F. lateralis (Florio et al. 2012).

authority: Florio, Ingram, Rakotondravony, Louis Jr. & Raxworthy, 2012
taxonomicNotes: Formally elevated to species level having previously been included within F. lateralis (Florio et al. 2012).

The larger form from the arid south (formerly treated as F. lateralis ssp. major) is now recognized to be a separate species, Furcifer major Florio et al. 2012). In addition, populations of F. lateralis from the north-west of its distribution are also recognised as a new species, Furcifer viridis (Florio et al. 2012).
The species is accepted by  Govaerts and Simpson  (2007), however, Menapace (1993) questioned the delineation considering it to be based on immature specimens.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.
The summer generation could possibly be a distinct species (Westrich 1990).

Considerable confusion exists in the taxonomic literature over the status of Acorus in North America. Whether Acorus is native or introduced, as well as the number of taxa in North America, has been debated for years. Evidence based on studies of morphology, essential oil chemistry, cytology, isozymes, and ethnobotany supports the existence of two species in North America; A. calamus, an introduced sterile triploid, and A. americanus, a native fertile diploid. A. americanus is not only morphologically distinct from triploid A. calamus but also from diploid and tetraploid A. calamus populations occurring in Asia (Thompson 2002).

In this assessment, the distinction is not recognised.

Cypripedium variegatum Georgi. is an invalid synonym

Cypripedium orientale Spreng. is an illegitimate synonym
Several variants have been observed in this species, which need to be studied properly to understand the distribution of the species.

As evident from the number of large number of synonyms, this species has been taxonomically very complex and misleading to orchid experts. Paphiopedilum insigne is the type species for the genus Paphiopedilum and hence holds special importance.
There are four subspecies: ssp. viride (Brullé, 1839); ssp. cabrerai (Warncke, 1975); ssp. palmae Ebmer, 1993; and ssp. unicolor (Brullé, 1840).
The species is closely related to Lasioglossum minutulum.
The subspecies Lasioglossum bavaricum olympicum (Warncke, 1982) is found in the mountains of Greece. The nominal subspecies is found throughout the rest of it's distribution.
Andrena (Cnemidandrena) freygessneri was first considered as subspecies of Andrena simillima Smith, 1851, but it is clearly a distinct species according to Ebmer (2001).

There are taxonomic uncertainties regarding the status of this taxon and A. boyerella (qv). Both A. leucolippa and A. boyerella are regarded as a valid names by Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002). However, in the maps provided by Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002), A. boyerella and A. leucolippa appear together in the same map since A. leucolippa was regarded as a subspecies by Warncke. After further examination, it seems that A. leucolippa occurs in Europe and A. boyerella occurs in North Africa (and the records from Sicily and Italy probably belong to it as well) (E. Scheuchl pers. comm. 2014).

This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). It is unclear that all biological populations within its large range are conspecific. However, these are included in the current assessment until their taxonomic identities can be clarified.

Sus verrucosus originally had three subspecies, the nominal subspecies on Java, S. v. olivieri on the island of Madura, which is now thought the be extinct (Blouch 1998), and S. v. blouchi of Bawean Island. S. v. blouchi was upgraded to full species by Groves and Grubb (2011), but pending additional genetic study it is for now maintained as a subspecies.

This taxon was formerly regarded as a subspecies of Sus philippensis, i.e. S. p. cebifrons, and was not recognized as a full species until in 1997 (Groves 1981, 1991, 1997). Two subspecies are currently recognized, i.e. the nominate form from Cebu (now extinct) and negrinus from Negros; though recent MtDNA studies have indicated the likely addition of a third subspecies from Panay (Tomowo Ozawa pers. comm. and in prep).

Formerly this taxon was recognized as a distinct species endemic to the Philippines by Groves (1981), who subsequently proposed recognition of three subspecies: philippensis from Luzon and associated islands; mindanensis from Mindanao and associated islands; and oliveri from Mindoro (later separated as a full species (Groves 1997, 2001; Groves and Grubb 1993)). More recent mtDNA studies have suggested the likelihood for separating ‘philippinensis’ and ‘mindanensis’ as full species (T. Ozawa pers. comm. and in prep.).

This taxon was recognized as a separate species from Sus philippensis according to Groves (2001). It is known from four skulls and a mounted head collected in 1993 now in the Field Museum, Chicago, which constitutes the holotype (Grubb 2005, W. Oliver unpublished).

This species has several synonyms, some have recently been separated from Caladenia dimorpha and Jones (2007) provides an account of the separation of these species when describing Stegostyla ustulata. However, the scientific evidence is still debated. Examination of the material from across the range and DNA analysis suggests that the delimitation of the species may be inconsistent and observed differences may have an ecological rather than a genetic basis in some cases (M.Clements pers. comm. 2014).
The genus Acis was lumped into Leucojum for more than a century, only to be returned to genus status in 2004 through DNA analysis (Lledó et al. 2004).

Populations of Carex canescens (section glareosae) are a variable complex which comprise 39 subordinate taxa (29 varieties, one form and nine subspecies).

Until recently, C. canescens has been treated in most of the European literature as C. curta Gooden.

C. canescens has been shown to hybridize with C. appropinquata, C. chordorrhiza (C. ×liddii Flatb.), C. dioica (C. ×macrostachya Ehrh.), C. echinata (C. ×biharica Simonk.), C. elongata, C. lachenallii (C. ×helvola Blytt ex Fr.), C. paniculata (C. ×ludibunda J. Gay), C. remota and others (Jermy et al. 2007). However, none of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species.
Two varieties are recognized, the nominate and var. changningensis S.Yun Liang.
Sorghum interjectum Lazarides is a tertiary wild relative of sorghum, Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench ssp. bicolor (USDA, ARS, National Resources Program 2015).
Sorghum virgatum (Hack.) Stapf is a wild relative of sorghum, Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench ssp. bicolor (Vincent et al. 2013).

Dioscorea quartiniana A.Rich. is a wild relative of cultivated yams, D. alata L. (water yam/greater yam), D. bulbifera L. (aerial yam), D. cayenensis Lam. (Lagos yam), D. dumetorum (Kunth) Pax (bitter yam), D. esculenta (Lour.) Burkill (Asiatic yam) and D. rotundata Poir. (white Guinea yam).


Joana’s comments:

Add publication details in ‘Taxonomic Sources’. For this species you can find here: http://www.tropicos.org/Name/11000267.

In addition to its overall appearance, its riparian habitat relates Arisaema heterophyllum to the American A. dracontium.

Specimens close to A. heterophyllum have been found on Mt. Emei (China), near the Baguo Monastery. Gusman and Gusman (2006) consider this a geographical form of A. heterophyllum, whilst deciding whether it deserves a subspecies status.
Cyperus boreochrysocephalus from Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda might be a synonym of C. remotus (Hoenselaar et al. 2010).
Sorghum purpureosericeum (Hochst. ex A. Rich.) Asch. & Schweinf. is a tertiary wild relative of sorghum, Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench ssp. bicolor (Vincent et al. 2013).
Sorghum angustum S. T. Blake is a tertiary wild relative of sorghum, Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench (Vincent et al. 2013)
Sorghum stipoideum (Ewart & Jean White) C. A. Gardner & C. E. Hubb. is a tertiary wild relative of sorghum, Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench ssp. bicolor (Vincent et al. 2013).

This species comprises many smaller taxa whose ecological behaviour differs as regard to warmth, acidity and other factors (Ellenberg 1988). Festuca pindica, which is only known from the type collection on Mount Karava (1,600 m) and grows in North Pindhos, chiefly on serpentine and was formerly considered as a very rare species of Greece (Damanakis and Scholz 1990) is treated here as a synonym of F. varia, a highly variable, widespread species (Strid and Tan 1991). Markgraf-Dannenberg (1978) recognized five species in Greece, within the F. varia complex. These are poorly defined local or regional populations, which cannot be accepted even as subspecies as there is wide overlapping in every possible character. The presence of rib schlerenchyma varies within the same population or even within the same individual. Festuca pindica is keyed out by “rib sclerenchyma always present” although the drawing in Markgraf-Dannenberg (1978) shows it to be one of the two species completely lacking rib schlerenchyma (Strid and Tan 1991).

According to Govindarajalu (1974), this species differs from Fimbristylis kingii, another high altitude endemic taxon from the south Indian Hill Stations by, among other features, its annual habit, stems without thickened base, flat acuminate and narrower leaves, smaller ovoid or elliptic-ovoid spikelets and tricostulate nuts with rounded and transversely elongated tubercles. The epithet monospicula is used on the basis that it usually bears a single spikelet at the end of the culm. However, there is some taxonomic uncertainty about the validity of F. monospicula as a species (Prasad pers. comm. 2008).
This taxon appears to be a species complex, with four morphologically distinct populations that are thought to represent distinct species (J.E. García-Pérez pers. comm. 2016).

Taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the relation with Cercosayua goeleti, considered as a full species by several authors and as a junior synonym of C. phelpsorom by others (Rivas et al. 2012). This account follows Rivas et al. (2012) in considering C. goeleti a junior synonym of C. phelpsorum.
This species was described from within the Ameiva ameiva species complex (Ugueto and Harvey 2011).

This species has two subspecies:
M. bicoloratus bicoloratus Sternfield, 1908
M. bicoloratus moyeri Rasmussen, 2002.
A. mwanzae was previously regarded as a subspecies of A. planiceps Peters, 1862 (Spawls et al. 2002).
Two subspecies are known: Callimenus macrogaster macrogaster and C. m. longicollis, defined on mostly subtle differences in the female subgenital plate.
Schargel et al. (2013) referred Atractus arangoi to the synonymy of A. major.
Three specimens attributed to this species (without examination) by Loveridge (1944) have instead been found to represent Cordylus tropidosternum (Broadley and Branch 2002).
Specimens originally classed as Atractus crassicaudatus collected from Panama have been redescribed as A. imperfectus Myers, 2003.

Some or all Tanzanian populations presently referred to the similar Trachylepis brevicollis may instead represent this species (Günther et al. 2005), and this is also suggested by the proximity of two localities to Klein's Camp, where T. dichroma is known to occur (Branch et al. 2007). Research is needed to confirm this.

This species was initially classified in the genus Bradypus, as it was thought that it was related to South American sloths, due to the absence of the two first upper incisors. Debate persists as to whether this species should be in the mono-specific genus Melursus, or in Ursus (Pagès et al. 2008, Krause et al. 2008, Kitchener 2010).

Two subspecies have been recognized. There is some evidence that they are distinct genetic clades (Fain et al. 1994). Melursus ursinus inornatus only occurs on the island of Sri Lanka and is physically smaller with shorter and sparser hair than its mainland (M. u. ursinus) counterpart.

The principal colour phase is black, with a white or cream/yellow crescent on the chest. Rusty brown phases are also known. The species is often confused with the Asiatic Black Bear (Ursus thibetanus), due to similar appearance.

This taxon is sometimes treated under the specific name asinus. However, this is considered to be the name applied to the domestic form and is so generally rejected in favour of africanus. Gentry (2006) criticized the incorrect use of the name E. asinus for the Wild Ass by Grubb (2005). There are two recognized extant subspecies, although there is disagreement as to whether the African Wild Ass is one continuously distributed species exhibiting clinal variation (see Moehlman 2002, Moehlman et al. 2013). Groves (2002) lists a third unnamed subspecies from the Sahara, although these may not have been true Wild Asses.

There are currently five generally recognized subspecies:
  1. Equus hemionus hemionus - the Mongolian khulan (in northern Mongolia) (E. h. luteus - the Gobi khulan or dziggetai in southern Mongolia and northern China, is probably a synonym of E. h. hemionus (Oakenfull et al. 2000, Grubb 2005, Kaczensky et al. 2011a)
  2. E. h. khur – the khur (India)
  3. E. h. kulan – the Turkmen kulan (in Turkmenistan, re-introduced in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Ukraine and mixed E. h. kulan x E. h. onager in Israel)
  4. E. h. onager - the onager (Iran and re-introduced and mixed E. h. kulan x E. h. onager in Israel)
  5. E. h. hemippus – the Syrian wild ass (Extinct, formerly from the eastern shore of the Mediterranean Sea south into the Arabian Peninsula)
However, the taxonomic arrangement of equids is quite complicated and modern (particularly genetic) analyses may result in future changes or clarifications (Oakenfull and Ryder 2002).

Recent genetic analysis of archaeological, historical and modern samples indeed suggest that there is only one species of Asiatic Wild Ass (Bennett et al. 2012, Bennett et al. in prep., assigning the modern Equus hemionus and Equus kiang as well as Equus hydruntinus which went extinct during the Holocene (Crees and Turvey 2014) to the same species), which is subdivided into regional subpopulations rather than subspecies. Comparative analysis of modern samples of Equus hemionus from Iran (E. h. onager) and China (E. h. hemionus) and Equus kiang also did not support monophyly (Rosenbom et al. 2015). However, this Red List assessment does not include Equus kiang and did not attempt to include semi-reserves where Equus hemionus was reintroduced in central or western Europe – the former distribution range of Equus hydruntinus.

The taxonomy of this species was revised by Groves and Mazak (1967) and Groves (1986), who with Bennett (1980) separated Equus kiang from Equus hemionus; Schlawe (1986) regarded kiang as a subspecies of hemionus. Recent population genetics research suggests that E. kiang is a subspecies of E. hemionus (Rosenbom et al. 2015). Three subspecies of Equus kiang are commonly recognized Equus k. kiang, E. k. holdereri and E. k. polyodon (Groves and Mazak 1967, Groves 1974, Shah 1994, Shah 2002, St-Louis and Côté 2009). These subspecies are known by their geographic range as the Western Kiang, Eastern Kiang and Southern Kiang, respectively.

Two allopatric subspecies of Mountain Zebra have traditionally been recognized, the nominate race E. z. zebra (Cape Mountain Zebra) and E. z. hartmannae (Hartmann's Mountain Zebra). Groves and Ryder (2000) proposed that the two be treated as distinct species, and Groves and Bell (2004) presented morphological evidence for separating the two subspecies as distinct species based on the diagnosability criterion of the phylogenetic species concept. Recent genetic analyses indicate that the two populations have a high incidence of mitochondrial haplotype sharing; the hypothesis that Cape and Hartmann's Mountain Zebra mitochondrial lineages were reciprocally monophyletic was not supported (Moodley and Hartley 2005). However, the presence of private alleles at nuclear loci rendered the two subspecies genetically distinct evolutionary significant units. We continue to recognize Mountain Zebra as a single species comprising two subspecies.

Groves and Bell (2004) described six subspecies of Equus quagga based on craniometric taxonomic methods, which showed all subspecies to be alike, and distinctly different from Mountain Zebras (Equus zebra). The six subspecies differ from one another in morphological characteristics, such as coat patterns and colouration, body size, and the presence (or absence) of a mane (Groves & Bell 2004). Although there is limited evidence for genetic diversity between subspecies and the classification may be a contested topic (Bennett 1980), a classification of subspecies can be useful as a way to emphasise ecological and morphological differences for management purposes. Following Groves and Bell (2004), six morphologically defined subspecies are listed as:
  • Equus q. crawshaii (Crawshay’s Zebra) occurs in east Zambia, east of Luangwa River, Malawi, south-eastern Tanzania, and Mozambique as far south as the Gorongoza district.

  • Equus q. borensis (Maneless Zebra) ranges over the northern parts of east Africa from north-west Kenya to the Karamoja district of Uganda and south-east Sudan, east of the Nile River (Boma National Park) to the northern limit of the species’ range (32 °N).

  • Equus q. boehmi (Grant’s Zebra or Boehm’s Zebra) is found in Zambia, west of the Luangwa River, west to Kariba, the Shaba Province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo north to Kibanzao Plateau, Tanzania north from Nyangaui abnd Kibwezi into south-west Uganda, south-west Kenya, and east Kenya, east of the Rift Valley, into southern Ethiopia and perhaps to the Juba River in Somalia. This subspecies constitutes of over 75% of Africa’s Plain Zebra population, and the Serengeti-Mara ecosystem supports approximately 200,000 individuals (East 1997; Hack et al. 2002).

  • Equus q. chapmani (Chapman’s Zebra) ranges from north-east South Africa, from about 24 °S, 31 °E, north to Zimbabwe, west into Botswana at about 19 °S, 24 °E, across the Caprivi Strip in Namibia, and into southern Angola.

  • Equus q. burchellii (Burchell’s Zebra) formally occurred north of the Vaal/Orange Rivers, extending north-west via Botswana to Etosha National Park and the Kaokoveld, south-east to KwaZulu-Natal and Swaziland. It is now extinct in the middle of its range. Equus. q. antiquorum is now included in this subspecies.

  • Equus q. quagga (Cape Quagga) occurred in the former Cape Province, south of the Orange and Vaal Rivers and west of the Drakensberg. This subspecies has been extinct since 1883.
Research indicates that the extinct E. q. quagga might differ morphologically from other Plains Zebra subspecies, but those differences are not sufficient to justify its classification as an independent species. Thus the extinct E. q. quagga should be considered a subspecies of E. quagga. From north to south of their geographic range, extant Plains Zebras show a gradual decline in the contrast between dark stripes and white interspaces, and an increase in body size is noted from east to south (Lorenzen et al. 2008). The extinct Cape Quagga, which was found at the southern limit of the species’ geographic range, exhibited the extreme case of this trend in pelage colouration (Groves & Bell 2004; Lorenzen et al. 2008).

Despite the wide distribution range and isolation (e.g. Sumatra) the Thai/Myanmar, the Malaysian/Southern Thailand and the Sumatran individuals cannot be genetically separated (Rovie-Ryan et al. 2008).

Caprolagus hispidus was originally described as a Lepus, but shortly thereafter its unique characteristics clearly defined it as a separate genus. There are no recognized subspecies of Caprolagus hispidus (Hoffmann and Smith 2005).

There are currently 16 recognized subspecies: Lepus timidus ainu, L. t. begitschevi, L. t. gichiganus, L. t. hibernicus, L. t. kamtschaticus, L. t. kolymensis, L. t. kozhevnikovi, L. t. lugubris, L. t. mordeni, L. t. orii, L. t. scoticus, L. t. sibiricorum, L. t. sylvaticus, L. t. timidus, L. t. transbaicalicus, and L. t. varronis (Angerbjörn 2018).

Lepus hainanus is currently recognized as a distinct species; previously it was classified as a subspecies of L. peguensis by past treatments (Hoffmann and Smith 2005). There are no recognized subspecies for L. hainanus (Hoffmann and Smith 2005).

The taxonomic status of the Alaskan Hare remains unclear, with some authorities suggesting, based on cranial or other morphometric measurements, that they are conspecific with Lepus arcticus and/or L. timidus. L. othus and L. arcticus also are known to share similar behavioral and ecological characteristics, yet, L. othus is geographically isolated and possesses different skull and incisor morphology from L. arcticus, and thus may warrant distinct taxonomic status.

Hall (1981) recognizes L. othus othus and L. o. poadromus as valid subspecies. Mammal Species of the World recognizes L. o. othus and L. o. tschuktschorum, listing poadromus as a nominate form synonym (Hoffmann and Smith 2005). Currently, there are insufficient data on eastern Siberian populations of hares to determine if they are linked to L. othus or to L. timidus (Hoffmann and Smith 2005). A recent molecular phylogenetic study of Arctic Hares suggests that the Chukotkan population of hares is more closely related to L. timidus, but more studies are required for conclusive distinction (Waltari et al. 2004). Should it be shown that linkage is to L. othus, "then tschuktschorum Nordquist, 1883 has priority over othus Merriam, 1900" (Hoffmann and Smith 2005).

There are no recognized subspecies for Lepus fagani (Hoffmann and Smith 2005, Tolesa and Johnston 2018). It was previously considered a subspecies of both Lepus saxatilis and L. victoriae (Flux and Angermann 1990). Recent mitochondrial and nuclear DNA analysis indicates it is closely allied with both L. starcki, but particularly with L. habessinicus (Tolesa et al. 2017, Tolesa and Johnston 2018).
Ochotona koslowi is within subgenus Conothoa. There are no recognized subspecies (Smith et al. 1990). Ochotona koslowi is a sister taxon to O. ladacensis (Yu et al. 2000, Lissovsky 2014).

this species is within subgenus Ochotona. There are two recognized subspecies: Ochotona nubrica lhasaensis and O. n. nubrica (includes O. n. aliensis and O. n. lama). Previously O. nubrica, while originally being described as an independent species, has been synonymized with O. pusilla, O. roylei, and O. thibetana. It is now clear from morphological and molecular analyses that it is an independent species and widely divergent from these forms. These analyses also indicate that nubrica does not form a single clade, but rather has undergone significant introgression with O. curzoniae (Lissovsky 2014).

Subgenus Lagotoma. There are currently two recognized subspecies: Ochotona pusilla angustifrons (east of the Ural River) and O. p. pusilla (west of the Ural River) (Smith et al. 1990). O. pusilla was formerly included in O. nubrica, O. forresti, and O. osgoodi (O. thibetana subspecies) (Smith et al. 1990)). This is a unique form of pika, and based on molecular evidence it stands alone in its subgenus (Lissovsky 2014).

This species is in the subgenus Ochotona. There are no recognized subspecies of Ochotona thomasi (Smith et al. 1990, Hoffmann and Smith 2005). This form is clearly distinguished morphologically and genetically from all other species of pika (Lissovsky 2014).
There are no recognized subspecies for this species. Formerly, Sylvilagus dicei was included in S. brasiliensis (Hoffmann and Smith 2005).
There are three recognized subspecies: Sylvilagus cunicularius cunicularius, S. c. insolitus, and S. c. pacificus (Cervantes et al. 2005).

Subgenus Ochotona. There are currently four recognized subspecies: O. c. cansus, O. c. morosa, O. c. sorella, and O. c. stevensi. Ochotona cansus was originally included in O. roylei and later listed under O. thibetana (Hoffmann and Smith 2005). Ochotona c. morosa was previously listed as a synonym of O. thibetana, but phylogenetic research indicates it is a subspecies of O. cansus (Yu et al. 1997).

This species is within subgenus Ochotona. There are no recognized subspecies Ochotona curzoniae. This species was formerly included by some treatments in O. dauurica. The form melanostoma is a synonym of this species (Smith et al. 1990). Ochotona curzoniae is possibly sister taxa to O. nubrica (Lissovsky 2014).

This species is within subgenus Ochotona. Currently there are three recognized subspecies: O. d. huangensis (annectens, bedfordi, and shaanxienis are synonyms); O. d. dauurica (altina and mursavi are synonyms), and O. d. latibullata. Previously, the subspecies O. d. annectens has been included by some in O. cansus. Formerly, O. dauurica was included in O. curzoniae (and thus melanostoma), but these two ecologically similar species are clearly separated based on morphological and molecular data.

This species is within subgenus Conothoa. There are no recognized subspecies (Smith and Xie 2008). Formerly O. ladacensis was included in O. curzoniae, with which it is broadly sympatric, but these forms are found in different subgenera of Ochotona (Lissovsky 2014). The Ladak Pika is very distinctive morphologically – its craniometrics measurements clearly separate it from all other species of Ochotona (Lissovsky 2014).

This species is within subgenus Pika. Currently there are three recognised subspecies: O. p. pallasii (southeastern Altai, Russia, across western Mongolia, extending into northeastern Xinjiang, China; O. p. hamica (Karlik Shan, eastern Xinjiang); O. p. sunidica (northern Nei Mongol, China). Essentially, O. pallasii is a recently elevated form of what was O. pallasi pricei in the Mongolian range plus the Chinese subspecies of O. pallasi. It was determined that the type locality of pallasi was incorrect and not in Kazakhstan, rather in Mongolia (where the form O. pallasi pricei occurred). Thus, the Mongolian range has become O. pallasii (spelled with two “i’s” following the law of priority), and following the law of priority, the Kazakhstan range now harbours the independent O. opaca. O. opaca and O. pallasii appear to be sister species, but sufficiently differentiated as to be considered independent.
There are currently three recognized subspecies, Lepus alleni alleni, L. a. palitans, and L. a. tiburonensis (Hall 1981).

The taxonomic status of the Arctic Hare remains unclear, with some authorities suggesting, based on cranial or other morphometric measurements, that they are conspecific with Lepus othus, and/or L. timidus. L. othus and L. arcticus also are known to share similar behavioural and ecological characteristics, but L. othus is geographically isolated and possesses different skull and incisor morphology from L. arcticus, and thus may warrant distinct taxonomic status. Wu et al. (2005) suggests that L. arcticus be included in L. timidus as "a single circumpolar species," based on molecular phylogenetics. However, Ben Slimen, Suchentrunk and Elgaaied (2008a) suggest that in the case of genus Lepus, whose evolution is "rapid and to some extent reticulated," mtDNA should only be regarded as preliminary evidence of species designation or lack thereof. Ben Slimen et al. (2008b) suggest that a more comprehensive examination that examines, "a combined phylogenetic, phylogeographic, and population genetic approach,…, based on various nuclear and mitochondrial markers and including other biological characters, such as phenotypic and morphometric data," would better elucidate taxonomic standing of Lepus species (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2018).

There are currently nine recognized subspecies: Lepus arcticus andersoni, L. a. arcticus, L. a. bangsii, L. a. banksicola, L. a. groenlandicus, L. a. hubbardi, L. a. labradorius, L. a. monstrabilis, and L. a. porsildi (Hall 1981). It appears that some of the subspecies designations are arbitrary and actually represent clinal variation among forms (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2018).

Lepus brachyurus is sometimes classified into four subspecies: L. b. angustidens, from the snowy area of Honshu; L. b. lyoni, Sado Island; L. b. okiensis, the Oki Islands; and L. b. brachyurus, from the remainder of the range.

There are 17 subspecies recognized: Lepus californicus altamirae, L. c. asellus, L. c. bennettii, L. c. californicus, L. c. curti, L. c. deserticola, L. c. eremicus, L. c. festinus, L. c. magdalenae, L. c. martrensis, L. c. melanotis, L. c. merriami, L. c. richardsonii, L. c. sheldoni, L. c. texianus, L. c. wallawalla, and L. c. xanti (Hall 1981, Ramírez–Silva et al. 2010, Álvarez-Castañeda and Lorenzo 2017, Lorenzo et al. 2018). The integrity of some of these forms has been questioned, and the phylogenetic relationships of these subspecies need to be evaluated. It is thought that the form altamirae may be independent, and the Black Jackrabbit (Lepus insularis) may be only a melanistic form of californicus and thus could eventually be placed in synonymy with it (Beever et al. 2018).

The entire taxonomy of Lepus capensis throughout its range is unclear. Taxonomic review of the species is urgently needed; otherwise, it is possible that some forms may go extinct before they are formally identified.

Hoffmann and Smith (2005) restricted L. capensis to the South African distribution, citing no evidence of gene flow between the southern and northern ranges. A list of synonyms is provided based on four geographic locations (South Africa, East Africa, Arabia and Near East, and northwest Africa), which are informal subdivisions of L. capensis sensu lato. The authors suggested that these four groups might represent distinct species. In the Near East and Arabia L. c. arabicus; in South Africa L. c. capensis; L. c. aquilo, L. c. carpi, L. c. granti; East Africa L. c. aegyptius, L. c. hawkeri, L. c. isabellinus, L. c. sinaiticus; and L. c. atlanticus, L. c. schulmbergeri, L. c. whitakeri in northwest Africa (Hoffmann and Smith 2005, Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2018).

According to Harrison and Bates (1991) there are eight subspecies in Arabia: L. c. syriacus (Syria, Lebanon, northern Israel); L. c. sinaiticus (southern Israel, Sinai); L. c. connori (east of the Euphrates in Iraq); L. c. arabicus (western Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Yemen); L. c. cheesmani (Saudi Arabia, Qatar, UAE, Yemen, Oman); L. c. omanensis (UAE, Oman); L. c. atallahi (Bahrain, Qatar?); L. c. jefferyi (Masirah Island, Oman). The taxonomic status of L. c. jefferyi needs clarification, as it may represent a good species. Hares present in Qatar also require taxonomic investigation.

The taxonomic position of the Sardinian Hare is unresolved. Hoffmann and Smith (2005) include the Sardinian Hare as one of the unassigned synonyms of L. mediterraneus Wagner, 1841 or typicus Hilzheimer, 1906, in L. granatensis. Analysis of the mtCR-1 sequence indicated that Sardinian Hares form a monophyletic clade with North African Hares (Scandura et al. 2007). A genetic and morphometric analysis supports the hypothesis that the Sardinian Hare was introduced from North Africa (Canu et al. 2012). A phylogenetic analysis of mtCR-1 sequences from Tunisian and Egyptian Hares characterized them as monophyletic and separate from L. capensis (Ben Slimen et al. 2006). However, a study of the nuclear gene pool of L. capensis, L. europaeus and the North African Hare indicated that the North African Hare as well as L. europaeus belong to L. capensis (Ben Slimen et al. 2005), supporting Petter's (1959, 1961) hypothesis of the inclusion of L. europaeus in capensis. Ben Slimen et al. (2008a) suggest that in a case such as the genus Lepus, where evolution is "rapid and to some extent reticulate", species designation based solely on mtDNA is misleading without examination of the nuclear gene pool. Ben Slimen et al. (2008a) has shown that genetic differentiation between L. capensis and L. europaeus could be attributed to geographic distance rather than divergence. They speculate that gene flow may be occurring in the Near East where distributions meet resulting in the potential for intergraded populations. However, Ben Slimen et al. (2008b) propose that "a combined phylogenetic, phylogeographic, and population genetic approach…, based on various nuclear and mitochondrial markers and including other biological characters, such as phenotypic and morphometric data," is needed for conclusive evidence of a single species complex. A recent study looking at a partial transferrin nuclear gene and phylogenetic relationship of hares in Tunisia showed “shared ancestral polymorphism between North African and Chinese hares” (Awadi et al. 2016). It also concluded that the Tunisian Hare is “well differentiated from hares considered belonging to brown hares L. europaeus from central Europe” (Awadi et al. 2016). In light of this continuing uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of the Sardinian and North African Hares, both will remain included in capensis and L. europaeus retains its taxonomic status as a distinct species.

Many treatments indicate that the range of L. capensis extends into China, Mongolia and Russia; however, recognition of L. tibetanus and L. tolai as distinct species removes consideration of L. capensis as occurring in this region (Hoffmann and Smith 2005).

There are no recognized subspecies in Hoffmann and Smith (2005). However, following Wang (2002), Smith and Xie (2008) and Smith et al. (2018) recognized three subspecies: Lepus comus comus (western Yunnan), L. c. peni (eastern Yunnan, western Guizhou, and southwestern Sichuan), and L. c. pygmaeus (Yunnan).

Lepus comus was formerly included in L. oiostolus, but is now recognized as a true species (Hoffmann and Smith 2005). The differentiation is based on ecological and morphological differences between the two species (Cai and Feng 1982, Wang et al. 1985). Molecular phylogenetics indicates that L. comus and oiostolus are sister taxa (Wu et al. 2005).

There are no recognized subspecies (Hoffmann and Smith 2005). There has been past uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Lepus coreanus with regard to other Lepus species in the region (Flux and Angermann 1990, Koh et al. 2001). It has previously been included in the Chinese Hare (L. sinensis), Japanese Hare (L. brachyurus), and the mountain Hare (L. timidus) (Hoffmann and Smith 2005, Wu et al. 2005). A study of mitochondrial cytochrome b gene sequencing has shown that L. coreanus is indeed a valid species (Koh et al. 2001), and that it is most closely related to the Manchurian Hare (L. mandshuricus).

The taxonomy of Lepus europaeus is still under debate. Clear distinction to other taxa is difficult due to sympatric occurrences with other Lepus species. The European Hare was formerly included in the Cape Hare (L. capensis) based on a cline in morphological characters (mainly size) from north-eastern Africa eastwards across the northern Arabian peninsula, the Middle East and northwards through Israel to Turkey (Petter 1961). A reanalysis showed a discontinuity between smaller “capensis” and larger “europaeus” running from the eastern Mediterranean coast through Iran (Ben Slimen et al. 2008).
