The treatment here follows Groves (2013) in recognizing, at least provisionally, three species: E. rufifrons occurring from Senegal to Sudan, west of the White Nile; E. albonotata in the Sudd of South Sudan, and E. tilonura to the east of the Blue Nile. Genetic research to clarify the relationships between these three forms and E. thomsonii is highly desirable.
Gazella speckei is a monotypic species, with no geographical variation reported.

Recent research has shown that Arabian Sand Gazelle (G. s. marica) is genetically distinct and and is now regarded as a separate species Gazella marica (Wacher et al. 2010).

Three further subspecies have been recognized: G. s. hilleriana; G. s. yarkandensis; and the nominate form, Persian Goitered Gazelle G. s. subgutturosa (Kingswood and Blank 1996, Grubb 2005). However most of these subspecies have not been verified by genetic analysis. Only the species is assessed here.

Several arrangements of the gazelles in the genus Eudorcas have been proposed, varying from one to four species. Thomson’s Gazelle (Eudorcas thomsonii) has been treated variously as conspecific with Mongalla Gazelle (E. albonotata) and/or Red-fronted Gazelle (E. rufifrons) (Gentry 1972, Kingdon 1997, East 1999) or as a separate species. The form tilonura, from east of the Nile River, is either considered a subspecies of E. rufifrons (e.g. Grubb 2005), or a distinct species (Groves 2013). The treatment here follows Groves (2013) in recognizing, at least provisionally, four species, including E. thomsonii. Genetic research to clarify the relationships between all four forms is highly desirable.

Included in the genus Eudorcas following Groves (2000) and Grubb (2005). Mongalla Gazelle is here treated as a species distinct from Thomson's Gazelle (E. thomsonii), following recent authors (FitzGibbon and Wilmshurst 2013, Groves 2013, Hashim and Kingdon 2013) (though see Grubb 2005 who includes it with Red-fronted Gazelle G. rufifrons).

Six subspecies have been described, but the validity of most of these is still in doubt, and recent genetic studies have shown that only the western African subspecies (Hippotragus equinus koba) constitutes a genetically separate group from those in the rest of Africa (Alpers et al. 2004). Management authorities therefore work with Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) and use H. e. equinus as the putative indigenous subspecies within the assessment region. Hippotragus e. cottoni should also be seen as an indigenous subspecies. The equinus/cottoni complex is treated as one by nature conservation authorities as there may be no significant genetic differences between the two. Many of the Roan Antelope in South Africa are H. e. cottoni or equinus x cottoni (especially on private properties).

Four subspecies are usually recognized: H. n. niger, H. n. kirkii, H. n. roosevelti and the isolated Giant Sable (H. n. variani) from Angola. As for many other antelope species, the validity and precise distribution of most of the described subspecies are uncertain. An extensive study of the geographical genetic structure of Hippotragus niger identified three genetic subdivisions representing a Kenya and east Tanzania clade (H. n. roosevelti), a west Tanzania clade (H. n. kirkii), and a southern African clade (H. n. niger) (Pitra et al. 2002), which corroborated the findings of Matthee and Robinson (1999) that delineated a genetic barrier between the east and southern African (Angola, Zambia and Malawi southwards) clades, thus cautioning against translocations between the two areas.

Four distinct lechwe populations are recognized as subspecies (Ansell and Banfield 1979, Birungi and Arctander 2001): Black Lechwe (K. l. smithemani); Kafue Lechwe (K. l. kafuensis); Red Lechwe (K. l. leche); and the extinct Robert's Lechwe (K. l. robertsi). A fifth taxon, the Upemba Lechwe from south-eastern DR Congo, which Cotterill (2005) described as a distinct species, is treated here as a subspecies, K. l. anselli.

Although previously regarded as separate species, the Defassa Waterbuck and the Common Waterbuck are now listed as the subspecies Kobus ellipsiprymnus defassa and K. e. ellipsiprymnus, respectively. These subspecies can be distinguished by differences in coat colouration, rump patterns, genetics (Lorenzen et al. 2006) and geographic range. Their distributions overlap somewhat in East Africa, where genetically intermediate populations exist, suggesting a high degree of hybridisation in the Nairobi National Park population in Kenya (Lorenzen et al. 2006).

Several subspecies have been named but three are usually recognized: White-eared Kob K. k. leucotis; Uganda Kob K. k. thomasi; and Buffon’s Kob K. k. kob (Kingdon 1997, East 1999, Fischer 2013). Lorenzen et al. (2007) question the taxonomic status of K. k. kob and K. k. thomasi as two separate subspecies due to the similarity of their mtDNA sequences (although they are phenotypically distinct). Birungi (1999) proposed that the Puku (Kobus vardonii) might be a subspecies of the Kob rather than a distinct species.
Molecular data (Birungi and Arctander 2000) provide evidence that the Puku may be a subspecies of the more widely distributed kob Kobus kob.

Previously this species was considered a subspecies of the Gemsbok Oryx gazella, but is here treated as distinct following Kingdon (1997), Grubb (2005) and Wacher and Kingdon (2013). Two subspecies are recognized: Beisa Oryx (O. b. beisa) and Fringe-eared Oryx (O. b. callotis), north and south of the Tana River, respectively. The two subspecies are morphologically recognizable and analysis of mtDNA control region and cytochrome b sequences revealed significant genetic differentiation and historic isolation (Masembe et al. 2006). However, three distinct lineages are present within the species, one corresponding to O. b. callotis and the other two within O. b. beisa, the latter demonstrating ancient introgressive hybridization (Masembe et al. 2006, Wacher and Kingdon 2013).

Previously regarded as a single species, Gemsbok (O. gazella) and Beisa Oryx (O. beisa), from East Africa, are now considered distinct species based on taxonomic results revealing high (40%) genetic divergence between haplotypes (Osmers et al. 2012), morphology and geographic distribution (Grubb 2005). Osmers et al. (2012) do, however, recommend further molecular investigations into the genetics of the species to confirm their results. Currently, no subspecies have been identified within the assessment region.

The common name may be derived from the Khoikhoi name orabi (Skinner & Chimimba 2005).

Apparent regional differences in body size and colouration have led to 13 Oribi subspecies being suggested (Ansell 1972). However, to date no genetic work has been done to confirm whether these different populations are in fact different subspecies (Brashares & Arcese 2013). Nevertheless, the latest look at these different populations suggests 12 possible subspecies (Brashares & Arcese 2013). These include: O. o. ourebi, O. o. hastata, O. o. rutila, O. o. cottoni, O. o. masakensis, O. o. aequatoria, O. o. kenyae, O. o. haggardi, O. o. gallarum, O. o. montana, O. o. gosling and O. o. quadriscopa. Of these, O. o. haggardi, which is found in Kenya and Somalia, is the only population geographically isolated from the rest of the subspecies (Brashares & Arcese 2013). Sadly, O. o. keniae from Mount Kenya is now extinct (Hillman et al. 1988).

Generally, three subspecies are recognised in southern Africa (Skinner & Chimimba 2005; Brashares & Arcese 2013) with O. o. ourebi (Zimmermann, 1783) occurring in South African, and southern and central Mozambique. A recent genetic study (van Vuuren et al. in prep.) has found that there is a high genetic variability within the South Africa Oribi population, and thus the population is healthy. Moreover, the genetic evidence indicates that all Oribi in South Africa belong to a single (panmictic) population. Thus, suggestions of geographic genetic differences north and south of the Tugela River are unfounded.

The Chiru or Tibetan Antelope is the only representative of a rather aberrant Caprinae genus (Pantholops) (Gatesy et al. 1997). It has previously been classified as a monotypic tribe Pantholopini and together with Saiga (Saiga tatarica) in a separate tribe Saigini.

Recent molecular work indicates that this species is a sister taxon to a clade that includes both waterbuck (Kobus) and reedbuck (Redunca) species (Robinson et al. 2014). No subspecies are recognised (Skinner & Chimimba 2005)

Procapra przewalskii has been considered a subspecies of Procapra picticaudata but species status is unanimously agreed. Genetic analysis shows the taxon is closer to the Mongolian Gazelle P. gutturosa than to P. picticaudata.
No subspecies are recognised (Skinner and Chimimba 2005).

Although various subspecies have been suggested, for example Ansell (1972) recorded eight and Meester et al. (1986) listed five subspecies south of the Sahara Desert, the validity of these subspecies remains questionable. Two commonly accepted subspecies include Raphicerus campestris campestris from southern Africa and R. c. neumanni from East Africa (Kingdon 1997; du Toit 2013). Taxonomic revision of this species is necessary (Skinner & Chimimba 2005).

A polytypic species; several subspecies have been named, but only two are widely recognised (Kingdon & Hoffmann 2013): a northern (R. a. occidentalis) and a southern (R. a. arundinum) (Skinner & Chimimba 2005), the latter of which is found in the assessment region. Only the species is assessed here.

There are three recognised subspecies (Ansell 1972; IUCN SSC Antelope Specialist Group 2008; Avenant 2013): Western Mountain Reedbuck (R. f. adamauae), Chanler’s Mountain Reedbuck (R. f. chanleri), and Southern Mountain Reedbuck (R. f. fulvorufula), which is the only subspecies to occur in the assessment region (Skinner & Chimimba 2005).
As many as seven subspecies have been recognized, which Kingdon and Hoffmann (2013) reduced to five, noting that a review was necessary.

Saiga tatarica is the only species in the genus Saiga. Two subspecies are recognised: Saiga tatarica tatarica (to which the majority of the global population belongs), and Saiga tatarica mongolica, endemic to western Mongolia.

Mongolian Saiga was first described as a separate species, Saiga mongolica by Bannikov (1946) based on differences in skull measurements, shape and size of horns, and colour of pelage. However, the author later revised his opinion and considered it to be only a subspecies (Bannikov 1954).

Grubb (2005) recognized the Pleistocene mammoth-steppe Saiga as a distinct species S. borealis, following Baryshnikov and Tikhonov (1994) and included the living subspecies mongolica. However, a later analysis of mtDNA from 93 tissue samples from all five extant Saiga populations confirmed that S. tatarica mongolica is genetically distinct, whereas the four populations of the nominate subspecies are polyphyletic, consistent with recent fragmentation and population declines; there were slight but clear differences between S. t. mongolica and S. t. tatarica, confirming the current designation of S. t. mongolica as a subspecies rather than a species Kholodova et al. (2006).

A second genetic study (Campos et al. 2010) analysed modern and fossil Saiga using mtDNA from 27 ancient and 38 modern specimens from all parts of Saiga range, including two specimens of putative S. borealis. The results showed two distinct lineages, the first including all modern and fossil Saiga from north-east Yakutia and the Urals; the second occurring only in the northern Urals and is now extinct. Campos et al. (2010) conclude that: “...the data suggest that S. borealis does not constitute a distinct subspecies or species”. Furthermore, the authors of this 2010 study include both Baryshnikov and Tikhonov, co-authors of the 1994 paper, and who are therefore regarded as supporting this revised view (Mallon 2016a).

The two genetic studies carried out to date show slight genetic differences between the two forms and agree that mongolica should be considered a subspecies. However, these conclusions are based on mtDNA only and depend on a relatively small number of Mongolian samples. For a definitive view of the phylogenetic relationship between tatarica and mongolica, further analysis based on a larger sample size and including nuclear DNA is needed.

As many as fourteen subspecies of Sylvicapra grimmia have been recognised in Africa (Grubb & Groves 2001; Wilson 2013), however it is difficult to identify the precise geographic limits of each subspecies as the Common Duiker has a continuous distribution across sub-Saharan Africa (Wilson 2013). Some of these subspecies can be distinguished based on colouration and size characteristics (Wilson 2013). Within the assessment region, S. g. grimmia occurs in the extreme south of the species’ range (Western, Eastern and Northern Cape provinces; Skinner & Chimimba 2005), and is substantially greyer in colour compared to the other subspecies, hence the alternate name, Grey Duiker in the Cape (Wilson 2013). Sylvicapra g. caffa is found further north of S. g. grimmia within the KwaZulu-Natal, North West, Gauteng, Mpumalanga and Limpopo provinces (Skinner & Chimimba 2005), extending into southern Mozambique and eastern Zimbabwe (Wilson 2013). The sandy-coloured S. g. steinhardti ranges throughout Namibia into Angola, Botswana and marginally into the Northern Cape Province to Port Nolloth (Wilson 2013). While distribution is continuous, there are many cases of intergradation but geographical boundaries between forms have not been delineated accurately (IUCN SSC Antelope Specialist Group 2016). Hence only the species is assessed here.

The African Buffalo (Syncerus caffer) exhibits substantial morphological variability (Skinner and Chimimba 2005), resulting in controversies regarding the recognition of the various subspecies (Smitz et al. 2013). Recent evidence supports the separation of two distinct groups, corresponding to a West and Central African group and an East and Southern African group (Smitz et al. 2013). The East and Southern African group is comprised of a single subspecies (Syncerus caffer caffer), which is found in the assessment region. The West and Central African group is assigned to two or three subspecies (S. c. nanus, S. c. brachyceros and S. c. aequinoctialis), although the latter two of these subspecies are not recognised by all authorities (Le Roex et al. 2012, Smitz et al. 2013).

The West African Savannah Buffalo, S. c. brachyceros (from Senegal to Cameroon) and the Central African Savannah Buffalo, S. c. aequinoctialis (from Central Africa to Sudan) are morphologically intermediate between S. c. caffer (Southern Savannah Buffalo) and S. c. nanus (Forest Buffalo) (Skinner and Chimimba 2005). Forest Buffalo are adapted to forest life, having a smaller size, unobtrusive swept back horns and a red to reddish-brown colouration, and are restricted to West Africa (Skinner and Chimimba 2005). Southern Savannah Buffalo are about twice the size of Forest Buffalo, with large downward curved horns and a brownish to black colouration (Smitz et al. 2013). The taxonomic uncertainty in these four subspecies is corroborated by the observation of interbreeding and intermediate phenotypes in contact zones between all four subspecies (Prins 1996), and at least one reported cross between S. c. caffer and S. c. nanus (Smitz et al. 2013). Based on recent genetic results, S. c. brachyceros and S. c. aequinoctialis would be included in S. c. nanus following standard nomenclature rules (Smitz et al. 2013). Evidence suggests that buffalo populations in Uganda and the Central African Republic display the highest genetic diversity of all African Buffalo populations and this could be the region where the most overlap exists between the two main groups (S. c. nanus and S. c. caffer) (Smitz et al. 2013). Analysis of 766 mtDNA sequences from 43 localities indicates that S. c. caffer is found in Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Botswana, South Africa and Namibia (Smitz et al. 2013).

The valid name of this species is Damaliscus pygargus, not Damaliscus dorcas which appears more commonly in the literature (see Rookmaaker 1991; Grubb 1999, 2005; David and Lloyd 2013). Two well-differentiated subspecies are recognized: the Bontebok D. p. pygargus and the Blesbok D. p. phillipsi. The two have been considered as separate species by some (e.g., Allen 1939, and see Essop et al. 1991), but are here regarded as conspecific.

This species was separated from Gazella and placed in the genus Nanger along with N. granti and N. dama by Grubb (2005) and this arrangement is widely followed. Three subspecies have been named, based on variations in coat colour and horns. The boundaries between the three forms have not been clearly delineated and their validity has not been confirmed by genetic analysis. Only the species is assessed here.
Prunus concinna Koehne is a genetic relative of Sweet Cherry P. avium (L.) L. having been used as graftstock for this crop (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Cryptomys hottentotus whytei, currently included here as a subspecies, may be a distinct species (Faulkes et al. 2004).

Taylor et al. (2009) and Engelbrecht et al. (2011) used mitochondrial and ecological data to delineate between two cryptic species: Otomys irroratus (Western and Eastern Cape Provinces) and Otomys auratus (Free State, KwaZulu-Natal Northern Cape, and Mpumalanga Provinces), with a contact zone between the two species in the Eastern Cape around Alice. These species correspond to bioregions (O. irroratus pertaining to fynbos and thicket regions; O. auratus pertaining to high-lying grasslands) rather than karyotype; and thus no subspecies are recognised (Taylor 2013). Similarly, while O. tropicalis was formerly included in O. irroratus sensu lato, the two can be distinguished on morphological and molecular grounds (Taylor et al. 2011).

Aethomys ineptus was split from A. chrysophilus based on chromosome number (A. intepus is 2n = 44 while A. chrysophilus is 2n = 50), sperm morphology and molecular data (Breed et al. 1988; Chimimba et al. 1998, 1999; Linzey et al. 2003; Russo et al. 2006). They cannot be separated by external or cranial features. However, the average separation between A. chrysophilus and A. ineptus based on mitochondrial DNA sequences is 2.70% (range = 1.69–3.78%), which is less genetic variation than within A. chrysophilus (Russo et al. 2006).

While the type locality for A. ineptus is Tete, along the Zambezi River in northern Mozambique, the species described as A. ineptus has yet to be positively reported north of the Limpopo River (see Linzey et al. 2003; Russo et al. 2006), and therefore is unlikely to occur further north in the Tete region of Mozambique. Hence, the name ineptus is probably a synonym of A. chrysophilus and the species will need a new name. Furthermore, although craniometrics analysis previously indicated A. ineptus extended north of the Limpopo River (see Chimimba et al. 1999; Chimimba 2001), more recent chromosomal and molecular work suggests that the species is restricted to south of the Limpopo River (Linzey et al. 2003; Russo et al. 2006), which means the species, based on available data, is near endemic or endemic to the assessment region (Monadjem et al. 2015).

Prunus rivularis Scheele belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh. and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl.; it has also been used as graftstock for Apricot P. armeniaca and Plum P. domestica L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species is considered a synonym of P. munsoniana W.Wight & Hedrick in the Flora of North America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006), however, The Plant List (2013) treats these two taxa as separate species, this is also the case in NatureServe (2013). Here the taxonomy used follows that of The Plant List.

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group.

Formerly included in a monophyletic group, the subfamily Acinonychinae (e.g., Wozencraft 1993), molecular evidence now clusters the Cheetah with the Puma Puma concolor and Jaguarundi P. yagouaroundi in the tribe Acinonychini, diverging some 6.9 million years ago (Johnson et al. 2006, O'Brien and Johnson 2007). A close relationship between these three species is in agreement with earlier studies (Johnson and O’Brien 1997, Bininda-Emonds et al. 1999, Mattern and MacLennan 2000). 


Krausman and Morales (2005) list five Cheetah subspecies: 

A. j. hecki Hilzheimer, 1913: Northwest Africa 
A. j. fearsoni (Smith, 1834): East Africa 
A. j. jubatus (Schreber, 1775): Southern Africa 
A. j. soemmerringi (Fitzinger, 1855): Northeast Africa 
A. j. venaticus (Griffith, 1821): North Africa to central India 

Only A. j. jubatus and A. j. raineyii have been compared using genetic analysis, and found to be extremely similar, but the subspecies distinction was still retained (O’Brien et al. 1987). 

The subspecies A. j. venaticus, commonly called the Asiatic Cheetah, is considered by Nowell and Jackson (1996) to survive only in Iran. They place the eastern limit of its range in Arabia. However, the review by Krausman and Morales (2005) included Cheetahs from the northern Sahara in venaticus. The type locality of A. j. venaticus (=Felis venatica [Griffith, 1821]) is unknown (Krausman and Morales 2005). At a November 2006 meeting of the North African Region Cheetah Action Group (NARCAG), Belbachir (2007) recommended genetic studies to clarify whether the Cheetahs of Algeria (which probably has the largest Saharan Cheetah population) should be classified as A. j. hecki or A. j. venaticus. Presently A. j. venaticus is considered restricted to Asia. 

The English name is derived from the Hindi Chita, meaning "spotted one". The generic name Acinonyx is a reference to its non-retractile claws (Caro 1994).

The taxonomy of the species remains unclear. Felis bieti was recently attributed species status by Kitchener and Rees (2009), based on morphology and potential sympatry with Asian Wildcat (Felis silvestris ornata). Genetic evidence has indicated F. bieti to be a subspecies of Felis silvestris (Driscoll et al. 2007), however, greater sampling and assessment of genetic materials from individuals living in the wild is urgently required to be able to draw firm conclusions. Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group.

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group (2014). Once thought to be closely related to the lynxes, which share its characteristic traits of tufted ears, long limbs and a short tail (Sunquist and Sunquist 2002), the Jungle Cat is actually a close relative of the domestic cat.  With a wide range, a number of subspecies have been proposed (Wozencraft 2005 recognized nine), but Corbet and Hill (1992) argue that the pelage characters used by classical designators vary widely.  No modern analysis of subspeciation has been undertaken.

Two subspecies have been described and these persist in theory (Meester et al. 1986). Felis nigripes nigripes, the nominate genotype form described by Burchell, was first described from near Kuruman in the Northern Cape. Its range includes present-day south eastern Namibia, Botswana, Northern Cape, North West, Gauteng, Limpopo and marginally into Mpumalanga. Felis nigripes thomasi (Shortridge 1931) is described from a specimen collected near Grahamstown in the Eastern Cape. Its range includes the present-day Eastern Cape, westwards to the southern regions of the Northern Cape and the Free State.

However, Smithers (1971) doubted the validity of two subspecies, and his thought is shared by Sliwa (2013) who suggests that the species may be polymorphic in the centre of its range but does exhibit on some geocline variations towards the extremes of its range. The northern race typically tends to be paler with less distinct striping whereas the southern race has a more tawny appearance with bolder patterning. However, since there are no obvious geographical or ecological barriers between the ranges which are the leading causes of genetic drift and speciation (Hoskin et al. 2005), it is likely that the subspecies status is invalid (Wilson 2016).

There is currently no clear agreement on how to relate geographically linked variation in morphology and genetics to the taxonomy and systematics of the widely distributed Wildcat (Felis silvestris) (Kitchener and Rees 2009). The latest phylogeographical analyses (Driscoll et al. 2007, 2009; Macdonald et al. 2010) suggest that the Wildcat consists of five subspecific groups and three traditional subspecies (Nowell and Jackson 1996, Stuart et al. 2013): including the recent recognition of the Southern African Wildcat (F. s. cafra Desmarest, 1822).

Based on genetic, morphological and archaeological evidence, the familiar housecat was believed to have been domesticated from the Near Eastern Wildcat (F. s. lybica), probably 9,000–10,000 years ago in the Fertile Crescent region (Vigne et al. 2004, Driscoll et al. 2007), coinciding with the first agricultural settlements (Driscoll et al. 2007, Macdonald et al. 2010). Although the domestic cat derived relatively recently from the Wildcat, in terms of biological processes and phylogeny, it can be taxonomically classified either as a subspecies (F. s. catus) of F. silvestris or as a separate species (F. catus) (Macdonald et al. 2010). Recent evidence supports the classification of domestic cats as genetically distinct from Wildcats (Driscoll et al. 2007).

For the purposes of this assessment, although we recognise the potential validity of the Southern African Wildcat (F. s. cafra), we defer to the species level until further research can accurately delineate subspecific geographical boundaries.

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group.  Johnson et al. (2006) and Eizirik et al. (2008) placed yagouaroundi in the genus Puma. However, Agnarsson et al. (2010) noted that the Jaguarundi is not a sister species to the Puma. More recently Segura et al. (2013) looked at cranial development within the Puma clade and found that while this is similar in Cheetah and Puma, that of the Jaguarundi is quite different. Given these phylogenetic uncertainties, and these and other morphological and behavioural differences, the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group retains this species in Herpailurus.

A recent molecular phylogenetic study revealed that the Serval is closely related to both the African Golden Cat (Caracal aurata) and the Caracal (Caracal caracal) (Johnson et al. 2006), diverging from a common ancestor approximately 5.4 million years ago, though distinct enough to be monospecific (O’Brien & Johnson 2007). The Serval taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group (Thiel 2015). Only one subspecies is recognised from within the assessment region, L. s. serval (Meester et al. 1986).
Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group (2014). Placed in Lynx according to genetic analysis (Johnson et al. 2006).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group.  Included in the genus Leopardus by Johnson et al. (2006). No genetic evidence of geographic subspecific partitioning was found in an analysis by Johnson et al. (1999). A zone of hybridization was found in southern Brazil where the northern extent of L. geoffroyi's range meets the southernmost extent of the range of the Oncilla, L. tigrinus (Eizirik et al. 2007).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. Previously recognized as belonging to a monotypic genus Oreailurus (Cabrera 1940, Wozencraft 1993, Nowell and Jackson 1996, Yensen and Seymour 2000), the Andean Cat is included in the genus Leopardus. The genus Leopardus includes most small Neotropical felids, and speciation within it has been relatively recent compared to other felid lineages (Johnson et al. 2006). While there is strong support for inclusion of the Andean Cat in this genus based on genetic analysis, how closely it is related to the Pampas Cat L. colocolo remains unclear. The classification of the Andean Cat as Oreailurus was based in part, from very few specimens, on the relative size difference in the skull's auditory chambers, but this trait is also found in other felid species (Johnson et al. 1998, Garcia-Perea 2002). The specific name, jacobita, is in honour of Jacobita Mantagazza (Cornalia 1865) and should not be declined to jacobitus (Yensen and Seymour 2000) as is sometimes seen in the literature. This is one of only two felids for which no subspecies have been classically described (Nowell and Jackson 1996).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group.  We currently follow Luo et al. (2004), who confirmed the division of Tiger into six extant subspecies on the basis of distinctive molecular markers:

Amur Tiger P. t. altaica: Russian Far East and northeastern China
Northern Indochinese Tiger P. t. corbetti: Indochina north of the Malayan Peninsula
Malayan Tiger P. t. jacksoni: Peninsular Malaysia
Sumatran Tiger P. t. sumatrae: Sumatra
Bengal Tiger P. t. tigris: Indian sub-continent
South China Tiger P. t. amoyensis (although this subspecies has not been directly observed in the wild since the 1970s and is possibly extinct)

Three subspecies previously recognized on the basis of morphology are extinct:

Bali Tiger P. t. balica Schwarz, 1912: Bali
Javan Tiger P. t. sondaica (Temminck, 1844): Java
Caspian Tiger P. t. virgata (Illiger, 1815): dry river valleys of the Takla Makan, western slopes of the Tianshan mountains, Amudarya and Syrdarya river valleys, shores of the Caspian sea, Elburz mountains, eastern Turkey, Tigris and Euphrates river valleys.

On the basis of morphological analysis, Groves (1997) suggested recognition of several distinct island subspecies, including:

P. b. borneoensis Brongersma, 1936: Borneo

P. b. heaneyi Groves, 1997: Palawan Island, Philippines

P. b. javenensis (Desmarest, 1816): Java and Bali

P. b. rabori Groves, 1997: Negros, Cebu and Panay islands, Philippines

P. b. sumatranus (Horsfield, 1821): Sumatra and the offshore island of Tebingtinggi

One mainland subspecies is generally recognized: the nominate P. b. bengalensis (Kerr 1792) (Groves 1997), but a number of mainland subspecies have been classically described, including the Amur Leopard Cat P. b. euptilurus of the Korean Peninsula, Russian Far East and northeast China. This was earlier proposed as a distinct species based on morphological differences from southeast Asian specimens, but Chinese specimens have been shown to be similar to those from southeast Asia and this distinction is not recognized (Wozencraft 2005).

The Iriomote Cat P. b. iriomotensis, from Japan's Iriomote island, was also originally described as a distinct species based on morphology (Imaizumi 1967), but based on genetic analysis is now considered a subspecies of Leopard Cat (Masuda and Yoshida 1995, Johnson et al. 1999).

Recent genetic analysis (Luo et al. 2014) suggests species-level distinction between the Indochinese and Sundaic populations of the Leopard Cat although further research is needed to support this.
Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group (2014). Placed in Prionailurus according to genetic analysis (Johnson et al. 2006, O'Brien and Johnson 2007).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. Placed in Prionailurus according to genetic analysis (Johnson et al. 2006, O'Brien and Johnson 2007). No modern analysis of subspecies available.

Formerly this species was placed in the genus Uncia but it is now assigned to Panthera according to genetic analysis (Johnson et al. 2006). It is most closely related to the tiger Panthera tigris, having diverged over two million years ago (O'Brien and Johnson 2007). Two subspecies have been named based on minor morphological differences (Medvedev 2000) but have not been confirmed by genetic analysis.

Prunus americana Marshall belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of peach P. persica (L.) Batsch and Japanese plum P. salicin Lindl.; it is also a tertiary genetic relative of plum P. domestica L. and is used as graft stock for apricot P. armeniaca L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus angustifolia Marshall belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Japanese Plum P. salicina (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Described as synonym of Anemone pulsatilla L. by The Plant List .
This was formerly classified as Rhinella granulosa, but all specimens from Panama are know classified as Rhinella centralis (Narvaes & Rodrigues 2009).

Southern populations presently assigned to this species appear to resemble Liolaemus bitaeniatus and may be referrable to the latter species (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016). If so, L. variegatus would be restricted to higher elevations in the vicinity of the type locality, with L. bitaeniatus replacing it in warmer inter-Andean valleys.
Real´s Wood White has recently been separated from the Wood White (L. sinapis). However, in the field the species cannot be distinguished from each other.

The Vipera ursinii species complex (or the synonymous subgenus Acridophaga REUSS, 1927) has a large distribution area from Eastern France to Western China, which was shaped by the last three glacial periods (Ferchaud et al. 2012). This species group comprises small vipers, which live in grasslands, either in lowlands or on mountain tops (Nilson and Andrén 2001). In the last two decades some V. ursinii subspecies have been elevated to distinct species level based on molecular and morphological analyses (V. renardi, V. anatolica, and V. eriwanensis). The Greek Meadow Viper (Vipera ursinii graeca) was described as a subspecies of Vipera ursinii by Nilson and Andrén (1988) based on morphological analyses. Ferchaud et al. (2012) proposed that V. u. graeca should be elevated to species, according to the results of mitochondrial DNA phylogenetic analyses. Based on a mitochondrial and nuclear DNA analyses Mizsei et al. (2017) proposed a full species rank for the Greek Meadow Viper (=Vipera graeca) to resolve the polyphyly in the Vipera ursinii–renardi complex.

Narcissus jacquemoudii is widely considered a synonym of Narcissus romieuxii subsp. jacquemoudii (Fern.Casas) Zonn. (e-Monocot 2014, Euro+Med 2014, WCSP 2014), however, we retain it as a valid species here supported by Fennane and Ibn Tattou (1998), Dobignard and Chatelain (2010), and Rankou et al. (2013).

Ammoides pusilla was already described and the name validly published by Félix de Avellar Brotero. Maurice A.F. Breistroffer, however, reclassified it into todays valid botanical systematics.


Polygonum aviculare L. Polygonum equisetiforme S.M., Polygonum maritimum L., and Daucus crinitus Desf. are misapplied names.
Mandragora officinarum sec. auct. non L. is a misapplied name.
Corrigiola litoralis subsp. telephiifolia (Pourr.) Briq. is a misapplied name.
The taxonomic status of this species is not clear.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. For long it was considered a subspecies of E. variegatus but recently it has been elevated to a separate species. However, its true taxonomic status is in need of revision.
Additional work differentiating this species from nearby populations of Ambystoma velasci is needed (Shaffer and McKnight 1996).
This species was previously included in the genus Pternohyla which was synonymized with Smilisca (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Scaphiopus hurterii was formerly regarded as a subspecies of S. holbrookii, but checklists (Crother et al. 2000, Collins and Taggart 2002) have treated it as a distinct species. Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

Based on mitochondrial DNA (Shaffer and McKnight 1996) and allozymes (Shaffer 1984) this species is extremely closely related to several other populations from the Mesa Central, and species boundaries are in need of careful review.
This form might be a complex of more than one species consisting of two taxa from the northern and southern parts of the range (Shaffer 1983, Shaffer and McKnight 1996).
This form is a complex of more than one species.

This form is a complex of more than one species (Dubois 1987), and further taxonomic work is required to fully delineate this species (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018). Subpopulations in northern Viet Nam and Lao People's Democratic Republic that were previously believed to have been Limnonectes hascheanus have now been assigned to Limnonectes limborgii (T. Nguyen pers. comm. October 2013).
The correct placement of the species requires confirmation, with some references (e.g., The Plant List 2014) placing the species in Anenome.

This species, which formerly included two subspecies (Micrurus pyrrocryptus pyrrhocryptus and M. p. tricolor) was split in two valid species, with the elevation of M. p. tricolor to full species status (da Silva Jr and Sites 1999).

There is a narrow zone of intergradation between Amphisbaena angustifrons and A. plumbea, in which there are individuals with intermediate characters, and there is a possibility that it is one species (Gans 1965, Gans and Diefenbach 1972).

This species should be considered endemic to Catamarca, Argentina (Troncoso-Palacios 2014). However, this species is taxonomically problematic because the type specimens are apparently lost and its type locality is unclear (Lobo et al. 2010, Troncoso-Palacios 2014). If it is not possible to collect topotypic specimens matching the description of the type to designate a neotype, Liolaemus andinus should be considered a nomen dubium, since it is a name of unknown application. Records from Jujuy (Argentina) and Atacama (Chile) probably correspond to other species (Troncoso-Palacios 2014).

authority: Breitman, Fulvio-Pérez, Parra, Morando, Sites & Avila, 2011

taxonomicNotes: The taxonomy of this species is currently being reviewed. It is possible that it is a junior synonym of L. kriegi (Medina 2015).
This species was confused with Eleutherodactylus sierramaestrae prior to its description.
Was under Iguanidae.

Liolaemus pantherinus was originally described based on two juvenile specimens, using two characters that are not sufficient either alone or in combination to validly distinguish a species of Liolaemus (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016). The name was not subsequently used in the literature to describe either a valid species or a synonym, even in comparative studies of related species, until Donoso-Barros (1966) who considered it an established species within the Chilean fauna.

Its taxonomic status has subsequently been uncertain; Laurent (1982) suggested that it represented a juvenile L. ornatus, and subsequently (Laurent 1992) that it was indistinguishable from L. signifer. An examination of the cotypes (Etheridge in litt.) broadly supports the latter interpretation, although the scale counts this author reports are not identical to those in L. signifer.

Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2002) revalidated L. pantherinus as a valid species, a decision subsequently upheld by Etheridge and by Langstroth (2005). Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2002), however, further complicated the taxonomy of this group by proposing that L. islugensis should be considered a junior synonym of L. pantherinus. This opinion is still held by H. Núñez (pers. comm. 2016), who however cautions that he has not examined the specimens. The synonymy was justified in part by the identification of the type locality as Lake Titicaca by Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2002), however, the cotypes do not have an associated type locality (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016).

Ruiz de Gamboa and Ortiz (2010) recognize L. isuglensis as distinct from both L. pantherinus and L. signifer.

R. Langstroth (in litt.) has carried out a detailed examination of specimens originally collected by P.O. Simons, which include Bolivian material determined to be Liolaemus annectens by Boulenger and subsequently recognized as L. orientalis by Laurent (1990), as well as a series identified by Boulenger as L. signifer used by Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005) in their characterization of this species. This study concluded both that the latter authors were misled by the "L. signifer" specimens, which represent the population from Uyuni considered to be L. islugensis by Ruiz de Gamboa and Ortiz (2010), and that the L. pantherinus cotypes are conspecific with Boulenger's Bolivian L. annectens from Uyuni and Potosi (=L. orientalis).

While the taxonomy involved is extremely complex, in summary this account considers that L. pantherinus is a senior synonym of L. orientalis and is not closely-related to either L. signifer or L. islugensis, with which it has been confused historically largely due to confusion regarding the correct delimitation of L. signifer.
Currently research is underway to determine if this taxon represents more than one species.

The taxonomic status of this species remains unclear (Avila et al. 2013). It was synonymized with Liolaemus dorbignyi by Nuñez and Jaksic (1992), and revalidated again by Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005).

Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005) synonymized Liolaemus schmidti with L. andinus, however, Lobo et al. (2010) disagree with this synonymy on the basis that L. andinus is taxonomically problematic because the type specimens are apparently lost and its type locality is unclear. R. Langstroth (pers. comm. 2016) has examined the L. schmidti type series and material from Catamarca and adjacent Chile and recommends considering the taxon valid on the basis of significant morphological differences, although it is part of a large group of taxonomically complex species related to Liolaemus multicolor which have never been subject to a taxonomic revision. As such, the true identity of many records is unknown. The concept applied in this account includes L. ormofi, a recent description considered a junior synonym of L. schmidti by Troncoso-Palacios (in litt.) and R. Langstroth (pers. comm. 2016).

Breitman et al. (2014) shows that there appears to be no genetic differentiation (based on mitochondrial markers) between this species and Liolaemus zullyae, recommending further studies to test whether there is hybridization between these species, or both represent a single species having two distinct male morphotypes.

There appears to be no genetic differentiation between this species and L. scolaroi. Detailed studies are needed to test whether there is hybridization between these species or if both represent a single species with two distinct male morphotypes (Breitman et al. 2014).
It is recommended that the taxonomic status of the subspecies be reviewed (Abdala et al. 2012, Avila et al. 2013).

Pincheira-Donoso et al. (2008) consider Phymaturus dorsimaculatus to be a junior synonym of P. vociferator, in which case this species would also occur in the Province of Neuquén, Argentina (Avila et al. 2013); however, Lobo et al. (2010) disagree with this synonymy and their scheme is followed here. M. Vidal (pers. comm. 2016) notes that no studies have been conducted that demonstrate this proposed synonymy. While Pincheira-Donoso et al. (2008) referred to previous work suggesting that the two taxa may be conspecific based on overlap between morphological traits (Pincheira-Donoso 2004), these authors provided no new data to support this conclusion and so the systematics of these taxa remains unresolved.

This species as it is currently known is probably a species complex (R. Espinoza pers. comm.). The occurrence of this species in Chile has been questioned, with suggestions that records are referable to a related species. Recent collections have, however, been taken from this country (M. Ruiz de Gamboa, unpubl. data) and the most recent published treatment of this species' distribution concluded that the species ranges to Arica and Parinacota Region in northern Chile (Troncoso-Palacios 2014).
The larva described as Aeshna peralta from Brazil (Santos 1966) corresponds to a different species (Rhionaeschna brasiliensis, von Ellenrieder and Costa 2002).

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Aguilar, Wood, Cusi, Guzman, Huari, Lundberg, Mortensen, Ramí, Robles, Suárez, Ticona, Vargas, Venegas & Sites, 2013
Aguilar, Wood, Cusi, Guzman, Huari, Lundberg, Mortensen, Ramí, Robles, Suárez, Ticona, Vargas, Venegas & Sites, 2013
Aguilar, Wood, Cusi, Guzman, Huari, Lundberg, Mortensen, Ramí, Robles, Suárez, Ticona, Vargas, Venegas & Sites, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This is a known species complex of at least ten species, some with restricted ranges in northeast Australia (C. Moritz pers. comm. 2017).
Anaxyrus baxteri was formerly included in this species.

While describing this species, Britton (1918) suggested that this species is closely related to P. polystachyus. Delgado-Salinas et al. (1999), place this species as a synonym of P. viridis, using ITS sequencing. However, a more recent study from the same author (Delgado-Salinas et al. 2006), the name P. lignosus is considered a valid and an accepted name.
Bombus mucidus was considered formerly as a distinct subgenus (Mucidobombus).

This species may be conspecific with B. hortorum but the taxonomic status is uncertain. No-one has a sufficiently broad analysis of this complex at present to conclude this authoritatively(P. Williams pers. comm. 2015).

Among the other members of the Bulbocodii section N. hedraeanthus is distinguishable for its dwarf size, with a typical small straw yellow-orange (more or less pale) with stamens exerted from corona: only in N. romieuxii Braun Blanquet & Maire stamens are also exerted but the colour is different and this species is growing in Morocco (Hanks 2002, Ríos et al. 2009, Fernández-Casas 2010). Currently two subspecies are accepted: the typical N. hedraeanthus subsp. hedraeanthus and N. hedraeanthus subsp. luteolentus (Barra & G.López) Aedo (= N. blancoi Barra & G.López) with pale yellow corolla and tube much larger than the type.

In the recent revision of genus Narcissus in the Flora Iberica (Aedo 2013), N. eugeniae is treated as a synonym of N. pseudonarcissus subsp. portensis (Pugsley) A.Fern.


However, the current opinion of WCSP (2017) is followed here, recognizing that the placement of the species may change to follow Aedo (2013).
There are two natural hybrid subpopulations between this species and the closely related N. segurensis.

Often included in the genus Alopex, current evidence suggests that inclusion in Vulpes (sensu Wozencraft 2005) is warranted as Vulpes is otherwise paraphyletic with respect to Alopex. Nuclear and matrilineal (mitochondrial) DNA unambiguously support the inclusion of Alopex lagopus in Vulpes (Geffen et al. 1992, Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005, Perini et al. 2010).

Hogna ingens was described in 1857 by John Blackwall (1857). Despite several taxonomic redescriptions from pioneer arachnologists (Blackwall 1867, Kulczynski 1899, Roewer 1960, Denis 1962 and later Wunderlich 1992), every other aspect of this remarkable species remained unknown until recently (Crespo et al. 2014).
The systematics of the various subpopulations need to be evaluated. There are four subspecies which will probably be described as distinct species in the near future (A. Diesmos pers. comm.).

Corsac Foxes range widely across Asia and several subspecies have been described. However, three subspecies are generally recognized, namely V. c. corsac, V. c. kalmykorum and V. c. turkmenicus (Clark et al. 2009). Range-wide genetic assessments of taxonomy have not been undertaken.

authority: Nuñez, Veloso, Espejo, Veloso, Cortes & Araya, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Was under Iguanidae.

There is uncertainty regarding the identity of records of this species from Argentina, considered to represent this species by Avila et al. (2013). Other authors suggest that these records may be referrable to L. abdalai (Quinteros 2012, Abdala et al. 2012).

We follow Córdova (1999) in treating Rhinella arequipensis as a variant phenotype of Rhinella spinulosa, and Bufo flavolineatus and Bufo trifolium as junior synonyms of Rhinella spinulosa. However, more than one species might be involved in Rhinella spinulosa. The form Rhinella spinulosa papillosa of Chile and Argentina is often considered distinct, but is not treated as such here.
The subpopulation from Huánuco likely comprises an undescribed species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). However, it is included in this assessment until it is formally described.
This form might be a complex of more than one species.
Pristimantis bellator is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr et al., 2007).
Oryza rufipogon Griff. is a primary wild relative of cultivated rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops biuncialis Vis. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii.

Two subspecies are native to Europe: Aegilops biuncialis ssp. archipelagica (Eig) Raus and Aegilops biuncialis Vis. ssp. biuncialis (Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly 2009).

The two subspecies of Pyrus communis L., P. communis subsp. caucasica (Fed.) Browicz and P. communis subsp. pyraster (L.) Ehrh. (syn. P. pyraster (L.) Baumg.), are wild relatives of cultivated pear, P. communis subsp. communis.
The origin of the species is not known, but may be of cultivated origin. The species is a unique tetraploid combination of Sorbus aria, Sorbus aucuparia and Sorbus torminalis.

This species was formerly classified in a distinct genus as Przewalskium albirostris, however, morphological, behavioural and genetic analyses align this species with the Red Deer clade (Wilson and Mittermeier 2011). No subspecies are recognized.

This is a well defined species (Grubb 1982, 2005; Groves et al. 1995). The form sifanicus was included in M. moschiferus as a subspecies by Ellerman and Morrison-Scott (1951) and considered an independent species by Gao (1963). However, Groves et al. (1995) included it in M. chrysogaster as subspecies. The chrysogaster of Cai and Feng (1981) is subspecifically or specifically distinct, and the available name for this taxon may be leucogaster Hodgson, 1839 (Groves et al. 1995, Grubb 2005). Some Chinese authors continue to recognize M. sifanicus as a full species (e.g., Yang et al. 2003, Zhou et al. 2004).

Currently, two subspecies are recognized in China:

1) M. c. chrysogaster (Hodgson, 1839) in southeastern and southern Tibet;
2) M. c. sifanicus (Büchner, 1891) in Qinghai, Gansu, Ningxia, western Sichuan and northwestern Yunnan.

There does not appear to be documentation of a clear delineation between these two forms.

This taxon is sometimes treated as a Himalayan subspecies of Alpine Musk Deer M. chrysogaster (e.g. Grubb 1990), but it was separated by Groves and Grubb (1987) and by Groves et al. (1995) on the basis of different skull proportions.

The lack of any biological type material for the oldest name (albeit of uncertain authorship: Meijaard and Groves 2004) referring to a chevrotain, javanicus, has led to its application within the genus Tragulus having a contorted history, elaborated in Meijaard and Groves (2004). In sum, into the 1940s, including within Chasen’s (1940) influential review, the name T. javanicus was used for the larger chevrotains here called T. napu, and T. kanchil was used for the smaller species (as here). Van Bemmel (1949), building on Chasen’s (1940: 194) comment that “I rather doubt if javanicus [i.e. the larger chevrotain] occurs there [ = anywhere on Java]”, proposed that T. javanicus must therefore refer to smaller chevrotains, and, as an older name, should displace the use of T. kanchil for these animals. This system almost universally was followed up to Meijaard and Groves (2004) who proposed that the smaller chevrotains contained several species, and that the form on Java was specifically distinct and endemic to the island. This form being T. javanicus, nearly all the off-Java forms fell once again under T. kanchil, although Tragulus k. williamsoni Kloss, 1916, placed within T. javanicus from Van Bemmel (1949) onwards, was, however not returned, but was segregated as a monotypic species by Meijaard and Groves (2004). Further change within the taxonomy and nomenclature of the genus is likely, given the ominous statement in Meijaard and Groves (2004) that "because many type specimens, especially of small island taxa are located in the Smithsonian Museum, which we did not visit, we were unable to assess the validity of all taxa. We intend to address the variation between these island taxa...in future publications". It has been suggested that T. (k.) klossi may be a distinct species (Meijaard et al. 2005).

Moschiola indica was recently segregated by Groves and Meijaard (2005) as a species separate from M. meminna, which they reserved for animals from parts of Sri Lanka. This segregation is founded upon a Phylogenetic Species Concept. Many sources up to 2005 referred to Indian animals as part of M. meminna (seen as the only species in the genus). Prior to Groves and Grubb (1987), the taxa within Moschiola were commonly referred to as Tragulus meminna. It is therefore under these two names (Moschiola meminna and Tragulus meminna) that most information on the species can be found.

This species was originally described as a subspecies of Alpine Musk Deer M. chrysogaster. It is very similar to Himalayan Musk Deer M. leucogaster, but Groves et al. (1995) suggested that it might be a separate species, a course followed by Grubb (2005) and it is so treated here.

Reviewed by McGrew (1979). Dragoo et al. (1990) considered Vulpes velox and Vulpes macrotis as conspecific; Mercure et al. (1993) retained both as separate species. Mercure et al. (1993) argued that the genetic differences between macrotis and velox were similar to that of Vulpes and Alopex, and therefore argued that they should be recognized at the species level (followed here) (and see Wozencraft 2005). 

Subspecific designations for Kit Foxes are not fully resolved. As many as eight subspecies have been recognized (McGrew 1979), although analyses by Dragoo et al. (1990) did not find support for any subspecific differentiation. However, although more subspecific clarification clearly is needed, most available data suggest that Kit Foxes in the San Joaquin Valley of California likely warrant subspecific designation, V. m. mutica, due to geographic isolation, and that all other Kit Foxes might be included within a second subspecies, V. m. macrotis (Waithman and Roest 1977, Mercure et al. 1993).
This species was described in 2015 by F.M. Crawford (Chase) and I. Darbyshire.

The Devenish record from northern KwaZulu-Natal may require investigation. However, Hilliard must have been quite certain of her identification to include it in her revision of the genus (Hilliard and Burtt 1991), although there are still some taxonomic problems within Dierama and some species are quite hard to differentiate (I. Johnson pers. comm.). This outlying record is not a unique case, and there are many other examples of such disjunctions (many of them collected by Devenish) between Wakkerstroom Montane Grasslands and either the KwaZulu-Natal Midlands Mistbelt and Drakensberg foothills grasslands or the high montane grasslands of the Mpumalanga escarpment. According to Mucina and Rutherford (2006), Wakkerstroom Montane Grasslands represent a relatively isolated link between the southern (KwaZulu-Natal) Drakensberg and northern (Mpumalanga) escarpment flora, which may explain why species distribution records tend to show such disjunctions.

H. castaneus and H. constellatus were recognized as recently diverged and distinct species by Greenbaum et al. (2013). The subspecies H. c. submarginatus from the Kabobo Plateau was transferred to the synonymy of H. constellatus, but the status of the unsampled subspecies H. c. rhodogaster, described from mid-elevations of the western Itombwe Plateau, remains problematic (Greenbaum et al. 2013).

Fu et al. (2005) synonymized Bufo andrewsi, Ye et al. (1993) synonymized Bufo minshanicus, Zhan and Fu (2011) synonymized Bufo tibetanus, Fei et al. (2009) synonymized Bufo wolongensis, and Fei et al. (2009) synonymized Bufo kabischi with Bufo gargarizans (Frost 2015).

This species seems to have colonised the Korean Peninsula about 2 million years ago, followed by continuous gene exchange (Borzée et al. 2017).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Limnonectes hascheanus by Dubois (1986), where it had been placed by Smith (1929).
There is considerable variation in leaf morphology throughout the elevation  range on Aberdares, with plants from the lower elevations having smaller, less  pubescent leaves (Knox 2005).

The plants that grow on the plateau are significantly smaller than those up in the afroalpine zone (Knox 2005). This species is closely related to Dendrosenecio keniensis, a Mount Kenya endemic (Hedberg 1957).

There are two subspecies, Dendrosenecio cheranganiensis subsp. cheranganiensis and D. cheranganiensis subsp. dalei which differ by habit and habitat type preferences (Mabberley 1971). They were originally published as two separate species (Cotton and Blakelock 1937) but are now considered to be ecotypes of the same species (Mabberley 1971).
A full list of synonyms are available in the Flora of Tropical East Africa (Knox 2005). There are two subspecies which differ by flower and leaf characters (Knox 2005).

A hybrid between this species and Dendrosenecio keniodendron has been described as Senecio × saundersii (Beck et al. 1992). However, according to the Flora of Tropical East Africa (Knox 2005) there is little evidence of hybrid swarms and therefore little reason to keep formally recognizing this hybrid species.

A hybrid between this species and Dendrosenecio keniensis has been described as Senecio × saundersii (Beck et al. 1992). However according to the Flora of Tropical East Africa (Knox 2005) there is little evidence of hybrid swarms and therefore little reason to keep formally recognizing this hybrid species.
This species only differs from the closely related Eragrostis habrantha by the pilose lemmas (Cope 1998).

This species is closely related to Helichrysum newii but can be distinguished by the width of the leaves and hairiness of the phyllaries (Beentje 2002). There are two varieties, var. glandulosum and var. brownei which differ by the leaf pubescence (Beentje 2002). Genetic studies should be undertaken to find out if these two varieties are genetically distinct.

The species has previously been described as subspecies of Senecio mweroensis which is found in Tanzania and Zambia but it is accepted as Kleinia leptophylla in Flora of Tropical East Africa (Beentje et al. 2005) and by Newton and Kamiti (2005).

Oncidium ensatum includes Oncidium floridanum. Authors of floristic literature (FNA 2002) lump O. floridanum with O. ensatum because studies of O. ensatum "reveal no characters consistent enough to warrant recognizing the Florida populations as a separate taxon (FNA 2002)."

Folsom (1984) indicates that Chapman’s Fringed Orchid (Platanthera chapmanii ) was described as a hybrid between the Orange Crested Orchid (Plantanthera cristata) and the Orange Fringed Orchid (Plantantherea ciliaris) erroneously. Folsom (1984) concludes that Chapman’s Fringed Orchid is not a hybrid, meaning Plantanthera x chapmanii, but a distinct taxon for several reasons including, it is “morphologically pure”, grows from seed, exists in areas independent of the other two taxon, etc. Chapman’s Fringed Orchid does hybridize with both of these species readily where they coexist; hybrids from these three closely related species are: Platanthera x apalachicola, Platanthera x channellii, Platanthera x osceola (Brown 2003, Brown and Stewart 2003). This hybridization does cause some confusion when distinguishing the species in areas where hybrids occur (Brown 2003).
The species was described in 2007 (Colwell et al. 2007). There are no taxonomic changes or doubts/debates regarding the validity or identity of this taxon.

Spiranthes torta excludes Spiranthes amesiana Schlechter which is often considered conspecific with S. torta. Recent studies support that it is distinct based on several differences: S. torta has a denser inflorescence, spade-shaped lip with a crenulate-ciliate margin, and densely pubescent basal calli than S. amesiana (FNA 2002).
Spiranthes brevilabris var. floridana was elevated to the species rank, therefore Spiranthes brevilabris reviewed here excludes S. floridana.

Navasota Ladies-tresses (Spiranthes parksii) cannot be genetically distinguished from the open-flower form of Spiranthes cernua (Walters 2005). The Navasota Ladies-tresses Orchid can be morphologically distinguished from Spiranthes cernua “by its upcurved and long lateral sepals relative to the petals as well as its white-tipped floral bracts” (Walters 2005).

The assessment covers both the subspecies P. n. nayaur and P. n. szechuanensis which are treated together. Neither taxonomy nor appropriate nomenclature of the Dwarf Blue Sheep are completely resolved. The Dwarf Blue Sheep is variously considered P. schaeferi (Wang 1998) or P. nayaur schaeferi (Shackleton 1997). In this assessment, we follow recent genetic studies (Zeng et al. 2008, Tan et al. 2012) which indicate that it should not be considered a separate species. We tentatively treat it as a subspecies P. nayaur schaeferi, and assess it separately as such.
Until recently the Iberian Sooty Copper was regarded as a subspecies of Lycaena tityrus (Casulo et al., 1989).
Recently the subpopulations in the Sierra de la Sagra (formerly described as Polyommatus sagratrox) have been assigned to this species.
The populations in the Pyrenees are by some authors treated as distinct species (E. rondoui).

authority: Taylor, Stoffberg, Monadjem, Schoeman, Bayliss & Cotterill, 2012
taxonomicNotes: In previous Red List assessments (2008), this species was included within Rhinolophus hildebrandtii. Taxonomic changes, based on molecular systematics and differences in morphology, echolocation call frequencies and biogeography, have taken place within the R. hildebrandtii complex. R. hildebrandtii was revised in 2012 (Taylor et al. 2012) and R. cohenae recognised as one of the four newly described species from this species complex.
There is taxonomic confusion in the literature between Argyophis [Typhlops] diardii and A. muelleri, the latter having previously been treated as a subspecies of the former.

The subspecies Pseudacris streckeri illinoensis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991) (without supporting data), but this subspecies was recognized by Phillips et al. (1999), Johnson (2000), and Crother et al. (2000, 2003).

Scaphiopus hurterii formerly was regarded as a subspecies of S. holbrookii, but checklists (Crother et al. 2000, Collins and Taggart 2002) have treated it as a distinct species. Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

Helianthus hirsutus Raf. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated H. annuus L. and to Taxon Group two of H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Helianthus decapelatus belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

Although Sympetrum janeae Carle, 1993, has never been formally synonymized with S. internum, most odonatologists in North America do not recognize the species as distinct. Populations in southeastern Canada and northeastern United States do show some differences from populations farther west, but a thorough analysis of the geographic variation has not been conducted.
This species was transferred from Plectranthus to Coleus by Downes and Darbyshire (2017).

Dioscorea hexagona Baker is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated yams, D. alata L. (Water Yam/Greater Yam), D. bulbifera L. (Aerial Yam), D. cayenensis Lam. (Lagos Yam), D. dumetorum (Kunth) Pax (Bitter Yam), D. esculenta (Lour.) Burkill (Asiatic Yam) and D. rotundata Poir. (White Guinea Yam).
Speta (1998) placed this species within the genus Chouardia. Whilst widely followed within the countries where this species occurs, the species is maintained within Scilla at present by WCSP (2018).
FABACEAE

The species concept of B. melanopygus is now considered to include B. edwardsii, the latter of which was formerly treated as a unique and morphologically distinct species from California and Oregon, but is now considered conspecific with B. melanopygus based on genetic similarity (Williams et al. 2014, Owen et al. 2010). Specifically, Owen & Plow (1980) found that these two morphs differ by a single pair of alleles at one locus controlling the color of the pubescens on gastral terga II-III. According to Owen et al. (2010), there can be little doubt that the two are conspecific.

Due to several major color pattern polymorphisms and evidence of genetic structuring among regional populations, the taxonomic status of regional populations of this species has been the subject of debate (Lozier et al. 2013). According to Williams et al. (2014), evidence from DNA barcodes supports a close relationship between two divergent groups with different color patterns and distributions, B. bifarius bifarius and B. bifarius nearcticus. At present, these two groups are treated as the nominant and nearcticus color patterns of the same species, although the potential need for taxonomic revision is currently under examination (Lozier 2014, pers. comm.).
Evidence from DNA barcodes supports B. centralis and B. flavifrons as distinct species, despite their close genetic relationship (Williams et al. 2014).

Some records previously treated as this species (e.g., from southern Appalachians) are now considered Bombus sandersoni, often determined as Bombus frigidus sandersoni (NatureServe 2014). It is now recognized that the two species are separate (Williams et al., 2014).

See Williams (2014) for a discussion of the taxonomic status of this species. In short, B. praticola (Kirby 1837) is considered a synonym based on Kirby's original descriptions (there is no type material of this species). Since B. praticola appears to be the oldest available name for this species, that name (the senior homonym) would typically take precedence. However, since the name B. mixtus has been in common use for the species since 1950, Williams (2014) suggests that, in the interests of stability, an application be made to ICZN to suppress the senior homonym. At present, B. mixtus continues to be the widely-accepted name for this species (Williams 2014; Williams et al. 2014).

Recent studies re-organized the binotatus group within the genus Chorthippus (Defaut 2011). This revision proposes two species: C. binotatus and C. saulcyi.

Five sub-species are currently recognized : 

*Chorthippus saulcyi saulcyi (Krauss, 1888), which is widespread on the eastern Pyrenees both on the French side (in the Pyrénée-Orientale department) and on Spanish side (east of the Cerdagne). 

*Chorthippus saulcyi vicdessossi Defaut, 2011, which is widespread in the French Pyrenees (in the Ariège, Haute-Garonne and Hautes-Pyrénées departments).

*Chorthippus saulcyi moralesi Uvarov, 1954, which is widespread in the Catalonian Pyrenees (mainly in Spain, in Aragon and Catalonia, but also in France in Cerdagne).

*Chorthippus saulcyi algoaldensis Chopard 1952, which is widespread in the South Massif Central (Gard, Hérault, Ardèche, Lozère, Aveyron and Tarn Departments).

*Chorthippus saulcyi daimei (Azam, 1893), which is widespread in the French South Alps (in the Alpes-Maritimes, Var and Alpes-de-Haute-Provence departments, but probably not in the Hautes-Alpes Department, where former records exist) and in Italy (in the peaks of Alpi Maritime).

The description of Chorthippus smardai lacks clear diagnosis and its distinction from Pseudochorthippus tatrae is problematic. According to its taxonomic affinity, C. smardai should be related to the genus Pseudochorthippus (A. Kristin pers. comm. 2015).
It was previously thought that the taxon authority of this species was (Rungs, 1952). However, Barat (2012) recently indicated that that the correct authority is (Ebner, 1938).
Bolívar (1897-1899) doubted the validity of this species.
This species was formerly recorded from Corsica under several different names, including E. magnifica (Costa, 1863), E. schmidti (Fieber, 1961) and E. chabrieri (Charpentier, 1825)

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).
Was under Iguanidae.

The Small Indian Mongoose Herpestes auropunctatus and Javan Mongoose H. javanicus have been considered as one species by some previous authors, as H. javanicus. However, the molecular studies of Veron et al. (2006) and Patou et al. (2009) showed that they are separate species; this is also supported by morphological evidence (Taylor and Matheson 1999). The operational problems of this division are considerable: a paucity of specimens makes it unclear how many and which species are present in large tracts of the combined range, including China and parts of northern South-East Asia (Veron et al. 2006).

The enigmatic taxon Herpestes palustris Ghose, 1965 is here considered conspecific with H. auropunctatus, although it has not been considered in recent investigations into mongoose taxonomy, and it remains widely treated elsewhere at species level (Mallick 2011 and references therein).

Patou et al. (2009) showed that the nine species of Asian Herpestes form a monophyletic group, and recommended that they be placed in the genus Urva.
The species was recently moved into the genus Pseudochorthippus by Defaut (2012). It is often referred to as Chorthippus tatrae.

The genus Capraiuscola was previously considered a sub-genus of Miramella, but it was upgraded to genus in 2014. This change was made without a clear statement to revise the status of this taxon. The authors (Chintauan-Marquier et al. 2014) compared a small sample of the sub-tribe Miramellina and the speciation of Capraiuscola is mentioned in comparison with Podisma. Thus, for the purposes of this assessment, the species is currently regarded here within the genus Miramella.

For many decades the genus Arctonyx was universally considered monospecific, under the oldest available name, A. collaris. It has been proposed that the genus contains multiple species: Sumatran Hog Badger A. hoevenii is disjunct from the rest of the genus's range (Helgen et al. 2008).

For many decades the genus Arctonyx was universally considered monospecific, under the oldest available name, A. collaris. It has been proposed that the genus contains multiple species: Sumatran Hog Badger A. hoevenii is disjunct from the rest of the genus's range, whilst Northern Hog Badger A. albogularis and Greater Hog Badger A. collaris (sensu stricto) occur in mainland Asia, with a poorly understood zone of overlap or contact (Helgen et al. 2008). This revision was not accepted by Choudhury (2013) who furthermore queried the neotype and accompanying type locality selected for A. collaris by Helgen et al. (2008). Nonetheless, Helgen et al. (2008: 369) were explicit that "the absolute, striking distinctions in size, pelage and qualitative cranial morphology between available adult samples of A. albogularis and A. collaris indicate no intergradation between these taxa". Therefore, three species of hog badger are recognized here.

P. nagyi has been described on the basis of small differences with P. fieberi and P. transilvanica in the male aedeagus. Nagy et al. (2010) suggest that it may be a synonym (or subspecies) of P. fieberi.
The western subpopulation of this species needs to be compared with the eastern subpopulation to verify if they are conspecific.

Future taxonomic and faunistic research on the Poecilimon elegans species complex (including P. albolineatus) would help to clarify the distribution and ecology of this taxon, which was formerly regarded as P. elegans.

The great variation and genetic similarity (Kaya et al. 2012, D. Chobanov pers. comm. 2015) suggest close relationships of P. tauricus and P. pliginskii and their possible infraspecific relationships. Kaya et al. (2012) consider Poecilimon boldyrevi to be a synonym of P. pliginskii.
The great morphological variation and genetic similarity (Kaya et al. 2012, D. Chobanov pers. comm. 2015) suggest close relationships between P. tauricus and P. pliginskii.
The taxonomic status of Poecilimon ukrainicus and Poecilimon fussi needs further study.
This species should be compared with M. karnyana, because according to the analyses performed so far they seem quite similar.
This species should be compared with M. hoermanni because according to the analyses performed so far they seem quite similar.

The large gap between the northern and southern subpopulations and the high degree of long-term isolation in different mountain ranges suggest a considerable infraspecific variability which requires detailed taxonomic research.
This species is closely related to Pholidoptera stankoi Karaman, and they are probably synonymous (D. Chobanov pers. comm. 2015).
The taxonomic status of this species is still uncertain (Chobanov 2011) and needs further investigation.
This species was described in Poelt & Sulzer, Nova Hedwigia 25: 182-184 (1974). There are no synonyms.
Hygrocybe virescens (Hesler & A.H. Sm.) Montoya & Bandala from North America is similar to this species and may be conspecific.

authority: Quinteros, Valladares, Semham, Acosta, Barrionuevo & Abdala, 2014

taxonomicNotes: The species needs taxonomic revision. It has been synonymized with V. oblongicollis by Willemse (1977) but reestablished as a species by Massa and Fontana (2011). According to the variation observed by Willemse (1977, 1984) the synonymy of Vichetia knipperi and V. oblongicollis is very probable.
This species needs further taxonomic research to identify the differences with M. nonveilleri (the only difference stated so far is its colour).

Zeuner (1941) described Parnassiana tymphrestos from Mt.Timfristos (= Mt. Veluchi, compare Ramme, 1931). Ramme (1951) discussed the possible synonymy of P. tymphrestos and P. coracis but, not being aware that Mt. Korax is close to Mt. Timfristos, and by lack of material of P. tymphrestos, did not solve it, and the matter remains unsolved. For the time being, the material from Mt. Vardhousia recorded under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1980 & 1984) should be transferred to Platycleis (Parnassiana) coracis Ramme, 1920. Likewise a re-evaluation of the population of Mt. Oiti, also arranged under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1973 & 1980) appears necessary.
The genus Acrida is in need of taxonomic revision.

According to several authors (e.g. Massa et al. 2012, Ragge and Reynolds 1998) this species is considered a junior synonym of C. cialancensis. However, other authors such as Morichon and Morin (2010) consider these two to be two distinct species. For the purposes of this assessment, both C. cialancensis and C. sampeyrensis are considered as distinct species.
The Authority for this taxon is given as (Obenberger, 1926), because although Puschnig (1910) named the species for the first time, he did not give a valid description.
The species is only known from the first description and its taxonomic status is probably doubtful.

Several endemic Corsican grasshoppers were previously described (Omocestus corsicus Chopard, 1924; Omocestus corsicus montanus Chopard, 1924; Omocestus pascuorum Chopard, 1924; Stauroderus incertus Chopard, 1924; Chorthippus chopardi Harz, 1971) and are now considered to belong to Chorthippus corsicus (Defaut 1999), with two subspecies: C. c. corsicus (Chopard, 1924) and C. c. pascuorum (Chopard, 1924). Both taxa overlap in distribution (Braud et al. 2002). In the same way, the morphological distinction is not always easy or possible due to the substantial intra-populational variability.
The taxonomy of this species needs to be studied as recent findings suggest that the species is in fact three distinct species (P. Fontana pers. comm 2015).
The two distinct subpopulations of this species are currently considered two subspecies but they may actually be two separate species (P. Fontana pers. comm. 2015).
Four subspecies have been reported for this species: O. chevrolati chevrolati, O. chevrolati longicarinatus, O. chevrolati omiltemi, and O. chevrolati retusus.
Cenchrus violaceus (Lam) Morrone is a primary wild relative of pearl millet C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.). (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017)
The generic status of Setirostris is currently in revision.

The taxonomy of the genus Mormopterus in Australia has been revised recently (Reardon et al. 2014), resulting in the description of a new species M. lumsdenae for Australian representatives allocated previously to M. beccarii. True Mormopterus beccarii is confined to Papua and Indonesia. Mormopterus lumsdenae is included in the subgenus Ozimops (Reardon, McKenzie and Adams 2014), which has been used at the level of genus (Jackson and Groves 2015).

Mormopterus petersi was resurrected recently from synonymy with M. planiceps (Reardon et al. 2014).
