Dendropicos obsoletus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Dendrocopos. It has previously been placed in the genus Dendropicos by Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Picoides by Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).

Picoides maculatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Dendrocopos. Dendrocopos maculatus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) has been split into D. maculatus and D. ramsayi following Collar et al. (1999) and BirdLife International (2001), who initially placed it in the genus Picoides. Subsequently, the genus Dendrocopos has been used, following Winkler and Christie (2002). Because this split was made in a BirdLife publication, the justification is repeated here in full (but the references are not supplied). Both Hachisuka (1931-1935) and Voous (1947) treated ramsayi as a separate species, and indeed it is so distinctive as to be arguably closer to Sulawesi Woodpecker P. temminckii than it is to P. maculatus (this view is also expressed, with the comment that ramsayi is "the ancestor common to both", by White and Bruce 1986), and given the evident morphological proximity of Brown-capped P. moluccensis, Grey-capped P. canicapillus and Pygmy Woodpeckers P. kizuki to both maculatus (non-Sulu forms) and ramsayi, there is no compelling reason to combine the latter two as a single species. Sulu birds differ from other Philippine forms in: replacing all black or dark brown with a mid-brown; lacking virtually all white spotting on wings and coverts; lacking black or dark brown spotting or streaking on the undersides; showing an ill-defined yellow or yellowish-orange breast-band, plus (in the male) a far more strongly developed red area on the nape. The specific separation of ramsayi is all the more arguable for the geographically closest representative of maculatus - fulvifasciatus of Mindanao and Basilan showing the strongest pied effect. The notion that these two forms are "bridged" by maculatus, with a throw-away description of ramsayi as "aberrant" (Salomonsen 1953), not only fails to deal with the suggestion of Voous (1947) that ramsayi represents an early invasion of the Philippines, but also misses the point that maculatus is not geographically interposed between the two forms it is supposed to bridge. It is worth noting that in the paper in which both ramsayi and fulvifasciatus were first established, the formal description of ramsayi compared it to temminckii rather than to maculatus (Hargitt 1881).

This species is a synonym of Sorbus austriaca subsp. hazslinszkyana (Soó) Kárpáti according to Kurtto (2009) however this requires confirmation.

A record from Hungary is doubtful and may refer to Sorbus buekkensis (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).

This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Considering its wide distribution and known variation, the many subpopulations under this name require a careful taxonomic reassessment, as very likely more than one species is currently included under this name (J. Faivovich pers. comm. October 2018).
This species has been split from Asellia tridens by Benda et al. (2011)
This species has been split from Rhinopoma muscatellum by Hulva et al. (2007) and Benda et al. (2009).

This species has been recently described by Martínez-Lanfranco et al. (2014), based on genetic and morphologic characters, which clearly separate the species from the commonly known, and more wide-spread Lutreolina crassicaudata. Lutreolina massoia is smaller in size than L. crassicaudata, both externally and for craniodental characters.
J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers this to be a high-altitude savanna form of Hylarana albolbris, since there is a gradual transition between the two forms, and there are no call differences.

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops longissima Schweinf. & Muschl. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats, including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

The Atelognathus praebasalticus complex needs to be re-examined taxonomically. There are four known subspecies, some of which may constitute new species. Some of these subspecies may be extinct.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"New species (Moreno & Albuja 2014)"}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14652,"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"11":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">This is a new species (Moreno and Albuja 2014).

This taxon was previously considered as belonging to the otherwise central Ryukyu species Takydromus smaragdinus (Boulenger 1887), but is now recognized to be a distinct, phylogenetically rather distant species (see Lin et al. 2002, Ota et al. 2002).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. The Asiatic Golden Cat resembles the African Golden Cat, but on the basis of genetic analysis it was grouped with the Marbled Cat in Pardofelis (Johnson et al. 2006, O'Brien and Johnson 2007). However, an evaluation of skull morphology by Sicuro and Oliveira (2011) revealed that skull structure in Pardofelis is quite different to that of Catopuma. Moreover, Pardofelis has a flexible ankle joint and elongated tail as adaptations to arboreality, which are lacking in Catopuma. Based on these differences, the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group retains Asiatic Golden Cat in Catopuma.
This species appeared in the 2004-2006 IUCN Red Lists under the misspelt name O. teradactylus.

The taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. Garcia Perea (1994) proposed that this species be subdivided into three separate species (Lynchailurus colocolo, L. pajeros, and L. braccatus) based on morphological traits. This was provisionally followed by Wozencraft (2005). However, genetic analysis supports the existence of populations subdivision in this species, but not at the species level (Johnson et al. 1999). The genetic partitioning (Uruguay and southern Brazil; Bolivia and northern Chile; and western Argentina and central Chile: Johnson et al. 1999) is somewhat different from the divisions recognized by Garcia-Perea (1994) on the basis of morphology (central Chile; the Andes from Ecuador and south to through Argentina; and Uruguay, Paraguay and Brazil). Moreover, Cossios and Angers (2007) found six highly divergent clades in genetic analysis of Andean populations (Peru, Bolivia and Argentina). Subspeciation and geographic divisions in this species requires further study. Placed in the genus Leopardus by Johnson et al. (2006).

A zone of hybridization between L. colocolo and L. tigrinus has been found through genetic analyses of specimens from central Brazil (Johnson et al. 1999, Eizirik et al. 2007).

Current scientific review of the taxonomy of wild equids (Groves 1986) places Przewalski's Horse as a subspecies of the extinct Equus ferus. Although Przewalski's Horse (Equus ferus przewalskii) can hybridize with domestic horses (Equus ferus caballus) to produce fertile offspring (Ryder et al. 1978, Trommerhausen-Smith et al. 1979), the existence of 2n = 66 chromosomes in Przewalski's Horse identifies it as being more different from its domestic relatives (2n = 64) than are any two breeds of domestic horse (Ryder 1994). Furthermore, mitochondrial DNA research has shown that the Przewalski's Horse is not the ancestor of modern domestic horses (Vilà et al. 2001). Przewalski's Horse also show a number of consistent differences in their appearance as compared to domestic horse breeds: the mane is short and erect when in good body condition; forelocks are nearly nonexistent; the upper part of the tail has short guard hairs; a dark dorsal stripe runs from the mane down the spine to the tail; several dark stripes can be present on the carpus and generally the tarsus (Groves 1994). Przewalski's Horses grow a thick mane in winter, which contrary to domestic horses they shed each spring with the rest of their winter coat.

Other studies of the genetic differences between Przewalski's and domestic horses have indicated very little genetic distinction between them. Only four alleles at four separate serological marker loci have been identified as specific to Przewalski's Horse (Bowling and Ryder 1987); the vast majority of blood protein variants are present in both Przewalski's and domestic horses and even the fastest evolving DNA region known in mammals (the mitochondrial DNA control region), does not show significant differences between the two types of horse (Ishida et al. 1995, Oakenfull and Ryder 1998). Thus it is clear that Przewalski's and domestic horses are very closely related and have in the past interbred, but the fixed chromosomal number difference between them indicates that they are distinct populations (Oakenfull et al. 2000). A variety of molecular studies support their phylogenetic relationship as sister taxa (Steiner et al. 2012, Côté et al. 2013) diverging between 150,000 and 250,000 years ago (Goto et al. 2011, Steiner and Ryder 2011).

The taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. While 32 subspecies have been classically described, on the basis of genetic analysis Culver et al. (2000) suggest six subspecies as follows:

P. c. cougar: North America
P. c. costaricensis: Central America
P. c. capricornensis: eastern South America
P. c. concolor: northern South America
P. c. cabrerae: central South America
P. c. puma: southern South America.

The former subspecies arizonense and durangoense were elevated to species by Serb et al. (2001). Subspecies spooneri is generally considered synonymous with flavescens (Berry and Berry 1984, Iverson 1992, Serb et al. 2001).

Previously this species was known as Clemmys insculpta, under which name it appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006; paraphyly of the traditional genus Clemmys (sensu McDowell, 1964) required placement of insculpta and muhlenbergii into Glyptemys (Holman and Fritz 2001, Parham and Feldman 2002).
Two subspecies are recognised: Terrapene ornata ornata (Agassiz, 1857), and Terrapene ornata luteola Smith & Ramsay, 1952
This species was removed from the synonymy of Atelopus ignescens by McDiarmid (1971).

Coloma, Lötters and Salas (2000) redefined Atelopus ignescens and restricted the species to the north-central Andes of Ecuador. Populations in northern Ecuador (in Cachi Province), and adjacent southern Colombia (Narino Department), previously assigned to Atelopus ignescens are now considered to belong to an undescribed species.
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Work by Werner et al. (2005) showed W. multicapsularis to be genetically distinct from W. longifolia by using nrITS sequence data. However, more recent work (D. Callaghan pers. comm. 2018) has shown that the type specimen is a mixture of two other species, so the name W. multicapsularis cannot be maintained. Plants that have been named W. multicapsularis by modern authors constitute a species that will be described later in 2019. Meanwhile, 'W. multicapsularis' can be assessed if only modern and reliable records are used.
Wilson et al. (2016) confirmed the separation of two subspecies; Iris sofarana subsp. sofarana and I.s. subsp. kasruwana (Dinsm.) Chaudhary, G.Kirkw. & C.Weymouth.

Although up to eight Chacma forms have been suggested in the literature (Hill 1970), today only three are commonly accepted (Jolly 1993; Groves 2001). These are: P. u. ursinus, P. u. griseipes, and P. u. ruacana. Papio u. ursinus, the typical Chacma, is a large baboon with black nape fringes, dark brown fur, black fur on hands and feet and a relatively short tail. This variant occurs in the more southerly and westerly part of the Chacma range, including South Africa and some parts of Botswana. This group incorporates Hill’s (1970) ursinus, orientalis and occidentalis subspecies. Papio ursinus griseipes, the Grey-Footed Baboon, is more fawn coloured and found in southwestern Zambia, Zimbabwe, in Mozambique south of the Zambezi, in parts of the Limpopo Province of South Africa, and in the Okavango Delta, Botswana (Jolly 1993). These are smaller than P. u. ursinus and have grey hands and feet, the same colour as their limbs, and a longer tail. This group incorporates Hill’s griesipes, ngamiensis, chobiensis and jubilaeus subspecies. Today it is clear that jubilaeus is in fact a Yellow Baboon and not a Chacma at all. Papio ursinus ruacana is a small black-footed baboon that is darker than P. u. griseipes and smaller than P. u. ursinus. They are found in Namibia and southwestern Angola (Groves 2001).

Mitochondrial genetic data confirms at least two distinct lineages within Chacma separating the species into northern (griseipes) and southern (ursinus) populations (Sithaldeen et al. 2009; Zinner et al. 2009). A third genetic clade may represent orientalis (Keller et al. 2010). As yet, no definitive data exist that distinguish a genetically distinct ruacana clade.
There are three varieties of this species, var. firmifolium, var. geophylum, var. hygrophylum.

This species is within subgenus Pika. Essentially, Ochotona opaca is a recently elevated form of what was O. pallasii pallasii in the Kazakhstan range of O. pallasii. It was determined that the type locality of pallasii was incorrect and not in Kazakhstan, rather in Mongolia (where the form O. pallasii pricei occurred). Thus, the Mongolian range has become O. pallasii (spelled with two “i’s” following the law of priority), and following the law of priority, the Kazakhstan range now harbours the independent O. opaca. O. opaca and O. pallasii appear to be sister species, but sufficiently differentiated as to be considered independent.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Cacosternum boettgeri by Channing (2001), where it had been placed by Poynton (1964). Channing et al. (2013) described four new species in Cacosternum genus and revised the distribution of known Cacosternum species, so the range of C. platys has been restricted (southern Cape Peninsula populations are now referred to as C. australis, sister species of C. platys).

Gossypium thurberi Tod. is a tertiary wild relative of Cotton (G. hirsutum L.), Sea Island Cotton (G. barbadense L.), Short-staple Cotton (G. herbaceum L.) and Tree Cotton (G. arboretum L.) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

C.D. Adams (1961 and 1963) and Lisowski (2009) cite a collection of this species from Cameroon; Lightbody FHI 26275. However, Mesfin Tadesse does not include it in the protologue for Bidens occidentalis (Hutch. & Dalziel) Mesfin. He has identified this specimen as cf. occidentalis ('immature'). D. J. N. Hind (pers. comm. 2016) agrees that this specimen looks somewhat different and is almost certainly not B. occidentalis.
The species was placed in a new genus, Wollastonaria, by De Mattia et al. (2018a,b).
The species was placed in a new genus, Wollastonaria, by De Mattia et al. (2018a,b).

This species is considered a synonym of Romulea columnae (as Romulea columnae subsp. assumptionis) by some references. However, the confusion with R. columnae is simply due to the convergent morphology of flowers (small white tepals and short style) due to the autogamous syndrome of both species: the ultimate stage of flower reduction in the genus.

This is not a good taxonomic marker and few botanists paid attention to the vegetative parts of bulbous plants, which indeed are more significant. The leaves and peduncle structure of R. assumptionis strongly different from those of R. columnae and suggest a fully unrelated taxon, probably closer to the requienii-group (J.-M. Tison pers. comm. 2016).

Pickersgill (2007) removed this species from the synonymy of Hyperolius acuticeps based on its voice. It is a member of the H. nasutus complex. A recent reevaluation of the group's taxonomy (Channing et al. 2013) confirmed the validity of this species, based on morphological, genetic, and acoustic evidence.
The taxonomy of this species is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. It has been placed in the genus Lynx according to genetic analysis (Johnson et al. 2006).

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of yak under Bos mutus, while the domestic form is considered under Bos grunniens (see Gentry et al. 1996).

Grubb (2005) lists mutus as a subspecies of grunniens, contrary to most authors.
This is a polymorphic species that presents different morphotypes adapted to aquatic or terrestrial environments (Cuello et al. 2008).
This diploid species was separated from the tetraploid Odontophrynus americanus.

This species is part of a group of polyploid and cryptic species within the genus Pleurodema (Vaira et al. 2012), along with P. cordobae (octoploid, from Sierras de Comenchingones, Córdoba) and P. bibroni (tetraploid, from Uruguay and southern Brazil).

Valetti et al. (2009) redescribed the species and differentiated it from P. cordobae and P. bibroni.
This species may be a synonym of M. stelzneri, further taxonomic work is needed to establish the taxonomic status of both species (D. Baldo pers. comm. October 2017)

The northern and southern populations exhibit some ecological differences, and further research is recommended to determine whether this reflects taxonomic differences (G. Shea, H. Cogger and M. Greenlees pers. comm. 2017).

There is unpublished morphological and genetic data suggesting that the Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Islands populations represent distinct species (R. Bray unpubl. data). Until this work is formally published, this account retains the traditional concept of Oligosoma lichenigerum.
This species is undergoing revision.

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to a clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved paraphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingli and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size) . Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. robustus as a widespread Australian species following Cogger (2014), while noting that at least two species are likely to be included under this name.

This is a complex of several species that is currently under revision. Rabosky et al. (2014) found that Ctenotus inornatus as presently understood is only poorly distinguishable from several other species on the basis of genetic data, and proposed wide-ranging taxonomic changes to resolve this issue, including subsuming five recognized species (helenae, brachyonyx, severus, saxatilis and fallens) within the synonymy of C. inornatus. These authors acknowledged that this complex requires consideration of further genetic and morphological material and, while noting that "there is no evidence that any supposedly diagnostic characters for the forms are grounded in phylogenetic reality", they do not support the proposed synonymies with morphological comparisons.  Additionally, their mitochondrial (but not cytochrome b) data cluster in accordance with the original species concepts proposed for the Western Australian taxa, with a distinct lineage comprising morphologically confusing central Australian populations (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017)

Given the complexity of the taxonomic issues involved and the need for further resolution, this assessment retains a traditional concept of C. inornatus following Cogger (2014), and recognizes C. helenae, C. brachyonyx, C. fallens, C. severus and C. saxatilis as valid pending further investigation of these proposed synonymies.

Three genetic lineages are known: one isolated in Guyra in northern New South Wales; one in the Victorian High Country to the New England Tablelands; and one in the Victorian Volcanic Plains and Tasmania (G. Shea, Wapstra, E., Clemann, N., Hutchinson, M. and P. Robertson pers. comm. 2017).
Three subspecies are presently recognized: Varanus acanthurus acanthurus Boulenger, 1885, V. a. brachyurus Sternfeld, 1919 and V. a. insulanicus Mertens, 1958.

This species has two recognized subspecies: Varanus gouldii gouldii, found throughout continental Australia except the arid interior; and V. g. flavirufus found in the arid interior of Australia (Cogger 2014).

According to genetic analyses, nine subspecies are recognized, with all continental African Leopards attributable to the nominate form, P. p. pardus (Miththapala et al. 1996, Uphyrkina et al. 2001).

UAE Taxonomic Note
Leopards occurring in the Arabian Peninsula, including the UAE, are traditionally considered to be the Arabian Leopard Panthera pardus nimr Hemprich & Ehrenberg, 1833 (Harrison and Bates 1991) which is much smaller and lighter in weight than other leopards.

The Caracal has been classified variously with Lynx and Felis in the past, but molecular evidence supports a monophyletic genus. It is closely allied with the African Golden Cat (Caracal aurata) and the Serval (Leptailurus serval), having diverged around 8.5 mya (Janczewski et al. 1995, Johnson and O’Brien 1997, Johnson et al. 2006).

Seven subspecies have been recognised in Africa (Smithers 1975), of which two occur in southern Africa: C. c. damarensis from Namibia, the Northern Cape, southern Botswana and southern and central Angola; and the nominate C. c. caracal from the remainder of the species’ range in southern Africa (Meester et al. 1986). According to Stuart and Stuart (2013), however, these subspecies should best be considered as geographical variants.

UAE taxonomic note
Specimens from Arabia have been assigned to Caracal caracal schmitzi Matschie, 1912 which is smaller and paler than the nominate form, which is not endemic to the region (Harrison and Bates 1991). Specimens from Arabia have been assigned to Caracal caracal schmitzi Matschie, 1912 which is smaller and paler than the nominate form, which does not occur in the region (Harrison and Bates 1991).

This species was recently described from populations formerly included within Tympanocryptis cephalus (Doughty et al. 2015). Genetic divergence between this taxon and T. diabolicus is nevertheless low and it exhibits little morphological difference from this taxon, raising some doubt about its validity (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017). The Fortescue River is however a likely barrier to dispersal that justifies provisional recognition of this taxon as a full species (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).

Three karyotypically and genetically distinct taxa have been identified within this name, but there are no known morphological differences (Oliver et al. 2009). These authors recommend further research to clarify the taxonomy of this species complex.
Genetic and morphological studies indicate the existence of multiple species under this name (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

Populations that may be referrable to this species have been found in the southeast and central Arnhem scarp (Oliver and Parkin 2014, P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). The known specimens from these localities exhibit a degree of morphological differentiation from Strophurus horneri, and molecular data is required to confirm their identity (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). Pending further taxonomic work these records are excluded from this assessment.
There are populations in the central ranges that may be geographically and genetically isolated (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).
The relationship between this species and Strophurus robinsoni needs to be investigated.
The relationship between this species and Strophurus mcmillani needs to be investigated.
Unpublished genetic analyses suggest that the subspecies P. s. bushi and P. s. nullarbor are conspecific with Parasuta gouldii (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

Storr (1984) analyzed variation in patterning in the widespread Denisonia (now Suta) suta and concluded that two sympatric forms occurred in the Ord river catchment in the eastern Kimberley. One of these, which he retained within S. suta, appeared to derive from central Australian S. suta; the other, which Storr described as Denisonia ordensis, was derived from populations in the Barkly Tableland.

Both the validity of S. ordensis and its distribution have subsequently been uncertain, and research is needed to confirm that Ord River Suta represent two distinct taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Storr (1984) did not distinguish S. ordensis from putative ancestral populations in the Barkly Tableland, and should S. ordensis prove to be valid it is consequently unclear whether it has a restricted distribution in the Ord River ranges or whether it is conspecific with the Barkly Tableland Suta. No genetic research has been conducted on this genus (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017), although it is likely that tissue exists in museum collections (R. Ellis pers. comm. 2017).
This species is currently accepted in the genus Saccharum (WCSP 2016), however in an unpublished revision it has been transferred to the genus Lasiorhachis (M. Vorontsova pers. comm. 2016).
This species is sometimes included in Cotoneaster integerrimus Medik., for example by Dickoré and Kasperek (2010) and others.
The two recognized subspecies are likely to be sunk into a single monotypic species (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017)

The species status needs to be revisited (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). It exhibits very low genetic divergence and few morphological differences from two species occurring in nearby areas (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).
Ongoing genetic and morphological studies indicate that this is a species complex (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
Morphological and genetic evidence suggests more than one species under this name. Some authorities recognize the species Anilios nigricauda (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
Genetic and morphological studies indicate that northwestern populations are taxonomically distinct from eastern Australian populations (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
A new species is under description from the northwest Kimberly Islands which has a very small distribution range (C. Moritz pers. comm. 2017).
This is a complex of at least two species, a northern and southern species (C. Moritz pers. comm.).
Its synonym, Acantodrilus neglectus Beddard, 1888, is often misdated.

NOTE: Originally spelt cockayni by Benham (1905) in honor of his colleague Dr L. Cockayne, Lee (1959: 153) subsequently changed it to cockaynei on the grounds that the Doctor’s name ended in an e.  However, under ICZN (1999: Art. 31.1.2, Example) this is an invalid emendation and the correct name must be returned to cockayni as per Blakemore (2016).

This species was given as an example of the irrelevance of penial setal details by Blakemore (2012) following Lee's (1962) report.  No image of its habitus (entire body) is found thus presence or absence of genital markings is wanting and it is long overdue for eco-taxonomic review from the original description in 1889 about 125 years ago.

As noted by Blakemore (2010, 2012: 120), its elongate markings on segment 10 were described but not shown on Lee (1952: fig. 1) nor mentioned by Lee (1959).  Taxonomic uncertainties for the almost dozen congeners currently known could be investigated using molecular methods with DNA barcodes.  Nevertheless, its listing is as of Least Concern.

Note that the species Deinodrilus montanus Lee, 1952 is often misattributed to Lee (1959).

Linder (1981) details the close similarities with Disa welwitschii. Disa roeperocharoides can be distinguished from this species by its larger flowers and distinctive petal shape (La Croix and Cribb 1995).

Disa ukingensis Schltr. looks very similar to D. engleriana (Summerhayes 1968, La Croix et al. 1991, La Croix and Cribb 1995). The species is most likely the upland form of Disa engleriana (Lebrun and Stork 2015).

There are several recognised subspecies: Paeonia officinalis L. subsp. officinalis, P. officinalis subsp. banatica (Rochel) Soó, P. officinalis subsp. huthii Soldano, P. officinalis subsp. italica N. G. Passal. & Bernardo and P. officinalis subsp. microcarpa (Boiss. & Reut.) Nyman (Aghababian 2011).
Cinclosoma cinnamomeum and C. alisteri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. cinnamomeum following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pericrocotus erythropygius and P. albifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. erythropygius following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Lanius isabellinus and L. phoenicuroides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. isabellinus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Petroica macrocephala and P. dannefaerdi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. macrocephala following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), Turbott (1990).
Cincloramphus timoriensis and C. macrurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Megalurus timoriensis following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Delichon urbicum and D. lagopodum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. urbicum following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Sylvia hortensis and S. crassirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. hortensis following Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Rhopophilus pekinensis and R. albosuperciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. pekinensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Mirafra apiata and M. fasciolata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. apiata following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Eremalauda dunni and E. eremodites (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as E. dunni following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lamprotornis mevesii, L. violacior and L. benguelensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. mevesii following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lamprotornis mevesii, L. violacior and L. benguelensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. mevesii following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Locustella fasciolata and L. amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. fasciolata following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psophocichla litsitsirupa and P. simensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. litsitsirupa following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Graminicola bengalensis and G. striatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. bengalensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Turdus naumanni and T. eunomus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. naumanni following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Actinodura ramsayi and A. radcliffei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. ramsayi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Estrilda atricapilla and E. kandti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as E. atricapilla following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Coccopygia melanotis, C. bocagei and C. quartinia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Estrilda and lumped as C. melanotis following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Coccopygia melanotis, C. bocagei and C. quartinia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Estrilda and lumped as C. melanotis following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Taeniopygia guttata and T. castanotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. guttata following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cistothorus platensis and C. stellaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. platensis (see AOU [1998 & supplements]; SACC [2005 & updates]; Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]).

Oenanthe oenanthe and O. seebohmi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. oenanthe following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Oenanthe bottae and O. frenata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. bottae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Carpodacus rodopeplus and C. verreauxii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. rodopeplus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Carpodacus synoicus and C. stoliczkae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. synoicus following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Chrysocorythus estherae and C. caniceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Serinus and lumped as S. estherae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Emberiza striolata and E. sahari (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as E. striolata following Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Mirafra africana and M. sharpii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. africana following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).

Cinnyris afer, C. stuhlmanni, C. prigoginei and C. ludovicensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. afra following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).

Cinnyris afer, C. stuhlmanni, C. prigoginei and C. ludovicensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. afra following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).

Cinnyris mediocris and C. usambaricus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. mediocris following Bowie et al. (2004), BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group.
Junco phaeonotus and J. bairdi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as J. phaeonotus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Passerculus sandwichensis, P. guttatus, P. sanctorum and P. rostratus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. sandwichensis following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements).
Anthreptes rectirostris and A. tephrolaemus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. rectirostris following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Asthenes vilcabambae and A. ayacuchensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. vilcabambae following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Cinnyris bifasciatus and C. tsavoensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. bifasciata following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cinnyris jugularis and C. idenburgi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. jugularis following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Aethopyga siparaja, A. magnifica and A. vigorsii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. siparaja following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Prinia atrogularis, P.khasiana and P. superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. atrogularis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Prinia flaviventris and P. sonitans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. flaviventris following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Riparia paludicola, R. cowani and R. chinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. paludicola following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Acrocephalus arundinaceus and A. orientalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. arundinaceus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Anthus lutescens and A. peruvianus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. lutescens following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Emberiza tahapisi and E. goslingi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as E. tahapisi following Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Calandrella brachydactyla and C. dukhunensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped into C. brachydactyla following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ptyonoprogne fuligula and P. rufigula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Hirundo fuligula following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Acridotheres burmannicus and A. leucocpehalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Sturnus burmannicus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Acridotheres grandis and A. javanicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. grandis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Zoothera mollissima and Z. griseiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. mollissima following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), which included the formerly overlooked Z. salimali (Alström et al. 2016)

Anthus similis and A. nyassae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. similis following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993). Anthus longicaudatus is no longer recognised as a species, following del Hoyo and Collar (2016) ; available material in museums is an amalgam of specimens of A. vaalensis and A. similis.
Turdus chiguanco and T. anthracinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. chiguanco following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Turdus merula, T. simillimus, T. maximus and T. mandarinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. merula following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Christidis & Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).

Physalis cordata Houst. ex Mill. is a wild relative of Cape gooseberry, P. peruviana L., low ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. and tomatillo, P. philadelphica Lam. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Physalis hastatula Waterf. is a wild relative of Cape Gooseberry, P. peruviana L., Low Ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. and Tomatillo, P. philadelphica Lam. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).
Physalis angulata L. is a tertiary wild relative of Low Ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

authority: Chaparro, Padial, Gutiérrez, & De la Riva, 2015

taxonomicNotes:
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

The former southern subspecies Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis azurea, known from Argentina, is assessed separately as Pithecopus azureus.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016). The species name has also changed from rangeri (a replacement name) to capensis, the original combination under Sclerophrys.

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. It was described as a subspecies of Amietophrynus funereus (Hulselmans 1977), and was considered a distinct species by Joger (1982) and Böhme and Schneider (1987). J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers that it is a junior synonym of Amietophrynus villiersi, an opinion not shared by U. Joger (pers. comm.).

There is confusion regarding the taxonomy of this species and Amietophrynus poweri (M. Largen, J. Poynton, L. Mazibuko and M. Tandy pers. comm.). It is possible that the true Amietophrynus garmani is restricted to northeastern Africa, with animals from further south belonging to another species (Largen 2001). In this account, we follow the traditional understanding of the species' distribution and taxonomy, pending further information.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Bufo but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Bufo chudeaui Chabanaud, 1919, which is known only from inadequate post-metamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985).

There is confusion regarding the taxonomy of this species and Amietophrynus garmani (M. Largen, J. Poynton, L. Mazibuko and M. Tandy pers. comm.).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Amietophrynus chudeaui (Chabanaud, 1919), which is known only from inadequate postmetamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985). The taxon is likely comprised of a complex of species (V. Gvozdik pers.comm. November 2012).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Sclerophrys (Amietophrynus) chudeaui (Chabanaud, 1919), which is known only from inadequate postmetamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Two subspecies of this species are known: Chorthippus changbaishanensis changbaishanensis and Chorthippus changbaishanensis longipennis (Lu et al. 2012). The latter is likely to be the macropterous morph of the former subspecies.
Several authors have stated that this species is likely to belong in a different genus, including Bhowmik (1986).
This species needs to be taxonomically studied and compared with material of other Australian grasshoppers (D. Rentz, pers. comm. 2018).
The taxonomy of this species has not been studied in recent years. A detailed taxonomic study is needed to test whether it consists of several species (Macfarlane et al. 2010).

This is the restricted concept of this species following the split of Xenopus fischbergi (Evans et al. 2015). 

It is part of a complex of poorly understood species closely related to Xenopus laevis.  It seems likely that many records from the inland parts of Tanzania currently assigned to this species should in fact be referred to Xenopus borealis, and the distribution maps probably records this species as occurring much too widely in this country.

authority: Ahmadzadeh, Flecks, Carretero, Mozaffari, Böhme, Harris, Freitas & Rödder, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Anderson (1999) suggested that the population from Mazanderan in the valley of the Rud-e Atrak of the Kopet Dagh may prove to be a distinct taxon. This form has subsequently been described as the new species Darevskia kopetdaghica by Ahmadzadeh et al. (2013).

Following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), Capsicum rhomboideum (Dunal) Kuntze is a wild relative (Taxon Group 4) of a number of pepper crops:
  • Bell/chili pepper, C. annuum L. var. annuum
  • Habanero pepper, C. chinense Jacq.,
  • Tabasco pepper, C. frutescens L.
  • Aji, C. baccatum L. var. pendulum (Willd.) Eshbaug
  • Rocoto, C. pubescens Ruiz & Pav.

The genus Ruspolia is in need of taxonomic revision. Ruspolia flavovirens has been described based upon a female, while it is likely that the male song is the best character to distinguish species of the genus. Genetic analyses of the genus are also lacking. Currently, it is likely that the species will become a nomina dubia unless the type specimen is sequenced and matched with males and their song recordings (P. Naskrecki, pers. comm. 2018).
This species (along with all other members of the genus Brachystelma) has recently been transferred to the genus Ceropegia - C. nutans (Bruyns) Bruyns (in Bruyns et al. 2017).

This species is currently under description at Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew. It is allied to the East African species C. whytei (Skan) Eb.Fisch. but differs in its glandular indumentum and paler, whitish flowers.

Goldblatt (1993, 1996) notes that the population from Namuli is unusual in having narrow, glabrous leaves with thickened margins and midribs; it is only tentatively placed in this species. Two records from miombo woodland in northern Malawi (la Croix 1021, Chapman 641) are considered likely to have been misnamed and so are omitted from this assessment - these specimens at Kew have not been seen by P. Goldblatt who has revised the taxonomy of Gladiolus.
Pimpinella mulanjensis was described by Townsend (1985), having been treated as Pimpinella sp. A in Flora Zambesiaca (Cannon 1978).

This is a new species to science, currently under description at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew by Elizabeth Downes and Iain Darbyshire. Following emerging molecular evidence, the genus Coleus is to be resurrected and will include many species previously treated within Plectranthus and including this new species, which is to be described as Coleus namuliensis.

Brenan (1954), in the protologue for this species, noted the similarity to S. milanjiensis S.Moore, which is larger in all parts than S. peltophorus. The genus Senecio is currently being revised in southern Africa by Henk Beentje (K) for the Flora Zambesiaca treatment.

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any of their 10 species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been preferable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) treated mwanzae, variabilis and bayoni as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including them under H. viridiflavus. 
The name Hyperolius viridiflavus pachydermus was wrongly associated with H. viridiflavus (as a subspecies pachydermus) by Laurent (M. Dehling pers. comm. April 2017).

In a wide-ranging genetic review of species boundaries in Ctenotus, Rabosky et al. (2014) proposed synonymizing C. borealis within their concept of C. robustus, as these authors could find no genetic differences between these taxa and they describe the morphological differences as "subtle" and "highly-overlapping". These authors acknowledge their very limited sampling of C. borealis (sequences from three specimens) and do not examine the primary morphological characters used to distinguish these taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). On this basis, and given continuing taxonomic issues within C. robustus, this account retains C. borealis as a valid species.

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to a clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved paraphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingli and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size) . Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. robustus as a widespread Australian species following Cogger (2014), while noting that at least two species are likely to be included under this name.

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to a clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved paraphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingli and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size) . Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. robustus as a widespread Australian species following Cogger (2014), while noting that at least two species are likely to be included under this name.
Taxonomic boundaries both between this species and related taxa, and between the two recognized subspecies, are not well-resolved (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
This is a species complex of perhaps two species under current revision (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).
Taxonomic boundaries between this species and Ctenotus militaris are poorly-defined, and there are likely to be multiple species within C. pulchellus as presently understood (G. Shea pers. comm.).

The taxonomic status of central and southern Australian populations allocated to this species require additional review (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to a clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved paraphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingli and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size) . Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. robustus as a widespread Australian species following Cogger (2014), while noting that at least two species are likely to be included under this name.
The two subspecies are poorly-defined and are difficult to consistently distinguish (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017)
This is probably more than one species.

Molecular, morphological and ecological work soon to be published has demonstrated that the Victorian and New South Wales populations of Liopholis guthega represent different species (Z. Atkins in prep.)

Aplin and Smith (2001) highlight extensive genetic diversity within the widespread "Menetia greyii complex", highlighting instances of sympatry, hybridization, polyploidy and "probable parthenogenesis" (parthenogenesis in M. greyii was later confirmed by Adams et al. 2003). Aplin and Smith (2001) suggested that a specimen from False Entrance Well, described by Storr as Menetia amaura, is very likely to represent an aberrant specimen of a locally abundant M. greyii complex species, and "quite possibly" represents M. greyii sensu stricto. M. amaura has never been recorded since its original description, although the name is still used to apply to the Shark Bay specimen (Cogger 2014), and is here included within the M. greyii complex on the advice of G. Gaikhorst (pers. comm. 2017) until its systematics are more fully resolved.

During the 18th and 19th centuries two species of warthog were recognised: Phacochoerus aethiopicus (Pallas 1766) from the Cape Province of South Africa and Phacochoerus africanus (Gmelin 1788) from West Africa. In the early 20th century, mammalian taxonomists lumped the two species under P. aethiopicus. Palaeontologists, however, continued to recognise two distinct species based on the absence of incisors in P. aethiopicus and differences between the two species in the structure of the third molar. The Cape Warthog (P. aethiopicus aethiopicus) was extinct by the 1870s, but it was not until the rediscovery of the Somali Warthog (P. aethiopicus delamerei) in the horn of Africa (Grubb 2013) that the 20th century confusion over the classification of the two species of warthog was resolved. The history of the classification of warthogs is fully described by Grubb and D’Huart (2010). All southern African forms are referred to P. africanus.

Physalis patula Mill. is a wild relative of Cape Gooseberry, P. peruviana L., Low Ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. and Tomatillo, P. philadelphica Lam. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Seehausen and Günther (2016) comment on possible relationships between Neurothemis nesaea and species of the N. intermedia-group, noting that it is possible that at least one of N. intermedia atalanta Ris, 1913 and N. intermedia excelsa Lieftinck, 1934 might be junior synonyms of N. nesaea.
Although Otomys sloggetti is considered to be defined by primitive dental characters, its position on the phylogeny of Otomyinae remains unresolved (Taylor et al. 2004).

In its wild form, Capsicum frutescens L. is a primary wild relative of Tabasco pepper, the cultivated form of the species. The species is also a secondary wild relative of aji, C. baccatum L. var. pendulum (Willd.) Eshbaug, bell/chili pepper, C. annuum L. var. annuum, and habanero pepper, C. chinense Jacq., as well as a tertiary wild relative of rocoto, C. pubescens Ruiz & Pav. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Ciconia episcopus and C. microscelis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. episcopus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
This taxon was elevated to species level by Raynal (1973), and compared morphologically and biogeographically with Sudano-Zambesian sister species Nemum atracuminatum by Larridon et al. (2008).

The Mefou specimens were confirmed in their identification by Dr A. Paton at Kew.  In view of the geographical disjunction perhaps the identity of the Cameroon material should be revisited.  The tribe was analysed by Press (1982) in Bull. Brit. Mus. Nat. Hist. 10(1): 71–74 but species limits were not covered.

Chlorophytum caudatibracteatum is known only from the type collection in 1909. In a recent flora of the Chlorophytum species from Cameroon this species was noted as uncertain, as the collection came from a young plant, but does not match any of the currently accepted species in the genus (Bjorå and Nordal 2014).
Rana kunyuensis has been synonymized under this species by Zhou et al. (2015).

Includes Afroedura langi 'Soutpansberg' and Afroedura 'Matlala' Jacobsen (1992). Subpopulations at Matlala and on the Blouberg are morphologically slightly different from one another and from specimens in the main Soutpansberg subpopulation, but molecular data is not available for them (Jacobsen et al. 2014). Their taxonomic status requires further investigation.

This species was included by Jacobsen (1992) in his A. pondolia complex, but although other members of this complex—A. marleyi, A. pongola sp. nov., and presumably A. rondavelica sp. nov. (also unsampled genetically), as well as A. maripi sp. nov.—do form a monophyletic group, referred to as the A. marleyi group, A. pondolia is only distantly related. The latter may be distinguished from A. pongola sp. nov. and especially A. marleyi on the basis of its greater number of midbody scale rows (mean of 102.56 versus 98.22 and 88.77, respectively) and larger size (maximum SVL 63 mm versus 40 mm and 36 mm, respectively) and has substantially fewer precloacal pores than A. pongola sp. nov. (11–13 versus 21–23); it also has significantly more supralabial scales than A. marleyi (p < 0.001, t37 d.f.); and it is larger (60 mm versus 55 mm maximum SVL) and has more precloacal pores (11–13 versus 7–9) than A. rondavelica sp. nov. (Jacobsen et al. 2014).

Included by Jacobsen (1992) in his A. pondolia complex. According to Jacobsen et al. (2014) that while it forms a clade with other members of thecomplex, it is only distantly related. Jacobsen et al. (21014) state that: “Afroedura pongola sp. nov. may be distinguished from the similarly sized A. marleyi on the basis of its greater number of midbody scale rows (p < 0.001, t20 d.f.) and from this species and the much larger A. maripi sp. nov. and A. rondavelica sp. nov. (maximum SVL 63 mm and 55 mm versus 40 mm for A. pongola sp. nov.) by its greater number of precloacal pores in males (mean of 22.4 versus 13.4 or fewer).”

Described by Onderstall (1984) as a subspecies of Afroedura pondolia. The taxon's specific status was first recognized by Branch (1998) and this has been followed by most subsequent authors (Monadjem et al. 2003, Boycott et al. 2007, Jacobsen et al. 2014).
A disjunct population of Aloe nubigena from the mountains south of Barberton was recently described as a separate species, Aloe condyae (Van Jaarsveld 2012).

Amblyopyrum muticum (Boiss.) Eig is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii (van Slageren 1994).

This species comprises two sub-taxa: A. muticum var. loliaceum and A. muticum var. muticum (van Slageren 1994).
Clanga clanga (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aquila.

Species was established as Sminthus loriger Nathusius in Nordmann, 1840, but during long time was considered as subspecies of Sicista subtilis sensu lato (Sicista subtilis nordmanni). Now this taxon elevated to species level following Zagorodniuk and Selyunina (2009) and Cserkész et al. (2016). Sicista nordmanni (Keyserling & Blasius, 1840) is synonym as it was pointed at by Chaworth-Musters (1934). Nomenclature was revised by Zagorodniuk (2009), and current name “Sminthus loriger Nathusius in Nordmann, 1840” listed as synonym of “Sicista nordmanni Keyserling et Blasius, 1840. Sicista loriger is geographically separated from Sicista subtilis s. str. (Zagorodniuk 2011).

There are currently seven known subspecies for this species: the nominate subspecies dolicaon; subspecies septentrionalis K. Brown, 1994; subspecies hebreus K. Brown & Lamas, 1994; subspecies tromes (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies cauraensis Möhn, 2002; subspecies deileon (C. Felder & R. Felder, 1865); and subspecies deicoon (C. Felder & R. Felder, 1864).

This species was, until recently, included in Otomys irroratus and the two cannot be distinguished on morphological grounds; however, O. auratus is closely associated with the Grassland biome in South Africa and the Eastern Highlands of Zimbabwe whilst O. irroratus is closely associated with the Fynbos and Thicket biomes of the Western Cape and Eastern Cape provinces of South Africa (Monadjem et al. 2015). Otomys auratus was shown to significantly differ from O. irroratus on molecular, chromosomal and ecological grounds (Taylor et al. 2009, Engelbrecht et al. 2011).

In accordance with Vela et al. (2016), this assessment follows a strict concept of the genus Charybdis Speta in preference to a broad concept of the genus Drimia Jacq. ex Willd. sensu Manning et al. (2004) or Pfosser et al. (2006). The nomenclatural recognition of the genus Charybdis (Speta 1998) is substantiated on the invalidity of the earlier genus Squilla Steinh., which has been interpreted as an involuntary orthographic variant of Scilla L. and thus being invalid for nomenclatural purposes (Speta 1998).

The genus Cryptomys previously included all species now listed under the genus Fukomys (Monadjem et al. 2015). These two genera cannot be distinguished morphologically from one another, but are considered highly divergent from one another on a molecular level (Faulkes et al. 2004). Monadjem et al. (2015) lists five species belonging to the Cryptomys genus, with four of these considered endemic to the South Africa, Eswatini and Lesotho (Bennett 2013):

  • Common Mole-rat, C. hottentotus (tentatively Northern Cape, Western Cape, Eastern Cape and Free State provinces).
  • Natal Mole-rat, C. natalensis (tentatively KwaZulu-Natal, Eastern Cape, Mpumalanga and Limpopo provinces; Eswatini and Lesotho).
  • Mahali Mole-rat, C. mahali (tentatively Gauteng with recent reports suggesting its extension into the Northern Cape and North-West provinces).
  • Highveld Mole-rat, C. pretoriae (tentatively Gauteng, North West Province, possibly extending to the Limpopo River).
  • The Matabeleland Mole-rat, C. nimrodi is not included in this assessment because it is considered a vagrant in South Africa. The southern limit of the species range is the Limpopo River and extends northwards to Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, but the eastern limit of its range is yet to be determined.

In general, they are considered allopatric, however, the specific limits of each range are yet to be defined (Monadjem et al. 2015). In general, they are considered allopatric, however the specific limits of each range are yet to be defined (Monadjem et al. 2015).

In general, they are considered allopatric, however, the specific limits of each range are yet to be defined (Monadjem et al. 2015). In general, they are considered allopatric, however the specific limits of each range are yet to be defined (Monadjem et al. 2015).

Otomys karoensis previously was included as a synonym or subspecies of O. saundersiae (Meester et al. 1986) but chromosomal and molecular evidence show that O. saundersiae from the Eastern Cape is a synonym of O. irroratus and that O. karoensis is the correct name for the species (Taylor et al. 2009).

Several recent molecular studies have provided support for a monophyletic assemblage of South American endemic canids (Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005, Perini et al. 2010), with Chrysocyon and Speothos forming a sister-clade to the monophyletic south American foxes and Atelocynus. On the basis of morphology, Zunino et al. (1995) reviewed previous work and also supported clustering species within the two previous paraphyletic genera (Pseudalopex, Lycalopex) into a single monophyletic genus. They further argued that Lycalopex had priority over Pseudalopex, subsequently also supported by Zrzavý et al. (2004: 324). The only outstanding question would have been whether Dusicyon would have been a more appropriate name, since Perini et al. (2010) reported a close relationship between L. culpaeus and Dusicyon. However, we now know that Dusicyon is far outside this clade (Slater et al. 2009, Austin et al. 2013). Based on this evidence, the genus Lycalopex is used over Pseudalopex for all South American foxes, following Wozencraft's (2005) earlier treatment.

Two morphometric studies (Zunino et al. 2005, Prevosti et al. 2013) have suggested that Lycalopex griseus and the Pampas Fox (L. gymnocercus) belong to the same species, with clinal differences in size. However, as Prevosti et al. (2013) note, most genetic studies have not recovered the two species as a monophyletic group (although see Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005). Given the uncertainty, and since both species are in any event assessed as Least Concern, we provisionally continue to recognize Chilla and Pampas Fox as two distinct species, pending further taxonomic investigations.

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops bicornis (Forssk.) Jaub. & Spach is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Eeinkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii.

There are two varieties: Ae. bicornis var. anathera Eig and Ae. bicornis var. bicornis (van Slageren 1994).

Initially the single, monotypic species Rhabdomys pumilio was recognised (Sparrman, 1784). Several subspecies have been proposed based on extensive variation in pelage colour and morphology across the distribution. Within southern Africa, Roberts (1951) proposed 20 subspecies of which Meester et al. (1986) regarded only seven as being valid. Rambau et al. (2003) recommended the recognition of two species based on cytogenetic and mitochondrial sequence data, the xeric R. pumilio and mesic R. dilectus, which was adopted by Musser and Carleton (2005). The authors further suggested the presence of two subspecies, R. d. dilectus and R. d. chakae within the latter taxon. This was confirmed in a recent molecular and chromosomal analysis of R. dilectus, which revealed high genetic divergence within the species, and the presence of three distinct clades (Castiglia et al. 2012). The basal clade, recognised as R. d. chakae is endemic to South Africa, while the two distinct sister clades (R. d. dilectus) are distributed allopatrically across northern parts of its range, into East Africa, including a new divergent karyotype found in the high altitudes of Mt. Meru and Mt. Kilimanjaro (Castiglia et al. 2012). Reproductive isolation due to pre- and post-mating barriers have been found among R. pumilio and R. dilectus, as well as among the proposed subspecies within the latter taxon (Pillay 2000; Pillay et al. 2006). Subsequently, du Toit et al. (2012) indicated three genetic lineages with distinct distributions related to biome boundaries within the xeric R. pumilio. Based on deep mitochondrial genetic divergence, paraphyly of R. pumilio with respect to R. dilectus and different ecological preferences of the three genetic lineages within R. pumilio, the recognition of four species (R. dilectus, R. pumilio, R. bechuanae, and R. intermedius) was suggested (du Toit et al. 2012). However, Monadjem et al. (2015) recognise R. chakae as a valid species due to at least one case of known sympatry between R. d. dilectus and R. d. chakae. Further molecular research (particularly including more nuclear data) and cranial morphometric analyses would be useful to fully resolve the taxonomy of the genus. Until such time, it is recommended that Rhabdomys be treated as a species complex.
This species was included in Spermophilus townsendii until 1938. It is now recognized under a new genus, Urocitellus (Helgen et al. 2009).

Coccymys shawmayeri has recently been documented as a member of the genus Coccymys, along with C. ruemmleri and C. kirrhos (Musser and Lunde 2009). Coccymys shawmayeri can be distinguished from C. kirrhos and C. ruemmleri, by fur coloration, tail traits, and quantitative cranial and dental characters (Musser and Lunde 2009). Coccymys shawmayeri is a vicariant relative of C. kirrhos and the eastern montane vicariant of the western New Guinea C. ruemmleri. Coccymys ruemmleri is regionally sympatric with C. shawmayeri in western Papua New Guinea where the former is apparently restricted to high altitudes on the Star Mountains and the latter occurs at lower altitudes in the highlands bounding the Telefomin Valley (Musser and Lunde 2009).

Until recently, Hyla wrightorum was regarded to be a synonym of Hyla eximia, but Duellman (2001) recognized H. wrightorum as a distinct species. This treatment was adopted by Crother et al. (2003). The taxonomic status of the Mexican populations north of the Mexico City region is uncertain (Crother et al. 2003).

Dryophytes japonicus is a member of the “Dryophytes japonicus group” (Hua et al. 2009), recently renamed from Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016), and as a clear split with the “Hyla arborea group” (sensu stricto Anderson and Green 1991). Dryophytes japonicus will be further divided into two taxa: D. japonicus and D. stepheni Boulenger, 1888 (senior synonym of H. ussuriensis Nikolskii, 1918). See Fei (1999) for further taxonomic resolution.

Cisticola galactotes, C. luapula, C. haematocephalus, C. lugubris and C. marginatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. galactotes following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cisticola galactotes, C. luapula, C. haematocephalus, C. lugubris and C. marginatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. galactotes following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Locustella fasciolata and L. amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. fasciolata following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Locustella thoracica and L. kashmirensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Bradypterus thoracicus following Round and Loskot (1995).
Locustella thoracica and L. kashmirensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Bradypterus thoracicus following Round and Loskot (1995).
Hirundo tahitica and H. domicola (Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped, and subsequently split into H. tahitica and H. javanica following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

Riparia paludicola, R. cowani and R. chinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. paludicola following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pycnonotus plumosus and P. cinereifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. plumosus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sylvia sarda and S. balearica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. sarda following Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sinosuthora brunnea and S. ricketti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Paradoxornis brunneus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sinosuthora brunnea and S. ricketti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Paradoxornis brunneus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Zosterops maderaspatanus , Z. kirki and Z. semiflavus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. maderaspatanus following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Zosterops cinereus and Z. ponapensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. cinereus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Zosterops cinereus and Z. ponapensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. cinereus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Illadopsis rufipennis and I. distans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as I. rufipennis following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Garrulax chinensis and G. monachus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. chinensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Garrulax lanceolatus and G. woodi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Babax lanceolatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This species has a confusing taxonomic history which has been reviewed several times (Tarrant et al. 2008, Channing 2015). Most recently known as Amietia umbraculata, Channing (2015) reverted the name to A. vertebralis based on examination of type specimens and Zoological Nomenclature rules. Channing et al. (2016) showed that the species forms a well-supported clade and is the sister species to Amietia delalandii with which it is synoptic.

Karyotype highly polymorphic with over 30 chromosomal forms. At least some of these forms are likely to be distinct species (e.g., four new species are recognized by Musser and Carleton 2005, namely Spalax carmeli, S. galili, S. golani and S. judae). Taxonomic work needs to be carried out on this group (Nannospalax ehrenbergi, leucodon and nehringi [now xanthodon]); until that is done the new splits in the ehrenbergi group are not followed here.
It is likely that the species will be split into several species. Taxonomic work needs to be carried out on this group (ehrenbergi, leucodon and nehringi [now xanthodon]).

It is likely that the species will be split into several species. The karyotype is highly polymorphic with over 30 chromosomal forms. At least some of these forms may be distinct species. Taxonomic work needs to be carried out on this group (ehrenbergi, leucodon and nehringi [now xanthodon]).

A study by Channing and Baptista (2013) based on mitochondrial DNA, advertisement calls and morphology splits this form into two distantly related taxa, which were previously assessed together: Amietia fuscigula (Duméril and Bibron 1841) from the southwestern Cape and a recently described species, Amietia poyntoni. The species occurs in sympatry with A. delalandii, A. vandijki, and A. poyntoni.
The species occurs in sympatry with Amietia nutti (Channing et al. 2016).
Oryza alta Swallen is a secondary genetic relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (Ge et al., 1999).
O. rhizomatis D.A.Vaughan is a secondary wild relative of cultivated rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).
There is considerable uncertainty around the taxonomic status of this species (S. Loader pers. comm. November 2015).
This species has been split from Hyperolius adspersus (Channing et al. 2013).
