The most recent analysis of all acontines (Lamb et al. 2010) reveals that it is embedded within a clade of taxa now assigned to Acontias. Transfer to the genus Acontias resulted in a new combination, Acontias lineatus, which is a junior secondary homonym of A. lineatus Peters, 1879. Lamb et al. (2010) proposed the replacement name A. rieppeli, using a previously nomenclaturally-unavailable epithet proposed by Welch (1982).

Loveridge and Williams (1957) referred all southern African Kinixys to K. belliana belliana but Broadley (1993) resurrected K. lobatsiana as a full species. The genetic distinctiveness of the species was validated by Kindler et al. (2012).
Initially placed in the genus Phyllodactylus, but transferred to Goggia by Bauer et al. (1997).

No subspecies have been described for this species, but a recent molecular study of mitochondrial and nuclear DNA of southern African tortoise radiations indicates that the westernmost group along the escarpment forms a distinct lineage (Hofmeyr et al. 2017). A phylogeographic study of the species is in progress.
No notable issues.

Until recently this species was known as Lamprophis inornatus. Northern and southern subpopulations differ with regard to body proportions and scalation and are genetically divergent, indicating that two taxa may be present (Kelly et al. 2011).

Afroedura amatolica was synonymized with A. nivaria by Loveridge (1947), and some earlier references to A. nivaria may refer to this species. The A. nivaria species complex  requires revision, as at least two cryptic species within A. nivaria have been identified (Makhubo et al. 2015).

Pachydactylus maculatus is sometimes confused with P. oculatus Hewitt, 1927, which was removed from its synonymy and treated as a subspecies by De Waal (1978) and as full species by Branch (1998). The two forms are considered sister taxa (Bauer and Lamb 2005). Pachydactylus microlepis and P. albomarginatus were synonymized with P. maculatus by Loveridge (1947). Although P. microlepis has been accepted as a junior synonym of P. maculatus, De Waal (1978) regarded P. albomarginatus as a synonym of P. oculatus, whereas other authors (e.g. Kluge 2001) have followed Loveridge's interpretation. The broad distribution of P. maculatus warrants a thorough revision to determine whether taxonomically significant substructuring exists.

Pachydactylus vansoni was regarded as a subspecies of P. capensis by FitzSimons (1943), Loveridge (1947), and Broadley (1977). Its specific distinctness was demonstrated by Jacobsen (1989), who found it in strict sympatry with P. capensis. He also suggested that there might be taxonomically significant variation within P. vansoni, with distinctive Highveld versus Lowveld groups, and this requires further investigation. A molecular and morphological assessment of these three species is in progress; cryptic species are suspected and the geographical range of P. vansoni is likely to be much reduced (Makhubo and Bates in prep.).
No notable issues.

There has been some confusion between Bradypodion dracomontanum and an undescribed species (the "Emerald Dwarf"). Both occur in the Drakensberg Mountains, but B. dracomontanum occurs from Cathedral Peak northwards, whereas the Emerald Dwarf occurs to the south of Cathedral Peak (Tolley and Burger 2007, da Silva and Tolley 2017).

This species displays regional variation in size and colouration, and there are isolated subpopulations in the Cape escarpment region and the eastern highlands of Zimbabwe (Alexander 1996). Molecular data analysed for South African subpopulations indicates limited phylogeographic structuring (A. Barlow and W. Wüster pers. comm.). Although there is no molecular data available for the relict subpopulation in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe, snakes from this area appear to have lower ventral and subcaudal counts than those in South Africa.
This species has been confused with Sceotes fitzsimonsi, described by Broadley (1994). Scelotes brevipes, long regarded as a distinct species, was synonymized with S. mossambicus by Broadley (1994).

Previously treated as a northern subpopulation of Leptotyphlops nigricans (Broadley 1990), but since described as a separate species (Broadley and Broadley 1999). This species is not addressed by Adalsteinsson et al. (2009).

Basutosaura cottrelli, Hewitt 1925, was described as a new genus and species, distinguished from Tropidosaura (T. montana Duméril & Bibron, 1839 and T. burchelli A. Smith, 1849) by the presence of a single post-nasal scale (versus two post-nasals), each nostril pierced in a single scale (versus nostrils pierced between three scales), and by the keeled but not acuminate rhombic dorsal scales (versus keeled and spine-tipped elongate dorsal scales) (Hewitt 1925). The subsequent discovery and description of T. m. rangeri Hewitt, 1926, T. essexi Hewitt, 1927 and T. gularis Hewitt, 1927, bridged the geographical and morphological gap between these genera (Hewitt 1926, 1927). Consequently, Hewitt (1927) transferred this species to Tropidosaura but assigned T. cottrelli, T. essexi and T. gularis to the subgenus Basutosaura. A recent molecular study by Engleder et al. (2013) confirmed that T. cottrelli and T. essexi are sister taxa, but showed that T. gularis was more closely related to T. montana.

Northern and southern populations of this species were investigated by Broadley and Greer (1969), who found average differences in scale counts. Daniels et al. (2006) were the first to investigated representatives of the northern populations genetically while Lamb et al. (2010) sequenced a specimen from an intermediate locality in northern Eastern Cape, but the most southern subpopulation has yet to be evaluated in a molecular phylogenetic context. Busschau et al. (2017) explored the phylogenetics of this species and found that the two northern subpopulations closest relation is not the nominal Eastern Cape form, but the widespread Acontias gracilicauda. They restricted the nominal form to the Eastern Cape and indicate the presence of undescribed diversity in the northern populations.

Several discrete populations occur along the southern African escarpment. Molecular analysis supports morphological differences between these isolates, indicating that at least three cryptic taxa are subsumed under this name (Bates et al. 2014). Although FitzSimons (1959) described the subspecies Bitis atropos unicolor on the basis of patternless specimens from Belfast, the applicability of this name to the Mpumalanga escarpment subpopulations requires further assessment.

The relationship of this species to other snakes remains uncertain, although its morphology suggests a close relationship with Amplorhinus, and it has accordingly been provisionally included in the Pseudoxyrhophiinae (Vidal et al. 2008; Kelly et al. 2009).

Synonymized with Afroedura nivaria by Loveridge (1947). Some earlier references to A. amatolica may be found under A. nivaria (e.g. Wermuth 1965). Cryptic species may be involved (Makhubo et al. 2015).

Afroedura halli was regarded as a subspecies of A. karroica (Loveridge 1947, Wermuth 1965), but later considered a valid species (Bates 1996, Branch 1998). The taxonomy of the A. nivaria species complex (including A. halli) is under revision and new species may be described (Makhubo et al. 2015, Bates et al. in prep.).

Afroedura halli (South Africa and Lesotho) and A. bogerti (Angola and extreme northwestern Namibia), were previously regarded as subspecies of A. karroica (Loveridge 1944, 1947; Wermuth 1965). The taxonomic status of A. k. wilmoti is being investigated (Bates et al. in prep.).
Formerly considered a subspecies of Afroedura pondolia (e.g. Onderstall 1984), but since elevated to specific status (Branch 1998).
A molecular assessment by Makhubo et al. (2015) confirmed that this is a distinct species.

The three subspecies of L. nigropunctatus are now all considered separate species (Travers et al. 2014). The isolated subpopulation in North-West Province that is currently assigned to L. nigropunctatus should be re-evaluated using molecular methods.
A recent molecular study (Travers 2012, Travers et al. 2014) indicates that this former subspecies of Lygodactylus nicropunctatus is genetically well-defined and represents a full species.

Lygodactylus ocellatus soutpansbergensis is now considered a full species, so L. ocellatus is now monotypic (Travers et al. 2014). The taxonomic status of the isolated populations of L. ocellatus (see Jacobsen 1989) should be investigated.
Lygodactylus ocellatus soutpansbergensis is now considered a full species (Travers et al. 2014).
Confirmed as a valid species by Travers et al. (2014). The genetic distance between the apparently isolated populations should be assessed.

Pachydactylus affinis was regarded as a subspecies of P. capensis by FitzSimons (1943) and Loveridge (1947). Its specific distinctness was recognized by McLachlan (in Branch 1981) and this was later accepted by Branch (1988, 1998) and Jacobsen (1989). Jacobsen (1989) suggested that there might be taxonomically significant variation within P. affinis and this requires further investigation. Although P. affinis has been shown to be genetically distinct from P. capensis and P. vansoni (Bauer and Lamb 2002), these three species can be difficult to distinguish morphologically (e.g. Jacobsen 1989). A molecular and morphological assessment of these three species is in progress; cryptic species are suspected and the geographical range of P. affinis is likely to be much reduced (Makhubo and Bates in prep.).
The Pachydactylus mariquensis species complex consists of four distinct species, namely P. mariquensis, P. amoenus, P. latirostris and P. macrolepis (Bauer et al. 2011).

Pachydactylus oculatus is sometimes confused with its sister species, P. maculatus, and records from their area of sympatry on the inland escarpent of the Eastern and Western Cape provinces require individual verification. This species was resurrected from the synonymy of P. maculatus by De Waal (1978) as P. maculatus oculatus, and subsequently elevated to full species status (Branch 1988, Branch and Braack 1989).

Broadley et al. (1976) identified three allopatric forms of Monopeltis capensis capensis that differed mainly in annulation, size and degree of pigmentation. Typical M. capensis is referable to Group A. Group B was later described as M. infuscata, whilst Group C was described as M. decosteri (Broadley et al. 1976, Broadley 1997). Broadley (1997) also elevated M. c. rhodesianus to full species status, rendering M. capensis monotypic. A molecular and phylogenetic analysis of Monopeltis is required.

Nucras lalandii is most closely related to N. livida, N. tesselata and N. taeniolata (Edwards et al. 2013). Because this species is widespread but patchy, a molecular investigation covering the range of this species may reveal the existence of cryptic taxa.
This species may be confused with its morphologically similar sister species Pedioplanis laticeps (but see phylogeny in Makokha et al. 2007).

Although Tropidosaura essexi and T. montana natalensis are morphologically very similar, these taxa are grouped in different clades (T. essexi with T. cottrelli, and T. montana with T. gularis) (Engleder et al. 2013; M.J. Cunningham unpubl. data). There is substantial geographical variation within T. essexi with regard to the number of femoral pores, colour pattern, and mitochondrial DNA sequences. This variation appears to be bimodal and further investigation is needed to determine whether or not this reflects the presence of cryptic taxa within T. essexi (M.J. Cunningham unpubl. data).

There are three subspecies: Tropidosaura montana montana, T. m. rangeri and T. m. natalensis. The first two forms are morphologically poorly separated, based on slight differences in the development of the collar and the numbers of femoral pores in males (Branch 1998). Tropidosaura montana natalensis is separated from the other two subspecies by several differences in scalation and is also geographically disjunct (FitzSimons 1947). Mitochondrial DNA sequence data support the continued recognition of the three subspecies as minor variants within T. montana, the sister species of T. gularis (see Bates et al. 2014). This status was confirmed for T. m. montana and T. m. natalensis, which were included in the analysis of Engleder et al. (2013).
No notable issues.

Recent work has established the phylogenetic relationships of African Agama, including those among the southern African taxa (Leache et al. 2009, 2014). It confirmed previous studies suggesting the monophyletic sister relationship between South Africa’s two predominantly rock dwelling taxa, A. atra and A. anchietae, who together are sister to all other members of ‘southern African’ Agama clade (sensu Leache et al. 2014). These studies were preceded by more detailed phylogeographic studies focused on population structure within the former, identifying three main clades in the A. atra complex; a  southern-eastern clade, a northern-central clade (including Namaqualand) and a Namibian clade (comprising A. atra knobeli) (Matthee and Flemming 2002). A follow-up study of A. atra in the Cape Floristic Region (part of the southern-eastern clade), revealed the existence of four geographically distinct clades of unresolved taxonomic status in this region (Swart et al. 2008). The latter study also confirmed that the Northern Cape and Namibian populations were genetically distinct from one another, with the Namibian population being recognized as a full species, namely A. knobeli. The taxonomic status of the large-bodied Northern Cape populations (see Flemming 1996) is currently investigated (Nielsen et al. unpub.). Agama atra knobeli was historically recorded from the Richtersveld area of Namaqualand (as far south as the Knersvlakte), apparently based on a larger caudal crest than in A. atra and medially-oriented dorsal imbrication (Branch 1998, Bauer and Branch 2003[2001]).  However, both of these characters are highly variable and subjectively interpreted, so for now A. knobeli is considered a Namibian endemic, based on the molecular analyses discussed above (Nielsen et al. unpub.). Utilizing much more detailed geographic sampling, multilocus molecular data, and morphological analysis, Nielsen’s (2016) unpublished thesis further delimits the population level boundaries of the subclades, but second guesses the species level recognition of either A. knobeli or any of the other recognized subclades.

There is considerable variation in colour pattern (see Branch 1998), habits and behaviour across the range of this species. This is accompanied by significant genetic divergence (Kelly et al. 2011) and it is therefore possible that ‘Lamprophis guttatus’ contains a number of taxa.

Previously known as Typhlops bibronii, but placed in the new endemic African genus Afrotyphlops by Broadley and Wallach (2009). The taxonomic status of the subpopulation in eastern Zimbabwe should be investigated using molecular techniques.

This species is part of a larger species complex (comprising Bradypodion melanocephalum and B. thamnobates) in which genetic differentiation is low but obvious morphological differences exist (daSilva and Tolley 2013, 2017).

Branch (1990) showed that Tetradactylus laevicauda (described from the KwaZulu-Natal Drakensberg, South Africa), treated as a subspecies of T. seps by FitzSimons (1943), is a junior synonym of the latter. However, the KwaZulu-Natal and Cape subpopulations are geographically well-separated, and a phylogenetic analysis is needed to determine whether T. laevicauda (KwaZulu-Natal) is in fact a valid species .

Although Loveridge (1942) and FitzSimons (1943) treated  Tetradactylus bilineatus as a subspecies of T. tetradactylus, Branch (1990) showed that it is a junior synonym of the latter. It is likely that the  central Eastern Cape population is genetically differentiated and if so, the name T. bilineatus will be re-instated.

This taxon was recently transferred from Typhlosaurus to Acontias by Lamb et al. (2010) on the basis of molecular phylogenetic results. Typhlosaurus cregoi bicolor, a Zimbabwean endemic, was elevated to specific status as Acontias bicolor, rendering A. cregoi monotypic (Lamb et al. 2010).

Recent molecular phylogenetic studies have demonstrated that Acontia gracilicauda gracilicauda and A. g. namaquensis are not closely related. The latter has been raised to full specific status (Lamb et al. 2010) despite only minor scalation differences between the two taxa (Broadley and Greer 1969). Busschau et al. (2017) investigate the relationships between A. gracilicauda and A. brevicpes and showed that the disjunt Northern Cape records of this species is referable to A. occidentalis. They also show that the two disjunct  Mpumalanga A. breviceps populations to show closer affiliation to this species.

Until recently this taxon was considered as a slender, striped color morph of Acontias meleagris orientalis (Broadley and Greer 1969; Daniels et al. 2002, 2005, 2006, 2009). Although easily diagnosable morphologically, A. "lineicauda" is neither monophyletic nor imbedded within A. orientalis (Daniels et al. 2005) and has been recognized as a paraphyletic species level taxon pending further study (Lamb et al. 2010). In a recent study of the biogeography of the A. meleagris complex, Engelbrecht et al. (2013) continue to recognize a A. meleagris orientalis ‘lineicauda’ morph, although restricting it to a clade distributed east of Algoa Bay (Alexandria to East London). Material from Port Elizabeth and Oyster Bay (not included in their range map) display the ‘lineacauda’ morphology but were not assigned to any named clade (Engelbrecht et al. 2013). The taxonomic status of A. lineicauda remains problematic, particularly as topotypic material from Dunbrody (Hewitt 1937) within Algoa Bay and outside of the geographic area of the clade to which Engelbrecht et al. (2013) have applied the name, has not been assessed.

This species was previously confused with the similar Acontias plumbeus (e.g. Broadley 1984), to which it is closely related (Lamb et al. 2010). Although it may be diagnosed morphologically from A. plumbeus, it is genetically very similar (Lamb et al. 2010). This suggests that further work, incorporating broader sampling across both species is required to clarify relationships in more detail.
This species was reviewed by Broadley (1994) and there are no outstanding issues.
This species was last reviewed by Broadley (1994) and there are no outstanding issues.

This species formed part of the Leptotyphlops scutifrons species complex (Broadley and Wallach 2007). However, Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) noted that many species groups previously recognized are paraphyletic and they therefore refrained from recognizing such groups. The status of the apparently isolated subpopulation in KwaZulu-Natal should be investigated.

Broadley and Broadley (1999) recognized that the disjunct northern subpopulations previously assigned to Leptotyphlops nigricans (e.g. Broadley and Watson 1976, Branch 1998) represented different species which they described as L. jacobseni and L. kafue. They also restricted L. nigricans to the two southern Cape provinces. However, recent molecular studies have revealed deep genetic divergence between Western and Eastern Cape subpopulations that may indicate separate species status (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009). The area of separation or overlap between the putative Cape species is unknown (i.e. Broadley and Broadley 1999).

In certain parts of its range, this species exhibits colour polymorphism. However, limited sampling by Kelly et al. (2008) which included the isolated subpopulation in eastern Zimbabwe, suggested that different subpopulations are not sufficiently divergent to justify separate taxonomic status.
No notable issues.

The Zimbabwean and South African populations are geographically well separated, and are substantially divergent genetically (Kelly et al. 2009). These populations, and perhaps also the two major regional populations in South Africa, i.e. Western Cape vs Lesotho and eastern parts of South Africa, may all represent separate species (Bates et al. 2014).

Raw (1973) described two subspecies (Lycodonomorphus laevissimus fitzsimonsi and L. l. natalensis) but these are no longer recognized (Haagner and Branch 1994, Branch 1998). A phylogeographic study of subpopulations from different drainage basins may be informative with regard to gene flow.
Treated as monotypic since Prosymna sundevallii lineata was elevated to species status by Broadley (1999).
The relationship of isolated subpopulations (e.g. Soutpansberg) to the main subpopulation should be investigated using molecular markers.

Until recently, Chamaesaura miopropus was treated as a northern subspecies of C. macrolepis (Broadley 1966, 1971; Broadley and Howell 1991; Branch 1998; Spawls et al. 2002). However, C. miopropus is geographically isolated (Angola, Zambia, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Malawi, Tanzania) and distinguished by the presence of vestigial forelimbs, which are absent in  C. macrolepis (Broadley and Howell 1991, Haagner et al. 2000, Spawls et al. 2002, Broadley and Cotterill 2004). It should therefore be considered a valid species, such that C. macrolepis reverts to binomial status. A molecular analysis would be helpful in assessing the taxonomic status of isolated subpopulations of C. macrolepis, such as the one in the Chimanimani Mountains of Zimbabwe.

A molecular analysis by Stanley et al. (2011) revealed that specimens assigned to Cordylus tasmani showed little genetic divergence from C. cordylus. Cordylus tasmani is therefore treated as a junior synonym of C. cordylus.

De Waal (1978) recognized three varieties of Cordylus vittifer vittifer. Branch (1998) elevated C. v. machadoi to full species status, rendering C. vittifer a monotypic species. This status was confirmed in a molecular analysis by Stanley et al. (2011). The taxonomy of C. vittifer is currently being evaluated using molecular and morphological approaches (M.F. Bates and M.J. Cunningham in prep.).
The genus Platysaurus is being revised. An analysis of molecular data will help resolve the status of the two subspecies, P. orientalis orientalis and P. o. fitzsimonsi (S. Keogh et al. in prep.).

Genetic and morphological data suggests that northern subpopulations of Pseudocordylus melanotus melanotus (northern Mpumalanga and Swaziland), southern subpopulations of P. m. melanotus and P. m. subviridis are all sufficiently differentiated to be considered separate species (Bates 2007). However, further analyses are needed to fully resolve the taxonomy of the P. melanotus species complex.

Although there are some morphological features that distinguish the subspecies from each other (Pseudocordylus microlepidotus microlepidotus, P. microlepidotus fasciatus and P. m. namaquensis) (FitzSimons 1943, Bates 2005), their taxonomic status should be re-evaluated. A molecular assessment of these relationships is currently underway (Bates et al. in prep.).

Based on morphological and molecular analyses, Pseudocordylus transvaalensis appears to be a valid species rather than a subspecies of P. melanotus (Jacobsen 1989; Bates 2005, 2007; Stanley et al. 2011). The three allopatric populations differ morphologically, but mitochondrial DNA sequence data for western and central subpopulations indicate that they are conspecific (Bates 2007).

Previously contained within the genus Cordylus (Stanley et al. 2011). The taxonomic status of forms in the Smaug warreni species complex to which S. barbertonensis belongs (see Jacobsen 1989), was evaluated using molecular methods (Stanley and Bates 2014). The study identified eight well supported and distinct clades that are allopatric. The study also found that S. warreni barbertonensis was polyphyletic. Smaug barbertonensis was considered a full species and not a subspecies of S. warreni. The taxonomic status of the south-eastern forms of the S. warreni complex requires investigation.

Previously contained within the genus Cordylus (Stanley et al. 2011). The taxonomic status of forms in the Smaug warreni species complex to which S. vandami belongs (Jacobsen 1989) was evaluated using molecular and morphological approaches (Stanley and Bates 2014). The study identified eight well supported distinct clades that are allopatric, and S. vandami was confirmed as a distinct species.

Previously recognized subspecies (smithi and peringueyi) were treated as junior synonyms of Mabuya (=Trachylepis) homalocephala by Branch (1998), who also elevated T. depressa to species status. The species is endemic to South Africa where there are apparently several isolated subpopulations (e.g. Namaqualand; eastern escarpment). Preliminary genetic data for the Namaqualand subpopulation, referable to T. h. peringueyi indicate that taxonomic revision is required (Bates et al. 2014). Jacobsen (1989) reported morphological differences between the escarpment populations of Mpumalanga/Limpopo and those in KwaZulu-Natal provinces, but this may be  clinal. The specific epithet "homalocephala" is a recent spelling of the original "homolocephalus" by Wiegmann (1828), but is maintained under Article 33.3.1 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (Bauer 2000, Broadley 2000).

This species reverts to binomials because Tetradactylus fitzsimonsi, generally considered a subspecies of T. africanus (e.g. FitzSimons 1943, Branch 1998), is here considered a valid species (see discussion under T. fitzsimonsi). A taxonomic review of the genus is in progress (M.F. Bates in prep.). A new record in the Eastern Cape province, near the border with KwaZulu-Natal, is referable to a new species related to T. africanus and T. fitzsimonsi (W. Conradie in prep.).
Narcissus jonquilla is one of a complex of species that require further taxonomic clarification, and a number of synonyms have been described.

Schmidtler (1997) raised the subspecies budaki, chernovi, and rueppellii to full species status, thus restricting Ablepharus kitaibelii to southeastern Europe and west and central Turkey. However, the taxonomy of this species is currently under review (P. Lymberakis pers. comm.). Ljubisvljevic et al. (2002) examined geographic variation in parts of the Balkan peninsula. Poulakakis et al. (2005) showed that A. kitaibelii is not monophyletic, and that the population on the Kastelorizo island group (Greece, off the Lycian coast of southwestern Turkey) is particularly distinct and deserves specific status. The remaining populations of A. kitaibelii consist of two clades, one comprising the populations inhabiting continental Greece and the west Aegean (Cyclades and Kithira) and Ionian (Leukada) islands, and the other comprising populations that inhabit the East Aegean islands (including ?Crete?) and Turkey.

Greenbaum et al. (2007) noted that Boulenger's (1885) amendment of the species name to 'wahlbergii', the name used predominately in subsequent literature, was unjustified. However, according to Ulber (1999), this is incorrect as Smith (1849) included a separate publisher's errata slip which indicated that 'walbergii' should be corrected to 'wahlbergii' wherever it appeared. Such an inserted slip, under Article 32.5.1.1 of the ICZN (1999) is clear evidence of an inadvertent error that must be corrected. The absence of the errata slip from some copies of Smith's work has contributed to confusion on this point.

A taxonomic review by Broadley et al. (2014), which included a molecular phylogeny, found that the subspecies Homopholis wahlbergii arnoldi of eastern Botswana, northern South Africa, Zimbabwe and Mozambique is a valid full species. Both subspecies were elevated to full species: H. wahlbergii and H. arnoldi.
The genus Calliptamulus is in need of taxonomic revision.
The genus Calliptamulus is in need of taxonomic revision.
The genus Calliptamulus is in need of taxonomic revision.

Lepidagathis is a genus in need of taxonomic revision and species boundaries may change in future. Lisowski (2009) lumps L. pobeguinii Hua together with L. chevalieri Benoist and L. felicis Benoist. We maintain L. chevalieri as a separate species, based on inflorescence characters.
Pacheco (2003) distinguished Thomasomys eleusis from T. cinereus and T. ischyrus, as a valid species. In addition, T. eleusis was found allied to T. incanus in the same clade.

This species was not recognised in the revision of Betula by Ashburner and McAllister (2013) nor by earlier eastern European taxonomic treatments (e.g., Tzvelev 2004), and it is sometimes considered to be an aberrant specimen of the Common Birch, Betula pubescens (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).

However, recent taxonomic work does recognise this species in its own right (Tarieiev pers. comm. 2015), as is also reflected in The Red List of Betulaceae (Shaw et al. 2014) and the World Checklist of Selected Plants (WCSP 2017).
WCSP (2018) considers the senior name for this species to be Arrhenatherum pallens (Link) Link.

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops comosa Sm. is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii. Two varieties are comprised within this species: Ae. comosa var. comosa and Ae. comosa var. subventricosa Boiss. (van Slageren 1994).

Picoides ramsayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Dendrocopos. Dendrocopos maculatus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) has been split into D. maculatus and D. ramsayi following Collar et al. (1999), who initially placed it in the genus Picoides. Subsequently, the genus Dendrocopos has been used, following Winkler and Christie (2002). Because this split was made in a BirdLife publication, the justification is repeated here in full (but the references are not supplied). Both Hachisuka (1931-1935) and Voous (1947) treated ramsayi as a separate species, and indeed it is so distinctive as to be arguably closer to Sulawesi Woodpecker P. temminckii than it is to P. maculatus (this view is also expressed, with the comment that ramsayi is "the ancestor common to both", by White and Bruce 1986), and given the evident morphological proximity of Brown-capped P. moluccensis, Grey-capped P. canicapillus and Pygmy Woodpeckers P. kizuki to both maculatus (non-Sulu forms) and ramsayi, there is no compelling reason to combine the latter two as a single species. Sulu birds differ from other Philippine forms in: replacing all black or dark brown with a mid-brown; lacking virtually all white spotting on wings and coverts; lacking black or dark brown spotting or streaking on the undersides; showing an ill-defined yellow or yellowish-orange breast-band, plus (in the male) a far more strongly developed red area on the nape. The specific separation of ramsayi is all the more arguable for the geographically closest representative of maculatus - fulvifasciatus of Mindanao and Basilan showing the strongest pied effect. The notion that these two forms are "bridged" by maculatus, with a throw-away description of ramsayi as "aberrant" (Salomonsen 1953), not only fails to deal with the suggestion of Voous (1947) that ramsayi represents an early invasion of the Philippines, but also misses the point that maculatus is not geographically interposed between the two forms it is supposed to bridge. It is worth noting that in the paper in which both ramsayi and fulvifasciatus were first established, the formal description of ramsayi compared it to temminckii rather than to maculatus (Hargitt 1881).
Cenchrus flaccidus (Griseb.) Morrone is a tertiary wild relative of Pearl Millet C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.).
Cenchrus basedowii is a tertiary wild relative of pearl millet C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Cenchrus ramosus (Hochst.) Morrone is a tertiary wild relative of pearl millet, C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Daucus pusillus Michx. is a tertiary wild relative of carrot, D. carota subsp. sativus var. sativus Hoffm. and D. carota subsp. sativus var. atrorubens Alef. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017)
Daucus sahariensis Murb. is a secondary genetic wild relative of carrot, D. carota subsp. sativus var. sativus Hoffm. and D. carota subsp. sativus var. atrorubens Alef. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017)
Cenchrus polystachios (L.) Schult. belongs to Gene Pool three of Pearl Millet Cenchrus americanus (L.) Morrone [=Pennisetum glaucum (L.) R.Br.]

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops ventricosa Tausch is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. subsp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. subsp. timopheevii.
Turdus eremita (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Nesocichla eremita.

Formerly in genus Spermophilus (Helgen et al. 2009). Yensen (1991) and Gill and Yensen (1992) suggested the two subspecies, Urocitellus b. brunneus and U. b. endemicus, could be full species. Although Thorington and Hoffmann (2005) listed endemicus as a synonym of brunneus, genetic studies by Hoisington-Lopez et al. (2012) confirmed the two are full species. U. brunneus and U. endemicus are now recognized as monotypic species.

Sorbus teodori is not accepted as a valid species by many taxonomists, and will be included as a heterotypic synonym to Sorbus meinichii in the forthcoming volume of Flora Nordica.

Based on current species concepts in the study of this genus (Rich et al. 2010) it would be arguable to keep a Baltic narrow endemic Sorbus teodori and a Norwegian endemic S. meinichii. However, if following this approach, several clonal variations observed might require taxonomic recognition, increasing the number of narrow endemic Sorbus spp. in Fennoscandia. The more traditional Linnaean species concept would include all those varieties in Sorbus meinichii. Taxonomic studies of the genus in northern Europe are underway, for example by the Arboretum and Botanical Garden of the University of Bergen (P.H. Salvesen pers. comm. 2010, Artsdatabanken 2010).

According to the latest Swedish Red List (ArtDatabanken 2015), S. teodorii (Swedish) is triploid and S. meinichii (Norwegian) is tetraploid and therefore both names should be retained. Unpublished results on the ploidy levels of these taxa show that the situation is more complicated, with several triploid populations occurring in Norway, and also a number of tetraploid populations as well (P.H. Salvesen pers. comm. 2016). Thus in addition to allowing the two names to be retained in the strict sense, there is probably a need for defining new species within the complex, both in Norway and Sweden, and possibly also in Finland.

Recent studies based on genome-wide sequencing and morphology have shown that "golden jackals" in Africa are larger in size than those from Eurasia and are actually more closely related to the Grey Wolf Canis lupus. African animals hence represent a previously overlooked distinct species, the African Wolf, Canis lupaster (see Rueness et al. 2011, Gaubert et al. 2012, Koepfli et al. 2015, Viranta et al. 2017). However, the putative presence of Golden Jackal in the Sinai Peninsula of Egypt remains unclear (see Gaubert et al. 2012, Viranta et al. 2017).

One small point of confusion pertains to the correct species name for the African Wolf, since authors have alternated between Canis lupaster and Canis anthus, of which the latter has priority. However, Viranta et al. (2017) provide a rationale for considering Canis anthus a nomen dubium (in part due to the fact that the holotype is also missing), and use C. lupaster as the name for the African Wolf.

The treatment herein therefore provisionally follows the latter authors, but the situation may warrant further investigation.
Calendulauda albescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Certhilauda albescens.
Buteo oreophilus and B. trizonatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as B. oreophilus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Chlamydotis undulata and C. macqueenii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. undulata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Gracupica contra and G. jalla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Sturnus contra following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Gyps rueppelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as G. rueppellii.
Psittiparus ruficeps and P. bakeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Paradoxornis ruficeps following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psittiparus ruficeps and P. bakeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Paradoxornis ruficeps following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psophocichla litsitsirupa and P. simensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. litsitsirupa following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Melaniparus leucomelas and M. guineensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. leucomelas following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Melaniparus leucomelas and M. guineensis (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as M. leucomelas following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).

Blakemore (2010a: 193) was obliged to provide this replacement name in order to presage potential restoration of the original name since that name occasionally resurfaces contrary to taxonomic protocol and conventions. Moreover, it appears that the required "standards, sense and stability" for zoological nomenclature were not met (ICZN 1999).  In particular, the original description appears invalid under ICZN (1999: Art. 11.4 - http://www.nhm.ac.uk/hosted-sites/iczn/code/index.jsp?article=11&nfv=true) since the Principle of Binominal Nomenclature [Art. 5.1] was not consistently applied in the original work as a Japanese vernacular name "Kotsubu-mimizu" (コツブミミズ) was simultaneously applied.  Between 1999-2000 approximately 60 new names were proposed by Mr Kotaru Ishizuka, several of these were homonyms, most were synonyms and many if not all were species incertae sedis or species inquirenda due to inconsistencies and inadequacy of original descriptions unaided by a failure to properly compare with prior Japanese or Korean taxa.  This too was hindered by the secreting of the crucial and historical Goto & Hatai type collection by Mr Ishizuka from 1980 until its rediscovery in 2010 (Blakemore and Ueshima 2011, Blakemore 2012b, 2016b).  The monumental and onerous task of correcting all these errors is now circumvented by invoking the ICZN (1999: Art. 11.4) invalidating and seeking suppression for all Ishizuka's names and nomenclatural acts allowing less hindered taxonomic progress following International rules and conventions.
The nominal and cosmopolitan sub-species, Amynthas corticis corticis, to which this synonym belongs (Blakemore 2003, 2012a) is included in the Japanese Redlist only because its original epithet,"Pheretima invisa" Ishizuka, 2000 (sic), still persists in parts of Japanese literature despite also being a permanently invalid primary homonym (non Pheretima invisa Cognetti, 1913).

Three subspecies are distinguished: Dendrobium brevicaule subsp. brevicaule, D. brevicaule subsp. calcarium and D. brevicaule subsp. pentagonum (Reeve and Woods 1989). Each of these have a number of synonyms, but for brevity these are not all listed (see WCSP 2018 for details).

J.J. Smith compared this species to Dendrobium torricellense Schltr. from which it differs in having smaller one-leaved pseudobulbs and in the shape of its lip. He suggests that the type of Dendrobium rariflorum may be an immature specimen judging from the size of its vegetative parts (Cribb 1983).

Observations by T. M. Reeve confirmed that the range of variability in this species encompassed Dendrobium guttatum, D. helenae, D. alpinum and D. giluwense all of which are considered by Cribb (1983) to be conspecific. Further study was recommended to assess the relative status of  D. acutisepalum and D. rhomboglossum (Cribb 1983). The World Checklist (WCSP2018) lists D. rhomboglossum as a synonym of this species.

Three varieties of the species are recognised by Reeve and Woods (1989): var. sulphureum, var. rigidifolium and var. cellulosum. The differences between the three varieties recognised  are considered by De Vogel et al. (2018) not to be clear cut but as an attempt to formalise what appears to be a 3-modal variability in the specimens that Reeve and Woods examined.

Traditionally, this species is placed within Ramusculus (e.g. Schileyko 1998, Balashov 2016a), and morphologically the species is not correctly placed in Brephulopsis (table by R. Bank in Gümüş and Neubert 2012), however, we currently follow MolluscaBase (Bank and Neubert 2017) in placing the species within the genus Brephulopsis until genetic confirmation is obtained.

In Europe, two subspecies are recognized: C. l. signatus (Iberia) and C. l. italicus (Italy, France and Switzerland).

In Asia, two subspecies are recognized: C. l. pallipes (most of the Asian range from Israel to China) and C. l. arabs (Arabian peninsula). Furthermore, wolves of the Himalayan range have been proposed as a distinct subspecies (C. l. chanco).

In North America, five subspecies are often recognized: C. l. arctos (Arctic wolf), C. l. lycaon (Eastern wolf), which Chambers et al. (2012) consider a distinct species, C. l. nubilus (Plains wolf), C. l. occidentalis (Northwestern wolf or Northern timber wolf), and C. l. baileyi (Mexican wolf).

Note that this assessment follows Jackson et al. (2017) in regarding the Dingo, sometimes considered a subspecies of Grey Wolf (C. l. dingo), as a feral dog population derived from a domesticate, and hence as C. familiaris, along with all other free-ranging dogs.
Calandrella cinerea, C. eremica and C. blanfordi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. cinerea following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Charadrius alexandrinus, C. dealbatus and C. nivosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. alexandrinus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Turdus ruficollis and T. atrogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. ruficollis following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hirundo tahitica and H. domicola (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped, and subsequently split into H. tahitica and H. javanica following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

Recent studies of hairy armadillos using morphological and molecular analyses (Abba et al. 2015, Gibb et al. 2016) revealed that there are insufficient differences between Chaetophractus nationi and C. vellerosus to classify them as separate species. Hence, C. nationi is considered an invalid species and has been synonymized with C. vellerosus based on the taxonomic principle of priority.

Molecular analyses of mitochondrial DNA control region (D-loop) revealed a single C. nationi haplotype that appeared to be identical with a C. vellerosus haplotype. Identical sequences in C. vellerosus and C. nationi were also observed for three of the five non-coding nuclear markers investigated. Three-dimensional landmark coordinate analyses of skulls did not allow differentiating the two species; the subtle morphological differences in skull shape were related to a latitudinal and/or altitudinal gradient.

The specimens formerly classified as C. nationi are similar in size to specimens of C. v. vellerosus, with which they also share mitochondrial haplotypes. They might thus be viewed as being part of this subspecies. Nevertheless, the reality of the subspecies definition within C. vellerosus requires more detailed phylogeographic and population genetics studies.
Daucus crinitus Desf. is a tertiary wild relative of carrot, D. carota L. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Plants of the World online (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2018) consider Daucus durieua Lange (western Mediterranean and North African distribution) and Daucus subsessilis Boiss. (eastern Mediterranean, west Asia and Arabian Peninsula distribution) as separate valid taxa, whilst this assessment follows the National Plant Germplasm System of the USDA Agricultural Research Service (GRIN 2017) in considering Daucus subsessilis to be a synonym of Daucus durieua.

Daucus durieua Lange is a tertiary wild relative of carrot, D. carota subsp. sativus var. sativus Hoffm. and D. carota subsp. sativus var. atrorubens Alef. (GRIN 2017).

UAE Taxonomic Notes
Plants of the World online (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2018) consider Daucus durieua Lange (western Mediterranean and North African distribution) and Daucus subsessilis Boiss. (eastern Mediterranean, west Asia and Arabian Peninsula distribution) as separate valid taxa, whilst this assessment follows the National Plant Germplasm System of the USDA Agricultural Research Service (GRIN 2017) in considering Daucus subsessilis to be a synonym of Daucus durieua.

Jongbloed (2003) mentions both Daucus durieua Lange and Daucus subsessilis Boiss. for the UAE, citing Böer. Böer and Chaudhary (1999) mention Daucus subsessilis. Pending further investigation, we include Daucus subsessilis within Daucus subsessilis.
Daucus involucratus Sibth. & Sm. is a wild relative of carrot, D. carota subsp. sativus var. sativus Hoffm., D. carota subsp. sativus var. atrorubens Alef. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Daucus muricatus (L.) L. is a tertiary wild relative of carrot, D. carota subsp. sativus var. sativus Hoffm. and D. carota subsp. sativus var. atrorubens Alef. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017)

Lathyrus hirsutus L. is cultivated in USA for animal food (forage and fodder) (Sarker et al. 2001), but only the wild populations are considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, L. hirsutus is a primary wild relative of caley pea, the cultivated form of the species. According to Shehadeh et al. (in prep), it is a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated grass pea (L. sativus L.)  although some sources state it is a tertiary genetic relative (Vincent et al. 2013. It is also a secondary genetic wild relative of sweet pea (L. odoratus L.) (Sarker et al. 2001). L. hirsutus is in the section Lathyrus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 2 of chickling vetch (L. cicera L.), and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species including broad-leaved everlasting pea (L. latifolius L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It is also in Taxon Group 4 of Cyprus vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

This species appeared on the IUCN Red List until 2016 as Carex conferta var. lycurus. It is now considered valid as Carex lycurus. An updated Red List assessment has been created to reflect this change.

The e-Monocot website states this is a nomen illegitimum and a synonym of Cyperus exaltatus var. exaltatus. As the African Plant Database still upholds the species (as do the African Floras) this assessment follows the African tradition.

A perennial herb, briefly rhizomatuous giving very long stolon with erect stems numerous tight ; 30-120 cm high, 0,6- 2 mm thick ; Leaves reduced, inflorescence is a glomerule of 3-20 spikelets sessile.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.

Equisetum ramosissimum was previously erroneously treated as a synonym of the Neotropical species E. giganteum, due to confusion of the specimens. However E. ramosissimum is a separate species (Christenhusz and Raab-Straube 2013) found in the Old World.

This taxon was previously included within Trachylepis aurata, as the subspecies T. a. septemtaeniata and T. a. transcaucasica. Following the validation of T. septemtaeniata as a full species (Mausfeld and Schmitz 2003, Moravec et al. 2006) the western range limit of this species in Anatolia (where T. aurata also occurs) is in need of clarification. This account provisionally follows the distribution provided in Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008).

Karin et al. (2016) now place this species in the genus Heremites.
Previously included in the genus Mabuya.  Karin et al. (2016) now place this species in a separate genus Heremites.

For many years the Red Deer complex, including European and North African Red Deer (Cervus elaphus), Tarim Red Deer and Eastern Asian and North American Wapiti (C. canadensis) were considered as one species. Several genetic studies have recently tried to clarify the taxonomy of this species complex, but their results are not always concordant.

Although Grubb (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) included canadensis in C. elaphus, sharing this conclusion with most taxonomists of 20th century, all original scientific papers published since 1995 have concluded that C. elaphus and C. canadensis are two valid species regardless of whether this conclusion was based on comparison of molecular (Kuwuyama and Ozawa 1999, Randi et al. 2001, Ludt et al. 2004, Pitra et al. 2004, Zhang and Zhang 2012, Liu et al. 2013, Lorenzini and Garofolo 2015), or ethological data (Cap et al. 2008, Frey and Riede 2013, Pereladova 2013). Based on morphological data this was suggested earlier by several authors, e.g. Lydekker (1898), Flerov (1952) and Geist (1998) and both recent reviews on cervid taxonomy are in line with this opinion (Groves and Grubb 2011, Mattioli 2011).

Recent analysis of the Cervus group (Lorenzini and Garofolo 2015, Mukesh et al. 2015, Kumar et al. 2016) have provided the first indications of another, fourth species (including Cervus nippon sensu latu). Mitochondrial complete cytochrome b and control region sequences were analysed under a Bayesian coalescent framework to derive phylogeny, with particular attention on populations from Central Asia. The resultant phylogenetic reconstruction suggested that, after excision of C. canadensis, red deer are differentiated  into two robust monophyletic clades corresponding to the western and eastern part of the range. At the species level, molecular data suggested this fourth species should be recognized as the Tarim Red Deer from Central Asia, including the populations from the Yarkand-Tarim and Bukhara regions and Indian Kashmir, which were formerly considered as subspecies of C. elaphus (C. e yarkandensis, C .e. bactrianus and C. e. hanglu, respectively).

Lorenzini and Garofolo (2015) suggest this taxon should be recognized as the Tarim Red Deer Cervus hanglu Wagner, 1844, as the name with priority over C. yarkandensis or C. bactrianus. This group forms a part of the western clade and appears to have diverged from C. elaphus during the middle Pleistocene, at a similar time as C. nippon diverged from C. canadensis. The genetic distinctiveness of the Tarim Red Deer group is supported by previous mitochondrial studies (Ludt et al. 2004, Pitra et al. 2004, Mukesh et al. 2015). Further investigations need to be conducted from additional molecular sources and nuclear coding genes as well as verification of morphology from museum specimens, before the elevation of the Tarim Red Deer to species level can be confirmed (Lorenzini and Garofalo 2015). Cervus hanglu was elevated to species level for the purpose of the IUCN Red List assessment in 2016. However, it should be noted that future clarification on genetic relatedness, especially studies with nuclear markers and a more formal morphological description, may lead to further revisions to the taxonomuy of this provisional species, as more information becomes available.

C. h. bactrianus and C. h. yarkandensis were not supported as distinct subspecies by molecular data (Lorenzini and Garofolo 2015). However, we refer to them throughout this account for ease of recognition
C. h. hanglu Wagner 1844 (N India (Kashmir))
C. h. bactrianus (W Turkestan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and N Afghanistan)
C. h. yarkandensis (E Turkestan (S Xinjiang, China))
Olinia chimanimani T.Shah & I. Darbysh. has recently been described in Kew Bulletin (Shah et al. 2018). Linder 3990 (collected 20/11/1986) is the designated Holotype.
Accepted as a valid taxon by most cactus researchers including Bravo-Hollis and Sanchez Mejorada (1991), Anderson (2001), Arredondo et al. (2001), Dicht and Lüthy A (2003) and Hunt et al. (2006).
Accepted as a valid species by cactus specialists Anderson (2001) and Hunt (1999).

This species comprises three subspecies - the typical form, subsp. bumamma (Ehrenb.) Dicht & A.Lüthy, and subsp. greenwoodii (Bravo) Dicht & A.Lüthy. The typical subspecies and subsp. bumamma are not threatened and hence are not listed separately; subsp. greenwoodii was assessed as Endangered in 2002, but it has not been reassessed here, hence the former listing has been dropped.
Two subspecies are recognized, the typical form and subsp. scheeri (Lem.) N.P.Taylor. These are not assessed separately.
May be conspecific with C. difficilis (Hunt et al. 2006).
Two susbpecies are recognized, the nominate and subsp. boyce-thompsonii (Orcutt) N.P.Taylor.

A distinct species with six subspecies: the nominate form, subsp. armatus (Poselg.) N.P.Taylor, subsp. baileyi (Rose) N.P.Taylor, subsp. burrensis G.Frank, Metorn & E.Scherer, subsp. fitchii (Britton & Rose) N.P.Taylor and subsp. perbellus (Britton & Rose) N.P.Taylor.
This species includes E. tubiflora (Pfeiff) Zucc. ex A.Dietr., from Salta and Tucuman in Argentina, which is considered a different species by Kiesling (in Zuloaga and Morrone 1999).
Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. fallax (Oehme) M.Lowry, and subsp. shaferi (Britton & Rose) M.Lowry.

This species has numerous variations and subspecies and is in need of taxonomic revision (T. Terrazas pers. comm. 2009). Four subspecies are currently recognized: the nominate form, subsp. acanthosetus (S.Arias & U.Guzmán) W.Blum, subsp. sharpii (N.P.Taylor) N.P.Taylor and subsp. weinbergii (Weing.) N.P.Taylor.
A note on the New Cactus Lexicon (Hunt et al. 2006) reads: "Doubtfully distinct from the allied E. scopulorum and E. sciurus ssp. floresii, both from coastal Sonora".
Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. haemantha (Rausch) M.Lowry and subsp. rossii (Boed.) G.Navarro.

There are numerous varieties and subspecies. The following subspecies are currently recognized: the nominate form, subsp. chloranthus (Engelm.) N.P.Taylor, subsp. correllii (L.D.Benson) W.Blum & Mich.Lange, subsp. cylindricus (Engelm.) N.P.Taylor, and subsp. davisii (Houghton) N.P.Taylor.
Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate, subsp. ctenoides (Engelm.) G.Frank and subsp. wenigeri (L.D.Benson) W.Blum & Rutow.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. rubispinus (G.Frank & A.B.Lau) N.P.Taylor.

The species should be placed under the name Echinopsis rauschii H.Friedrich, and should include E. rojasii Cárdenas (assessed separately here). According to Hunt et al. (2006) the concept of E. calorubra also includes E. cardenasiana (Rausch) H.Friedrich which should be assessed independently as a good species (M. Lowry pers. comm. 2010). It is all treated as a single species complex here.

Four subspecies are recognized, the typical form, subsp. dactylifera (Vaupel). D.R.Hunt, subsp. echinacea (F.Ritter) D.R.Hunt, subsp. ignescens (Vaupel) D.R.Hunt (Hunt et al. 2006). C. mistiensis (Backeb.) E.F.Anderson  is included within this complex (Hunt et al. 2006) but should be considered as a separate species (F. Cáceres and C. Ostolaza pers. comm. 2011). The complex is assessed here as a single species.
Coryphantha retusa is difficult to distinguish from Corphantha pycnacantha as well as other species in the genus.
Three subspecies are recognized (Hunt et al. 2006), namely the nominate form, subsp. caespitosa (J.A.Pupus) M.Lowry and subsp. westii (Hutchison) M.Lowry.

Two subspecies are recognized by Hunt et al. (2006), the nominate form, subsp. bertramiana (Backeb.) M.Lowry. A third subpecies is recognized by some authors, namely subsp. herzogiana (Cárdenas) G.Navarro.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. pasacana (F.A.C.Weber ex Rümpler) G.Navarro.
Comprises two subspecies, the typical form and subsp. stipitata (Schweid.) Dicht & A.Lüthy. Both subspecies are considered to be not threatened and hence are not assessed separately.

This species includes Austrocactus patagonicus from southern Chile.
